DEBATE.TITLE: CODE OF CONDUCT FOR MINISTERSCODE OF CONDUCT FOR SENATORS AND MEMBERS

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter—I ask that notices of motion Nos 937 and 942 standing in my name be taken as formal.
Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the contingent notice of motion standing in my name, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Coulter) moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate or to provide for the consideration of any other matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to delay the Senate as it still has a great deal of material to be debated in the session. However, these two notices of motion have now been standing before the Senate for some number of days. There has been plenty of opportunity for all honourable senators to examine both notices of motion. Indeed, the substance which lies behind both these notices of motion has been before both chambers of Parliament for some considerable time.

PARA.TAB: The question of an ethics committee was raised by a former Democrat, Michael Macklin, quite some time ago. Of course, the commencement of construction of a committee occurred in, I think, September last year in the House of Representatives. What we have here is an adding of a code of conduct to that committee. As I say, that particular reference has been before the committee and under quite intense consideration both inside and outside the chamber for some considerable time. It is therefore appropriate on this last sitting day that we debate this matter now, set up the committee and get the processes in order. It is almost certain that the substantive issues will be debated once this motion for suspension is passed, so I will not say anything more at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the motion for the suspension of standing orders. No matter of urgency has been put to the Senate in relation to these two notices of motion. The first, as Senator Coulter said, relates to the extension of the mandate for this informal working group. If it decides to extend its mandate, that is within its own province. It is certainly not an issue that needs to be debated as a matter of urgency this morning, bearing in mind the program that is before us today and what I thought was the Australian Democrats' point of view that the program should take precedence. But if it is to be debated, I will be amending it to deal with the matter of urgency—that is, the need for a proper and full inquiry into the Marshall Islands affair.
—You will be seeking to do so.

—And, in particular, the conduct of Ministers and the conduct of Senator Evans, who is seeking to interrupt the debate at the moment. We will try to get to the bottom of that matter, finally establish the facts and determine from that the matter that flows from it, which is in Senator Coulter's motion—I would have thought that Senator Coulter's motion logically followed—that is, whether there is a need for a ministerial code of conduct; whether Government Ministers, if they cannot be relied upon to abide by the conventions, practices and standards of the past, need to have those standards codified in some way in order for it to be easier for the Parliament to discipline them when they breach those standards. So if the Government accords with the Democrats' desire to have these matters debated today, that is what we will be seeking to do in relation to the first notice of motion.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the second notice of motion, which deals with the question of the composition of this working group on standards, we will be moving to amend that as well, in order to delete the names of three members of the New South Wales Right of the Labor Party—the President of the Senate, Senator Sibraa, who has been a party to the Marshall Islands affair, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr McLeay, and Senator Loosley—because this is all about a breach of ministerial standards by Senator Richardson, the leader of the New South Wales Right of the Labor Party. We think it is an appalling irony that what is being asked is that a committee be set up, comprised principally of mates of the Right, to look at the standard of behaviour of Senator Richardson, the leader of that faction and, upon that, to devise a codified set of standards with which we all should comply. What a farcical situation is being suggested.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't judge us by your standards.

—Let us talk about it, if Senator McMullan wants to have a debate about the New South Wales Right of the Labor Party, described by the honourable senator's own colleagues as thugs. It is that faction that the honourable senator wants to be applying standards for the rest of us. That is what is appalling. I am surprised that Senator McMullan has the gall to suggest that that should be the case. But then again, Government senators are all under the control of that particular faction. If that is to be the fate of the proposed motions, that is the amendment that we will be seeking in relation to the second of Senator Coulter's notices of motion.

PARA.TAB: What should occur is what the Democrats were prepared to support a little while ago—a proper and full inquiry into the Marshall Islands affair to establish where fault lies in order that the Parliament might take the proper action that flows therefrom. It was only a few days ago that the Democrats called for an independent judicial inquiry to get to the bottom of the matter. Of course, when the Government said no, the Democrats rolled over and abandoned it. At the same time they were saying that perhaps the facts even demanded a royal commission into this matter. That seems to have been forgotten.

I thought that the Democrats' charter was to ensure ministerial accountability. If that is the case, if they are prepared to stand by that charter, I would have thought what they would want to do today is to establish the facts so that these questions as to whether it is necessary to codify standards can be answered, and matters can flow from that. It is a matter of great regret to me, Mr President, that the Democrats have abandoned that charter of ministerial accountability that they put to the Australian people in the past. Nevertheless, in the course of the debate that will follow, because it seems that the Democrats have done another deal with the Government on this matter—of course, the deal is to get it off the hook on the Marshall Islands affair—we will give them the chance to face up to their responsibility again by moving the amendments that I have just outlined.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —It takes a particularly breathtaking brand of chutzpah for Senator Hill to come in here the day after the Premier of New South Wales has been drummed out of office on the basis of a finding of official corruption by an independent commission of inquiry and to fulminate indignantly about the alleged standards and misbehaviour so far as those on our side of politics are concerned. It is a disgraceful exercise of hypocrisy, one of which we are no doubt going to hear a great deal more over the next little while.

PARA.TAB: Let me simply say on this occasion, in order not to delay the business of the Senate any longer than necessary, that the Government is prepared to support the Australian Democrats' motion as an appropriate way on this last day of sitting to bring the so-called Marshall Islands affair to an appropriate resolution. We believe there are some issues of principle or policy that do need some further consideration. We believe that the particular working group that has been established by you, Mr President, with your counterpart, the Speaker, is an appropriate vehicle for the consideration of these particular policy issues. Under those circumstances, I intimate now that we will be supporting the substantive motions of which Senator Coulter has given notice, as well as this motion for the suspension of standing orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks of my colleague Senator Hill on this issue. It is fairly clear that the real motion has not been put before this chamber. The substance of the real motion is, of course, to have a proper inquiry to deal with the activities of Ministers and the performance of Senator Evans's Department in relation to the Marshall Islands affair.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter has flipped and flopped on this issue over the last four or five weeks. Firstly, Senator Coulter said to us that he was opposed to any inquiry. Then some weeks later, on 1 June, he came out with a very strong press statement headed, `Democrats propose an independent judicial Marshall Islands inquiry'. I invite Senator Coulter and the other Australian Democrats to re-read that press statement. It was not, by and large, a bad press statement; it contained a few words that I might query, but I thought he outlined the issues very neatly. He did not propose any wishy-washy motion to look into a code of conduct of Ministers. What he said was that he wanted a full, fair dinkum inquiry. The reason he said that was as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Cumulative evidence in the Marshall Islands affair had reached the point where questions as to whether improper ministerial influence had been brought to bear were inescapable.
He went on to say, in support of his proposal for an independent judicial inquiry:

It is questionable whether certain people, including ministerial and departmental staff, have been overtly compliant in assessing the business dealings of Mr Symons. Senator Coulter said ministerial standards were at the heart of the matter and hoped that a commissioner would make recommendations about appropriate use of ministerial powers with a view to establishing a ministerial code of conduct.
He then concluded:
He said the important issue of ministerial conduct and standards lay at the heart of the affair and an independent judicial inquiry was the best way to clear the air.

He was not supporting the reference to a committee which is dominated by members of the Labor Party, dominated by members of the New South Wales Right. That is not what he was proposing; he was proposing a fully fledged, fair dinkum inquiry.

PARA.TAB: I found it intriguing that Senator Evans, above all, should say, `Look what happened in New South Wales'. I say to Senator Evans, `Look what did happen in New South Wales. There was an independent inquiry'. That is what he is so dead scared about. This whole grubby affair, which Senator Evans has been involved in from day one, is not going to be resolved by the inquiry that is being proposed, dominated by the Labor Party, with no reference at all to the particular activities of the Marshall Islands affair, and with the committee itself being under the control of the New South Wales Labor Right. What Senator Coulter has done is try to cover up his flip-flops on the issue. He has gone to his Party, and clearly a majority in the party room has said that his press release of 1 June no longer stands. A majority of people in that party room were not prepared to stick with the tradition of the Australian Democrats and support a proper inquiry to make sure that we keep the Government honest.

It is very interesting that, although Senator Richardson was forced to resign, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has already indicated that Senator Richardson would be welcome back in the Government at some later stage. The Prime Minister has not conceded any fault on the part of Senator Richardson. Senator Coulter asked Senator Evans a similar question here: whether, on reflection, Senator Evans's behaviour in agreeing to the phone call that Senator Richardson made to the Marshall Islands was an appropriate use of his authority as a Minister of the Crown. Despite all that has happened, on reflection, Senator Evans has failed to admit any guilt or concede any problem in relation to that matter.

What we have is a grubby affair involving at least two senior Ministers of this Government. We have a Prime Minister who has not conceded any fault whatsoever and we have a department which seems to have been paralysed over the whole affair. That is the message that certainly comes through the papers tabled by Senator Evans. Senator Coulter is not prepared to stand up for what he has argued for in the past. He has flip-flopped around on this issue. Apparently, he no longer supports his strong and worthy press release of 1 June. Now it is pretty clear that the Australian Democrats have ducked the real issues and have done a deal with the Government. As a result, we are not going to have a proper inquiry into the Marshall Islands affair. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want briefly to support the remarks of my Leader, Senator Hill, and Senator Kemp and to express my very considerable concern that the Australian Democrats are bringing forward this motion for debate today yet at the same time they are not prepared to institute, or to join with the Opposition in instituting, the type of inquiry that we all know is necessary if we are going to inquire into and maintain ministerial standards in this Parliament. We have a situation in Australia today where there is a great deal of cynicism and concern about the standards of parliamentarians, not least those of Ministers and not least those of Ministers in this Government. Yet a party which sought election to this place on the basis of keeping politicians honest is not prepared to enter into an inquiry into what is, without equivocation, the most important, most concerning issue of ministerial propriety and ministerial standards that there has been for many years in this place, and that is the involvement of Ministers of the Keating Government in the Marshall Islands affair.

PARA.TAB: We have seen already the involvement of one Minister in a way which led to his resignation. We have had very considerable concerns expressed about the involvement of other leading members of the Australian Labor Party in this place, namely, the President of this chamber, Senator Sibraa, and the second most senior Minister in this chamber, Senator Gareth Evans. The prospect is that other Ministers may have been involved in some way. If we are serious about the question of ethics, ministerial standards and the standards of parliamentarians, it makes no sense at all not to inquire into an issue which is number one on the agenda in that category at this stage.

The motion that Senator Coulter has moved does not in any way touch these vital matters. What he is talking about doing is in effect setting up a group to have a look at drafting a code of ethics for politicians. That is nowhere near sufficient for the purposes at hand. That committee, as I understand it, would have no proper powers of inquiry at all. It would not have terms of reference that would enable it to inquire properly into the issues that arise concerning ministerial standards, as it should. The Marshall Islands affair is the most important one at the moment, but it is by no means the only one. If one went through the Keating Ministry, one could point very easily at a considerable number of Ministers whose actions are at the very least questionable and which should be looked at in considerable detail. Yet Senator Coulter and the Democrats are not prepared to put proper procedures in train in this place that would enable that to be done.

I say that it is about time Senator Coulter and the Democrats came clean with the Australian people in terms of their bona fides. Every action that you have taken as a party in this place—at least for the last three or four years, and I believe well beyond that—is in total contravention of what you claim you stand for. You have a great opportunity today to put the record straight on that. You have a great opportunity to show, by joining with the coalition in seeking a proper inquiry into the Marshall Islands affair, that your whole raison d'etre in this place is valid. If you do not support us today—as you have continued to indicate you will not—then I believe the bona fides of the Democrats and even the raison d'etre of the Democrats will be, as we have all known for so many years now, totally invalid.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Coulter) agreed to:

That General Business notices of motion Nos 937 and 942, standing in the name of the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Coulter) and relating to developing a Code of Conduct for Ministers and the necessity of the Liberal Party to appoint a Senator to the Working Group, be called on and have precedence over all other business till determined.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: 1. That the Senate recommends to the Working Group to Develop a Code of Conduct for Senators and Members that it gives priority to developing a code of Conduct for Ministers, and that the terms of such a Code of conduct be transmitted to both Houses of Federal Parliament on or before the first day of sitting in 1993.

2. That the Senate calls on the Liberal Party, as a matter of urgency, to appoint a Senator to the Working Group to Develop a Code of Conduct for Senators and Members, as it was requested to do in 1991, thus allowing the Working Group to meet for the first time.
Ordered that there be a cognate debate on the two motions and that the question on each motion be put separately.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that it is important that these two matters be dealt with now. The committee should be properly constituted so that it can get on with the business of deciding not only on a code of ethics but also on a code of conduct for Ministers. This is the subject of the principal motion, that the working group developing the code of conduct for senators and members be given the priority to develop a code of conduct for Ministers, and that the terms of such a code of conduct should be transmitted to both Houses of the Federal Parliament on or before the first day of sitting in 1993. There are several aspects to that.

PARA.TAB: A moment ago we heard the Opposition arguing as if this committee would actually decide definitively on the code of conduct. Of course that is not the case. The committee, like all other committees, would be reporting back to both Houses of the Parliament. It would be for the Parliament to decide—whatever came out of that committee—whether either of those terms of reference was adequate or not. It seems to me that that rather undercuts some of the objections which the Opposition has made to the composition of the committee.

Moreover, it seems to me that in the absence of an existing code of ethics or code of conduct for Ministers, it ill behoves the Opposition to cast aspersions on particular people who might be on that committee. There is no objective standard, as yet, by which the behaviour of those people can be judged. For the Opposition to be pointing a particular finger at the New South Wales Right, however they may have behaved, is simply to do that in the absence of the very thing that this committee is designed to look into. As Senator Evans pointed out a moment ago, for the Opposition to be pointing such a finger the very day after Mr Greiner in New South Wales had sought to argue a difference between corruption and technical corruption, is, to say the least, a bit choice.

According to the notice of motion, which was moved just this morning by my colleague Senator Kernot, the actions of the Tasmanian Liberal Government certainly smack of `mates'. I use that word quite deliberately because there you have a liberal government which has decided to pay the legal costs of Mr Edmund Rouse, who was gaoled for his part in the affair of bribing a person; and of the former Premier, Mr Robin Gray, and Mr David Mcquestin, thus overruling the findings of three Supreme Court judges that Messrs Grey and Mcquestin should pay for their Supreme Court action. These payments did not extend to eight other witnesses, including Mr Jim Cox. If the principal complaint by the Opposition is that the New South Wales Right is looking after its mates, then it seems to me that really they should cast the mote out of their own eye before they point to the mote in the eye of anybody on the Government side.

I make no judgment as to whether the New South Wales Right is any more or less corrupt than members of the Opposition. But in the absence of a code of conduct, a code of ethics, it is quite inappropriate to make these prejudgments, particularly bearing in mind that, whatever this committee comes forward with, it will come forward to both chambers of the Parliament and those chambers can consider whatever recommendations are forthcoming.

The debate which briefly preceded this debate was couched in terms which seemed to indicate that the principal concern about behaviour was in relation to the Marshall Islands. But surely we have example after example—not just in this Parliament but far more widely throughout Australia—of behaviour that many of us would regard as unacceptable. It is therefore appropriate to go much more widely than simply a consideration of the Marshall Islands affair.

In relation to the Marshall Islands affair, Senator Kemp indicated earlier that at a previous time I had put out a press release calling for an independent judicial inquiry. He was quite correct. At that time that was the appropriate way to go. In some respects it would still be an advantage to go down that path. However, that path is not available to us and, moreover, the alternative being offered by the Opposition is simply unworkable.

Mr Symons, who is currently, as I understand it, under arrest in the Marshall Islands, may well be in gaol for some considerable time as a consequence of the hearing yet to be conducted in the Marshall Islands. I make no judgment as to whether he is guilty or not, but it is a possibility. Therefore, he would not be available now because of the problems of sub judice unless a council of at least equivalent legal standing were established in Australia, which we cannot do, and/or he may not be available for an extended period beyond that. Pursuing that path is not possible because one of the key witnesses before such an inquiry would not be available. Many senior public servants would also be overseas and would be difficult to bring back in the context of that inquiry.

Criticism has been made, moreover, that there are not sufficient counterbalancing influences on the committee we are considering. From the House of Representatives there will be a member of the Opposition, an Independent—Mr Ted Mack—and, if the Liberal Party is to appoint a senator to the committee, there will be a Democrat senator, a National Party senator and a Liberal senator. If that is not a sufficient counterweight to those people—

TALK.START.PARA: —Five Labor and two Liberals; great!
—And an Independent and a Democrat—who will be at every committee meeting, watching all the time and reporting back, moreover, to this chamber and also to the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: For all these reasons it seems to us appropriate that this matter be dealt with today, that the committee be established, that the Liberals appoint their senator and that the committee report back on the first day of sitting next year so that this matter can be dealt with in the context of the then existing code of ethics and code of behaviour.

I think Senator Kemp made the point a moment ago that Senator Richardson has not admitted fault. Certainly it is the case that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has not admitted that what Senator Richardson did was in any way faulty.

Senator Evans also has not admitted fault. But I must say that when I asked Senator Evans the particular question to which Senator Kemp drew our attention a moment ago he did say—and this is the relevant point—that people of good conscience have different views about that particular matter. That matter was whether it was appropriate for other senior Ministers to seek to intercede when a legal matter was before the courts in a foreign country. That, of course, is the very issue: that people of good conscience can have different views. Senator Kemp may believe—as I believe—that the behaviour of Senator Richardson in seeking to intercede was inappropriate, and it was inappropriate for Senator Evans to provide that advice. I do happen to hold that view. Senator Evans holds a different view. Surely it is appropriate that this committee look at those situations, which it can adequately do, and then come back with a recommendation as to whether that is appropriate.

I also hold the view that Senator Richardson was wrong in providing that reference without going through proper procedures to satisfy himself as to the past business dealings of Symons, the present business proposal, and also to know more about the character of Symons himself. Again, it is appropriate for this committee to look at those matters and, if it is appropriate for Ministers to give references under those sorts of circumstances, to outline the procedures that Ministers might go through before such a reference is issued. It is quite easy to conceive of a set of procedures which might be followed. Senator Richardson might, in fact, have gone to certain authorities and sought information as to Mr Symons previous business dealings. He may well have sought other character references, and may have sought a lot more detail as to the proposals which Mr Symons was at that time intending to launch in the Marshall Islands.

If that is done, it seems to me that we will then have a yardstick by which the actions of Senator Richardson can be judged, albeit retrospectively. If that committee recommends, and the Senate and the House of Representatives accept, that there should be a procedure by which Ministers who are asked to give such a reference should proceed, and if Senator Richardson did not proceed according to those standards, then at least retrospectively we do have a judgment on the action of Senator Richardson. Surely that is as far as we can reasonably go under these circumstances.

I think Senator Short pointed out a moment ago, and I certainly pointed out yesterday, that there is a great deal of disquiet in the community as to the behaviour of politicians—not just in this place, but generally around the country. That disquiet, in my view, is justified. It goes to the matter of the broad ethical behaviour of politicians, and it goes to the matter of the detailed day-to-day behaviour of politicians in this chamber in relation to the conduct of debate. While that is dealt with elsewhere, it is important that this matter be delayed no further—that it is dealt with now. Given the fact that the general proposition has been around for a long, long time, the Opposition certainly has had plenty of time to come forward with an alternative. It has failed to do so. It is therefore appropriate that we pass these two motions now and get on with the business. If we are dissatisfied with what the committee comes back with, then let us have another look at it. But at least this committee must report by the first sitting day next year and we will have something concrete before us, instead of the lack of procedures which we have had so far.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said a while ago, we will seek to amend this motion in order that there might be a proper inquiry into the Marshall Islands affair, which in turn, to some extent, will develop a case as to whether or not a code of conduct of ministerial behaviour is necessary. To facilitate that debate, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)That a select committee, to be known as the Senate Select Committee into Australian Government Involvement in the Marshall Islands Affair, be established to inquire into and report on the role played by Australian Government Ministers and departmental officials in the business affairs of Mr Gregory Symons as they relate to the Marshall Islands, with particular reference to the nature and extent of the involvement of:

PARA.TAB: (a)the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, particularly in relation to access by investors in Mr Symons' scheme to Australian immigration services;
(b)Austrade, particularly action and advice in support of Mr Symons' business scheme, and also in relation to the Export Market Development grant of $131,443 to Mr Symons in 1990-91;

(c)the Minister for Employment, Education and Training and the Department of Employment, Education and Training, particularly in relation to access to Australian education services by investors in Mr Symons' scheme; and

(d)the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, particularly in relation to support for the scheme, the promotion of the scheme or liaison with other countries, and in the provision of services to investors in Mr Symons' scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: (2)That the committee report by the first sitting day in August 1992.
(3)That the committee consist of seven Senators, as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a)three nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b)three nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and
(c)one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: (4)That the committee may proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(5)(a)That the chairman of the committee be appointed by and from the members of the committee.

PARA.TAB: (b)That the deputy-chairman of the committee be appointed by and from the members of the committee immediately after the appointment of the chairman.
(c)That the deputy-chairman act as chairman when there is no chairman or the chairman is not present at a meeting.
(d)That, in the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chairman, or the deputy-chairman when acting as chairman, have a casting vote.

SPEECH.PARA: (6)That the quorum of the committee be three members.

(7)That the committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

(8)That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the subcommittee.

(9)That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee with the approval of the President.
(10)That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

Sadly, let us make no mistake that what we see today is an arrangement between the Australian Democrats and the Government which lets the Government, in particular its Ministers, off the hook. It is a deal designed to ensure that there is no proper parliamentary inquiry to establish the outstanding facts in relation to the Marshall Islands affair. It is really beyond my comprehension why the Democrats are so blatantly prepared to abdicate their responsibility to help ensure ministerial accountability in this way. At times I think it is simply that they are a soft touch; at other times a deal. All I can say is I hope the Democrats got a good price for their deal because when they leave the chamber at the end of this debate, the Government will be laughing at them. The Government will be laughing at the Democrats because by the deal, the soft touch or whatever it has done with the Australian Democrats, it has ensured that there will not be a proper inquiry to establish these facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rave on. Why don't you get to the issue.

—That is the issue. This morning why has the Government dumped its guillotine to debate this motion at the request of the Australian Democrats? Because that gets the Government out of the possibility of an inquiry into the conduct of its Ministers. That is what it is all about. That is the deal the Government has done with the Australian Democrats. I can understand why the Government would want to do it because there are many outstanding issues that should be properly inquired into, which the Government obviously does not want to happen.

PARA.TAB: A few minutes ago, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) had the gall to condemn Mr Greiner who has lost his job as a result of an inquiry. However, the Government is not prepared to stand up to an investigation of its conduct in this matter and let the Parliament then make a judgment upon it. The Government does not want the full facts to come out because it has something to hide.

Every document we wanted we have had to extract like teeth out of the Government. There has been no attempt or willingness at all to put the full facts on the table in this matter. Day by day in here the Government has sought to avoid the full facts being brought out. That is still its attitude and that is why the Government objects to a proper inquiry into this particular matter.
But if the Minister is going to come in here and have a go at Greiner, how does he explain the difference between that and his

SPEECH.PARA: conduct in relation to David Charles? When the Minister wanted to bring Crean into the Parliament, he decided to give David Charles—a former parliamentarian—a job in the United States. How does the Minister distinguish between that and what he condemns Mr Greiner for? There is no way in which the Minister can distinguish between Greiner and what he did to benefit his Party to give Crean a seat in this Parliament by finding a job for David Charles so that he could retire with dignity and get paid as a diplomat in the United States. How does the Minister distinguish between that situation and what he condemns Mr Greiner for? Perhaps when the Minister responds in this debate, he might have a go at distinguishing that for us so we can see—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the quality of the appointment.

—The Minister should not try to suggest that it is the quality of the appointment. Everybody knows that that was not the reason. The reason was to create the seat for Crean because that was in the Labor Party's interest. And it happened before: we know it happened with Vince Gair; it has happened often in the past. But the Minister seeks to apply a different standard to Mr Greiner, and that is what I criticise.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the motion and the amendment that I have moved. What the Australian Democrats want to do is to extend the charter of this so-called informal working group to develop a code of conduct. What is the history of that? Madam Deputy President, you might remember that a few years ago Senator Macklin of the Australian Democrats moved a motion in this place to set up a formal parliamentary committee to look at the desirability of developing a code of conduct on ethical behaviour of members of parliament.

It is interesting, in the light of the new morality of this Government, to look back at the response of Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, when he responded to Senator Macklin in that matter. He did so on 22 December 1989. He was asked why the Government was not supporting Senator Macklin's motion. The answer of Senator Button, not very long ago, was:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government did not support the establishment of a Joint Select Committee on the Ethical Behaviour of Members of Parliament in the Senate on 22 November 1989 because it is the view that Members of Parliament are already aware of the ethical standards of behaviour to which they should conform, and that these are not in need of codification, even if their codification were possible.

PARA.TAB: The Government also believes that public, party and parliamentary mechanisms of kinds already existing, such as the House of Representatives register of interests referred to in the question, are the best means to ensure adherence to appropriate standards of behaviour.

SPEECH.PARA: That was the formal Government attitude to the idea of an attempt to set up a code on what everyone knows should be the proper standards of behaviour of members of parliament.

PARA.TAB: But, not very long ago, Mr Mack, the independent in the House of Representatives, raised the question again and put it in a question to the then Prime Minister. He used some statements of Mr Temby and ICAC in New South Wales as a basis. He said, `Is it not time to set up a committee to codify standards of behaviour of members of parliament?'. Mr Hawke at that time obviously believed that there was some reason to give benefit to Mr Mack, and said okay. But instead of setting up a proper parliamentary inquiry in which there would be a balance of representation between the parties—as is the normal case in relation to these things—he instructed the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate, two members of the New South Wales right of the Labor Party, to set up this informal working group and to write to party leaders and request nominations. It had no formal parliamentary composition at all. It was not set up as a result of any reasoned case. It was set up simply as a result of the then Prime Minister wanting to give benefit, for some reason or another, to Mr Mack; and we can only speculate on what that might be. As a result of that, this so-called working group was put together.

It was interesting that, when its composition was first published in the letters of the President and the Speaker, it had five members of the Labor Party on it and one member of the Liberal Party. That has now been changed. Very generously, they have said that we can have two members of the Liberal Party to their five members of the Labor Party! And Senator Coulter comes in here today and says, `Do not worry about that because there is going to be an Australian Democrat on it'. We have seen this morning to what extent we can rely upon the Australian Democrats to ensure proper accountability of Ministers of this Government; that is, as soon as the pressure is put on, they go to water. They will do it when it is at the easy stage of a matter but, as soon as it becomes difficult, they go to water, do a deal with the Government, put it aside and pursue it no further. That is the body whose mandate Senator Coulter and the Government have conspired today to extend, to try to develop a code of conduct not only for members but also now for Ministers.

We say that what the committee should do, if it is to be the working group—it would be much better if it were a proper parliamentary committee—is take the example of the Marshall Islands affair and get to the bottom of it. We have already seen that there was sufficient misbehaviour by one Minister that he had to resign over the matter. Of course, he should have been sacked by the Prime Minister in any event, but he resigned. The committee should look at the matter and establish the facts. Then, on that basis, it should determine whether there would be any worthwhile purpose in trying to codify standards of behaviour of Ministers. That would develop a sound basis for its work. It would have the side benefit of the Parliament then being made fully and properly aware of the circumstances and facts of the Marshall Islands affair, which facts will not be made available to us in any other way. That is why I moved my amendment.

Let us address for a minute or two the question of why Senator Gareth Evans is so opposed to the issue of the Marshall Islands being further explored. The answer is that if Senator Evans applied the standards that he sought to apply, in 1982 when he was in Opposition in relation to Senator Durack, he would have hung his head in shame and resigned weeks ago over this matter. There is little doubt, on what facts we know, that Senator Evans has acted improperly in relation to this matter. First, he has acted improperly in authorising Senator Richardson—presumably on the instructions of Senator Richardson, because that seems to be the power of Senator Richardson within the Labor Party and the power of the New South Wales Right faction of the Labor Party—to make contact with the President of the Marshall Islands to seek benefit for a relative of Senator Richardson, Mr Symons, who is now under arrest in the Marshall Islands on forgery charges.

That was an astonishing thing for a Minister for Foreign Affairs to do—to authorise one of his Ministers to make direct contact with the head of state of another country to seek benefit for one of Senator Richardson's friends and relatives. The Minister has given no adequate explanation of that at all. One would have thought that he would have, firstly, gone to his Department and said, `Let us establish the facts of this matter of Mr Symons who has been arrested in the Marshall Islands'. He might even have sought the advice of his Department, but Senator Evans is a particularly arrogant Minister. At least when he authorised Senator Richardson to make this incredible incursion into the affairs of the Marshall Islands, one would have thought he would have put it on the records of the Department so that, when the officers of the Department were further dealing with matters relating to the Marshall Islands and Symons in particular, they would at least have known of the involvement and intervention of their own Minister, Senator Evans.

He failed to do all these things. One can only wonder why. One can only suspect it was because of the incredible power and influence that Senator Richardson seemed to wield within the Labor Party, the same power and influence that, when he took Symons around to see the President of the Senate, Senator Sibraa, and introduced him to him—although Senator Sibraa had previously known him in the Young Labor movement—and said,`Give this man, my friend, some help', Senator Sibraa was well-prepared to do another incredible thing. He contacted the Australian mission in Washington direct and asked that it help Symons. Did he contact the Department also and check the circumstances of what Symons was seeking to do?

Symons was holding out that the Australian Government had been asked by the Government, and in particular the President, of the Marshall Islands to help in this matter. Did he check that out? Did he confer with the Minister for Foreign Affairs? No, of course he did not. He simply picked up the instruction of Richardson because Symons had been introduced to him by his factional leader, Senator Richardson, the Minister in question, and he wrote off to Washington without checking with the Department or taking any of those usual precautions. After that, did he drop a note to the Minister for Foreign Affairs or drop a note to the Department in Canberra so that they would at least know what he had been doing and the action he had taken? Of course he did not, because there is a different set of standards when Senator Richardson issues an instruction. So we see constant action which in all circumstances, to give it a generous interpretation, would be unusual and, to give it perhaps a more balanced interpretation, would be incredible, simply because it was on the basis of an instruction of Senator Richardson.

Senator Evans wrongly authorised Senator Richardson to intervene in the affairs of the Marshall Islands. If one picks up Senator Evans's own book on foreign affairs one sees cautions within it about the way in which one should deal with the small island states, because they could so easily misinterpret interventions or actions. That is exactly what occurred in this case. Anyone reading the transcript of the preliminary hearing in the Marshall Islands will find from the words of the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands that that is exactly what occurred. This was not just any Minister that had made contact with the President of the Marshall Islands, according to the words of that Attorney-General; this was a particularly powerful Minister. He was right. This was Senator Richardson. On that basis alone, Senator Evans should be prepared to have the full circumstances of this matter investigated.

Secondly, on 6 April, the Department brought to the attention of Senator Evans's personal office not only the intervention of Senator Richardson. His personal office was advised that Senator Richardson might have gone even further than simply calling to deal with a matter of bail. The file note that we finally extracted from the Minister tells us:

SPEECH.PARA: Suggestion that Richo has been ringing members of Cabinet and President seeking leniency.

That goes well beyond seeking a return of Symons's passport. When that was advised to the Minister's office, was any action taken on it? It was inconsistent with what had previously been authorised, but no action was taken on that at all.

PARA.TAB: When Senator Evans's office was advised that Senator Sibraa had been involved in the matter, did he check with Senator Sibraa to find the extent of that involvement and whether it was proper, and establish the link between Senator Richardson and Senator Sibraa in this matter? No, he did not bother to do that. One does not intervene in these factional matters, even if they concern the affairs of another nation.

When Senator Evans found out, from the advice that was given to his office, that the mission in Washington had been involved in this matter, did he take any action to investigate that, to find the extent to which it had been involved, to ensure that it had been regular and to try to link up the involvement of the Washington mission of our Foreign Affairs Department with what had happened in the Marshall Islands and the arrest of Symons in the Marshall Islands—and the links with Richardson and then the links with Senator Sibraa? No, none of these things were done.

Why were none of these things done which one would normally expect of a Minister? One can only say that it was because this relates to affairs concerning Senator Richardson, and when Senator Richardson says, `Jump', this Minister, Senator Evans, jumps, as it seems do most within this Labor Government.

Basically, what Senator Evans did is to ignore these matters that should have been properly investigated and should have had action taken upon them when his office was advised of them on 6 April. When he came into the Senate a month later, on 7 May, and said, `I know nothing about these matters', he misled the Senate. Why did he mislead the Senate? Because there was no way that he could distinguish his own state of mind from the advice given to his office.

He sits back there giggling but I remind the Senate that in 1982 he was prepared to hang former Senator Durack for a failure by a bureaucrat in a regional office of Senator Durack's department. He said that Senator Durack should be responsible for the failure of that particular officer, who happened to be in the Perth branch of his Department. Yet he says, in relation to himself, that he should not be damned for the knowledge of his personal office.

The Minister cannot have it both ways. All he can reasonably expect of his Department is that it advises his personal office. When his personal office is advised, that is to be treated as his knowledge, otherwise the whole system of ministerial accountability cannot—

TALK.START.PARA: —He thinks it is a joke. He is sitting over there laughing.

—I know he thinks it is a joke. He is applying a different standard to himself from the one he applies to Senator Durack. Otherwise, if one does not accept that, the whole basis of ministerial responsibility cannot work. Ministers would simply close their eyes and block their ears against business that is occurring within their departments, within their offices and do as this Minister does, saying, `I have therefore excused myself from that responsibility'.

PARA.TAB: On all the precedents, he knows that he cannot get away with that, and that is why he is so keen to bring this matter to an end. On 7 May, when he came in here and said, `I know nothing about it', that was not a valid excuse because his personal officers had known these circumstances for over a month. He made the position even worse later in that day—he should have learnt about it personally months ago—when he finally became aware of the full circumstances. But rather than come back and correct the misrepresentation that he had made in Question Time, he chose to leave it in the hope that the matter would die during the ensuing two weeks in which the Senate was going to be up, and that it would not progress further.

Well of course it deteriorated, because he would not take action. The Prime Minister had to cause an investigation of the matter within his own Department. Out of that we found finally the further letter from Symons to Senator Richardson, which was evidence of the fact that Senator Richardson knew in great detail of the scheme in the Marshall Islands, and further developed the case of Senator Richardson misleading the Senate. Senator Richardson then had no alternative but to resign.

They are the reasons why Senator Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, does not want this matter to go any further and why he does not want it further investigated. That is why it is in his interest to have done this deal with the Australian Democrats today, to try to bring this matter to an end.

Let me, in the few minutes remaining, look at just a few of the outstanding matters that could be pursued through a proper inquiry into the Marshall Islands affair. As I said, Senator Evans has still not adequately explained his agreement to allow Senator Richardson to telephone the President of the Marshall Islands. He still has not told us what was the end result of a proper investigation—which was not taken, of course—into the suggestions that Senator Richardson had been contacting others within the Marshall Islands, Cabinet Ministers as well as the President, and on matters that went beyond the return of the passport.

Such an inquiry could look at Senator Evans's failure to consult with his Department at all about the propriety of that phone call, something that I mentioned a moment ago. It could look further at his failure to investigate the rumours about Senator Richardson heavying the President and seeking leniency, as was reported in the press—which is something that I have not dealt with today, but nevertheless it had been reported in the press. It could look at his failures and seek briefings from his Department about the events surrounding the arrest of Mr Symons, which was very much a case of Senator Evans wanting to avoid the whole issue.

We even found this yesterday in an answer to Senator Teague, when we had asked the Minister why in fact were there not, on the documents that he had released, suggested answers to questions from his Department. The answer we got back from Senator Evans was that his office had told the Department that they did not wish to have such things, because these matters would be dealt with within his personal office. He did not want his Department involved in this matter because this was a political matter. He had been instructed to act by Senator Richardson, he had acted and knew that he had acted wrongly, and they wanted to keep it in the club. They did not want to bring in the wider bureaucracy because that becomes embarrassing.

If such an inquiry would further look at his failure to seek briefings from his Department about the Washington Post's involvement, especially seeing the Department was aware of that since November of last year, it would look at the nature of the involvement of Congressman Solarz who apparently was met by Mr Symons. We still have not asked that question as to whether Senator Evans was involved in helping arrange that contact, between two friends, of course. Any inquiry would look at the fact that Mr Kupa's version of events, both on 6 April and 13 May, directly contradicts that of Mr O'Leary.

Mr Kupa is being given the chance to make a statutory declaration—do honourable senators remember that?—to try to get himself on the hook. He had his personal officer make a statutory declaration that got one of his officers in the Department deeper into trouble. He did not mind doing that because the neck that counted with Senator Evans was his own and if it cost a bureaucrat a promotion or a bad point on his record, that is too bad. That is the sort of sacrifice they should be expected to make for Senator Evans.

That incredible sequence of events could properly be explored by a committee. The committee could look at why Senator Evans so abdicated his responsibility that the Prime Minister had to require that DFAT's files be searched. It could look at what action the Minister took—I do not think there was any—to restore Australia's reputation after this matter. I remind the Minister of the cable, document 74, which said that damage to Australia's international relations is certainly one of the consequences of this event. Has the Minister been interested in that? He said, `No, I am not interested in that because this is a political matter and we will distinguish a political matter from what is in Australia's interests'.

Such a committee could look at the incredible event of the documents being tabled having statements in them that demonstrated that the Department knew the danger and consequence of this matter being whited out. He has given one explanation to justify the whiting out of certain documents. He said, `We did not want to give it to the Prime Minister with extraneous material on it'. It is interesting that another one of the documents had some aspects whited out and some of the pencilled notes remained. The parts that were whited out were also damaging to the interests of Senator Evans.

These intolerable circumstances could properly be explored by an inquiry, and then Senator Coulter would have a basis on which to determine whether or not there are matters relating to ministerial standards that should properly be explored by this committee. The committee could also look at matters relating to on whose authority Symons was promising, in the Marshall Islands trust documents, that investors in the scheme would have access to university education in the Marshall Islands, the USA and Australia. That has never been properly explored because it is not possible to explore these issues properly when one gets six questions a day in Question Time. The only way to do it properly is through a full formal inquiry.

The committee could look at what has happened to the $1.25m that has been lost in this scheme, some of which, we understand, was filtered back into Australia. What did Senator Evans say to that when we raised it in this place? He said, `The matter is not really an Australian concern'. He was overlooking the fact that Symons is an Australian citizen. At least one Australian citizen has lost a quarter of a million dollars, and the ill-gotten gains of this scheme, at least in part, seem to have filtered back into this country. He has not demonstrated any concern at all in this matter for those who have lost money in a scheme that was, at least in part, facilitated by his Government. That could be looked at in depth by such a committee.

It could look at the incredible issue of why Mr Lamb in the United States would send all relevant documents back to the Department in Washington except the document that demonstrates that Senator Richardson knew the full details of the scheme. Have we had a satisfactory, or any, explanation of that? Not at all. That document was found only when the Prime Minister intervened and required a search of the DFAT files, both in Australia and internationally.

It could look at matters relating to the Austrade grants, the incredible sequence of grants that Symons had obtained to his benefit when he was under receivership and, furthermore, that others who have a relationship with him seem to have got so easily out of Austrade. It could look at the involvement of the Department of Immigration and the way in which Senator Richardson's office was used in this matter, quite wrongly, in an effort to facilitate the entry of somebody into Australia. These are just a few of the important matters that could properly be explored further through a formal inquiry, but the Minister and the Government do not seek such an investigation of them.

Others of my colleagues want to expand upon the outstanding issues that might be further looked at by such a committee. That could then produce evidence upon which one could logically move to the next step, which is whether or not a code of conduct for Ministers can be properly developed out of this experience. The Government is not going to permit such an inquiry to take place. It refused the invitation for a judicial inquiry, and the Australian Democrats went to water and said, `If you are not going to cooperate with a judicial inquiry, we will let you off the hook and we will not have a parliamentary inquiry'.

The last matter is the second amendment that I have moved, with regret, which is to exclude factional members of the New South Wales Right from the working group. As things stand at the moment, when the Government is not prepared to undertake a proper inquiry into the Marshall Islands to determine fault, we are unhappy. We will not tolerate a situation where members of the New South Wales Right are going to meet and attempt to set down standards of behaviour for us. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will support the Democrat motions and reject out of hand the amendments that have been moved to them by the Opposition. The Government is very firmly of the view that there is no basis whatsoever to justify a judicial inquiry, a quasi-judicial inquiry or a Senate committee inquiry of the kind that the Opposition has proposed into the detail of the matters that have come in issue during this so-called Marshall Islands affair over the last few weeks.

PARA.TAB: There has already been a sustained public exposure of all the issues using just about all the available forms of this House. During the course of that sustained exposure, day after day, week after week, in Question Time and in subsequent debates, no prima facie evidence of default or wrongdoing has emerged on the part of any Minister, any ministerial staffer or any departmental officer in relation to the affairs of Mr Symons, such as could possibly justify this kind of inquiry in this or any other country.

To the extent that specific issues did arise about the propriety or the appearance of propriety of Senator Richardson's personal associations with Mr Symons while he was a Minister, Senator Richardson has already paid the ultimate price for those associations, for those appearances, with his resignation.

So far as my own involvement is concerned, marginal as it was, it has been exhaustively examined, with no basis whatever for any further action by such an inquiry of the kind that Senator Hill has proposed. There have been full and frank responses by me to every one of the questions that have been put, including those that were listed again today by Senator Hill. There has been a full and frank disclosure by me of all relevant documents that have been called for, with the absolute minimum of deletions and exemptions claimed—each of them on good grounds; that has not been challenged by the Opposition—and none of that material has demonstrated any basis whatsoever for pursuing this matter further.

The kind of speculative extravaganza we have just heard from Senator Hill—and no doubt we will hear a lot more of it from subsequent speakers—about what might be further investigated and what might result from those investigations simply does not in itself constitute any kind of prima facie grounds for this kind of inquiry.

The quantity of mud-slinging does not make up for its quality. There just has not been much quality at all, I have to say frankly, as one professional allegedly to others, about the nature of the Opposition performance on this particular occasion. If those on the other side are going to do a job, one would expect it to be done with a little more finesse, a little more class, than the kind of crude, wallowing around, blundering in the dark, fishing expedition kind of exercise that we have seen ever since this particular matter got started.

As the Australian Democrats have said, the only possible basis for pursuing the kind of inquiry that the Opposition is calling for on this occasion is political—and crudely political. The crudely political nature of it is demonstrated, if anybody had any residual illusions, by the terms of the second amendment that Senator Hill has moved, seeking the exclusion from this working group process of members of the New South Wales Right faction. No basis was put forward for that other than just another generalised piece of poor quality mud-slinging drawing attention to particular individuals for reasons that have nothing to do with the substantive nature of the matters in issue here. It is all about creating an atmosphere of general political distaste.

The object of the exercise is clearly to distract, hopefully to debilitate the Government—as these sorts of inquiries always tend to do, whatever the nature of the issues, whatever the merits may be, by requiring the Government to devote resources to serving a major inquiry of the kind that is proposed. The object is to create, by all the familiar methods that are associated with these inquiries, the impression that there is something to be hidden, something to be investigated, something to be defended. The object is to hope against hope that, arising out of all of this, there may be some new political scalp achieved at the end of the day. The hope, obviously, that has also been there and has been added to this list as a result of the events in the last couple of days is that enough political dust will be raised by such an exercise to conceal from public gaze or distract public gaze from the fate of Mr Greiner, who has had to leave public life as a result of a finding of official corruption against him.

This is not an inquiry that is necessary or reasonable on the basis of any reasonable assessment of the material that has come into the public domain, that has been explored and that has been the subject of documentary production in this particular matter. There is a question whether there needs to be some further investigation or analysis, nonetheless, of some of the policy issues to have emerged from this affair. That is a matter on which views again could differ—but, on this occasion, views of reasonable people, not just views of those seeking to make a partisan political case.

The Democrats have argued that issues have been thrown up by the Marshall Islands affair that are not the subject of existing, clear ground rules, that have not been seriously or directly addressed before. An example is the question of the circumstances in which Ministers should provide letters of reference or introduction for people who are essentially engaged in business or seeking business contacts.

There are rules governing ministerial behaviour which are reasonably well established in their basic content and shape, even if they are not terrifically precise at the margin. Some of these rules, for example the code of conduct suggested in the Bowen report on public duty and private interest, have been adopted over the years as a statement of broad principles applicable to Ministers and other public office holders. Again, chapter 2 of the published Cabinet handbook sets out the conventions and principles which apply to Ministers in particular, covering collective responsibility, Cabinet confidentiality, ministerial responsibility for proposals, declarations of interest, caretaker conventions in election periods and so on. It is an attempt at some kind of a codification of the basic Westminster rules governing ministerial responsibility.

Then again, there are the explanatory notes issued to Ministers with the statement of private interest forms, which summarise the kinds of rules or the principles that have been regarded as properly applicable to Ministers in relation to their private interests. There is also a summary there on the handling of gifts by Ministers. Also, there is a system of guidelines on the registration of lobbyists that has been applicable since 1984, as a result of which Ministers and officials are required to check that lobbyists are registered before dealing with them.

There are piecemeal attempts to deal with this issue that are on the record and have been on the record for some time. It may be that there is a case for codifying in some way these piecemeal provisions and documents that are lying around with varying kinds of status. That is an issue which has been addressed from time to time but it has never been effectively resolved. There may, for example, be a case for trying to define the circumstances in which letters of reference should be written by public office holders. It might be extremely helpful to have such a formalised system of that kind on the record in order to get people off our backs. I am talking here not just about Ministers but about members of parliament, who are constantly confronting requests of this kind. Such requests are often very difficult to refuse when there are no codified rules around which specifically address this matter.

If this kind of task is to be done, in our judgment there does seem to be a good case for giving that task to the so-called ethics working group which has already been established—it was set up in August 1991—for this particular purpose. The terms of reference for that inquiry are most conveniently set out in the letter that was sent by the President and the Speaker to the Whips of all the parties in each House and the independent members. I seek leave to incorporate that letter setting out the terms of reference and the composition of the Committee in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator G.N. Jones28 AUG 1991

Dear Senator Jones,
On 27 May 1991 the Prime Minister wrote to us proposing that a working group be established under our aegis to develop a seminar on standards of behaviour expected of Members and Senators.

In our response of 3 July we advised the Prime Minister that we welcomed the proposal and assured him that we would lend our support to it. However, it is our view that for any Code of Conduct that addresses the ethical responsibilities of Federal Parliamentarians to have a recognised status and receive widespread acceptance, it will be necessary for all Parties and a representative of the Independent Member and Senators to be involved in its development and for the Code of Conduct to be endorsed by both Houses.

Following further advice from the Prime Minister on 6 August 1991 we have concluded that the initial task of the working group should be to develop a Code of Conduct. The working group would also have a role in developing appropriate means of disseminating information about the Code, such as seminars for Members and Senators.
We now wish to proceed to establish a broadly-based representative working group and consider that it should comprise the following:

PARA.TAB: The Presiding Officers
Two Government Members of the House of Representatives

One Government Senator

One Independent Member or Senator

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, we have written to the Prime Minister asking him to nominate a Minister to be a member of the working group, which would bring the membership to ten.
We therefore write seeking nomination of one Government Senator to the working group. Your advice in due course would be appreciated.
Yours sincerely,
(Sgd) KERRY W. SIBRAA(Sgd) LEO McLEAY

TALK.START.PARA: —I also seek leave to incorporate, just for the record, the current membership of that particular working group.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you read the names?

—Yes. The members are Senator Sibraa, President of the Senate; Leo McLeay, Speaker of the House of Representatives; Senator Nick Bolkus, Minister for Administrative Services, as the Prime Minister's ministerial nominee; Senator Florence Bjelke-Petersen, Opposition senator; Mr Jim Snow, MP, Government member; Senator Vicki Bourne, Australian Democrats senator; Mr Bob Halverson, OBE, MP, Opposition member; Senator Gerry Jones, Government senator, who has replaced Senator Loosley; and Mr Ted Mack, MP, who is an independent member. There is also a slot for a Liberal Party senator which has not, of course, been filled, and which is the subject of a second motion before us from the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: The terms of reference, in a nutshell, are to develop a code of conduct for members of parliament addressing the ethical responsibility of Federal parliamentarians generally. As the letter makes clear, the working group is also to have a role in developing appropriate means of disseminating information about the code, such as seminars for members and senators.

The committee as it is presently established was set up to establish a code for parliamentarians generally rather than Ministers in particular; but I think it would be acknowledged that essentially the roles and responsibilities of Ministers are incremental to those of parliamentarians rather than being different in kind. What makes a Minister's role especially complex and pressured in the Australian system is that there are so many roles simultaneously demanding or requiring to be played. This particular matter was addressed in an interesting discussion of this by former Prime Minister Hawke in his Garran Oration in 1988. What Mr Hawke made clear in that speech in a neat summary was the extraordinary diversity of roles and functions that Ministers play. It is not only the responsibility derived from the Constitution to administer one's department, and not only one's overriding responsibility as a member of the executive Government with its associated responsibility to Cabinet and Cabinet committees. There are the legislative and parliamentary obligations, the unavoidable party political duties inside the Parliament and in the broader party organisation, and the quite specific responsibilities that we all have in relation to our electorates and constituents.

That combination of responsibilities can sometimes create difficult situations for Ministers. It may not be inappropriate at all, from that particular perspective, for the group that is being charged to look at the particular responsibilities of members of parliament generally to also have the task of looking at the possible development of a code of conduct for Ministers. It is the interrelationship of the Minister's responsibilities with those of the ordinary member of parliament that produce some of the more interesting, difficult and sensitive questions that arise in practice. It may well be that the working group can do a very useful job in defining the elements of this ministerial code. Maybe it will prove not to be able to do the job—other attempts in the past have tended to have floundered in this respect—but at least it is reasonable that this group be given the opportunity to try.

Finally, so far as the membership question is concerned, it is obviously important that the Liberal senators opposite should make up their minds about who their particular candidate for participation in this group should be. It really is rather extraordinary that so many months should have elapsed with the Liberals opposite being unwilling to exercise the most fundamental of all their responsibilities to this Parliament by contributing a member of that particular group. It is really a classic demonstration of the lack of interest that the members opposite tend to have on these ethical questions—questions of principle—except when they see a potential victim on this side of the chamber in their sights.

What the Democrats are seeking to do in this instance, entirely legitimately, I think, is to raise their sights to these larger questions of policy and principle. That was exactly the issue which had been raised by Mr Mack in August or earlier last year and which the Speaker and the President sought to address by establishing this working group. But such was the lack of interest in the exercise on the part of the Opposition that in all these months it still has not got around to appointing a member to participate in the group.

There is no ground whatsoever for criticism of the participation of Senator Sibraa and the Speaker, Mr McLeay, in the group. The inquiry that is being proposed is not into the Marshall Islands affair in any way that could raise questions about the personal participation in the exercise of Senator Sibraa. The terms of reference that are proposed for the Committee are the policy issues that have naturally arisen as a result of some of this discussion. There is no reference to the Marshall Islands in the terms of the motion. There is no case for using the working group as a vehicle for raking over the coals on this miscellany, this ragbag, of issues that we have heard about and will no doubt hear about ad nauseam in the time ahead.

So far as Senator Loosley is concerned, all the fulmination in this respect has been entirely wasted. He is no longer a member of the committee. He took the view some little time ago that since his position on the committee was likely to generate controversy, whether justified or not, it might be appropriate for him to stand down. He has done that, and Senator Jones has replaced him. Similarly, if some questions should arise at any stage during the working group's deliberation when some question of potential embarrassment to any member of the committee is concerned, including either of the Presiding Officers, I am sure that in accordance with the normal practice and principles of commonsense and decency that apply in these situations, appropriate ways would be found of addressing that possible conflict of interest situation that might arise. But there is absolutely no basis whatever for proposing that the two Presiding Officers who set up, in total good faith, this working group to look at an issue of principle and an issue of policy which has not been systematically addressed in the past, should in any way resile from their responsibilities just because some sleazy attack, of the kind that we have become all too familiar with over the years, on the New South Wales Right and all its works, should be made by the Opposition. The issues here are issues of principle. That is the basis on which the Democrats have moved the motions now before us. I commend them for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators are well aware, I do not usually speak on subjects such as this or allied subjects, but I find it absolutely incredible that we should be debating this sort of rubbish at a time like this. It seems to me, if I may test my memory, to be only a few days ago, probably last week, when we were castigated roundly by the honourable senator who has brought this matter into the chamber today for wishing to discuss youth unemployment and to suspend Standing Orders to do that. Youth unemployment is the cancer that is eating Australia to death. With the aid of the Government, we were not permitted to bring that matter back for discussion in this chamber—but it is quite okay for us to take an hour or two or three today to bring up this rubbish that will not make one iota of difference to any single member or senator in the Parliament of Australia if it lives for 1,000 years.

PARA.TAB: Because Senator Evans, with his meagre mentality, seems to believe that one can legislate for morals and ethics, this is what we are wasting our time on now. Such stupidity and such humbug and hypocrisy, causing us to be fiddling about with this on the last day of sitting, when there are going to be many items of important business before us, because it has been decreed by the Government and the Democrats that they would rather waste the day on something as meaningless as this, is beyond comprehension.

We have got this committee being set up. How are we going to determine whose views achieve priority? Is it going to presume to cover the spoken word in the chamber, or what is spoken in speeches elsewhere? Is it to cover actions? Is it to cover the sort of gesture that we saw Senator Evans make to one of his colleagues in the chamber a few moments ago? Is it to cover intonations in the way things are said? Is it to cover interjections in or out of the chamber? Is it to comply with the approach that Senator Evans himself may have to matters of morals and ethics and so on—or Senator Button, or, say, Senator Bolkus and perhaps Senator Loosley? All of them, I think, would have quite different approaches. Why is it that we cannot have, say, Senator Cooney give us the benefit of his approach? Let us have somebody whose approach to these matters is beyond reproach.

What will the committee do? I ask Senator Evans what on earth he thinks this sort of committee would do or could do. How could the views of the sorts of people that I mentioned, the senators opposite, possibly produce a uniformity of approach? Is it designed just to fool the electorate? Is it seen to be a way by which a few votes can picked up? Will it change the fundamental attitudes of the people who come into this chamber, or the other one? Is it going to make them different people? Whom do the Democrats hope to impress? Do they see this as a means of gathering up a few more of one of these minority groups? What can it do? Senator Evans was good enough to run through a list of attempts which have been made but which have changed nothing. As he admits, with the best will in the world and with all the people who have done this, nothing has been achieved. We are now looking for yet another committee to see why it did not work and why such a person as Senator Richardson chooses, despite all the morals, ethics, codes of conduct and things that there are, to go his own way.
Senator Hill outlined the reasons why a proper inquiry into the Evans affair is so necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —The `Evans affair'!

—It is the Evans affair. The Minister does not see it this way; his standards and the sorts of standards that he now wants to commit to writing may not be the same. Senator Hill gave a long list of issues on which the information is grossly inadequate. If Senator Evans had some standards and codes, he would be prepared not only willingly but enthusiastically to bare them before a committee so that everybody in Australia could stop wondering about the standards that he had set for himself and that he was now trying to defend for other people.
