PARA.TAB: Is it possible in this or any other profession or occupation to produce standards by decree? Does the Minister really believe, with all the wisdom that he claims to have and with all the grace and pomp that he brings before this Parliament, that he could produce something that would change any of this?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, I am being wrenched away.

—The honourable senator is very welcome. It is a pleasure to see him go. Is this body supposed to have penal powers? Does the honourable senator really believe that we could have a committee that would commit some senator or member for, say, 10 minutes in the sin-bin, for having made a rude gesture across the chamber or for having interjected at the wrong time, if that is the sort of thing that he has in mind? If we are going to have a committee that comprises six Government members and two or three non-government members, is this the sort of committee that will be able to fairly, reasonably and justly consider all of the sorts of matters that come before us and that have clearly attacked the mind of Senator Evans? The whole thing is just ludicrous. Here we are on the last day of sitting, with about 15 hours work ahead of us, subjected to the decision made between the Government and the Democrats because they wanted to do it today.
—Why are you waffling if you are complaining about wasting time?

—Those opposite decided to do it today. If they want it done today, we will at least try to do it reasonably properly. I would have thought that Senator Button would have been able to tell us why it is so necessary. What is going to be achieved between now and 19 August? On 19 August we will be back here looking for legislation to consider, and those opposite will be wanting us to run urgency motions and things of that nature just so that we can fill up the days, when we could have had this as a stuffer, to go on for days if it was wanted. This is the position we are in. Here we are, on the last day, poking around trying to cover something for some reason that nobody has yet been able to explain. No-one has been able to point out why it is urgent. Nobody has been able to point out one thing that it is likely to achieve. I support the comments made by my Leader. I thought he outlined the case very adequately, and I support the amendment that he moved.

—I think this is a matter in need of a prompt appointment of a committee, and for this affair to go to that committee. In other words, I am saying that the approach taken by Senator Coulter is the correct one. I say that for the following reasons. First, I think that the control of conduct of parliamentarians is being taken too much away from the Parliament itself. It has always been my view that the Parliament, by and large, should look to its own order. I think that bodies such as the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland and the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales bring all sorts of problems with them. This is not something I have said only today; this is something I have said on other occasions. The reason I do it is this.
—You were right on all occasions.

—I thank Senator Baume. The reason I say that is that, to work out a proper standard for parliamentary and ministerial conduct, we need two things: experience of what it is like to be a parliamentarian, and a strong sense of morality. Ethics is simply that—a mixture of experience in a particular field with a sense of morality. I think that what bodies like ICAC, royal commissions, judicial inquiries and criminal justice committees lack is experience as politicians—experience of what it is like to legislate and what it is like to be a Minister. That is why Senator Coulter has brought forward a motion that should be supported by us all. I think that we can, as a group, so conduct ourselves that it becomes a good committee.

PARA.TAB: What is happening at the moment, of course, is that we are into the pay-back mode: because somebody from the coalition hits the hurdle, there is a desire to see that somebody on the Government side hits a similar hurdle. What we do is get an exchange across the chamber, which I am sure is expressed in very eloquent language, but where it gets us is another matter.

The amendment moved by Senator Hill goes against the sorts of things I have been saying so far. It is true that he looks to a Senate select committee to look at certain issues. I am not against that as a proposal—especially in this particular instance—but it should be a proposal when a matter arises, as is proper when the Senate looks at issues. He wants a judge of the superior court of the Commonwealth—or the State or the Territory—to advise the committee on the conduct of its inquiry, and for the committee to be pretty well bound by what that judge says.

There are a couple of problems with that. There will be real problems with a judge being willing to perform that function, and, in any event, there are some real problems in the Constitution in terms of the separation of powers. But in any event, the major concern is that it is for the Parliament itself and not for a judge to tell us what to do and how to conduct ourselves. If we as a chamber cannot work out a series of points to put into a code of conduct, we have come to a very sad situation indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we don't know that already, God help us!

—That is exactly what I say: if we do not know how to do that, God needs to help us. But what is being pressed for the whole time is that there ought to be an inquiry into what is called the Marshall Islands affair, without there being a sufficient basis for doing so. Let us develop what I mean by that. There is no standard set for ministerial conduct.
—They know right from wrong.

—Of course; they would know right from wrong. What happens in these sorts of situations is that the same sets of facts are interpreted on each side of the chamber in different ways. Senator Evans says, `I cannot identify a particular document; I cannot find a particular document'. People interpret that as being a cover-up. That is the problem. The facts are not the problem; it is the interpretation of the facts that counts. The difficulty with this sort of—
—A code of conduct will not solve that.

—A code of conduct may help to solve it in the following way: if there is a code of conduct, at least people have a check list before they get up and abuse each other across the chamber. One can say, `You seem to have fallen away from this particular code', or `You have adhered to this particular code; you have expected more than it is reasonable to expect. On the other hand, you have not achieved the sorts of things that you should have achieved in trying to carry out that particular area'. Our conduct in the chamber itself might need to be looked at.
—Some of us are exemplary.

—Some of us are exemplary; others are not so exemplary. It just seemed to me, as I listened to what Senator Coulter said, that this is an opportunity to look at this whole issue. Indeed, in the end we might decide not to establish a code of conduct. It may be that, on the basis of what Senator Coulter's motion states, the development of a code of conduct is found to be inappropriate in all the circumstances. But it is a very sensible proposition to look at it. It is a much more sensible proposition at this stage than wanting to go off to a judicial inquiry or a Senate inquiry, motivated in part by a desire to win political scalps. That is not said to the Opposition in any derogatory sense, but it would clearly be a very big coup if an inquiry could find a damaging piece of evidence against the other side; if it could go on a fishing expedition and find something that could be used against the other side. If one conducts an inquiry with that sort of motive, with that sort of intent, if only in part, then it is a very unfortunate way of going about things.

PARA.TAB: What Senator Coulter, as I understand it, is trying to do is to say,`All right, before we go through all that blood letting, before we get into the tribal warfare, before we exchange insults across the chamber and yell and scream for resignations, let's at least see whether we can come to some sort of commonality on the issue of how we ought to conduct ourselves'. What is wrong with that? That would seem to me to be the sort of thing that should be at least preliminary to any sort of inquiry that we have in this area.

We have got to decide whether it is not only Ministers who are going to be looked at carefully but whether backbenchers are also going to be looked at, and, if so, for what sorts of things. As Senator Coulter said—I think he said it—the conduct in this chamber might be something to be looked at. If we could improve on that, maybe we could progress further, not only on the issue of what ministerial responsibility means, but also on the issue of getting legislation passed.

I support the motion put forward by Senator Coulter. I think his original idea of having a judicial inquiry was wrong, for the reasons I have already given. Our responsibility is to see to our own conduct, to see that we conduct ourselves in a proper way. If there is criminal conduct anywhere, that can be dealt with by the courts, as is normal. But with regard to this idea of creating one body to look after another, in the case of ICAC, in the case of the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland, in the case of any judicial inquiry, none of them was elected. I would have thought that the sanction on the sort of conduct, for example, that Mr Greiner pursued should have been dealt with at the ballot box and by the people in the Parliament. He went ahead and set up ICAC and he set up a particular person, Ian Temby. He left it to one person to decide the issue of whether a government should stand or fall. That seems to me to be wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pity he didn't pursue the Wran Government.

—The comment from Senator Tierney illustrates exactly what I am talking about. What I am trying to do, and I think what Senator Coulter is trying to do, is to get away from the pay-back system, to get away from the revenge syndrome, to get away from the baser motives that sometimes operate in this chamber, whereby as soon as somebody picks up one name, somebody throws up another name. We have got to get away from that.

PARA.TAB: I understand what Senator Coulter is trying to do. He is trying to get away from this exchange which is based not on a rational debate but on an attempt to score points across the chamber. Surely, given that sort of milieu, that sort of atmosphere in this chamber, it is time we came right back to it and said, `What are the principles by which we ought to conduct debate in this chamber? What are the principles that ought to lead to a Minister being censured or to a Minister resigning?'. Let us have a look at that. Once we have had a look at that, it might at least limit the sorts of unhappy exchanges that take place across this chamber too often.

I simply say, to finish where I started, that Senator Coulter, in bringing forward this motion, has provided an answer for the right need, and the right answer to the right need, which is that we have to establish ethical codes. Ethics are a mixture of experience, which we can provide in this chamber and which judges outside cannot provide, and an element of morality. With those two things mixed, let us hope that we can come up with a code which will lead to some very rational and decent debate in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence my remarks by suggesting that the least surprising comment that I have heard during my time in this Parliament was when Senator Evans stood up and said that he did not support an inquiry into the Marshall Islands affair—or, as Senator Archer renamed it, perhaps appropriately, the Evans affair. It was interesting that Senator Evans pointed out the fact that he was quite happy to allow an investigation into the development of a code of conduct. But he did warn us—accurately, I think—that he did not see much coming out of an investigation, and that perhaps it might be of some value at the margin. I think Senator Evans was right on that point.

PARA.TAB: Our system of government, the Westminster system, has had some 200 years of experience in developing standards and conventions to govern the behaviour of Ministers. Senator Evans drew our attention to a number of weighty tomes on this very issue—the issue of ministerial responsibility. Of course, as ministerial standards have developed over time, there have been many commentaries made on it. I do not think the issue is that we lack proper guidelines on ministerial standards. The guidelines are there; they are writ large in the history of this Parliament and in the traditions that we have inherited from Westminster. Perhaps the guidelines could all be put in one volume for the convenience of members of parliament. Those who are concerned about these issues know where to look, know what the experience is and know what precedents have been established. The reality is that little, if anything, will emerge from this inquiry.

I also agreed with Senator Evans when he said—he made it very clear—that this will not be an inquiry into the Marshall Islands affair. How accurate Senator Evans was when he made that comment. What Senator Coulter has done today—and this is a heavy responsibility that Senator Coulter and the Australian Democrats must now bear—is to attempt to bury the Marshall Islands affair. Time, of course, will tell whether it will be buried once and for all.

Many issues will have to be explored in the course of the debate. I will be going through some of them. Senator Hill went through some of them. Senator Coulter and the Australian Democrats have joined with the Australian Labor Party in this final attempt to bury the Marshall Islands affair. This is the same Senator Coulter who, just three weeks ago, came out with all guns blazing on this issue. What Senator Coulter was doing then was reflecting the community concern that had arisen as a result of this affair. He was reflecting the editorials that had been written in a number of newspapers. Above all, I think he was reflecting a very real concern that had emerged during the debate on the Marshall Islands affair about innumerable unanswered questions.

I remind Senator Coulter of the remarks he made when moving a motion which, among other things, called for an independent judicial inquiry to report within eight weeks on the appropriateness and propriety of the conduct and decisions of Ministers, ministerial staff and departmental officers in relation to the business activities of Gregory Symons. This is what he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout much of the questioning in these last couple of weeks, there have been implications—and I do not put it any higher than that—that members of ministerial staff, other Ministers or bureaucrats perhaps have been leant on to further the interests of Mr Symons. So far, we do not know whether that has occurred, and in answers to those sorts of questions Senator Evans principally but also others have said, `You provide the evidence and then we will carry out an inquiry'.
Then Senator Coulter made a very significant statement. He said:

It seems that that is really the wrong way to go; that with all the evidence within government departments it is appropriate that that evidence be brought out from there rather than that those who are in the dark as to what might have gone on be required to produce the evidence first of all. We make no judgment in relation to these matters as to whether these intercessions by other persons did or did not take place, whether they were or were not appropriate, and to what extent they may have furthered the business interests of Mr Symons.
That is pretty strong stuff from Senator Coulter, supporting his call for an independent inquiry into this issue. He put his name to a press statement which further spelt out these issues.

PARA.TAB: So what has happened in the last three weeks or so which may have turned the mind of Senator Coulter? Senator Coulter put forward the proposal for an independent inquiry but then—surprise, surprise—the Government said it did not want to have one. Did Senator Coulter really feel that he could make this proposal, which was well-founded, and then decide that because the Government did not want to have an investigation into the activities of its senior Ministers and major government departments, the proposal should be dropped? That is essentially what he said. He argued strongly. He put the proposal forward. The Government did not want an inquiry into its Ministers and major departments, and therefore he dropped the proposal.

He said to us, `There was no alternative'. There are many alternatives. I wonder whether Senator Coulter has had a chance to look at the history of inquiries that have been carried out by the Senate and at the way in which an independent inquiry can be established. I suggest there are a number of ways to do them, one of which is set out in the motion that the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, has moved. In that motion Senator Hill picks up the major themes that Senator Coulter is concerned about and proposes, among other things, the appointment of a judge of a superior court to that inquiry.

What we had was a very clear alternative that could have gone forward, but what Senator Coulter has done, in a somewhat disgraceful manner, is to attempt to turn the fire back on the Liberal Party, to attempt to raise this spurious issue that somehow the real issue that was involved here was the lack of a ministerial code of conduct. We have a ministerial code of conduct. It is writ large in the conventions and precedents of the last 200 years. In an attempt to take the heat off the Government and off himself, the senator has tried this pathetic stunt, which I suspect will blow up in his face—as it duly should. He seemed at one stage to recognise the need for a major inquiry, an independent inquiry to suss out all the facts that are involved in this issue; yet now he says that he believes the real issue to be a code of conduct.

The issue is not a code of conduct. It is the willingness of a Prime Minister to enforce proper standards of government. We saw in the case of Senator Richardson that only when this Parliament was able to drag out the facts, only when we were able to table documents which Senator Richardson said he could not find, only when we were able to pursue the questioning, did we come to the facts of the case and the involvement of Senator Richardson in this matter. But even having established that Senator Richardson had misled this chamber, having established all that, we still have not been able to get a statement from Mr Keating that there was anything wrong with the behaviour of Senator Richardson.

It is not the code of conduct which is the problem in this case. We know that when Ministers mislead the Parliament they must face the ultimate sanction. It is the behaviour of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and it is his failure to enforce, at an early stage, proper standards of ministerial accountability which is the problem. I suggest that not only is Senator Coulter trying to divert the issue from the Marshall Islands affair—why, I do not know—to the issue of the code of conduct, but the code of conduct is not the issue. It is the willingness of senior people, of political leaders, to enforce a proper code of conduct. In the case of Mr Keating, his values are writ large. Mr Keating has failed to condemn the behaviour of Senator Richardson in any way whatsoever.

Can a ministerial code of conduct deal with the astonishing behaviour of Senator Evans? It must be obvious to the most junior consular officer in the Department of Foreign Affairs that one thing not to do is to get oneself involved in the judicial process in another country. It would have been the most obvious principle that the newest, most junior members of the Department of Foreign Affairs know. That is their code of conduct. But here we have a Minister, Senator Evans, who still stands up and tries to justify his absolutely disgraceful behaviour, and who still has not conceded that there was anything wrong with giving approval to Senator Richardson to phone up the President of another country to seek a special favour for a colleague of Senator Richardson.

There are large numbers of matters which must be explored but will not be explored till we have a proper inquiry put in place. I suggest that the chances are that in the fullness of time, we will have an inquiry into the Marshall Islands affair. It will not happen today, because of the Australian Democrats, but doubtless as more and more material emerges in this particular area we will find out. We need an inquiry into the ministerial accountability, particularly as demonstrated by Senator Evans; we need an inquiry to look at the astonishing behaviour of the Department of Foreign Affairs in this whole issue, and the astonishing behaviour of some of its officers.

Much of the behaviour of the Department of Foreign Affairs may be accounted for by the fact that Senator Evans made it very clear—and he confirmed that in his remarks today—that the Department of Foreign Affairs was to avoid at all costs any inquiry into the Marshall Islands affair. We have had a major issue running in this Parliament for some two months now, and not one briefing note on a possible parliamentary question has appeared from the Department of Foreign Affairs on this matter. I believe the Department of Foreign Affairs was, to a certain extent, warned off looking at any element of this Marshall Islands affair.

We have to establish that. We have to establish just why that Department seemed to not supply the proper briefing notes to Ministers, why the Department failed to inform Senator Evans late last November of the involvement of Senator Sibraa, and what happened to the follow-through on that particular important issue, which signalled the start of what has become one of the most grubby affairs in this country. We want to find out, as Senator Coulter has told this chamber before, why the Department behaved as it did, why the Department did not provide adequate briefing notes on these matters, and why the Department whited out certain briefing notes that were made public. There are a large number of issues which I believe have got to be fully explored.

One of the questions that was put to Senator Evans the other day was a request from Senator Baden Teague for copies of the transcripts of the Symons court hearing in the Marshall Islands on 14 and 15 May. Senator Evans said, some one month after this event—and I do not dispute what the Department have told him—that these transcripts are not available. But we do have a report of some of the evidence that was put before the court at that time, and this evidence has simply not been covered in this country.

I invite Senator Coulter to listen to this. This is evidence that was led in the inquiry by Mr Strauss, the lawyer employed by Mr Gregory Symons. It comes from a very bad photocopy which is included in the papers that Senator Evans tabled in the Senate some time ago. This is what the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: Symons said in concluding his defence on Monday that the Marshall Islands has no jurisdiction to try him, arguing that the government prosecutors were "attempting to prosecute an Australian for alleged criminal activity that occurred in Australia.
It goes on to say:

While defence attorney David Strauss acknowledged that the Government had "made a case of probable cause that a felony had occurred in Australia", he said "all evidence introduced by the prosecution showed that these acts did not occur in the Marshall Islands".

The reality is, if they did not occur in the Marshall Islands, where did these criminal offences occur? Should we take the word of the lawyer and Mr Gregory Symons and say that these alleged acts did not occur in the Marshall Islands, but may have occurred in Australia or elsewhere?

PARA.TAB: One of the aspects of such an inquiry would be to establish where criminal acts did occur, what particular action may be taken, and what involvement of any other Australians there is in this particular matter. I suggest to you that there has been a total failure by the Government to follow through on this matter. Of course the Government does not want an inquiry; but with their alleged commitment to proper accountability, and with their alleged commitment to proper standards in government, one would have thought the Australian Democrats would have been strong supporters of such a motion. At one time, they were.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I do not know whether you were in the chamber for Senator Evans's remarks. It was very interesting that he called out four or five times across this chamber some rather unflattering comments about the former Premier of New South Wales. It was clear that Senator Evans was obsessed by the problems of an inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obsessed? He was terrified!

—Of course he was terrified. We all have a variety of views on what happened to the former Premier of New South Wales, and I was particularly interested in the views that Senator Cooney put forward. Senator Evans was obsessed by the problems of an inquiry, obsessed by what might happen if an inquiry were put in train.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans knows full well that the full facts of this matter can only emerge when we have a proper inquiry and when we have the opportunity to speak under oath and under parliamentary privilege to officers of the Department to give them a chance to explain whether their Department behaved in a sloppy and incompetent manner in relation to the Marshall Islands affair or whether the Minister was determined not only to hide from the Australian people what was occurring, but also to prevent his Department from looking closely into these matters.

So there are many issues which must be explored and which will remain to be explored. Why did Senator Evans, for example, agree to Senator Richardson making this phone call? Did he seek any advice from the Department as to the nature of this call? Did he seek advice on the appropriateness of allowing Senator Richardson to make such a request? Was there possibly any other alternative? There is no evidence that having agreed to this astonishing phone call—a phone call which ultimately led to the downfall of Senator Richardson—Senator Evans took any chance to consult his Department on the protocol of the matter. If he had, his Department would have made it very clear to him that it was a very risky and silly thing to do and that the code of conduct of the Department would certainly preclude such behaviour.

But that had no effect on Senator Evans. Indeed, there is enough evidence to suggest that Senator Evans was very anxious to ensure that no further inquiries were made about Senator Richardson's behaviour in relation to this phone call. We have notes on file, tabled by Senator Evans, which point out that Senator Richardson apparently, according to a file note, had phoned a number of officials in the Marshall Islands.

We will continue to pursue this matter. It is a fair question to ask whether Senator Coulter has taken the time to read those documents which were tabled by Senator Evans on 4 June. If he did, I suspect the same questions which have occurred to us and to members of the press would have occurred to him. For example, I believe the documents give substantial basis to concerns that they provide further evidence of the misleading of the Parliament by Senator Evans.

We know that the DFAT Assistant Secretary, Mr O'Leary, disputes the statutory declaration of Senator Evans's senior adviser, Miles Kupa. Mr O'Leary points out, as I mentioned to the Senate, in document 28, that Mr Kupa recalled the Sibraa letter being mentioned to him in the telephone conversation of April 6. The papers tabled by Senator Evans prove that the documents released by the Prime Minister had been tampered with—we did not know that before—and significant notations on documents had been whited out. When Senator Evans tabled these documents, he made no acknowledgment of the whiting out of information and he presumably hoped that this particular cover up would continue.

Senator Evans has called on Senator Coulter and the other Australian Democrats to believe that he and Senator Richardson have provided all required information on this Marshall Islands affair. Given the behaviour of this Government, given the behaviour of Senator Evans in relation to the Burkegate affair—and we can all remember the huge enthusiasm with which Senator Evans pursued the many, many questions that Senator Campbell and Senator Knowles had raised in relation to that affair—it beggars belief that Senator Evans has provided a full and frank volume of material which sets out all the issues which have occurred in this particular debate.

We have not heard, of course, the departmental view on this matter. I point out that there is a huge interest, an overriding interest, on the part of the Government to avoid a proper inquiry into the Marshall Islands affair. Senator Coulter and his colleagues, for reasons that we do not know, and for reasons which have not been spelt out, have decided to cooperate with the Government.

This affair will not go away. I suggest to Senator Coulter that in the not too distant future he will rue the fact that he agreed in the Parliament this morning to this grubby deal with the Government to avoid an inquiry into the Marshall Islands affair and to pretend that the real issue before this Parliament was some code of conduct.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a simple problem with regard to Senator Coulter's motion; that is, if one does not know what has been going on, how can one decide what to do about it? That is the nub of the problem. By determining not to have an inquiry, the Democrats are preventing us finding out what on earth has been going on in recent times in this Government on matters like the Marshall Islands affair.
—It is a pay-back.

—Whether or not it is a pay-back, the issue is clear: if one does not know what is going on, how can one fix it? We want to find out what is going on, and I believe we have got every right to do so. I acknowledge the sound points that Senator Cooney made about the extent to which inquiries, particularly external ones, can lead to difficulties. We are talking about a Senate inquiry, yet we are being denied a Senate inquiry to establish the extent of the problems which we all concede have to be dealt with. We have to find properly—it is a universal view, I would suggest—the way in which this place should be conducted. It is our general view that if people do not know they ought to know, anyway. But if it is conceded that a formal committee has to do it, how can that formal committee operate when it does not know what is going on and Senator Coulter is blocking and preventing it finding out what is going on?

PARA.TAB: The illogicality of Senator Coulter's position is overwhelming. That is why, of course, we are saying that there has to be an inquiry. We do not want to participate in what is developing as an absolute sham being put up as an alternative to establishing properly just what on earth has been going on under this Government and what sorts of standards have been breached. Then, I suppose, having established that, we will be in a much better position to determine what the standards should be, if that is what Senator Coulter thinks should happen.

There is no doubt that the Marshall Islands affair has left a volume of unanswered questions. That has generally emerged as a result of the precipitate departure of Senator Richardson. If we raise matters of substance relating to Senator Richardson's Department or the Marshall Islands affair, we are accused of raking over old coals. In fact, that is exactly what Senator Evans said today.

The issue is apparently verboten to us. We must not talk about it; we are simply raking over old coals. What may well emerge from a proper inquiry is that there may have been improper conduct, sloppy administration and incredible breakdowns of communication which cannot be justified between a Minister's office and the Minister and/or his Department. But to dismiss any examination of the matters involved, including the principles involved, as raking over old coals is absolute nonsense.

There are some key questions that remain unanswered. The ABC's Four Corners asked a key question: Has Senator Richardson been totally candid about the extent of the involvement of his office with Symons's business migration scheme? It is question No. 1. We are not getting an answer. His precipitate departure—defended by the Government as being the action of a man who had done nothing wrong; his resignation was simply to protect the Government from an outrageous and disgraceful set of attacks—raises in itself the very question: if the Government says he has done nothing wrong, what has it got to fear from an inquiry? Why will it not have an inquiry?

The more the Government protests that Senator Richardson did nothing wrong and his resignation was evidence of nobility rather than culpability, as long as the Government maintains that proposition, I believe it is essential that that proposition be tested. The Government's refusal to test that proposition puts it totally and absolutely in doubt. Senator Coulter's preparedness to go along with the Government over that and to accept by inference the Government's claim that nothing Senator Richardson did was wrong strikes me as absolutely extraordinary. His committee will do nothing to establish the facts of this matter.

As the ABC pointed out on its Four Corners program, Symons did not even need to have Senator Richardson in the country in order to get access to the resources of his ministerial office, because Senator Richardson says he was overseas when the faxes were sent to Suva. He said he only found out about them after the Marshall Islands affair blew up. Of course, we all know about the Multiplex letter which—unwittingly, I believe—told the absolute lie that Chang Jr, one of the Chinese involved in this matter, was going to work for Multiplex in Australia, although there is a question of doubt about the meaning of that letter. But the key thing emerges. There can be no doubt that Senator Richardson's office was used in an attempt to deceive Australian immigration officials. That is clear cut and we have to establish why and how that could come about.

Another matter that is clear is that surely Senator Evans must have known the significance of Senator Richardson's reference and his phone call. Everyone involved in this affair agrees that the letter of reference that Senator Richardson wrote for Mr Symons had a big effect on the Marshall Islands Government's decision to help Mr Symons initially. It is clear that the fact that Senator Richardson was backing him was very important indeed. In fact, Michael Bonney, who was also conned by Mr Symons, said that it was certainly one of the major factors in his credibility for the undertaking of such a project. It was not just Mr Bonney, the ABC said, who was impressed with Mr Symons's credentials, especially the personal reference from Senator Graham Richardson. It is clear the personal reference played a key role in the Marshall Island Government's decision to allow the whole venture to go ahead. But nowhere in that reference is there any mention of the string of Symons business failures or his near bankruptcy.

People at the University of Queensland have described statements in the reference, that Symons worked closely with them, as a gross exaggeration. In fact, they hardly knew him.Senator Richardson says he did not know all that. Those are some of the issues that have to be pursued. To what extent is this irresponsible behaviour on the part of a Minister not to know matters of this nature when, in fact, they are put in a reference which is of significance to another country?
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., we will proceed to the debate on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the last day when Bruce Webster will be the senior announcer of the parliamentary broadcasting network. Bruce will be retiring from the ABC after a stint at the Olympic Games in Barcelona, where he will be studio anchorman and also commentator on the opening and closing ceremonies. That is not new to him: he worked with ABC radio at the Melbourne Olympics also. There is no doubt that Bruce has had a very long and distinguished career in Australian broadcasting, since beginning in 1947 as a messenger boy for the ABC.

PARA.TAB: In his early work with the ABC, Bruce served in Victoria, Tasmania, New South Wales and Queensland as a broadcaster. In fact, he was the regional manager of the ABC in Cairns. One interesting story about Bruce relates to his time in Cairns. A local journalist with the ABC took ill and a replacement was sent from Brisbane. This replacement was very critical of the standard of news copy and the standard of stories on ABC radio in Cairns and he decided to do something about it. He was a pretty objectionable character, by all reports, but he fell into a trap well and truly set for him by Bruce.

The new, hot-shot journalist from Brisbane got a really good tip that there was a dinghy missing in Torres Strait and he was given a telephone number for the fishing board, which it was expected would have further information. The new journo from Brisbane thought that this would be a terrific story. It would have not only local interest but, obviously, State and national interest as well. He contacted the telephone number that was given to him for the fishing board, and the story was confirmed by a gentlemen at the fishing board, in a very heavy southern European accent. The new journalist thought he had really something to go on with and things were looking pretty good, until someone in the ABC in Cairns suggested he take it a bit easy because no-one knew of anyone with a heavy southern European accent working for the fishing board in Cairns. He was told to check with the fishing board.

The journalist did check; he phoned the fishing board again and spoke to the spokesperson there, who on this occasion turned out to have a very dinky-di Australian accent. That person got stuck mercilessly into this fellow for being irresponsible in running an unfounded story and something that was untrue. He was very highly critical of this journalist and how he brought his profession into disrepute. At the end of that conversation the journalist turned round and found Bruce Webster laughing behind him. The phone number he had been given was Bruce's home phone number. I understand that there was no more nonsense from that hot-shot journo in Cairns.

After his very long stint with the ABC, Bruce went to work for Qantas for a couple of years from 1966 to 1968, when he was the chief press and information officer of Qantas in Canada and the USA. He became very prominent from 1968 to 1975, when he pioneered breakfast television in Australia. As many would remember, for very many years he hosted the Today program on Channel 7 with Pat Lovell.

After that, he became active in parliamentary politics, and on 8 February 1975 he won the Pittwater by-election in Sydney, following the resignation of the former Premier, Robin Askin. He did it with a pretty solid 63 per cent of the primary vote in the State seat of Pittwater. He was re-elected in the 1976 general election—that was when the Wran Government was first elected—suffering a very small swing of 1.8 per cent, but being re-elected with 61.2 per cent of the primary vote. I can recall at that time, as a young activist in the ALP, being very concerned about Bruce Webster's promotion in the Liberal Party. He had by then become the shadow Minister for Mines and Energy. There were problems with the leadership in the New South Wales Liberal Party. Many of us thought that Bruce Webster would be a very likely prospective leadership contender for the Liberal Party and might well have been very dangerous indeed for New South Wales Labor, if he had accepted that role.

What in fact occurred is that Bruce Webster basically loathed parliamentary politics, and the conflict that went with it. He found himself, he said to me, in a state of constant conflict, and that is at all levels: conflict in the Party, conflict in the Parliament, conflict in his own electorate and conflict in his own electorate conference. After what turned out to be a very short parliamentary career, Bruce decided to resign. He was not happy and he gave it away. As most people sitting in this chamber know, it is very unusual in Australian politics for someone to resign after a fairly short parliamentary career in a safe constituency for their Party. He did that. Very few of his parliamentary colleagues had any knowledge that he was going to do that, when he decided to resign just before the 1978 State election. I think for Bruce it may well have all been summed up by him receiving from his electorate conference as a farewell gift a little model of a square peg in a round hole.

He had no regrets about his resignation from parliament, but it did give him a unique insight into the institution of Parliament and, of course, unique knowledge of how it worked. He had only a very short period active in party politics, a very brief fling indeed, and only a comparatively short time as a member of the Liberal Party, in fact. But he has remained very active in terms of his community service since giving parliamentary politics away.

He had a brief stint as news director for 2UE in Sydney from 1978 to 1979, and went back to the ABC in 1979. In 1986 he transferred to Canberra as the senior parliamentary broadcaster, and he set about attempting to make the parliamentary broadcasts a great deal more relevant and more interesting than they had been, which, I must say, is no mean task, because when someone like myself makes a speech like this, the parliamentary broadcasters can say very little except perhaps, `Senator Faulkner, Labor, New South Wales'. Of course, they come into their own during divisions. Bruce's record at the moment is 12 divisions on the trot in the House of Representatives when he has had to keep commentary up. In fact, he fronts Question Time on television and has kept a commentary going there for some 47 minutes, which is no mean feat, as I think everyone would know.

I think he always made tremendous efforts throughout his time here to be ahead of the game. I know from my own role here that he was in constant contact and consultation with the Whip's office. He kept in touch with the parliamentary liaison officers, the managers of government business, the Clerks and all those people that he needed to, to be aware of what was going to happen in Parliament during the course of the day. He took a great deal of pride in getting it right. I think on every occasion he did get it right. He is an extremely popular figure in Parliament House. I seek leave now to incorporate in Hansard a letter I have received from Brian Hasler, who is one of the supervisors with the guide service here at Parliament House, attesting to some of the work that Bruce has done and the commitment that Bruce had to this Parliament.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator John Faulkner
Parliament House
Canberra 2600
Dear Senator

PARA.TAB: I am one of three supervisors with the Guide Service from Public and Marketing section of Joint House Dept. Together with the Principal Guide we look after thirty six Guides to give a service to Senators, Members, staff and the Public.

On many occasions it becomes necessary to answer some very difficult questions asked by members of the Public. If for any reason these questions can't be answered we are required to find out and pass on the relevant information. Over the years we have found our best source to be BRUCE WEBSTER.

Having known Bruce for some ten years now, I have become quite close friends with him. He has become a roving Encyclopedia and if he can't answer immediately he will research the query for me and come with an answer very soon after.
His wide experience in various fields eg. Pilot, Sea Master, Politician, Television and Radio have given him a wealth of knowledge far beyond that of a normal person.
Just to have a quiet drink and discussion with him is just something one never forgets as it's always so enlightening in many aspects of life.

Twelve months ago to the very day, the morning adjourned after the Autumn session, Bruce intended to leave Canberra early for his annual holidays. We had an intake of six new Guides and I asked Bruce if he could brief them for two hours on the institution of Parliament, not knowing that he was taking leave. As always in his usual very helpful manner he delayed his departure to spend the time with them and give them the most encouraging welcome anyone could expect on commencing a new job, apart from of course giving them a tour of the building that very few people ever get to see and passing on his vast knowledge of Parliament.

I will miss Bruce and his vivid broadcasts of Parliament, his wide experience in all areas of life, his great sense of humour, his company on many occasions for a social get together and of course the staff bar where he always enjoyed a glass of ale with the BOYS during meal times.

On behalf of all the guides I wish him well in his retirement which I know he and his wife will thoroughly enjoy and of course his last assignment, BARCELONA is a fitting reward to a wonderful career.

SPEECH.PARA: Yours Sincerely
Brian Hasler

TALK.START.PARA: —It must be pretty difficult at times for Bruce Webster and the others involved in the parliamentary broadcasting service such as Errol Silver, Peter Leonard and Kevin Chapman—all those who front the microphones and all those behind the scenes—to make it interesting. It is probably not as interesting as an incident that apparently occurred in an ABC television show that was run many years ago at about five minutes to seven, called Market to Market. Bruce used to front that show. They would bring in baskets of produce, examine them and talk about the market prices and so forth. At one stage—I am sure it would not happen in this day and age—one of his colleagues in the studio started to ping peas at him across the television studio and he was under a shower of peas there. Bruce, absolutely deadpan, said to those watching the program, `Ladies and gentlemen, I am being peed upon from a great height'.

PARA.TAB: The sort of commitment that the parliamentary broadcasting network announcers have is well-known to all honourable senators and members of parliament. They work very long hours. They work very long shifts. Senator Knowles and I, who are Whips, know what it is like to be on hour-about shifts. The announcers have to concentrate extremely hard in the broadcast box. It is a difficult job and it has been done extraordinarily well by Bruce Webster over the many years that he has been the chief announcer with the parliamentary broadcasting network.

All his colleagues attest to his professionalism. In fact, some of them describe him as a perfectionist. He is not the sort of person who will allow himself to make mistakes. The best thing I can say about Bruce Webster is that I can attest to his objectivity, which is obviously very important in the sort of role that he plays. In June of this year he was awarded an Order of Australia medal for services to media broadcasting and increasing public awareness of the parliamentary process.

I have heard many speeches in this chamber during which a senator has said that he or she would like to say something on behalf of all honourable senators. I do not think I have ever found myself in a position where I could do that. I think, when it is done, at times it is perhaps a little pretentious. On this occasion I think we can all say to Bruce, who is personally known to nearly every member and senator in the Commonwealth Parliament, `Congratulations on a job very well done'. I will not say, `Best wishes to Bruce on your retirement' because I imagine he is not the sort of man who will retire, but I wish all the best to Bruce Webster and his family for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I am sure it has not escaped your notice that the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Keating) has a particular interest and fascination with the Australian flag. I thought it would be of interest today to draw to the attention of the Prime Minister's colleagues and the whole Senate the fact that perhaps the Prime Minister has not exactly read his history well enough.

PARA.TAB: I know that Mr Keating is very interested in Australian history. Sadly, I hope not uncharitably, I believe it is true to say that his view of our history is a very unique view, and sometimes I suspect that he may even be trying to rewrite our history. But be that as it may, I think he has perhaps not gone far enough back into history to look at the question of the Australian flag. I would like to take a few minutes of the Senate's time to make sure that some of his colleagues tell him a little more history than he knows already.

It is obviously not well known in Australia that in 1849 the Reverend John West, who was then the editor of the Launceston Examiner, which is still a venerable paper today I am glad to say, was a very keen proponent of the ending of convict transportation. He got like-minded people together in Launceston, a very small provincial town at that time, and formed the Anti-Transportation League. As part of that—this is 1849—the Reverend John West designed a flag for the Anti-Transportation League. That flag was produced by the needlecraft of the ladies of Launceston, and it was used in lectures all over Australia.

In 1851 the delegates from Van Diemen's Land went to Melbourne for the second inter-colonial conference of colonists, and it was then called the Australasian Anti-transportation League. The delegates to that conference in Melbourne were so taken with Reverend John West's flag that the women of Melbourne made a copy of the flag which had been embroidered in Launceston. At that time there were five of the colonies in the League. It was called the Australasian League for a very good reason: New Zealand was one of the colonies, as were Van Diemen's Land, Victoria, New South Wales—which still had Queensland as part of it at that time—and, I think, South Australia. Those five colonies were represented on the flag designed by Reverend John West.

The flag had a blue field, it had a Union Jack, and a Southern Cross in exactly the same positions as they are today. Madam Acting Deputy President, just so that you can see that for yourself, I will show you. This is the Australasian League's flag. This is the one that was made by the ladies in Melbourne in 1851, but it was an exact copy of the one made by the ladies of Launceston in 1849. You can see the Southern Cross, and each of those stars of the Southern Cross represented one of the colonies involved in the Australasian Anti-Transportation League.

Many copies of that flag were produced and, interestingly, it was flown on inter-colonial schooners trading between the colonies for some time. The motto of members of the League was `The Australians are one'. Their flag was described by them as a tangible symbol of unity and was adopted as their flag at that Melbourne conference in 1851. It has since been claimed that it was the forerunner, both of the Victorian flag and eventually of the Australian flag. The interesting thing is—this is the lesson that is to be learned from this little story—that the purpose of the League was not only to end transportation but also to cement the ties between the colonies, and to produce some form of government, in those colonies, in which the colonists would have complete political power. They claimed that they were intent on removing the misrule of Downing Street; they wanted to get rid of the misrule of Downing Street.

The push for independence that this League started in 1849 demonstrated an independence of spirit which has been part of our history since that time. For over 100 years, nearly 150 years, we Australians, in our various colonies and then States, have been demonstrating an independence of spirit. A battle first of all with Britain, which sent convicts to Australia, and then a battle to achieve representative government in the colonies. We have all taken that independence for granted until, just recently, we find we have a Prime Minister who tells us that we have never been independent.

I just ask you, Madam Acting Deputy President, to make sure that the Prime Minister of Australia understands that that flag, embroidered by the ladies of Launceston in 1849, is a symbol of where our fight for independence started and that we have had an independent spirit since that time. The sudden craze to get rid of a flag which is based on this flag, which has its origins in this flag, is a nonsense. That flag demonstrates beyond any shadow of a doubt that we have had an independent spirit. That flag is an integral part of our history. It is not something that suddenly became our flag in the national Flags Act in 1953; it has been with us in some form or other since 1849.

The Prime Minister of this country needs to get his history right. He needs to do a bit more study and he should recognise that there is no need to try to push for independence and fight Britain and all that nonsense he has been going on with lately. That has been the way of it in this country for 150 years. It is a nonsense to try to produce a diversion now based on the flag. I hope that he will learn a little bit of history from the flag produced by the ladies of Launceston.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the chamber on a topic which is of particular interest to me—the Constitution. Before I follow through with my remarks, I would like to congratulate Senator Newman for the speech that she has just made to the chamber. I had not appreciated that the history of the flag went back as far as she has pointed out. It is certainly of value and I hope that Senator Ray, who I know is a very strong supporter of the Australian flag and has said so in this chamber—
—I didn't say anything of the sort.

—Now Senator Ray has changed his mind again. He agreed with me when I said that it was the most beautiful flag in the world, and naturally I took that to be an expression of support for the Australian flag. I am sorry that he seems to have backed away from that issue. I hope that the soldiers he commands as the Minister for Defence will show a greater capacity to defend the flag than he does. I thank Senator Newman for the contribution she made. I found it particularly valuable.

PARA.TAB: I want to speak briefly today about a related matter which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has raised for public debate: whether Australia should move towards a republic. I pointed out in this chamber that within the ranks of the republican movement there is fairly substantial division. We do not actually know what sort of republican constitution the Prime Minister supports. All we know is that he does not support the Constitution which has carried us through 92 years, probably making Australia the world's oldest continuous democracy. We know that he does not support our current Constitution; we do not know as yet what sort of republican constitution he supports.

There is some division in the ranks of the republicans. There are those who adopt the minimalist position. In other words, they want to leave the Constitution as far as practicable in its current form but remove references to the monarch. These people I would classify as following the general views of Mr Thomas Keneally. There are quite a number—for example, Donald Horne—who have said that they really want what they would describe as a full revamping of the Constitution. We can wonder as to what form this huge revamp would take; there are some who would prefer an American type constitution and some who have other views. There are tensions within the republican movement and as this debate continues it is quite possible that we will find further fractures appearing amongst the republicans over what sort of Constitution they want to support.

The so-called minimalist camp recently took the running in a quest to wrest the initiative in the republican debate from their more radical colleagues, with the publishing of a supplement in the March edition of the Independent Monthly which presented a proposal for a republican constitution. This proposal was prepared by Professor Winterton, Professor of Law at the University of New South Wales, who is the author of Monarchy to Republic: Australian Republican Government. Professor Winterton is a principal mentor of the republican movement. I have never been quite clear from his writings just why he so strongly supports overturning the Constitution which has worked so well.

It is an interesting thing that so often, in these debates between one's heart and one's head, the heart seems to rule the head—particularly in politics. If there is any value at all in this debate which has emerged, it will require the rational, practical reasons to be laid out before the Australian public. Those views will have to be forcefully expressed. One of Australia's great achievements, to my mind, is its Constitution. I find it a bit obscure why an academic has suddenly adopted the view that we should overturn what is by all accounts a well functioning constitution. It is not a perfect constitution, and certainly it is a constitution which has some problems, but it is a constitution that has served this country particularly well and a constitution which is worthy of strong support.

Professor Winterton in his article said that it demonstrates how an Australian republic could be implemented while leaving intact all the essential features of Australian government except the monarchy. Two features of the minimalist position need to be clearly identified. First, even the minimalist proposal involves a substantial rewriting of the Constitution. Certainly a glance at the draft constitution put forward by Professor Winterton reveals the extent of changes that must be made to our current Constitution. Second, it is incorrect to say that it is possible to remove the position of the monarchy and the role of the Governor-General from our Constitution and have our system of government remain unchanged, as Professor Winterton asserts. Even the position advocated by him will have significant ramifications for the Australian system of government.

There are essentially three major problems with the position put forward by Professor Winterton. The first is that Professor Winterton fails to deal with a central question in a republic, how the substitute head of state is to be chosen. Every possible method for choosing a substitute head of state raises serious problems. A directly elected president could rightly claim more authority than the Prime Minister of the day, and could upset our system of government by seeking to exercise that authority contrary to the conventions applying to the Crown and the Governor-General under our current arrangements. An indirectly elected president—elected, for example, by the Parliament—would likely be the product of a backroom political deal resulting in the selection of a party hack or an innocuous identity.

TALK.START.PARA: —That means I can't run.

—Senator Ray said he cannot run. I think Senator Ray would actually have some support in the community. From time to time when Senator Ray makes a contribution to the debate I can see deep down beneath the Labor Party bluster a man who has some affection for the Parliament and some affection for the standards of the Parliament. That is more than I can say for quite a number of his colleagues. But that is quite enough. I will not go on and threaten Senator Ray's preselection.

PARA.TAB: I think there is a problem in the election as specified by Professor Winterton, if the head of state were elected in the parliamentary process. I certainly make no reflection on our current Presiding Officer in this chamber, but I have to point out that the Presiding Officer in the other chamber was elected by this sort of process. I can only quote Senator Ray and suggest, albeit in more moderate terms, that perhaps he is not the most distinguished person to occupy that position.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that. The Sydney Morning Herald said that.

—Okay, the press got it wrong. The second serious problem that emerges from Professor Winterton's proposal is the question of how to make a president subject to the conventions which apply to the Crown and the Governor-General. These conventions, which underpin our constitutional arrangements, are well understood and fairly well established. They provide a flexible yet certain framework within which our institutions function. Indeed, they are an essential element of Australia's constitutional system.

PARA.TAB: By their very nature, these conventions derive their authority from the Crown. With the removal of the Crown, all these conventions will not necessarily survive, particularly when an elected politician is substituted as head of state for the monarch and the Governor-General. As Professor Cheryl Saunders, Professor of Law at the University of Melbourne, has observed, there is no point in removing all references to the Queen and leaving a vacuum in the Constitution. At that point, Professor Saunders says, we are in total chaos.

The third, and equally serious, question relates to the position of the monarch in each of the Australian States. Each State is a constitutional monarchy in its own right, with its own link to the Crown. Unless the republicans are unconcerned about having an anomalous situation in which Australia is a republic federally while some or all of the States choose to remain constitutional monarchies, they will certainly have to address this problem. I can draw attention to the dangers of that process by citing a remark made by a gentleman who is head of the Australian Republican Party and who was quoted in the press as saying that it is possible that the move to a republic would lead to the secession of States. As Senator Walters is here in the chamber, I point out that the ARP spokesman suggested that Tasmania would be the first State to secede.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly would be.

—Senator Walters confirms that view. I thought that was an interesting admission coming from the Australian Republican Party, and it really shows the sort of hazardous course the republicans are prepared to pitch Australia into. What other country in the world would overturn a successful working constitution for totally spurious benefits in an attempt to settle once and for all an old world debate?

PARA.TAB: This debate as to whether we should move to a republic or retain our current Constitution is not a reflection of Australian concerns. Senator Ray, who is a great student of the political process, would know that in all the surveys of what concerns Australians most—and I have been following those surveys for 20 years—there has never been any concern expressed by Australians about their Constitution or about their flag.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot about the GST, though.

—Senator Ray, in an interesting way, has actually confirmed my comment that there has been no concern expressed. The people certainly have concerns about the Keating Government—there is no question of that—but they have expressed no concerns about the Constitution or about the flag. This is a totally contrived debate which has been brought before the Australian public by Mr Keating, and it really harks back to some views that have their roots in the old world rather than in the new world.

PARA.TAB: I would like, in the time available to me, to look briefly at Professor Winterton's solution to the problem of how we may incorporate all the constitutional conventions which govern the workings of our Constitution actually in a constitution. Professor Winterton's draft attempts to overcome this problem, which is, I repeat, the problem of confining the role of the President to the conventional role of the Governor-General, by writing that role into the Constitution and then, to avoid giving it constitutional rigidity, by providing that that role may be changed by ordinary legislation passed by the Federal Parliament.

It is here that the draft of Professor Winterton gives rise to potentially the greatest problems. Proposed new section 60A provides that the President is to exercise and perform his powers and functions in accordance with the constitutional conventions relating to the Governor-General, but then goes on to provide that these constitutional conventions do not have the force of law.

A constitution, however, as you will know, Madam Acting Deputy President, is the supreme law of the country. One would have to ask, if the conventions under Professor Winterton's proposal do not have the force of law, what purpose is served by referring to them in this way. The section proposed by Professor Winterton is an empty section and, in consequence, when exercising a proposed legislative power, the Parliament would be filling a legal vacuum. The proposed new section 51(xi) would allow the Parliament to legislate concerning `the exercise of any power vested by this Constitution in the President, the President-in-Council or any other person or authority exercising executive power of the Commonwealth'. This provision would allow the Federal Parliament, which means any party or combination of parties with a majority in both Houses, to alter the Constitution in the most radical way, by ordinary legislation without a referendum.

The brief remarks that I have made in this chamber suggest that very real problems will emerge if the proposal floated by Mr Keating is proceeded with. It will cause great division in the Australian community. That would not worry Mr Keating. He is probably the most divisive Prime Minister that this country has had. Whatever faults may be attributed to Mr Hawke, and I have attributed a few in my time, I feel that Mr Hawke would certainly have avoided such a divisive act. Australia has a successfully working constitution, and it is surprising that academics such as Professor Winterton see the need to overturn a document that has served this country well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join Senator Faulkner in commenting on the remarkable service to Parliament of Bruce Webster, not only on his service to Parliament as the person who did more than any other to make parliamentary broadcasts almost interesting, but also on his service to the people of New South Wales as a member of the State Parliament. I have known Bruce Webster for a long time. He is, of course, older than I am, and that is why he is retiring, being obliged to retire.
—He looks younger.

—I agree, he does look younger, and it shows what a sensible move it was for him to decide that staying in the State Parliament would have made his hair fall out, as staying here in the Federal Parliament has made mine fall out. Our media roles overlapped for many of the years that he was in New South Wales in the media in some distinguished roles which Senator Faulkner mentioned in his speech. We were certainly contemporaries in the media in the 1950s and 1960s. He did very well in that area. His social conscience has been evident in a lot of the activities that he has carried on. For example, his spirit of community service prompted him to spend 15 years with the Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol, and he has been heavily involved in the scouting movement. Those feelings of community service prompted him to go into State Parliament as the member for Pittwater.

PARA.TAB: I was closely associated with Bruce during that time because, very sensibly, having recognised that I was likely to win a seat, particularly with his efforts, he came down to assist me in the 1975 election campaign. In fact I have a photocopy of the front page of the Nowra News Leader, which I would like to table. It outlines Bruce Webster's outstanding speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should have had him there in 1983.
—Senator Ray is right. It would have helped, but I did have Mr Fraser there in 1983.

PARA.TAB: I seek leave to table the front page of the Nowra News Leader of Friday, 30 May 1975.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The newspaper reports on its front page:

PARA.TAB: Bruce Webster spoke for almost fifteen minutes and there was a familiar ring about his words as though they had been heard somewhere before; and yet what he said applied to today.
At the conclusion of his address, all present at the meeting rose in a resounding peal of applause which went on until the chairman called for silence.

When it became possible for the speaker to continue he said that the speech was not his own, but had been delivered by Sir Robert Menzies in November 1949 when, facing an election, he warned against the policies of the socialists.

I must say there are many of us who perhaps need to be reminded of what Bruce Webster thought were important words and which I am certain we all think were important words. I will just quote a couple of things from that speech that Bruce Webster gave that night. This is one of the points from Sir Robert Menzies' speech:

First, we must avoid the common fallacy of supposing that freedom and discipline are inconsistent. It was that rugged thinker, Jeremy Bentham, who said that the mark of a good citizen was `to censure freely and to obey punctually'. The notion is, after all, not a complex one. The discipline we must look for is not the discipline of the slave, but the discipline of the volunteer. Such discipline does not take the form of a compulsory obedience to a higher authority, but is based upon an intelligent understanding of the fact that order and sanity are essential if the liberty of the individual is to be reconciled with the rights of other individuals. For many people, the desire for freedom appears to connote an impatience of government or, at the very least, an indifference to government. Such a view is among the deadliest enemies of liberty, for the responsible individual, not the irresponsible individual, is the real basis of a truly free society.

SPEECH.PARA: This is another part of Sir Robert Menzies' speech that Mr Webster quoted:

PARA.TAB: My protest is against that false humanitarianism which does not strengthen but corrupts; which does not rest upon the view that I am my brother's keeper, a view which is the noblest embodiment of the Christian philosophy, but rests upon the belief that my brother should be my keeper, and that I should leave my troubles to him. The protection of the poor and the weak, and the elimination of the causes of poverty and weakness are undoubtedly the supreme business of politics. One can recognise that without in any way ceasing to insist that the first duty of every man is to do his utmost to stand on his own feet, to form his own judgments, and to accept his own responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: Another part of that speech states:

. . . we must realize with clarity that the whole principle of individual freedom in an ordered society is not `Each for himself and the devil take the hindmost' but, as the lawyers would say: `Sic utere tuo ut alienum non laedas'—`So use your own that you do not injure another's.' This great maxim is not only at the root of much of our civil law; it is the whole basis of civil order, since it states with precision the limits which we must always be willing to place upon our own liberty if true social liberty is to be achieved.

PARA.TAB: The maxim serves as a constant reminder that we cannot decently or sensibly talk about our rights without also admitting our duties.

SPEECH.PARA: That speech, as Bruce said at the time, summed up his view of individual rights and that, of course, naturally explains why Bruce Webster felt such a strong commitment to the concept of parliament. It was in his role here, after he had decided that being a member of the parliament was not for him, that he was able to express or to give effective substance to those views he had of the importance of the parliamentary system, the significance, or the utmost role—the major role, of course—that individual freedom must play in any democracy, and the role of the parliament in preserving that democracy.

PARA.TAB: I must say that Bruce Webster has been consistent to those principles with absolute fairness. As Senator Faulkner noted, he has been fair. There is no question of political attitudes intruding at any stage in Bruce Webster's role here in the Parliament. Underneath it all, there is the evident view of the primacy of the rights of the individual. For that I commend Bruce Webster.

It was because of my longstanding friendship with him that, when he was the member for Pittwater in the New South Wales Parliament, he opened my first electorate office in Campbelltown in 1975 when I was elected the member for Macarthur. Bruce, as was his wont, travelled to Campbelltown on his motorbike; a clear view that the adornments of status were not for him. I do not know whether many other members of parliament would have decided that they should travel as perhaps many of their constituents could only travel, and that was by motorbike.

Bruce was never one to lord it over anyone else, no matter what his role, no matter that he was in some instances, for example, in an executive position in the media. Bruce was a man of the people because he believed in people. I am overjoyed that, during his time in the parliaments, both as a member and as someone in a key role in the Parliament communicating itself to the people, Bruce Webster has always remained a man of the people concerned with the rights of the people. I hope that in his retirement from this job he finds another satisfying way of expressing his belief in the rights of Australians and in the principles of freedom that he has espoused all his life.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join with my colleagues Senator Baume and Senator Faulkner because today marks the last day in this place of Mr Bruce Webster. He has become known over the last six years as the voice of the Federal Parliament—the person who, above all, has been able to explain the intricacies of this place in such concise terms and with such clarity of voice that no listener is left in doubt about what is happening or about to happen. He would say when the events would create a precedent, or how frequently they had happened before, and other interesting facts about them. I believe that, when we all hear him on the ABC in the morning, we listen intently because at least we will know what is about to happen in our own chamber.

PARA.TAB: In the days of the old building and before the televising of Parliament and the ABC radio broadcasts, Bruce Webster was the only direct contact between the Senate and the House of Representatives, and the people of Australia. His unique experience—as a broadcaster, press and information officer, television host of the top rating Today show, television newscaster, State member of parliament and commercial radio journalist—has equipped him with all the skills necessary to make any subject interesting, understandable and easy to listen to. That applies even to the Federal Parliament.

It is interesting to note that after his three years as the member for Pittwater and, as has already been said today, his disenchantment with that, Bruce was only able to stay away from the parliamentary arena for one year. Such is the nature of the occupation we all share. It is certainly addictive, has a narcotic effect and tends to draw all who leave it back in one way or another, often years after they have retired.

I recall that some time ago—I think it was in 1986—Senator Crowley took a point of order when I had claimed that Senator Don Grimes was a disgrace to Her Majesty's Government. I was asked to withdraw that and I refused to do so. After a lengthy debate across the chamber, I was finally named and a division was called. Because it was very late at night and the Labor members had all gone home, we won the division. The Government was defeated. There was a lot of discussion of what should take place and whether this was the first time such a thing had ever occurred. Bruce Webster was ahead of us all. He had already told his listeners that a similar occurrence had taken place a long while earlier, when Senator Willesee had been at the centre of a similar defeat of the government of the day. Such are the powers of recall that Bruce is so lucky to have.

His career started with the ABC in 1947, when he was employed as a messenger boy, and he spent most of his working life with that organisation. He rose considerably within the ABC. He served in Victoria, Tasmania, Queensland and New South Wales; and as a broadcaster he rose to the highest grading, so he knows much about our States. Those 18 years included 10 months BBC training and 18 months in Cairns as a regional manager. While in Cairns he founded the still thriving Cairns Little Theatre. As a broadcaster he covered four royal tours, the Melbourne Olympics, and a major world tour which produced a television documentary on Mexico, a radio feature and numerous interviews for both media.

He has indulged in a lot of community service: 15 years with the Royal Volunteer Coast Patrol, three years of that as a divisional commander, and 18 years with the scouting movement. He also served with the Federal Immigration Review Panel. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today in this public interest debate with two matters which I wish to put on the public record. Due to time constraints of the hearing and the unfortunate appearance of extremely heavy fog in Canberra on 5 June, which prevented the plane bringing the witnesses from Melbourne to Canberra from landing for several hours, the witnesses were unable to appear before the Committee until 12.30 of the day of the hearing.
