But because of the time constraint, time was not available from the Government in respect of the issues raised.

When the Bill was debated again under very strict time constraints in this chamber, Senator McMullan replied on the issue to the witnesses, Mr Anthony Proctor of KPMG Peat Marwick and Mr Mark Hopkinson of Macquarie Bank. However, the reply from both witnesses was not available as a consequence of the events that I have described. I therefore ask permission of the Senate to table letters from Mr Anthony E. Proctor, a partner of KPMG Peat Marwick, which respond to the arguments as presented previously by Senator McMullan on behalf of the Government. I believe that it is important that Mr Proctor should be able to respond in the same forum in which the case was presented by the Government, and I seek leave to have that letter incorporated in the Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Peat Marwick
Chartered Accountants
24 June 1992
Honourable Senators,
Parliament House,
Canberra, ACT 2600
Dear Senators,
STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 3) 1992 LIMITED PARTNERSHIPS

I appreciated the opportunity of appearing as a witness before the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on 5 June 1992 during its deliberations on the provisions of clauses 34, 35 and 36 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No 3) 1992 dealing with infrastructure borrowings.

The major thrust of my submission was that the Bill should be amended so that Limited Partnerships would be able to utilise infrastructure borrowings for the purpose of financing the three specified forms of infrastructure facilities.

An issue central to the acceptability of Limited Partnerships having a role as the owner and controller of an infrastructure facility is that they should not be able to be used in a way which would cause a loss of revenue to the Treasury in excess of the loss which would be occasioned by the proposed provisions.

I submitted that there would not be any material loss to revenue (and potentially, no loss) if limited partnerships were to be compromised only of entities which were taxable as companies under the income tax law. It was unfortunate that a detailed report I had prepared in support of that view could not be presented to the Committee due to time constraints.

That report provides a comparative analysis of the taxation issues which arise under the traditional forms of ownership of major projects which would be suitable for private investment and transport and electricity generating infrastructure facilities.

It concludes that the availability of deductions under the income tax law (and therefore the potential to impact the revenue) to an unincorporated joint venture of limited liability companies would be no different if a major project was owned by a limited partnership comprising companies limited by shares. A joint venture comprising limited liability companies is one of the most common forms of undertaking a major project to be owned and operated by several participants. It facilitates the agreement of the sharing of the commercial risks and benefits of a project between the parties and its financing.

I understand that it is the view of the Australian Taxation Office that members of limited partnerships whose liability is limited under the provisions of the partnership agreement would, if limited partnerships were permitted, be able to share in the losses of the partnership in excess of their capital contribution and therefore in excess of the risks that they are assuming by that capital contribution. The point can be made that the same result could arise under an unincorporated joint venture structure. As there is no greater impact on the revenue, this is not a valid ground for excluding limited partnerships from consideration.

A further view of the Taxation Office is apparently that limited partners do not participate in the management of a limited partnership and are therefore similar to shareholders in a company. Accordingly, as the issuer of a direct infrastructure borrowing must meet the test of intending to "own, operate and effectively control the use of, the facilities on which the money will be spent", a limited partnership must fail this test because a limited partner is not in a position to exercise effective control and is not exposed to the risks associated with ownership.

Such a proposition fails to recognise the commercial basis under which a limited partnership would be formed where each potential partner would have a real interest in negotiating the appointment of the general partner (whose liability is unlimited), the level of partnership capital, funding etc.

The proposition also fails to recognise that major project financings are generally undertaken on a non-recourse or very limited recourse basis where project risk is mostly taken by the financiers particularly having regard to the commercial viability and cash flow certainty of a project.

The Taxation Office arguments are all the more difficult to accept when it is recognised that the effect of an infrastructure borrowing by a limited partnership, because of the non-tax deductibility of the interest, will be to increase the taxable income or decrease the loss of the partnership which will be borne by the limited partners.

The policy of the One Nation initiatives on infrastructure borrowings is intended to permit the loss to the revenue to fall on the providers of finance under an infrastructure funds facility. That policy objective would be met if a limited partnership was able to issue infrastructure borrowings. No additional loss, which could have an impact on the revenue, is capable of being created.

Senators will recognise that there are many complex commercial and financial issues involved in the determination of the best structure available to own and finance an infrastructure facility. Taxation is but one of these. It is submitted that if it can be demonstrated that there is no greater impact on the revenue than would be the case under alternative structures that would meet the tests of eligibility to issue infrastructure borrowings, then there is no policy reason why a commercially acceptable limited partnership should be excluded. I believe that I can demonstrate the validity of that submission.
If Australia is to continue to encourage overseas equity participation and funding for its major developments we must be able to demonstrate that we can achieve "world best practice" in this area.
Limited partnerships are accepted in a number of Australian States and in many developed countries, including the United States of America, as an appropriate entity for carrying on a business.

Our taxation laws should not preclude the use of this form of business undertaking. In fact, limited partnerships have been recognised as an acceptable business entity for taxation purposes since various Australian States introduced their respective legislative regimes.

I believe that limited partnerships should be permitted to issue infrastructure borrowings, and that I can demonstrate that not only will there be no or minimal impact on revenue, but there will be greater efficiencies in the structuring, ownership and funding of major projects in Australia.

I would be pleased to assist Senators in their further deliberations in this area either by responding to individual requests or by making a detailed presentation to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration.
Yours faithfully,
(Sgd) Anthony E. Proctor
Partner

PARA.TAB: The second matter I wish to raise is also connected with the debates surrounding the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.3). SPEECH.PARA: Deloitte Ross Tohmatsu
Ref: RLC/ GDC/ Department of Tourism/ 172980/701/6047
24 June 1992
The Australian Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 1600
Honourable Senators

I refer to comments made by Senator McMullan before the Senate Committee on Finance and Public Administration on Friday 5 June 1992 in respect of my strong objections to the retrospective amendment of section 73B of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

Senator McMullan expressed puzzlement that Deloitte had not written to the Government or the Taxation Office in respect of the amendment. He also said that we should have made it known that we had a client that was adversely affected by the proposed amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: MINISTERIAL STATEMENT

As indicated in my statement to the Senate on 18 December 1991, during debate on the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No 3), the Government has adopted a structured, staged approach to the implementation of the major recommendations of the Brown Review of the Comcare program. This Bill represents the next logical step in that process.

In meeting the commitment I gave to the Senate in my Ministerial Statement of 18 December 1991, this Bill introduces legislative amendments covering two very important aspects of the Brown Review recommendations:
licensing of self-administering authorities; and
improved financial arrangements to enable Comcare Australia's financial statements to show that the scheme is fully funded.

This Bill delivers on the commitment the Government has already given in relation to the licensing of Commonwealth authorities. It provides, among other things, for the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees (the Commission) to:
issue licences subject to such conditions as the Commission determines, including issuing a licence to a Commonwealth authority on a State by State basis;
set performance standards for licence holders;
issue guidelines on the administration of the Act;
monitor the performance of licence holders;
issue directions to licence holders either generally or in relation to a specific matter or particular claim;
suspend or revoke a licence for failure on the part of the licence holder to comply with a condition of a licence including failure to comply with a direction issued by the Commission.

Section 89D of the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 already empowers me, as the relevant Minister, to issue directions to the Commission with respect to the performance of its functions or the exercise of its powers under the Act. Section 89S of that Act requires the Commission to include in its Annual Report, among other things, particulars of the operations of each licence holder under the Act.

In view of the difficulties identified in the Brown Review, and elsewhere, in relation to the self-administration arrangements under the current legislation, I expect the Commission, when setting performance standards, issuing guidelines, monitoring performance and issuing directions as provided by this Bill, to pay particular attention to the following specific issues to ensure that fair and proper practices prevail:
surveillance practices;
procedures for review of disputed claims, including the option that such reviews initially be carried out by Comcare Australia;
procedures for ongoing review of claimants to whom the special transitional provisions of the Act apply;
procedures for the provision of appropriate rehabilitation programs to all claimants employed, or previously employed, by the relevant licence holder.

It would be remiss of me if I did not include in this statement an acknowledgment of the efforts of Senator Bell, and members of his staff, in providing significant input into the framing of these licensing arrangements. I extend to Senator Bell my appreciation of his efforts.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of the Bill in Committee of the whole be made an order of the day for a later hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the indulgence of honourable senators to make a few remarks about this Bill, as I was not in the chamber during the second reading stage.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats are supporting this legislation. We believe that the legislation is the beginning of the end of a long period of abusive behaviour by two Commonwealth corporations, Australia Post and AOTC, towards their compensable employees. Hitherto, neither Australia Post nor AOTC has been subject to the jurisdiction of Comcare when interpreting or administering the provisions of the Comcare Act, and they have used certain of its provisions to justify video surveillance, phone tapping, doctor shopping and harsh and arbitrary rulings. They have gloated about the number of long term compensation claimants they have managed to remove from their books by unfairly denying their claims. Neither the claimants nor the Minister have had the means, apart from moral suasion, to seek redress.

My colleague Senator Robert Bell has raised this matter many times in this place and has been active in ensuring that Democrat concerns about this issue will be addressed by this Bill. In his absence, I wish to reiterate his view and the view of all Democrats that it is imperative that the powers of the Commission are fully and properly exercised in relation to the licensing function. We have asked the Government to give an undertaking that the Commission will make it a condition of any licence that Comcare itself will be an arbiter in any complaint made by a claimant about a delegated authority, and that this avenue of appeal will not prejudice any later appeal to the AAT.

We have also asked that the Commission award licences on a State branch basis to ensure that Comcare can more directly and closely monitor the performance of those States where the greatest number of problems have been identified. The powers given to the Commission under the licensing arrangements are considerable and wide ranging and will, we hope, resolve many of the problems that some claimants have suffered hitherto.

I note that several other recommendations made to the Minister by Senator Robert Bell on behalf of the Democrats have been incorporated into the Bill and referred to by the Minister in his speech. I am pleased to note that the allocation of class 2 and 3 licences includes consultation with the relevant unions, ensuring that workers' past grievances will be heard before a licence is granted.

I am also pleased to note that the Commission will be directed to monitor closely, on a case by case basis, the standard and result of rehabilitation packages offered to compensable employees. The findings of this monitoring arrangement will be used as a performance criterion to assess the viability of a licence, and reported on in Comcare's annual report. The Democrats will also continue to monitor the hundreds of cases we have become aware of, particularly in Western Australia and Queensland.

These licensing arrangements will be subject to review in one year's time. The Democrats will support the legislation at this time and will watch closely over the next year to see that its provisions adequately address the problems of fair, impartial and compassionate administration of claims handled by the self-administrators of the Comcare Act.
Bill agreed to, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian National Audit Office: Rental of Premises

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to his statement to the Senate on 16 June 1992 that the Australian National Audit Office would pay to the Labor Party a rental of `an all up figure of $322 per square metre per annum'. Why did the Minister mislead the Senate by stating this sum when the gross rental on the completion of the building has been calculated to be around $386 per square metre per annum, calculated in accordance with the agreement for lease entered into by the Commonwealth?

—This is what one could call a rather curious question. The Senate has addressed this issue on a number of occasions. The first occasion on which it was raised, I think, was in a press statement by Senator Parer on 16 January this year. A couple of weeks ago we spent a few afternoons and nights on this issue. In the context of those discussions in this place, questions were asked and copious documents were tabled both by me and by Senator McMullan.

PARA.TAB: During those debates it was made very clear by me and by Senator McMullan—in fact, it was stressed quite consistently by the Opposition—that the point went to the actual level of rent. We made clear that the rental agreement provided for—I must apologise because the precise details are not here; I will go on my memory—$280 per square metre per annum, plus $42.88, I think, per square metre per annum which would also be by way of costs that would have to be incurred by the Australian National Audit Office.

As part of the agreement, as part of the documents tabled, and as part of the answers that I gave and that Senator McMullan gave, it was acknowledged quite clearly that there were mechanisms in the lease to ensure that there was an increase of rental in accordance with those mechanisms. The point that Senator Parer made at the start was that when Audit actually went into the building there would already have been an increase in the level of rent it would have to pay. That was acknowledged both by me and by Senator McMullan. So $322 per square metre per annum is the ab initio amount in the lease and, as I say, mechanisms are in the lease documents and the agreement for lease to provide for increases. Whether or not that takes it to $386 per square metre per annum, I do not know, but if it is in accordance with the mechanism that is provided in the lease it is $386 per square metre per annum.

In regard to those mechanisms in the lease—I can anticipate a supplementary coming on—they provide for a certain rate of increase for the first period. There would then be a review after four years of the percentage of increase that is in the lease, and thereafter, after nine years, those rates of increase would once again be reviewed, but reviewed not less than the amount that is in the lease.

So, what are those amounts and how were they arrived at? I need to go to this because it is important. Those amounts range from between 9 per cent and about 10.5 per cent. As I say, I have not got the precise figures. What I do say is that those figures that were entrenched in the agreement are within—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I have a break?
—Order!

—The Opposition is getting its answer. The levels that have been incorporated in the lease agreement are below the levels advised to government by the Australian Valuation Office as being the anticipated rates of increase for property in that area. So it is below that. We have in place a lease agreement which provides—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Give it a break!
—Order!

—Thank you, Mr President. We have an ab initio rent in the lease agreement. As well, we have a rate of increase provided for between the date of the lease and the date, I think, of occupation and a mechanism for providing increases thereafter. There is nothing unusual about that.

PARA.TAB: Time and time again in this place we have established that this particular agreement was conducted without any political interference, it was conducted on the best commercial advice available to the Government, and it is a proper and decent arrangement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister neglected to say that the initial increase of 10 1/2 per cent was retrospective to 1 January 1991.

PARA.TAB: The international target of 0.7 per cent in the ODA to GNP ratio was reaffirmed recently at UNCED in view of the pressing need to support sustainable development in developing countries. —Order! I believe the Minister has finished his answer.

—No, I have not finished my answer, Mr President. What I want to say is that it is inconceivable that the Opposition should be able to get away with continued hypocrisy on this particular subject. It says it will improve aid quality, but it will rip the quality control system right out of the aid program. It says it supports UNCED, but it will not have any money at all available to support environmental development programs. It claims its cuts will only be temporary, but the damage it would create would take absolutely years to repair.

—Mr President, on a point of order: Senator Evans may have jet lag, but you have asked him to either answer the question or sit down. He is proceeding to flout your ruling and I ask you now to sit him down.
—The Minister has finished the answer. I am sure it is no surprise to our visitors that this is the last day of sitting.

—I refer the Minister for Defence to the Government's ongoing divisions over his decision on homosexuals in the Defence Force, in particular Senator Tate's criticism of the decision, the clash between the Minister and Senator Aulich outside the Caucus room yesterday, and Mr Duffy's move to overturn the decision in Cabinet, apparently supported by Mr Howe. Does the Minister agree with the criticism from Mr Duffy, Mr Howe, Senator Tate and Senator Aulich?

—As usual, Senator Newman has been able to summarise what her own reading of newspaper articles is and make her own assumption. She is not very good at it. In relation to Senator Tate, Senator Newman asked him a question yesterday. She raised the question of Cabinet solidarity. First of all, the matter has not been before Cabinet. There is no question of Cabinet solidarity. There would be no question of Senator Tate being bound by Cabinet unless he happened to attend a discussion on it. The second point to be made is that only the most—
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The Minister is claiming that I mentioned Cabinet solidarity in my question yesterday. I made no such mention and he knows it. I ask him to withdraw it.
—There is no point of order.

—On the secondary matter, only the most obtuse would say—and I do not think that this is a debate which should occur in an absolute vacuum—that there is no overlapping responsibility in regard to issues such as this that go beyond the Defence Force. Of course, there is. Senator Tate represents a portfolio that is responsible for international conventions and otherwise. In the ultimate, we may have a disagreement over the binding nature of those international conventions, but I do not dispute the fact that Senator Tate, with his portfolio interest in the Attorney-General's Department, should or should not have some interest in this issue.

PARA.TAB: As for the stupid newspaper article about Senator Aulich and me, Senator Aulich and I did not have a discussion outside the Caucus room. We had a discussion inside the Caucus room and we were not debating the fundamental issue, as Senator Aulich can affirm. We were debating processes that we should go through and Senator Aulich and I happen to be in total agreement on the way the Labor Party will handle this issue. I point out that we are neighbours in Canberra and it would be terrible if we started to feud over anything.

TALK.START.PARA: —You used to live together.

—That is right, we used to; with separate bedrooms, I might add. The third point made by Senator Newman is that Mr Duffy has opposed the decision that Gordon Bilney and I have made. He has not. What he has said is that, having been written to by the Human Rights Commissioner on this subject, he feels impelled at least to put it before the Government. As to the technicalities of how that comes before the Government, that is up to the Government to decide.

PARA.TAB: When I made this statement the other day, and in subsequent debate in this chamber, I acknowledged this as a controversial issue. It is a controversial issue because it involves rights of a range of individuals. I have no difficulty with some of my colleagues putting to me a contrary point of view. I do not say that it will be successful, but I welcome their contributions.

I do not welcome the press distortions on this matter. I certainly do not welcome the distortions that have appeared in the Age. Any comment I make that may be a little to one side of the argument is always produced, but none of the other contributions I make in here are published. If the press wants to run its own agenda, it can. I have never really worried about what the Fairfax organisation writes in terms of credibility. I never have and I never will.

The question is predicated on some false assumptions. One is that Senator Tate has no right to put a view on these matters. He does have a right and it is his portfolio responsibility to put a view. The difficulty with the process of government is that, when a decision is reaffirmed, it does not go through the normal party processes—that is, policy committees, Cabinet committees and Cabinet. When a policy is reaffirmed, one does not go through those processes. That has a disadvantage that I do not know how to get around. I am not going to walk in and reaffirm every policy every day from now to eternity. That is a process problem of how other people can make an input.

I say for the record that, even though this issue has been contentious and has been in the public domain for several months, no-one has made a formal appointment to come and see my office about it, and only three or four people from both sides of the chamber have mentioned it to me in passing. If they really felt strongly about the issue, they should have made more effort to avail themselves of an opportunity to talk to me about it, because I think people would affirm that I do not deny people access to do that.

Senator Newman's question is predicated on our having wide divisions on this matter, which is not true. We have some differences of view on it. The final decision will remain with me. Some of the newspaper reports have been erroneous and inaccurate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to clarify the early part of his answer when he referred to the public criticism by Senator Tate of a decision made by the two defence Ministers. I ask the Minister: does that mean that if Senator Tate and other colleagues make decisions in their portfolio areas, the Minister, Mr Bilney and other Ministers see it as right, proper and reasonable that they should be able to publicly criticise those decisions made by Senator Tate or his colleagues in the public arena rather than in the privacy of the Ministry?

—If I believed that Senator Tate had made a major criticism of my decision, I would not be happy, because I do not do that to him. But he does not do that to me. What Senator Newman interprets as major criticisms by Senator Tate on this issue I do not interpret in that way.

PARA.TAB: What Senator Tate has generally been commenting on is the ramifications of a particular decision by the Australian Defence Force, me and Minister Bilney in terms of our international obligations. I am not going to close my mind to those; I have my own interpretation of them. I have looked at it very carefully. I am sufficiently convinced that the decision that both Mr Bilney and I made was properly based in international law. Many other signatories to that agreement have made absolutely the same decision; the UK through to the US through to New Zealand have made the same decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why doesn't he discuss it with you privately? Why does he do it publicly?

—If Senator Tate is asked questions, I do not ask him to be silent. We all know where to draw the line in commenting on each other's portfolios. Where there is an overlap—and in this case there is a patent overlap of responsibility—I expect Senator Tate to make some contribution to the debate. As I say, the matter has not been taken formally in front of government for him to make a contribution, simply on the basis that what we have done is not to create new policy but to reaffirm old policy.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to comments by some shippers that the benefits of the Government's maritime reforms are being eaten away by increased government charges. Can the Minister advise how the Federal Government is ensuring the containment of those charges that are within its area of responsibility?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Government's responsibilities for providing commercial and safety services to the shipping industry are discharged by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. Since the Authority's establishment on 1 January last year, as part of the maritime reform program by Senator Collins, it has been highly successful in enhancing the efficiency and containing the costs of its services. In line with the Government's cost recovery policy, the Authority's commercial shipping services will be fully cost recovered from the industry by 1993-94 rather than subsidised from the taxpayers' pocket.

PARA.TAB: The Authority administers three levies applied to commercial shipping to fund most of its activities. They are the maritime navigation levy, which maintains the network of maritime or marine navigation aids around the Australian coast; the oil pollution levy, which provides for oil pollution prevention and recovery measures; and the maritime regulatory levy, which recovers the costs of regulatory and survey functions, including inspection of foreign ships trading to Australia.

Last year the Authority was able to offset the introduction of the new regulatory levy by a reduction in its navigation levy. This meant that all levies and charges overall were held constant in money terms. This year the Authority will again reduce its levies and charges from 1 July. A change to the levy structure will result in some 3,500 of the 4,000 merchant ships that visit Australian ports each year having their levies reduced. Meanwhile, the levy rate on the remaining 500 ships will remain unchanged.

This represents a multimillion dollar saving for the commercial shipping industry. The Authority estimates that the shipping industry will have saved about $9m in reduced levies and charges over its 2 1/2-year lifetime to the end of the next financial year. The new levy structure will particularly benefit Australia's exports as large bulk carriers which ship most of Australia's mineral and bulk farm trade will have their levy charges cut by several thousands of dollars per quarter. In addition, the Authority will be making a 17 per cent reduction in its fee-for-service charges for ship survey, design and certification work, which will make its regulatory charges extremely competitive with those of other countries.

AMSA continues to make a solid contribution to the Government's maritime reforms by meeting its charter of enhancing efficiency and containing costs in the delivery of safety and regulatory services to the maritime industry. I congratulate the Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Government planning to introduce a lower youth wage level topped up with a public subsidy? If so, how will the Government ensure that youth wages do not fall below the poverty line, thus creating an underclass of exploited young people? What precautions will the Government take to ensure that employers do not lay off adult workers in preference for a younger and cheaper work force, thus further exacerbating unemployment amongst older people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The last question is predicated on an answer to the first question being yes. The Government does not propose to introduce lower wages and a subsidy for young unemployed. The Government wants to carry through the recommendations of the Carmichael report, which is to take wages for young workers away from wages being determined by their age to a wage based on their competency, their skill and experience, and their time spent in productive work. Under this new system, wage determination will therefore be a combination of those three things: competency, skill and experience; and time spent in productive work. More importantly, the more training young workers undertake as a consequence of this, the higher the qualifications they will obtain and in terms of the competency and skills component of the wage structure, the higher their wage will be as well. We think it is a repositioning of wages and a recognition of the skill and training component to fuel the need in this economy for a highly skilled work force and for young workers to be given access to that sort of training.

PARA.TAB: It is not a situation, which is characterised more obviously by the Opposition's approach, of simply reducing youth wages. This is a high wage scenario; we are not into a low wage scenario. Unlike the Opposition, we are not in a situation of wanting to slash youth wages and create an underclass of working poor who will then be picked up as cheap labour and displace more mature workers in the work force in the more menial or labour oriented tasks. In order to ensure that that is not the case, there will be a floor. The floor will be based on the level of Austudy and will be paid by the Government. If the award rate is lower than the floor wage, we will make up the difference between the award rate and the floor wage.

I do not know whether anybody has bothered to read John Stone's column in today's Australian Financial Review. John Stone, who is a former member of this place and the coalition, is, of course, advocating that we follow the New Zealand model. Under the New Zealand model there is no minimum wage at all for young workers—none whatsoever. Under the direct contract bargaining system in New Zealand, if an employer proposes to a young worker a wage lower than the dole—bearing in mind there are unemployed people ready to take that young worker's place—and the young worker refuses to accept it, that young worker can be dismissed and is not then eligible for unemployment benefit for six months. That is the bargaining position in New Zealand. It is a low wage, exploitative bargaining position and it is certainly not one that we will follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of reports that the Government will be selling all of Qantas to foreign interests? Can the Minister indicate whether the reports are true and could he comment on the impact of recent Government aviation policy announcements on international air travel to Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reports are untrue but they are based on what I would consider to be one of the silliest letters to the editor that I have ever seen, which is hardly surprising as it came from an Opposition frontbencher.
—John Sharp?

—No. Julian Beale, who is, amazingly enough, the Opposition spokesperson on privatisation. He wrote a letter on the sale of Qantas which was headlined correctly in the paper as `Selling Our Heritage'. This is the Opposition spokesperson on privatisation criticising the Government for selling Qantas. The final paragraph of the letter states:

ANSWER.PARA: What would Rex Connor think of his former protege's efforts `to sell our national heritage'.
That is a pretty silly letter from a shadow Minister—

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the whole letter.
—I have read the whole of it. What the letter asserts, ridiculously, is that the Government's proposal is to sell all of Qantas to foreign interests. It is a piece of nonsense.

PARA.TAB: I also do not know from where the sudden paranoia has developed on the front bench of the Opposition to foreign equity in terms of sales of anything in Australia. The Government is proposing to allow Qantas to do what any airline in the world has to do in order to survive; that is, to form firm alliances with other airlines. That is precisely what the Government proposal does. That is a world trend now which is well entrenched and accelerating. Any airline which wants to succeed in what is cutthroat competition in this industry has to form alliances with other airlines or die.

The letter from Mr Beale claimed that the Government would be selling off the airlines to overseas interests and forgetting about the Australian public and the employees of the airlines. Of course, the Government is not doing anything of the sort. In the proposed sale of 100 per cent of Qantas, at least 65 per cent of the shares will be available to Australian shareholders. Sensible opportunities will remain, which I can tell honourable senators Qantas is extremely anxious to take up, of forming alliances within that minority percentage with overseas carriers—not just in terms, of course, of the capital involved, but in terms of the opportunities to form synergistic benefits between the airlines concerned.

I note with interest comments made by another one of the many Opposition spokespersons on aviation, the honourable member for O'Connor. The Opposition seems to have, to my knowledge, about 12 spokespersons who regularly comment. The honourable member for O'Connor also had a view that he expressed publicly on aviation policy. He was publicly reported as saying that the Government's policy would not necessarily increase international air travel as no overseas country would allow `open slather without a trade-off'. I repeat that: no overseas country would allow open slather without a trade-off. That statement is absolutely correct and is completely at odds with the Opposition's aviation proposal in the Fightback package which in fact proposes exactly that: the Opposition would provide extremely valuable—and I mean valuable in dollar terms—rights to international carriers without negotiating any reciprocal rights for Australian carriers. It is an outrageous policy. As I have said before, and I will conclude on this point, in the national interest I ask the Opposition to reconsider—as clearly some of its own members are reconsidering—that particular aspect of the Fightback! document and reject it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Given that the Senate has resolved that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation should be able to participate in pay television and that one transponder must be allocated—
—You would take $50m off it.

—We will debate that at another time, if Senator Ray wishes. This is the most important issue facing the ABC at the present time. As I was saying, given that the Senate has resolved that one transponder must be allocated for the exclusive use of the ABC, why is the Prime Minister determined to deny the ABC the right to participate in this major new technology? Is the simple fact of the matter that, despite the Minister's desire to accommodate the ABC, he has been rolled once again because the Prime Minister's media mates will not wear it?

—Talk about being bowled a full toss! Just as a side issue, I was interested to look at the press reports today. One can take one's pick from the press today as far as this issue is concerned. If one reads the Australian, one will be assured by the writer for the Australian that `the Australian Broadcasting Corporation has been virtually guaranteed a licence for pay TV'. If one reads the Sydney Morning Herald, one will get exactly the same assurance. If one reads the report in the Australian Financial Review on the same debate, it states, `The Government is certain to reject the proposal in the House of Representatives'. So we can take our pick. Not only has this Government—this is the comparison and this is the problem we have with the Opposition's proposal—
—Comparison! What is he talking about?

—Let me tell Senator Hill about this; he will be amazed to hear it. First of all, the Opposition made such a total mess of drafting its amendments yesterday—and it has the hide to talk about government policy on the run—
—Ha, ha!

—Senator Hill was not in here for the debate; I suggest that he look at the Hansard. There was such a total mess made of its amendment to exclude journalists from having their notebooks accessed; in its desire to try to crawl to the Press Gallery, it made such a total mess of the amendment that—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. We wasted a good 10 minutes on this nonsense last night. Mr President, the simple question is: why is the Prime Minister—
—What is the point of order?

—I am making the point of order. The question is: why is the Government determined to deny access to the ABC? All we have to date is something about the Opposition. Mr President, I ask you to direct the Minister to answer that question.
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Collins, please—
—Please what, Mr President?
—Please take note of the fact that we have had seven questions today.

—Mr President, I would have happily sat here and not participated in Question Time at all. The question was asked by the Opposition, not by a Government senator. I will answer the question. Mr President, the Opposition not only completely ruined the amendment, but put it in the wrong clause of the Bill.
—Why do you hate the ABC?

—I will tell Senator Alston the relevance of this: it applies to the Opposition amendments on the ABC. I was going to canvass this issue in debate, but if those opposite want it canvassed now, I will canvass it now. The Democrats know about this because we have briefed them.

PARA.TAB: One of the reasons we cannot accept the amendment—and this is totally relevant, Mr President—is that, as well as stuffing up the amendment on journalists' notebooks, the Opposition also made a total hash of this amendment on the ABC and the transponder.

I hoped this would have been a matter for debate, not Question Time, but Senator Alston has asked the question. We cannot accept the amendment because, apart from other reasons, the Opposition forgot to move, with the amendment it did move, at least two consequential amendments to the Bill. We now have an amended Bill that has gone from the Senate to the House of Representatives with one clause that says that one of these transponders has to be used exclusively by the ABC but which contains two other clauses, which the Opposition forgot to amend, which totally contradict that. So the Opposition has made a hash of that as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is now debating the question. I ask you to ask him to answer the question or to sit down.
—There is no point of order.

—The fact is—and this will be debated and made very clear in the House of Representatives, hopefully, this afternoon—that the Opposition has made a total mess of the amendment. We examined it carefully this morning and we cannot support it because it is not correct.
—Oh!

—Have a look at the Bill, Robert. The Opposition made a mess of it. I conclude by saying that not only has the Government publicly asserted, as Senator Alston knows, its strong support for the ABC to become involved in pay television, but also it has provided up-front a commitment to fund the ABC to the tune of $12.5m to help it get into it. That is totally contrary to the Opposition's policy, which is to cut $50m a year from the ABC's recurrent budget. What the Opposition wants to do—and we know it—is to allow the ABC to get into pay TV so that it can cut off its public funding completely.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the Minister chooses to argue—
—That is what they chose to do.
—Will Senator Collins listen to my question.
—It doesn't follow.

—Perhaps Senator Tate had better tell me. If the Minister chooses to argue that there is some ambiguity in the way in which the Senate expressed its clear preference for the ABC to have access to one transponder, is the Minister saying that the Government's position is that it will not even seek to amend the legislation—the effect of that therefore being that the ABC will not have access to pay television?

—I know the embarrassment that Senator Alston feels. Opposition senators made a mess of every substantive amendment they moved last night, and they know it. That includes this one; they have not woken up to this one yet. We are just telling them about it now. Anybody who had any lingering doubts as to the motives of the Opposition in trying to strangle the ABC with pay TV—as opposed to the motives of the Government, which is actually going the give the ABC $12.5m of funding to help it get into it—should have had a listen to the shadow Minister this morning on AM. When the shadow Minister was asked by the interviewer on AM whether these moves would help the ABC to become `more commercial' he said, `Oh, yes. That will certainly have that effect'.
—What is wrong with that?

—I will tell Senator Hill what is wrong with that. The Party on this side of this chamber is absolutely committed to the continuation of the ABC as an advertising free, sponsorship free, national broadcaster. The Opposition wants to help the ABC into pay TV and anything else so that it can cut its throat and remove its public funding. It will eventually get to the position where, just like with public broadcasting in the United States—and that is what this is all about—it will be able to say to people, `If you want to watch the ABC, you can watch it on pay TV'.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: United Nations Rapid Deployment Force for Peace Enforcement

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to last week's report to the United Nations Security Council by UN Secretary-General Boutros-Ghali which recommends, amongst other things, the creation of a UN rapid deployment force for peace enforcement. Does the Minister accept that the difficulties which have been experienced with the cease-fire and the disarmament provisions of the Cambodian peace plan suggest that UN enforcement of Security Council resolutions may be necessary under some circumstances? Does he further accept that the danger of unilateral military action by individual states would be reduced if the UN acquired that capacity? Does the Government endorse the proposal?

—The UN Secretary-General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, has submitted a report to the Security Council on ways of strengthening the UN capacity for preventive diplomacy, peacemaking and peacekeeping. That report is expected to be released publicly next week.

PARA.TAB: The Senate will be aware that Security Council resolutions are mandatory and the UN has a range of measures at its disposal to seek to enforce those resolutions, including through negotiation, economic sanctions and arms embargoes as well as the option of military action. However, the complexity and size of the UN operations in Cambodia and now in Yugoslavia as well have highlighted a number of deficiencies in the UN's current modus operandi and, to that extent, both the Australian Government and I welcome the general thrust of the Secretary-General's recommendations which address that issue.

We do support UN efforts to strengthen capacity in all these various areas. That will contribute to the capacity of the international community to respond effectively to resolve a number of these conflicts, and particularly we are concerned to strengthen the preventive diplomacy and peacemaking aspects of the UN's role—and I have to say that from my preliminary scrutiny of the Secretary-General's report in this respect that does seem to be disappointingly thin as compared with the recommendations elsewhere. But we do have a preliminary response of enthusiasm for the inclusion, for example, of proposals made initially by Australia, together with New Zealand, Canada and the Nordics, which include improved information gathering, an integrated peacekeeping mechanism and the creation of a peacekeeping reserve fund.

It is just too early to comment sensibly, I think, on the recommendations about the creation of a rapid deployment force and a number of other matters of that kind. This is an issue that has in fact been around for almost as long as the UN has existed. There is provision for the identification of forces that can be earmarked for UN use. That has not happened and countries have not been willing for the whole history of the UN so far to put themselves in that position to respond rapidly in that way. There are a number of pros and cons to the argument. I will be in a better position to give Senator Bourne a more considered answer on this when we resume.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Building Industry Working Party: Travel Expenses

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to his letter of 23 October 1991 to council members of the building industry work change assistance industrial relations working party, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . your representatives will be expected to meet all travel and other cost related to attendance. . .

Why has the Minister approved payments of $2,267 and $634 for travel and related expenses for 3 December 1991 and 17 December 1991, respectively, to his mate Mr Kevin Reynolds, the Secretary of the Western Australian Builders Labourers Federation, as these payments are clearly outside the terms of his own letter and against the advice of his own Department and his own adviser?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Winston Crane for the advice he gives me about what occurred on 23 October 1991. I do not have perfect recollection of what was contained in that letter, but I do know that for the building industry reform strategy group I did expect all the participants to meet their own travel expenses.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane says that an amount has been paid to one of the people who participated along with others in the reform strategy. I will have to just check that information and reply to it. I know that Mr Reynolds has attended meetings of the building industry reform strategy—and I am pleased that he has because he has been a very worthwhile contributor—but I do not automatically assume that all of the travel he may have engaged in has been exclusively for the purposes of that strategy.

I am aware and can remember other occasions on which he has come to Canberra or gone to other places which relate to government programs, and there may be and may have been a due and proper expenditure in those particular cases.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that the Minister has said that he will look at these things and give us further information. I remind the Minister—and I am sure he will remember this—that his own Department has said:

QUESTION.PARA: These claims are clearly outside the conditions upon which funding was approved viz. outstanding claims for travel and accommodations costs in relation to the Minister's Industrial Relations Working Party.

His adviser went on to say, `We should not pay for Reynolds' expenses'. Therefore, why has Mr Reynolds been paid—the Minister did not answer that part of the question—against the advice once again of his own Department and his own adviser?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I did answer the question. I would be pleased if, through you, Mr President, Senator Winston Crane would make available to me the documents from which he is quoting as the formal advice of my Department to me or as the formal advice of advisers in my Department to me. That would enable me to check to see whether this is a legitimate document and proper, documented advice.

PARA.TAB: I have said that I know that Reynolds travelled to various functions, one of which involved the building industry reform strategy, to which Senator Crane's question refers directly. I will be a bit cautious after my experience here yesterday, in which I took, in the form of a question, the advice being given to me as true, later to find that it was not exactly the same as the advice in the question. I will examine the record and I will reply to Senator Crane.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen newspaper reports concerning investment plans in Australia of the major automotive components manufacturer, Bosch Australia? This morning's Australian Financial Review reports that the company is planning a $40m to $50m investment program, but only if the tariff arrangements announced by the Government for the car industry remain unchanged. Can the Minister confirm the Government's commitment to the tariff changes outlined for the car industry in March last year? Can the Minister advise the Senate of the consequences for investment if alternative tariff arrangements were put in place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the newspaper reports concerning Bosch Australia, which is a major automotive component manufacturing firm. I have also seen a copy of a press release put out by the company confirming what is in those press statements. The press statements which Senator Sherry referred to are contained in the Australian Financial Review.

PARA.TAB: The Government is firmly committed to the tariff changes outlined for the car industry in March last year. They were made on the basis of a full and thorough Industry Commission inquiry into the car industry, the automotive industry. The consequences for investment if the alternative tariff arrangements were put in place would be, indeed, severe.

Comments attributed to Bosch Australia, as I said, have been confirmed in a news release this morning. Since 1985, this Government has had in place a clear policy framework for the automotive industry. The stability of that framework, in the process of transition from high protection to low protection, is very important to the program, particularly to investment, and crucial to the investment decisions which both the car manufacturers and the component producers must make if we are to increase our competitiveness.

I want to make it clear that the Government will remain committed to that policy. The only threat to it, to a stable policy environment, is the one which has been articulated by Opposition spokesmen and is in the Fightback document on zero tariffs for the automotive industry. Let me set the record straight. From January next year the tariff rate for passenger motor vehicles will be 32.5 per cent, phasing down to 15 per cent in the year 2000.

Going with the commitment to tariffs is a commitment to export facilitation for the automotive industry. That commitment to export facilitation led to something like $1.2 billion of automotive component exports last year. The simple fact is that zero tariffs mean no export facilitation, and no exports in a volume related industry means no automotive industry at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —As it is taxpayer subsidised.

—No, it is not. Export facilitation is not taxpayer subsidised. In fact, taxpayers get cheaper imports as a result of the export facilitation scheme.Despite that, and despite all the industry's warnings, the Opposition sticks with its commitment to zero tariffs and refuses to face the realities of the international automotive industry. That was on display here last week. One had the Western Australian second-hand Japanese car led recovery, articulated by Senator Campbell and Senator Panizza with great passion. It shows how much they know about industry—a bit of advice from a company employing 20-odd people—
—Thirty-five.

—Up to 35, and that is because of the Government's largess. Jac Nasser, the President of Ford, was one of those very senior industry executives so concerned about second-hand imports that he gave evidence to the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology a week or so ago. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: The single thing I know about my company is that it feels very strongly in that it believes that the Australian Government does want an automotive industry in Australia.

It is that belief in the Government's commitment which has given many in the automotive industry the confidence to invest. The question out there in industry land—and a lot of those opposite know this—is: is the Opposition committed to this industry, or any other industry for that matter? The only answer to that question is no; its commitment is to ideology whatever the price of investment and jobs. There has been a lot of talk about jobs in here—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. This is a clear abuse of Question Time. The Minister is reading a prepared speech in answer to a dorothy dix question on tariffs. If he wants to put down a statement, he can put it down after Question Time and we will debate it. We have had 55 minutes of Question Time and on this side of the chamber we have had four questions. I cannot remember an occasion in the last 10 years when we have had only four questions in 55 minutes. I ask you to bring him to order and sit him down in order that we might get on with Question Time.

—There have been all sorts of discussions about employment and the future of employment. Dr Hewson says he will create two million jobs. I can tell the Senate that they will not be in the automotive industry, and people know that now.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. Perhaps I was not concentrating, but I did not hear you make a ruling on Senator Hill's point of order. I have noticed you expressing an opinion on how long questions should be and how long supplementary questions should be. I see no indication in the Standing Orders that answerers of questions have any greater rights than askers of questions. I wonder what your ruling is on Senator Hill's point of order.
—Order! I have pointed out repeatedly today that I believe the answers have been too long.
—Thank you, Mr President. The second part—
—Sit down, then.
—Order! There are also too many interjections, which leads to debates.

—The second part of Senator Sherry's question related to investment in the automotive industry. In the next three years, given a stable environment, there will be $2.5 billion worth of investment in the automotive industry. That is what is at stake—$2.5 billion of investment in the automotive industry in the next three years. That is what is threatened. This industry realises the threat and that is what the statements by Robert Bosch and a similar wide range of manufacturing companies producing for the automotive industry in Australia are all about.

—The relevant paragraph states:

QUESTION.PARA: It will be a matter for the review alone to determine the procedures under which it will operate and to ensure that there are arrangements in place which will respect necessary confidentiality of individuals and organisations making submissions during the Review's proceedings.

In view of the Minister's clear intention to have a comprehensive and independent review, how does he propose to confer adequate legal powers on the inquiry so that it can have access to all relevant documents, given the history of obstruction to the workings of this Parliament by the CAA in the recent past? How does he propose to protect from libel witnesses giving evidence under oath on what they believe to be true?

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. For the duration of that question being asked by my colleague, Senator Collins was interrupting by implying that Senator MacGibbon was asking that question because of a vested interest and a conflict of interest. He was reflecting upon Senator MacGibbon's motive. In reflecting upon his motive he is in breach of the Standing Orders, which you understand, and I ask that he withdraw it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I note Senator MacGibbon's ongoing and continuing interest in the subject of the CAA and the independent inquiry. After Question Time yesterday I was detained in the chamber for a reasonable period. While I was being detained in the chamber I was at the same time trying to conduct a meeting with the Acting Chairman of the CAA, Mr Henry Bosch, and the selected independent inquirer, Mr Ian Macphee. The proceedings in this chamber required me, and I was not available for all of the time of that meeting.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of that meeting was to discuss with the inquirer, firstly, the terms of reference; secondly, the access to technical and financial advice; thirdly, the secretarial and other issues necessary to mount a successful inquiry; and, finally, other matters that are publicly notorious in this debate—whether they deserve to be is another matter, but that will be an outcome of the inquiry. There were the matters of the protection of witnesses; whether there is adequate legal power to obtain documents; and the ongoing negotiations about the contract between the CAA and Thomson.

The meeting did not conclude by finalising a position on all of those matters. Clearly, the independent inquirer would want to have a clear position established before the inquiry commences properly. All I can say is that at this time the matter was in hand. It was not finalised—I was detained elsewhere—but we intend to finalise it next week and there will be a statement setting out all the detail at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. How will the Minister guarantee to a witness immunity from legal action without passing legislation? How will he transfer that power to the inquiry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of a number of matters that are under consideration—to use the classic cliche—as we speak. I have also sought advice from the Attorney-General as to what are the powers in these circumstances to ensure full and proper protection of witnesses. I do not make any assumption that necessarily that protection would be required, but I do recognise that for the inquiry to be seen to be free and independent, and able to adduce before it all the necessary evidence, a requirement of that sort ought to be in place.

PARA.TAB: As I have said, I am not in a position to answer fully now but I do intend to be in a position to do so as soon as I can—probably next week. I will make a statement at that time. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion No. 31 standing in my name, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) moving a motion that, at question time on any day, questions may be put to Ministers until 28 questions, including supplementary questions, have been asked and answered.

SPEECH.PARA: I move this motion today because today has been a constant abuse of Question Time by Ministers. The total number of questions that we on this side have had the opportunity to ask in one hour is five. The total number of questions asked by all sides today, including the dorothy dixers on the Government's side, is 11, plus five supplementaries. That was all that was dealt with today because of constant abuse by Ministers. The first to abuse Question Time today was Senator Bolkus, who was asked a simple question about this sordid deal between the ALP and the Audit Office, in which—

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. I assert once again, Mr President, that Senator Hill has to base his motion on proper facts. There is absolutely nothing sordid about the arrangement. I do not think we should tolerate in this place a continuation of the smear from the Opposition, led by Senator Bishop and followed by Senator Hill.
—Order! There is no point of order. It was a debating term.

—A 15-year deal between the ALP and a government instrumentality for a lease which includes increases at the rate of at least 9 per cent a year—perhaps I should not describe that as a sordid deal, but I would say to the Minister that one would have to describe it as a very generous deal for the ALP at the expense of the taxpayer. The Minister took nine minutes trying to avoid answering that very simple question.

PARA.TAB: Then Senator Evans was asked another simple question on his Government's record with ODA. Did he answer that? No, he wanted to talk about our policy. If he wanted to be truthful in the few minutes which he took to answer that question, he could have told us that when he came to office ODA was about 0.47 per cent of GDP and that it is now about 0.33 per cent. Every year the Government promises to increase overseas aid, but it has reduced it. Now the Minister condemns us for keeping our promises, for being truthful and for being prepared to go to the Australian people. That was the second abuse.

The third abuse was by Senator Collins himself and it was the oldest trick in the book. If a Minister does not want to answer a question—and it was a simple question about government policy in relation to the ABC and what it would do in response to the resolution of the Senate last night—the oldest trick is to take up the technical argument. The Minister said, `We queried the drafting of the amendment. We have had our draftsmen looking at it all night'. I see Senator Collins is smiling. He recognises that it is the oldest trick in the book. He spent nearly 10 minutes talking about the drafting of that amendment rather than answering the simple question which was asked. Then Question Time ended with a dorothy dixer to Senator Button who wanted to give us a lecture on tariff policy.
Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Government senators should compare the record when we were last in government. How many questions did our Ministers answer? It was constantly around 25, 28 and 30 questions a day. And what did we get today? Five questions were asked from this side of the chamber. Government Ministers are determined not to answer questions any longer in this place. We should have the right to ask a reasonable number of questions in order to meet our responsibility of trying to keep you lot honest. Therefore, I have moved this contingent notice of motion in order that we might have the opportunity to ask 28 questions, including supplementaries, today.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, the Government will oppose the suspension of Standing Orders. This sort of thing arises from time to time. I know that Senator Hill is heading off to a conference soon. That will not re-promote Fightback. The honourable senator wants to make a bit of an impression. The fact of the matter is that it is necessary for Opposition senators to psych themselves up every now and again.

PARA.TAB: Eleven questions and five supplementaries were asked today. The Opposition asked five questions and five supplementaries, which is the equivalent of 10 questions. Senator Hill has taken the opportunity to move the suspension of Standing Orders on the basis, he says, that the Opposition had only five questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't answer one of them.

—I do not know where the senator has been, but he should not get excited. There is an hour for Question Time in this place. If people want more questions to be dealt with, they should ask shorter questions and seek the President's indulgence to get shorter answers. It is not a question of extending Question Time for this sort of reason. So the Government will not support the suspension. There is a lot of Government business to be dealt with.

—We will support the suspension of Standing Orders on certain conditions, which are these: the Opposition would have another five questions, because we believe that that is the average number of questions asked by it during Question Time this session, when roughly 21 or 22 questions have been asked; and we strongly urge the Opposition to take no vexatious points of order during those five questions. On those conditions, we support the suspension.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was beginning to think that I was not going to have a chance to put this very important question before the Senate today. I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Prime Minister to the fact that no small business organisations have been included in the July unemployment summit. Is the Minister aware that the small business sector already employs nearly half the private sector work force and accounts for 96 per cent of all firms in operation? Is the Minister also aware that if every small business in Australia took on just one extra employee, every Australian looking for full time employment would get a job? I ask the Minister: If finding jobs for Australia's unemployed is now supposed to be the Government's number one priority, why then has the Government deliberately omitted one of the biggest employers in the private sector work force from attending the summit, or is the summit merely a publicity exercise designed to take pressure off the Government's lack of initiatives in this area?

—I am aware of the statistics about small business which Senator Bjelke-Petersen mentioned in her question. Of course, I am aware that, by and large, small business would not get any benefit from the abolition of payroll tax, for example, which is often mooted as a good invigorator of employment. Certainly, what the honourable senator says is true. The full list of people attending the meeting is not yet available. When it is, I will be able to answer that question in the light of what she has said.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it a fact that, despite Australia's production of copper, nickel and aluminium and Australia's call for value adding, the Reserve Bank and/or the Australian Mint is importing the blanks for the $1 and $2 coins in Australia?

—Yes, I believe that to be true. That work was formerly done by a company called Austral Bronze, which was not able to do it competitively. I believe that to be true. By the same token, the Australian Mint is producing coins here for a number of other countries to which it is exporting. That is a very high value added process and is something which we welcome.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister obviously knows that that is what is happening. Could he tell me why there has been a departure from the statement and undertaking given by Senator Evans on 23 September 1987 that Australian suppliers must use Australian material?

—I have no idea of the circumstances under which that undertaking was given. I am sure that it has been taken out of context. Senator Panizza is always giving me lectures about trade. Trade is two-way—we import and export. If we do things well in Australia, we export. If we do not do them so well, we import. That is what trade is about and that is what is happening here.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the Government's sales tax legislation currently before the Parliament. Is it true that the removal of various exemptions for oil company activities, including the removal of the deemed manufacturer provisions in the current legislation, will result in higher oil and petrol prices, as much as half a cent per litre in the case of petrol? Is this a deliberate Government policy or another unintended consequence?
—That legislation is currently before the Parliament and will be examined by it. It is in no circumstances a question which is in order.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian National Audit Office: Rental of Premises

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Administrative Services explain why a lease was negotiated at the same time by the Commonwealth Government for an adjacent building similar to the one owned by the Australian Labor Party at $315 per square metre when the lease with the ALP was $386 per square metre?

—There were major differences, I think, in the two projects. It is fair that I should come back to the Senate with details of the latter project. I understand that it was a totally different proposition. I make the point that John McEwen House, for instance—a 20- or 30-year-old building—is charging $330 per square metre and it is almost next door.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services aware of claims being made by pharmacists that approvals to dispense large quantities with multiple repeats of schedule 8 drugs are being given in cases where the prescribing practitioner does not indicate a repeat interval or instruction to the dispensing pharmacist to monitor the dosage by limiting the quantity dispensed at any one time? Does the approval of the HIC of this practice put the dispensing pharmacist in a position where he could be charged under State poisons and pharmacy laws for dispensing the repeat prescription when no repeat interval is indicated on the prescription by the prescribing practitioner? If so, what action does the Government intend to take to rectify this problem?

—I believe the question of the information that is required by national health regulations to be included on the prescription does not cover the inclusion of the interval or repeat of the prescription. The interval or repeat on certain prescriptions is a matter which is regulated by State law, as I understand it. In that case, the approval by the Health Insurance Commission of an authority supply, including the number of repeats that may be included in a prescription, is not an approval for medication to be supplied contrary to State legislation. It is important to emphasise that the responsibility to ensure that the prescription meets all the requirements of a particular State rests with the prescriber and the pharmacist.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Patterson asked me a question concerning a discrepancy in funding between the Australian Paralympic and Olympic teams so far as the Federal Government's contributions are concerned. This latest contribution was prompted by the Government's concern and disappointment over the continuing financial plight of the Australian Paralympic Federation. Specifically, funds have been provided in the following areas: $386,000 directly to national sporting organisations for the disabled for the preparation of teams; $450,000 towards team costs, including assembly, outfitting and transportation; and $100,000 to be borne by the Government to cover the costs of the summer Paralympic training camp at the Australian Institute of Sport.

I know that Senator Patterson has also taken an interest in the promotion of the CD Aussie Gold which has been put together by Angry Anderson and some other performers. I understand that Mr Anderson has organised the CD and has I think written but certainly sings the theme song Bound for Glory. In that situation, I believe the best way in which the Paralympics could be helped would be for Australians to purchase that particular CD so that profits from their sale—given the fact that there would be substantial profits, given the very generous voluntary contributions by the various performers and those who put the CD together—would go towards supplementing the Federal Government's contribution to this very important event.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much is it?

—I think it is in the usual price range for CDs. I believe that this particular CD, if bought by every Australian family or those with a CD player, would greatly contribute to enabling the paralympic team from Australia to perform to its best ability. ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 June, Senator Brownhill asked me a question concerning drought relief in the western area of New South Wales. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Hon. Simon Crean, has provided me with an answer to that question. It is a rather long answer and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: A National Drought Policy (NDP) is being developed as part of a wider set of policies for rural industries and areas. The Drought Policy Working Group, an officials' working group of Commonwealth (DPIE and Department of Finance) and State officials are working towards a draft, with substantial progress having been made.

The Government appreciates the serious effect that drought has on rural Australians and is working towards developing measures that allow farmers to be better prepared for drought and to be able to effectively manage the risks associated with drought. I intend that the National Drought Policy be considered at the next meeting of the Agricultural Council of Australia and New Zealand on 24 July 1992.

The meetings held by me in the West were very helpful in clarifying what farmers were seeking and the capacity of the Rural Adjustment Scheme (RAS) to meet their needs. These meetings have come at a crucial time in rural policy formulation as I am not only in the process of negotiating a National Drought Policy with the States, but there are also reviews of both the RAS and the Income Equalisation Scheme underway.
I will also be meeting next week with the banks to talk generally about the situation in the Western Division and the support that the banks are able to provide to farmers in the region.

The RAS does provide for financial assistance to farmers in the west. Under Part B of the Scheme there is provision for up to 50% subsidy on interest payments on new commercial borrowing for carry-on finance purposes. The Debt Reconstruction with Interest Subsidy (DRIS) provides for up to 50% interest subsidy on existing debt that needs restructuring and is targeted at those farmers who cannot carry further debt.

The principles upon which the NDP is based do embrace the concept of additional assistance in circumstances of extreme drought. I am currently looking at several options in the context of the situation that exists in the Western Division of New South Wales.
In line with NDP principles, any additional assistance will necessarily be consistent with demonstrated long term profitability and sustainability of farming enterprises in the region.
