TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked a question some days ago by Senator Harradine concerning an applicant for refugee status undergoing an abortion in Western Australia. I seek leave to incorporate that particular answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: During debate on Migration Amendment Bill No. 2 on 22 June 1992 (Hansard p 4181), Senator Harradine asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice:

Has any other applicant for refugee status undergone an abortion in Western Australia as a result of her fearing that if she were returned to China she would be required to undergo an abortion and choosing—as she saw it—the lesser of two evils?
Senator Tate—The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Neither the Minister nor officials of his Department are aware of any such claim.

There has been one pregnancy termination involving an unaccompanied married woman. I understand that the motives for the woman choosing to have the termination were not linked to perceptions of China's population policy. Arrangements for the termination were made privately, and the costs of the termination were not met from public funds.

I would emphasise that the Minister has made it known that any decision relating to pregnancy is entirely a matter for the individual, in consultation with their professional counsellors and medical advisers. Neither he nor his Department has taken nor will take any steps to influence decisions on such matters.
I would also like to make it clear that the Government will not arrange nor pay for any termination of pregnancy that an asylum claimant may choose to have.

DEBATE.TITLE: BUILDING INDUSTRY WORKING PARTY: TRAVEL EXPENSES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Crane on 25 June 1992 relating to the approval of travel expenses.

SPEECH.PARA: I move to take note of this answer because what I believe to be a very serious matter has been brought to my attention relating to the approval of Government expenditure for travel expenses made by Mr Kevin Reynolds, the Secretary of the BLF in Western Australia. In my view, this was done on the basis of helping out a mate. The guidelines that were set down and approved by the Minister for Industrial Relations for the building industry work change assistance industrial relations working party stated quite clearly that a total of up to $20,000 can be approved under work change assistance for the reimbursement of costs relating to the implementation—I underline the word `implementation'—of the building industry working party. Council members were specifically informed in a letter from the Minister dated 23 October 1991 that `your representatives will be expected to meet all travel and other costs related to attendance'.

PARA.TAB: There has already been substantial expenditure by the Government on Mr Reynolds amounting to $4,336 and $1,669 pertaining to establishment fees. This matter raises some very serious questions. I can accept that a government has the right to override a department and advice from its advisers if it is part of government policy, but this matter raises the question of the overriding of that advice. It is quite clearly spelt out on the papers which I wish to incorporate—and I have been given approval to do so—that this expenditure was, firstly, outside the guidelines which had been set down and, secondly, against the advice of the Department and, as I have already stated, the advice of the Minister's advisers.

Furthermore, there is a handwritten note to the Minister on a departmental minute which reads, `Minister, what was 17 December meeting?'. So his adviser did not even know whether this expenditure was related to the purpose for which it was being paid. So it begs the question: is it government policy to pay the expenses of its mates so they can come to Canberra at taxpayers' expense?'. I believe taxpayers have a right to know the answer to that question.

On the setting up of these guidelines, if the Minister is to make a decision to allocate expenditure of further public funds, he should make it in a clear and open way so that the public and this Parliament knows about it. Clearly, that has not been done in this case.

As I understand it, these additional payments to Mr Reynolds have already been made or they are about to be made. That brings very seriously into question the position of this Minister in relation to the payments to Mr Reynolds. From the note on this paper, certainly the Minister's own adviser is very suspicious as to what this expenditure related to. Certainly, the expenditure is outside of the initial instruction on expenditure relating to this particular working party. I believe the Minister has a duty to explain to this Parliament—he has not done so at this point in time—why this additional expenditure was approved and whether anyone else has been paid additional moneys in this area outside the original instructions.

It is a very serious matter. It is also an abuse of taxpayers' money. It also comes on the heels of a question that Senator Kemp asked on 2 April 1992 concerning an additional $50,000 of expenditure in regard to union amalgamations.

I raise this matter in the five minutes that I have because in terms of these payments, the Minister has acted in a way not befitting a Minister, particularly given that it relates to a person who is a very close friend. It certainly brings into question the legitimacy of a Minister authorising these types of payments.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Does Senator Crane wish to seek leave to incorporate those documents?

TALK.START.PARA: —I note for the record that I certainly approved leave for the incorporation of these documents. Before I come to the moment of this matter, I say that these documents apparently have been illegally leaked from my Department, the Department of Industrial Relations, to Senator Crane. At no time during his speech did he make any explanation of how he came by them or why he is in possession of documents that legally he is not entitled to be in possession of.

PARA.TAB: I make no objection to the fact that this issue has been brought forward. We have in this Parliament a process called Estimates committees whereby the Parliament inquires into departmental expenditure. In essence, I imagine that I am answering questions which would in any case arise during an Estimates committee procedure. The point, for the record, is that these documents are illegally in the possession of Senator Winston Crane. I understand that there are three documents: the document dated 6 May 1992 from my Department, written on its letterhead; and the two documents on the letterhead of the Australian Builders Labourers Federated Union of Workers WA branch both dated 20 January 1992.

The first thing that has to be said about the documents is that when I was asked a question a few minutes ago by Senator Winston Crane on this matter, he referred to a meeting with the Minister on 17 December 1991. Now that I have the documentation I can see that that was in reference to a meeting that had occurred in the past. The importance is that it occurred in a way which is not relevant to the allegation. That is what I am meaning to say, Senator Short; I thank you for looking quizzically in my direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Had it occurred on the 17th or not?

—I do not know whether it occurred on the 17th. The letter said that it occurred on the 17th. I will have to check my record to see whether it in fact did. The first thing is that the departmental minute is not addressed to me; it is addressed to Mr Mason, who is a member of my staff. To the best of my knowledge, this is the first time I have seen this document, and that is not surprising. Literally millions of documents go through my office every week. This is one addressed to a staff member, not to me. Therefore, it is not surprising that I have not seen it.

PARA.TAB: The second thing I say about it is that it refers to payments that have been made to Mr Reynolds to ensure progress in building industry reform. That apparently refers to some payments that have been made in order to enlist the cooperation of a key figure in the building industry reform process to that reform process. If one reads the letter—it is incorporated, so everyone can—one sees that it is not apparently the subject of the allegation that is made against me now.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is nothing to do with the setting up.
—I am pleased that Senator Crane made that interjection, and I would like that to be acknowledged in Hansard. That is important in getting a logical consideration of the issues at play here.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, this letter refers to an inquiry from a Ms Arnold in the office of Mr Reynolds. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Ms Arnold recently inquired as to the status of the two outstanding claims and I indicated that they were to be referred to the Minister's office for further consideration.
Then this letter is notated in handwriting as follows:
We should not pay for Reynolds expenses in this case, particularly 3/12.

It is signed by `Ashley' who I take to be Mr Ashley Mason, a staff member of mine. I do not at this point have any perfect knowledge as to whether or not the amounts claimed, that apparently Ms Arnold was agitated about and inquired of from the Department, have in fact been paid. I do not know whether Senator Crane's allegation—

TALK.START.PARA: —You approved of it.

—It does not say here that I have approved of anything, as far as I can tell. What this letter says is that someone in Reynolds's office is agitated that the amounts have not been paid—not that they have, but that they have not—and the claims have been referred to my office for consideration.
—Have they been paid yet?

—I do not know. In the short few minutes available to me since this matter was raised, I do not know whether they have or have not been paid. I will undertake to the Senate to report to it in the due and proper way as soon as I do know.
—Will that be today?
—I hope so.
—Mr President, I would like to close this debate. It will take me two minutes. In doing so, I would like to read into Hansard—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I will not stop Senator Crane from closing the debate, but it is not within the motion that we moved, which was to allow five minutes each. I indicate to Senator Bishop and Senator Herron that it is not a precedent and it will not be done every time. I understand that Senator Crane only wants a minute or two and I do not want to vary it, but it actually is not within the motion that I moved. Given that I am sure I heard him ask for leave, it has just been given.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! I do not want to be too repressive about matters like this but, as I remember it, the motion moved by the Parliamentary Secretary was that Standing Orders that would stand in the way of both the Minister and Senator Crane speaking once only were to be set aside. That does not allow Senator Crane to close the debate in the way that would normally occur. Senator Crane, if you had wanted to move a different motion which would have allowed that to occur, you could have done so. The only option you have is to seek leave, and the Minister can then respond. Would you like to officially seek leave?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Mr Acting Deputy President. I can finish what I have to say during the adjournment debate tonight. I ask the Minister whether he can get me the information this afternoon.
—I have said I will endeavour to do that.

—I will clarify my motion, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am just trying to make it equal on both sides. We do not want to have two speakers. The simplest thing is that those opposite have two, we have one, but the amount of time for each side is the same. Otherwise we can be silly and just prop someone else up to speak for five minutes, but that does not seem very sensible. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Bishop on 25 June 1992 relating to rented premises.

SPEECH.PARA: In moving this motion to take note of Senator Bolkus's answer, I do so from this point of view: Senator Bolkus has continued to defend the lease that has been entered into between the Australian Labor Party through its corporate structure, John Curtin House Ltd, and the Commonwealth of Australia for and on behalf of the Australian National Audit Office, on the basis that this lease is commercial and has been negotiated in a strictly commercial manner. The facts of the matter very simply do not bear this out.

PARA.TAB: In the five minutes that I have available to me, I am going to deal specifically with the question of whether or not this is a commercial lease and in accordance with normal practice. As to the way in which the matter was negotiated, and the way in which the Audit Office was duped and not told that the Australian Labor Party was the landlord until after it had written and said that it would want to be given the lease, I will have to deal with those issues on another occasion.
On 28 May, at page 3,062 of the Hansard, Senator Bolkus said:

SPEECH.PARA: As I have already shown convincingly to this chamber, the documents show that this deal was very much a commercial proposition, and a good one for the Government. It was conducted professionally and on a commercial basis.

I went away to do some homework to find out from the market exactly what was the position. Mr Andrew Robb commissioned a survey of the market by Price Waterhouse, who has today reported on a survey of leases available in the Barton area and leases that had been entered into by the Australian Government—that is, the Commonwealth—concerning various departments. None of them meet the favourable, slush fund type conditions that are available in the lease for the Australian Labor Party. For starters, the length of the lease is from three to 10 years, the rentals are much lower and certainly there is no 9 per cent annual increment in the levels of rental.

PARA.TAB: Having been handed this survey, a further question was then asked, again by Mr Robb of Price Waterhouse—to compare the ALP lease with the survey of leases that had been entered into by the Australian Government. Its quote is—I put it into the record now—after appraising the market as it is, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The above would seem to indicate that the arrangement is extremely generous to the owner—
that is, the Labor Party—
and we have difficulty, unless there are facts of which we are not aware, concluding the arrangement is a good commercial proposition for the Government.

In other words, it is not a good commercial proposition for the Government. I would charge Senator Bolkus to find any evidence that he can to try to refute the statement that this is not a good deal for the Government, because the documentation that he has presently put on the record does not do that. When we have more time we will go through it item by item.

PARA.TAB: There is a further document I want to table, and that is a table which is simple to read. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the three documents, Mr Acting Deputy President.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not seen them. I would like to look at them first.
—Is leave granted?
—These are the surveys I have just referred to, and a calculation of the profit to be derived from the Labor Party development.
—Senator, the Government could look at the documents and during Senator Herron's speech leave could be granted for their incorporation.

—I want to get this in quickly, if I may. I said today in Question Time that the Labor Party could sell its building immediately upon completion and make a $15.4m profit. If it held it for an additional year it would be $18.2m; five years, $29m; 10 years, $43m; and 15 years, $58m. That is as well as getting the rental during that period. Pardon my voice; I still have the dreaded lurgi that I seem to have caught from the air-conditioning in this place. I seek leave to incorporate these documents because they show the yield, how the yield is calculated and how that profit would be derived. As I said, I also seek leave to incorporate this document into the Hansard.

PARA.TAB: There is a case to answer and there are many questions to answer concerning the relationship between Senator Bolkus, his Department, Mr Hogg and the manner in which these negotiations were carried out. I wish to have the opportunity at a future time to fully investigate those questions that need to be answered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I became interested in this matter because I am aware of a building which is similar in structure and adjacent or close to the building that we are talking about, which has been leased for $386 per square metre per annum. The Commonwealth Government negotiated a lease in this adjacent building for $315 per square metre. This was done at the same time as the lease in question was negotiated.

PARA.TAB: There are four points that I wish to bring out in the short time available to me. The first point concerns Senator Bolkus's statement on 28 May, at page 3058 of the current Senate Hansard, in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Most major leases provide for a minimum base term of 10 years, with two options for an additional five years each. I am further advised that in the current property market where there is a scarcity of investors, developers are now requesting lease terms of 15 years before commencing new construction programs.

The second point concerns Senator Bolkus's statement that the departments looking for office space were the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service, the Australian National Audit Office, the Industry Commission, the Attorney-General's Department, the Public Service Commission, the Fisheries Service and the National Food Authority. The third point is that on the following page he said:

PARA.TAB: The next question that was signalled was: what are the rental levels for the various major areas of the ACT? We have received Australian Valuation Office advice which suggests that the rentals for the various areas are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: For brevity, I quote:
for Barton—the area that was preferred—$330 per square metre per annum;
The fourth point that I wish to make is in relation to the gross rental. Further on, on the same page, he said:

PARA.TAB: The next question that would have been put to me was: how does the rental for the subject building, the Lend Lease proposition on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, compare with the rest of the market? I am advised that the prime net rental is based on $280 per square metre as at 1 January 1991, escalated at a fixed percentage of 10.5 per cent till occupancy. I am further advised that outgoings have been estimated to be $42 per square metre, and that this all up compares favourably with similar standard buildings in similar locations.

My fifth point is that the Minister said today that, all up, he was unaware of the exact figure but that from memory it was between $380 and $386—or he agreed that that may be the correct figure. I have a copy of the lease of a building, as I mentioned before, which is a five-year lease, in contradistinction to the 15-year lease that the ALP has negotiated with the Commonwealth Government. It is for $315 per square metre, with an option of a further five years commencing on 1 January 1996.

There is obviously a case to answer. This is a comparable building, built at the same time and of equivalent standing. It is not a 20-year-old building, as the Minister suggested it might be. It has similar outfittings. There is an enormous disparity—$70 a square metre over a 15-year lease period as compared with a five-year lease period. I do not believe that it can be left hanging in the air. The Minister has to answer. How was this negotiated? Why is there an enormous disparity in the return? I thought of the word `sophistry'. Sophistry is a subtle, tricky, specious but generally fallacious method of reasoning. I think the Minister is acting in an extraordinary manner to produce an answer which gives the lie to the figures that are available on the market. I believe that he has a case to answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no trouble in allowing the two documents to be incorporated in the Hansard. I have not seen the third document yet, but I probably will during the course of this debate.

PARA.TAB: I was very tempted to get up and say that I do not need to reply because nothing new has been produced at this stage. But let me go through the assertions made. Senator Bishop goes to the commercial nature of the lease and makes some points about that. At the outset I suggest to people who might be listening, particularly AAP, which has been religiously following the Opposition's pursuit of this matter—I think it is the only organisation that has given the Opposition a run—that maybe this time they should actually listen to me as well before they go off and blindly write their stories. It is a suggestion only.

We go to the commercial nature of the document. We should put on the public record that Mr Andrew Robb, who has commissioned these assessments, is a Federal director of the Liberal Party of Australia.

The basic point that the Opposition is putting to us is that it is a generous commercial proposition. But let me put a couple of points on the record. The first, a basic point, is that we are talking about a market which has collapsed over the last 18 months or so. That has meant that a lot of players in the market are, of course, much keener to get rid of their properties at this particular time, and we are finding that all over the place. Price Waterhouse says, `As you are aware, we have recently carried out a survey of leasing activity within the Barton area'—it has looked to see what property is available.

The first point is that between early 1991 and mid-1992 there has been a major change in the market. Property that was commanding particular prices then can command nowhere near those prices now. That is pretty well understood in the marketplace, and it was understood at the time. Let me put one item on the record to reinforce that point: it is very easy to go and see what is on the market now and compare that to 18 months ago. But look at John McEwen House: as I said, and I will keep on saying, it is a building that is some 20 or 30 years old. On a short term rental arrangement, that is commanding $330 per square metre per annum.

TALK.START.PARA: —Short term.

—Short term, but it is within the price range. One does not compare prices now to prices then. Secondly, Senator Herron mentioned Tourism House. There are some aspects of Tourism House that need to go on the record to indicate—
—On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I did not mention the building. The Minister said that I mentioned Tourism House.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! That is not a point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, let me go to an adjacent building without mentioning its name. It is seeking $320 per square metre per annum.
—Three hundred and fifteen dollars.

—But there are some major differences between that building and the John Curtin House proposition. Firstly, it is a strata title; there are nine leases in respect of this particular building. Secondly, there is a different arrangement for fitout. I think the public record shows that for John Curtin House something in the vicinity of $400,000 or $500,000—I am not sure on the figures—was provided by the owners for the fitout. It is much different in this case.

PARA.TAB: Tourism House was built at the same time as nine other buildings and there were no pre-existing commitments. So it is part of the marketplace. Property owners are really undercutting each other at the moment to make sure that they have tenants.

The other thing about this adjacent building is that it has received only qualified acceptance from the Commonwealth. It is not up to Administrative Services standards in air conditioning, height and facilities. So it is a wrong comparison to make on timing in a general sense. Let us face it: if one has a strata title arrangement with nine different leases, it does make a difference to the price that can be commanded.

On the Price Waterhouse comparison, I suggest to Mr J. C. C. Warren, who is a partner—and I am close to some partners of Price Waterhouse—that when he is making the comparison, he ought to take a number of factors into account. For example, he compares the arrangement for John Curtin House with the Burns Centre and Macquarie House.

The lease for the Burns Centre is $315 per square metre. The survey by Price Waterhouse refers to, `Fitout concession—three months rent free during period'. One just cannot compare a raw figure of $315, $320 or $330.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, you can.

—Senator Bishop could; she could compare whatever she likes. But if one is in the commercial market then it is not an equal comparison. So that is one comparison. With regard to Macquarie House, Mr Warren says quite clearly, `We are not aware of any fitout concessions'. So, given that on the one hand one has a fitout figure—as I recollect, of some $400,000 to $500,000—and, on the other, there are no fitout concessions, it is obviously very hard to compare.

PARA.TAB: But it is interesting to note that in the brief provided for Mr Warren—I do not tag Mr Warren for this in any sense at all—by Mr Robb, the Federal Director of the Liberal Party of Australia, there does not seem to be any reference to the fact that there was a fitout arrangement between John Curtin House and the Government. So Mr Warren has probably been set up. He has been asked to compare apples with oranges. As I say, the comparison is wrong.

Let me just go back to the essential point that we made, which is on the public record, and I say this specifically for those who might be listening outside this chamber because it is quite apparent that those in here have firm and fixed views about this: the arrangement—

TALK.START.PARA: —We're not even on broadcast, Nick.

—Then I say this for anyone's parents who might take an interest in reading Hansard: the basic thing is that there has been no interference. The machinery of government acted without ministerial or political interference. It acted on the best commercial advice available at the start of 1991 and it acted very properly within that advice. Nothing has been raised to indicate anything other than that.

PARA.TAB: I suggest to Senator Herron that he not get on the toboggan with Yellow Mellow over there; he should think about this himself because he might get sucked in to something that really is a brumby. This one is a bit of a bummer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop, you sought leave to incorporate some documents?
