INTERJECT.PARA: Yield on an investment refers to the return on the cost of the investment. For example, a savings account will currently offer a yield of around 6% per annum and shares in BHP, on a purchase price of $14.28, will show a yield of 2.83% and an investor would receive a dividend of 40 cents.

In the property industry yields are sometimes referred to as capitalisation rates and the capitalisation rate really means valuing a cash flow at a given yield. For instance, if we talk about a capitalisation rate of 7.5% we mean an investment bought at a given price would return 7.5% eg $1,000 capitalisation cost would return $75.

Capitalisation rates (or yields) reflect the quality of the investment. First class investments such as the State Bank Building in Martin Place are currently valued at yields of 5%: the Grosvenor Building in George Street is currently valued at a yield of 5%. These reflect that the value is perceived to be of a quality investment. However, a building in Collins Street could be valued at a yield of 10% as the valuers would perceive that that would not be of the same quality, with bigger tenancy risks, as the abovementioned properties.
Attractive CBD properties in Canberra City, with varying lease terms in the building, let to reasonably good tenants, show yields between 7.75% and 9%.

The ALP property, having its income capitalised at 7.5%, would be considered reasonable and saleable due to the unusually long lease, the high rentals with an unheard of built in rental escalator of 9%, in a location adjoining Australia's Parliament House.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator MacDonald on 24 June 1992 relating to the local government information services program.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to put on record my appreciation to Senator Tate, Mr Crean and Mr Simmons for taking note of the urgency which I stressed in relation to the local government information services program. It is a very valuable service which puts people living in remote country areas in almost the same category as someone living in the suburbs or in the provincial cities in terms of having access to Commonwealth services and information. So it is a very important service.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased to hear that Mr Crean, who is funding the service at present, is considering an extension. The current trial service concludes at the end of this month. I urge Mr Crean to consider very favourably the continuation of that service. I also urge that the service be extended through the auspices of local government throughout Australia.

In three instances the trial service was conducted through local governments and in other instances through the DSS, the DPI and various other government agencies. I understand the service has not been quite as successful in those other agencies but it was very successful in the case of the three local authorities. I urge Mr Crean to consider extending the service through the auspices of local government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation, as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On at least three occasions during Question Time in the House of Representatives today the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) sought to imply in the strongest possible terms that I was an advocate of euthanasia. That is not only a vicious calumny but also a wilful and utterly dishonest and despicable attempt to smear, not just a citizen of this country—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! Senator Alston, some of the words you used are unparliamentary. I understand that the matter you are raising is of serious import. You are entitled to make a personal explanation, not to debate the issue or comment on other people's motives. If you want to clarify the record in relation to your personal view, you may do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will proceed to make a personal explanation, Mr Acting Deputy President. On 18 June, in the course of the tabling of a report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, I made a contribution to the debate in which I canvassed the implications of the rising cost of age pensions and the effect that progress in biotechnology would have over the next 20 or 30 years.

PARA.TAB: In response to an interjection from the other side of the chamber, I made passing reference to the term that was specifically proposed. At no stage did I advocate euthanasia or indicate that it was something that ought to be pursued in any shape or form. Indeed, I was at pains to point out that it was an abhorrent notion. It is perfectly clear from the thrust of my remarks that I was drawing attention, as have many other commentators, to the likelihood that medical costs of surgical treatment and the care of the elderly may well fall as a result of the accelerating pace of technological change and dramatic reforms in biotechnology. In no way, shape or form was I advocating euthanasia, nor was I suggesting that that had relevance to the debate, other than in the way in which it was proffered. I therefore deplore the way in which these words have been extracted from the Hansard of 18 June.

The concern that I have is not simply that several nights ago in this chamber, Senator Sherry, who was present during that original debate, chose to take those words and put them forward to imply in a snide manner that somehow I was such an advocate. What is of much greater concern is that yesterday Dr Blewett allowed himself to be asked a dorothy dixer which again used the same selective quotations. I then wrote to Dr Blewett in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the dorothy dixer directed to you in Question Time today in which you used selective quotes from me to imply that I somehow supported euthanasia.
I reject your assertions entirely. They are completely misleading, based on selective quoting and as such are mischievous.
In referring to euthanasia I was responding to an interjection which put forward that very proposition and which, I was at pains to point out, was an abhorrent notion to our side of politics.
This sequence of events was endorsed today in the chamber by Senator Kernot who had been present during my speech of June 18.
Therefore I utterly reject your crude and unfair attempt to distort my remarks and I ask that you provide me with an immediate written apology.
In the circumstances and in order to ensure the accuracy of the public record, I will be publicly releasing this letter.

I subsequently received a reply from Dr Blewett which declined to apologise. The matter was then reported, to my knowledge, only in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald in what I would regard as a fair and balanced presentation. It made it perfectly clear that I had been quoted out of context and that I was fortunate—as indeed I was—that Senator Kernot just happened to be in the chamber yesterday and just happened to say that what I had outlined was true and that I was able to, as it were, call on her to support my version of events.

PARA.TAB: It is, therefore, with the greatest sorrow that one finds that not only did the matter surface in the House of Representatives today but that in no less than three separate questions asked of the Prime Minister he continued to defame me in this despicable manner. I can understand the political desperation of someone whose policies are in tatters and who is clutching desperately to try to divert attention from himself, but I cannot abide anyone, either inside the Parliament or outside, seeking to denigrate and crucify someone on the basis of facts which he patently knows to be untrue. It therefore sickens me to find that the Prime Minister of this country can stoop so low at the very time when a Premier of a leading State of this country has just been forced to resign because of one isolated failure to meet the highest standards of political integrity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I accept that Senator Alston feels very strongly about this. I cannot go to the merits of it but I understand that he feels strongly and is therefore entitled to make a personal explanation. But he has now gone beyond the point of making a personal explanation; he is now attacking the Prime Minister. I ask you to keep him to the personal explanation, which I think is finished because he has read the letter which outlined his position and he should not be going on in this manner.
—Do you wish to speak on the point of order, Senator Alston?
—No, I am intending to proceed on the basis—

—I must uphold the point of order. A personal explanation has a specific purpose in this House which is to clarify matters on which one thinks one may have been misrepresented. I ask you once again to remain absolutely relevant to that particular function.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I have never in any shape or form advocated euthanasia. I find the whole concept utterly repugnant and immoral. My whole religious upbringing has made me acutely aware of the sufferings that can be experienced in old age. Those experiences are very close to me at present. In no way could I ever contemplate that taking the easy way out could provide a solution, having regard to the enormity of the consequences both in this life and in the hereafter. The sanctity of human life is something that I have always held very dear and I believe that the overwhelming majority of Australians hold that view with the same intensity.

PARA.TAB: It is therefore difficult to imagine a more serious calumny than to suggest that someone was an advocate of that practice. There may well be some people in this country who would see it as an easy way out. There are a lot of people who take short cuts in life. I personally hold the view that those who suffer most in this life are the ones who are most likely to get their reward in the next. Therefore, there is a greater purpose to be served by those who do endure suffering towards the end of their lifetimes.

It is against that background that I not only feel very strongly but I am also absolutely appalled that anyone, let alone the Prime Minister of this country, could tell such grievous, deliberate and premeditated lies about me in the manner that he has. I therefore utterly reject his remarks and I call upon him to apologise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Alston, you cannot say in this place that a member of this chamber or the other chamber has told a deliberate lie. That is totally unparliamentary. I understand your feelings on this issue. You have clarified your personal views, which you say were misrepresented, which was the purpose of your personal explanation, but you must withdraw the phrase `a deliberate lie'.
—It's an absolutely despicable act.
—Senator, I ask you again to withdraw.

—I am not prepared to withdraw, Mr Acting Deputy President. In the circumstances, I feel I have no choice. If it were simply a passing reference based on what might have been said in the first instance, one could perhaps understand that someone might have been misled. But the way that matters have proceeded today can only be construed as a very calculated and deliberate effort to somehow maximise personal political advantage from a sequence of events which must have been known to all concerned to be utterly and completely untrue. In those circumstances, it would not be proper in terms of my own integrity or the importance of defending one's own position to simply proceed otherwise.

—Senator Alston, I have heard your explanation. I have given you a fair degree of latitude in the areas that you have traversed since you sought leave. I ask you once again to withdraw the statement that the Prime Minister wilfully or deliberately lied.
—I am not prepared to do so.
—Then I have no option but to name you.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, you having given the senator, as I understand it, an opportunity to make an explanation or apology in accordance with the Standing Orders—

—At this stage I will give him one more opportunity and I will do it strictly according to Standing Orders. I suggest that the Senate or at least members of the Opposition discuss the issue with each other before I take this step. I am reluctant to do so, but I have no option unless there is some consideration of the position that you put me and this chamber in.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Is there a procedure in the rules where the Prime Minister could be asked to apologise?

—No, there is no procedure at this stage whereby the Prime Minister is to apologise. The behaviour of this House is the matter that concerns us at this stage. If the Prime Minister manages to do something which might in fact constitute an apology to Senator Alston, then he is free to do so, or he may be required to do so at some other time in another House or in some other forum. There is no way today in this chamber that the Prime Minister could be expected to apologise.

—Further to that point of order, it seems fairly clear to me that this chamber should have some powers. I am again seeking your guidance on this point of order that I have raised. Mr Acting Deputy President, could you indicate to me if there is some way in which this chamber could call upon the Prime Minister to withdraw those words which are clearly—
—Which are defamatory; clearly defamatory.
—Not only defamatory but clearly not correct as appears from Senator Alston's explanation. The accusation that has been levelled against Senator Alston is simply not factual.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the purported point of order, which is turning into a speech lasting a couple of minutes, without referring to Standing Orders, at the moment we have before the Chair your request to Senator Alston to make an explanation. I understood it was reasonable for him to be given a bit of time for consideration and we all had our telescope to our blind eye for a little while. It cannot go on forever. The matter before us is your request to Senator Alston to make an explanation or apology pursuant to standing order 203. Having been a bit indulgent while Senator Macdonald gave him a bit of time to think about it, we really have to come back to that matter and your request, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—I call Senator Alston or Senator Short.

—Perhaps I should speak first. I am indebted to Senator Short. There are occasions in the heat of the moment when people are tempted to go over the top in the expressions they use. I suppose we are all guilty of that from time to time, but there are some matters where there are points of principle that simply have to be taken. I did not come into this chamber today determined to be thrown out. Indeed, I was not even aware that this matter had been pursued in the House of Representatives until towards the end of Question Time in this place.

PARA.TAB: But I have to say, with the most seriousness that one can bring to a very serious matter, that it should be possible to refute in the strongest terms something that goes to the core of one's own integrity and the principles that one holds dear, and to make it in such categorical terms and in such a way that outside this place would be a very commonplace and natural response. One does not have to go to a football match or be at a party. One just has to be in any discussion where someone rejects a proposition and says `rubbish', `lies', `nonsense' or whatever else. In the circumstances it strikes me as—perhaps precious is not the right word—not doing justice to the gravity of the matter for the Parliament to take the view that somehow one cannot reject in those strong terms something that goes to the very heart of a member's, or a senator's in this instance, integrity. That is what this is about.

This is not just another cheap political debate or the opportunity to have a bit of a go at someone to try to pick up some short term advantage. It is a very central issue of morality and something about which I—and I imagine a number of my colleagues—feel very strongly as someone who holds religion dear and takes pride in maintaining a moral integrity. It seems to me that I would be doing less than justice to myself if I were to simply accept the proposition that somehow I cannot say in this chamber what one would instinctively say outside.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston, I wonder whether you would take your seat and we can look at this. I will explain quite clearly what the situation is. Personal explanations are meant by nature to be just that, not a debate with regard to a particular issue. If people feel as if they have been in some way defamed in this place and misrepresented personally, it is obviously about an issue that they regard as very important to them and to their own self-regard.

PARA.TAB: The fact is, though, that we have rules here, as all honourable senators who have been here long enough know, and they are clearly designed to ensure, no matter what we feel and what we would like to say about some people, that for the good behaviour and the good governance of this chamber—and it is essential—we do not use certain words. Therefore, certain words are regarded as unparliamentary, much as we would like to say them; or in fact they may well be the truth.

You have put me in a position where I have no option but to name you unless you can make an explanation or apology which is satisfactory to the Chair so that the good governance of this chamber can continue. I understand your views about the issue. I understand there are other avenues through which you may take action in order to make the point that you were misrepresented in a way that you regarded as blatant misrepresentation and so on. Once again, I have to put to you the notion that you need to make an explanation or apologise; otherwise I have to name you.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept that you have a duty to perform, and that is the matter that I am addressing, Mr Acting Deputy President. I put it to you very strongly that, if an explanation is to mean anything, it must mean that you should properly consider not only what is said but also the circumstances that led to it and the context in which an expression is used.

PARA.TAB: We do not have to have much more than a passing knowledge of what goes on in the House of Representatives to know the sorts of rhetoric and expletives that are used on occasions. `Stuff up' now seems to be common parlance in this place, although I would have thought until a couple of days ago that it was unparliamentary. If one looks at the Prime Minister's use of the English language, it is quite clear that almost anything goes on occasions in that chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Indeed. I do not for a moment argue that we ought to have standards in this place that allow people with parliamentary impunity to say what they like or to come in and feign indignation and throw around a whole range of words. But I do say to you very seriously that, if you judge an issue on the seriousness and the consequences of it for an individual, I cannot see how you could regard a slur that someone is an advocate of euthanasia as constituting anything other than the most serious personal attack.

PARA.TAB: In those circumstances—without for one moment setting precedents or somehow paving the way for others in other circumstances to use the same terminology—I simply say that you ought to consider my response to the Prime Minister's response. It would seem to me that in no way would any members of this chamber on either side seek to use such an expression in the normal course of events or, indeed, in circumstances other than the most exceptional where it goes very much to the heart of their own personal characters and reputations.

I would have thought that if you adopted a rule that accepted that proposition then you would be doing justice to all concerned; otherwise you are ignoring the distinction between explanation and apology, because I am not apologising. If words mean anything, there must be a basis on which an explanation can be satisfactory.

I am simply putting to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that in these circumstances, having regard to the enormity of the allegation and the mere use of a term which is in common currency in the community to effectively refute the substance of those allegations, you would simply be acting with commonsense and fairness to all concerned. I therefore invite you to accept that explanation.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is another way of dealing with this issue. With respect, the interpretation—
—After your effort last night!
—Senator Kemp remembers it.
—Be constructive this time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Coulter

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be constructive. With respect, Mr Acting Deputy President, the interpretation you have given to standing order 203 is not quite correct in this respect. It says that if objectionable words are used, the senator refuses to withdraw such words and persistently and wilfully refuses to conform to the Standing Orders and so on, the President may report to the Senate that that has occurred. We have reached that point. However, it then says:

INTERJECT.PARA: A Senator who has been reported as having committed an offence shall attend in the Senator's place—
the senator is clearly in his place—
and be called upon to make an explanation or apology—
we have got to that point—
and then a motion may be moved that the Senator be suspended . . .

Mr Acting Deputy President, it seems to me that, under these circumstances, you can go as far as you have and rule that the language was unparliamentary. You may name the senator, but there is a discretion as to whether a motion must be moved. A motion may be moved. It seems to me that, under these circumstances, it would be appropriate to have proceeded as far as you have and then for a motion not to be put that the senator be removed.

PARA.TAB: Quite clearly, Senator Alston feels very deeply about the particular matter over which he feels he has been maligned. For him to have made that explanation and to have used the word he did is perhaps outside the normal language of this chamber. For us to accept the very gravity of this situation and therefore refuse to take that next step to actually move a motion would be an appropriate way around this problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, you are obviously in an awkward position, as is everyone else in the chamber. Anyone who heard Senator Alston today could not have anything other than total sympathy with his situation and feelings and the views he has expressed. We also agree that one could find no stronger advocate of the upholding of parliamentary standards and integrity in this chamber than Senator Alston.

PARA.TAB: I put to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, a point that follows the very constructive comments of Senator Coulter in relation to standing order 203. As I understand it, there is not at the moment any motion before the Chair on this matter. Mr Acting Deputy President, you may report to the Senate that a senator has committed an offence under standing order 203(1); as I understand it, that is a matter for your discretion.

I put it to you very strongly, Mr Acting Deputy President, that in all the circumstances of this matter today—the way it has arisen, the circumstances that led to Senator Alston making his personal explanation and the words he used—the right and proper thing for you to do would be to take into account all those circumstances and not report to the Senate that Senator Alston has committed an offence. As I understand the wording of standing order 203, that is within your power. I hope that, as a man of integrity and propriety, you would see your way clear to take that course of action.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the matter is not proceeding much further, I would not wish to take up any more time on it. Lest it may proceed further, I would wish to say some words on this matter.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—If you take your seat, Senator Reid, I will explain where we are so far. I have been put in a position where a senator has refused to withdraw or apologise for using a word which is plainly unparliamentary. I gave him a great deal of leeway in his personal explanation. I took into account the fact that he was obviously upset by what had been said about him in terms of his strong personal beliefs.

On two occasions I gave the senator the opportunity to explain or apologise; I am aware of the fact that he can explain. But simply saying to the Chair, `I cannot withdraw' or `I am not prepared to explain because I am in an unusual situation' cannot be acceptable in the Senate. Any number of members of this Senate will at some time or another feel so upset or hurt about accusations made about them that they will breach this very basic standing order which states that they cannot say someone is a deliberate liar.

There are many occasions when we tend to overlook these matters, but in this case Senator Alston has put me in a position where he has simply said that he will not withdraw. There are a number of stages that we go through here, but the main point, with all due respect to Senator Coulter, is that, if an explanation that is of sufficient validity or an apology is not forthcoming, I have no option but to name Senator Alston, and someone would then move the appropriate motion.

I again ask that Senator Alston favour me with an explanation which is of sufficient value to convince the Senate, and me in the chair, that he is apologetic about the fact that he used that word. Otherwise we set a precedent here which, if I make a decision today, will from then on become par for the course. The standards of behaviour in this place from time to time have already gone down, as all of you have commented in various debates. I ask whether any other senator wishes at this stage to make a point, because once the motion is moved, it will be put without debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the matter so that we are clear on where things are at. As I understand it—and this is the point that both Senator Coulter and Senator Short have made—standing order 203(1)(c) clearly contemplates that a senator may use objectionable words and may refuse to withdraw such words but that, in the circumstances, the person in the chair has a choice as to whether he or she reports the matter to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—I am listening, senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I would prefer to have your undivided attention.
—I can assure you that it is absolutely undivided.

—I will start again. Standing order 203(1)(c) contemplates a situation where a senator can use objectionable words and refuse to withdraw them and yet the person in the chair will not proceed to report the matter to the Senate. I would have thought that that is incontrovertible. I hope that you agree with that, Mr Acting Deputy President, because if you do not, I will proceed to elaborate.
—That is correct.
—Therefore, it follows that, in order to convince you, I do not have to apologise or withdraw the words; I simply have to provide a sufficient explanation.

PARA.TAB: I trust that what I am putting to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, is not about to be refuted. In other words, it follows that if a senator does use objectionable words and refuses to withdraw them, then there are circumstances in which you may choose not to take the matter further. That must mean that it is not necessary for an apology to be forthcoming, but merely that a sufficient explanation in the circumstances be provided to you. If that is the case, I say to you that you, therefore, have to turn your mind to these particular circumstances and whether they amount to a sufficient explanation.

In those circumstances, it is no use at all talking in terms of precedents. By definition, if the standing order clearly contemplates that there may be circumstances in which you choose not to take the matter further, it is clearly a precedent on the first occasion that it is used in that way—and it may already have been used for all I know. Clearly, that proposition cannot be rejected merely on the grounds that it may constitute a precedent.

The whole object of allowing discretion is that discretion is to be exercised on its merits. In other words, it does not become a precedent. One cannot simply say that because Senator McMullan was able to describe me as a windbag, that authorises everyone else to use that term in the future. It is to be judged on the circumstances at the time and in the environment of the issue. It is not a sufficient starting point for your deliberations, Mr Acting Deputy President, to say that you cannot contemplate a refusal because somehow it might tend to lower the standards of the chamber or encourage others to do likewise. They would do so at their peril; they clearly would not be able to draw any comfort from a special case or a single instance where a judgment was made on the facts and on the merits. I would have thought that that was the plain meaning of the words.

In those circumstances, I say to you again that my explanation is very much directed not just to my personal circumstances but to the gravity of the allegation, and to what I regard as perhaps one of the most serious things that could ever be said about anyone. If you regard murder as a capital offence, and there are not too many offences more serious than murder—treason used to be but perhaps that has fallen into disuse—it follows that a capital offence is the most serious crime known to the criminal law. Euthanasia is clearly in that category. We do not condone euthanasia in this society. It is a shorthand expression for committing the crime of murder in compassionate circumstances.

If that is the situation, one cannot imagine a more serious allegation. If someone said, `You are in favour of murder', I would have thought it would be hard to put bounds on one's sense of outrage. Yet that is precisely what is being said here, and what was said not just on one occasion by Senator Sherry two nights ago and by Dr Blewett yesterday, but in the most calculated and cold-blooded way on three separate occasions in the House of Representatives, where it was deliberately designed to bring maximum political attention to an issue. Whether that was for diversionary purposes or out of political desperation, I do not know. The fact of the matter is that one could not imagine a more serious calumny than to use that expression about any other member of parliament or, indeed, any other citizen.

Mr Acting Deputy President, if you do not regard that as sufficient to satisfy the discretion vested in you, it is very hard to imagine what the draftsman was contemplating when he provided that discretion. Otherwise, the standing order would simply say, `If you use objectionable words and you refuse to withdraw, you must be named—out'. That is not what it says. The standing order is clearly designed to recognise the circumstances of people's actions, whether they be the use of objectionable words, persistently and wilfully refusing to conform to standing orders or persistently and wilfully disregarding the authority of the Chair. You may make a judgment that the person who is prima facie guilty is not in control of himself any more—he may have any sort of condition or illness which makes him less than fully responsible. There clearly has to be a discretion for those sorts of reasons.

Finally, I cannot contemplate a more serious allegation. Therefore, if that is not sufficient to allow you to exercise your discretion in the way that you are able to, those words do not have much meaning.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the generality of Senator Alston's argument is correct, but he has the wrong copy of May's Parliamentary Practice. If he goes through standing order 203 again he will find that there is no call for an explanation or an apology at the point at which you may report to the Senate. I think you, Mr Acting Deputy President, have already gone past that point anyway; I think you have named him. The May which is relevant is that a motion may be moved. I think that is the relevant point. I say to Senator McMullan that if we get to that point—and I think we have reached it—and he chooses to move that way, I will choose not to support that motion.

—In explanation to Senator Coulter, I said, `I will have no option but to name you'. That is subject to an apology, a withdrawal or an explanation sufficient to satisfy me that the behaviour in the Senate will not be affected in the future by what Senator Alston said today.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I hoped that you might give me the latitude to speak to this point of order that everyone else has had; because I do not think anyone has spoken much to the Standing Orders. I accept that this is an important issue. I would like to make some general comments about the circumstances in which we find ourselves and the statements that have been made with regard to this question.

PARA.TAB: I have to say that I have never asked anyone in the Senate that I can recall to withdraw any words. I do not take the narrow definition of unparliamentary language in the same manner as many people do. As adults, we ought to be able to cope with things which are said, in a sense in the words Senator Alston used, in the normal course of conversation to us in the street or in public—I do not mean words that are illegal to use in public, but things which can be said in the normal course of public conversation.

That happens to be the view which I hold but it is not the standard which applies in this Senate; it is not the standard which the Opposition applies to Government members when they speak. Those opposite have been extraordinarily active in calling upon Government members to withdraw. Senator Hill was looking for Senator Evans to withdraw today when he said, `Thank goodness I will not have to look at you for two weeks' because he thought it was unparliamentary and offensive and needed to be withdrawn.

I have to say that that was probably an extreme example, but we do find many examples of people being called upon to withdraw comments where, by no measure, is there any precedent for them being unparliamentary and offensive—they are in the English language—but people withdraw them at the request of the Presiding Officer for the smooth running of the Parliament. I have been called upon to withdraw. I called a senator an ignoramus—a perfectly good English word which means a person ignorant of the facts. In my view, it is in no way unparliamentary. The Presiding Officer at the time—a Labor Presiding Officer—called upon me to withdraw. I had to say to him that I thought it was a long way from being unparliamentary.

TALK.START.PARA: —You thought he was an ignoramus.

—I thought he was being excessively generous to the senator who raised the concern and probably excessively generous to the senator about whom I had said it—but that is a different issue. I withdrew in the interests of the management of the Senate. There is no way that I regard that as contending that the word `ignoramus' is unparliamentary, but it is an explanation of the traditional, very narrow interpretation of this which is being taken by the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: Apart from those words which would be illegal to use in the street, swear words in the common parlance which are obviously unparliamentary and in my view obviously should remain so—one should not be able to say in this chamber things which would be illegal in normal language used to a citizen outside—there are probably two words, of those which one can legally use elsewhere, most consistently regarded as unparliamentary. They are the words `liar' and `hypocrite'.

I was in here last night or perhaps the night before when Senator Alston was calling me a hypocrite. I said, `Look, I am not going to call on him to withdraw that because I do not regard his double standards on that matter as important'. I said to him, `The next time you are interjected upon, you will show that you have double standards. You are prepared to use words like that to others but you are not prepared to accept them'. I think that quite clearly would be true. That is a matter about which I am quite relaxed. History will vindicate that. I am relaxed about him using unparliamentary language in calling me a hypocrite, but the honourable senators opposite cannot have the standards that they seek to apply to others and not apply them to themselves. Those opposite have the view—

TALK.START.PARA: —The really guilty party here is Keating, isn't it?

—I understand that this is a political stunt by the Opposition. It is very kind of Senator Hill to make it absolutely clear that what he was trying to do was make a political point about the Prime Minister. I am in no doubt that that always has been the case, irrespective of whether the facts as Senator Alston outlines them are true, and I have no idea whether they are or not. I have no intention of reflecting on what he has said because I just do not know. We have not known him to come in and tell untruths in the Parliament. I am not accusing him of that; I just do not know.

PARA.TAB: I am saying that, irrespective of the accuracy of the facts, Senator Alston had been given an extremely generous opportunity, and properly so, to make a lengthy exposition far beyond what normally would happen in a matter of personal explanation, and he did it effectively. I have no idea whether he is right or wrong. Other people will judge that when they read what was in the House of Representatives Hansard and the Senate Hansard. They can make their comparisons and make their own judgments. I do not know those facts.

Senator Alston had ample opportunity to make his proposition. Right at the end, having had all that generosity extended to him, he threw in this extra allegation. He had on several occasions, once by way of me raising a point of order, strayed so far that his speech was not a personal explanation but an attack on the Prime Minister. Right at the end he said, `The Prime Minister has told lies'. If anybody on this side of the Parliament—or might I say on Senator Coulter's side—had said on any occasion that any member of Parliament had told lies, those opposite would have leapt to their feet and called for it to be withdrawn.

I have to say that, if this motion is moved and defeated today, we will be setting a very substantial new standard. We will be saying that any word can be used in this Parliament as then it is up to the person who used it to seek to make an explanation about whether or not it is justifiable. That is fine by me. I have the view that we should be more open about the language that is used in the Parliament. I have the view that honourable senators have all been excessively precious for the four years that I have been here and that we should be prepared to put up with more robust language. I have tried to apply that principle to myself, as I say, with regard to things which those opposite have said about me and colleagues. But what I am saying is that those opposite should seek to apply to themselves the standards they seek to apply to others.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get back to the issue.
—The issue is whether the word `lie' can be used. That is exactly the issue I am talking about.
—It has been used so often and not made to be withdrawn.

—If honourable senators opposite are saying that it has become acceptable and that is what they are trying to advocate; if it is their view, as Senator Walters's interjection said, that it has become an acceptable form of language—
—She did not say that.
—I said if that is the implication of her interjection.
—That was not the implication of my interjection. What I said was that on other occasions it has been used—
—If I need your advice, I will be desperate.
—And people have not been asked to withdraw.
—There is no occasion Senator Walters can cite where a Presiding Officer has asked for it to be withdrawn, it has not been and no action has been taken.
—That is a different matter.

—That is the circumstance we are in now. There was no way Senator Aulich could pretend he had not heard those words. It was not an interjection. It was not a muffled comment to one side. It was said within yards of Senator Aulich directly to him in the course of a major contribution to the Chair. I think the Chair is being put in an intolerable position given that—
—It is your discretion as to whether you move it or not.
—It is not necessarily, but I am quite relaxed about that. That is why I am speaking now.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—I wonder whether we need to go through this because there are a number of other members of the Opposition, for example, who wanted to speak on the point of order. I have, in a sense, heard as much as I wish to hear in order to have my judgment affected one way or another on this question of the procedural difficulties.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one more point I want to make, Mr Acting Deputy President. I know others have spoken at great length but I will respect that. I understand that, in terms of the acceptance of the explanation, that is a matter for your judgment. I have had that assessment confirmed by the Clerk. I do not think I have much discretion, if the Presiding Officer considers it is not a satisfactory explanation, other than to act—
—Total discretion.
—The only time that discretion was exercised in the House of Representatives, the Opposition thought it was a pretty controversial circumstance.
—You didn't though, Bob. You supported that.
—That is a very interesting interpretation of history, but Senator Kemp should worry about that some other time.
—Why don't you go and have a talk to the Prime Minister before you move your motion.

—Why don't you just relax. What I am saying is simply that the Opposition is applying the grossest of double standards in a way that is putting Senator Aulich in an extraordinarily difficult situation.
—Putting you in a difficult situation because he has made his decision.

—If he has made it, I will support him in whatever final decision he makes because he is the Presiding Officer. If he makes a decision, I will support him, but he is listening to contributions from senators as he should. Mr Acting Deputy President, I want to make clear to you that we will support you in whatever decision you make with regard to this matter. But if it becomes the view of the Senate that this is not an unparliamentary word in at least some circumstances, that will be a very major change—perhaps a change I will welcome, but a very major change.

—I will once again put the Senate in the picture in terms of what I perceive to be the appropriate processes. I have indicated that unless, from Senator Alston, I receive an apology, a withdrawal or an explanation which is to my satisfaction, I have no option but to name him. I indicated that right at the beginning. I have heard points of order on this from a number of senators. The question is whether or not I believe that what Senator Alston said today will in fact set a precedent for behaviour in this chamber in the future.

PARA.TAB: Quite frankly, I do not give two hoots what is said in the other chamber. That is not a matter of concern to me. I am not the Presiding Officer of the House of Representatives, thank heaven. I cannot call upon the Prime Minister or anyone else in that chamber to withdraw or to apologise, but in this chamber the code of behaviour while I am in the chair is my responsibility. Therefore, I cannot allow a precedent to occur unless there is some explanation suitable to me while I am in the chair.

During the course of the debate and the various points of order that have been taken, Senator Alston has indicated to me quite clearly what his viewpoints are. He has explained why he acted in the way that he did. I have indicated that the three options are an apology, a withdrawal or an explanation to my satisfaction. Since I originally indicated to Senator Alston what could occur, I have listened very carefully to what he said. I believe there is, of course, a fourth option and that is a question of a substantive motion which is entirely in the hands of the Opposition in regard to this issue. I do not think there should be any discussion in this chamber about what I or anyone else can do about the Prime Minister and what he says. It is entirely in the Opposition's hands as to whether it wishes to move a substantive motion on that issue.

At this stage I am satisfied—and it is a unique situation—with the explanation given in the latter part—I repeat that, in the latter part—of Senator Alston's discussions in the points of order he was making. I accept that he has given a sufficient explanation. I do not want this to be used as a precedent, at least while I am in the chair, so at this stage we will continue with the proceedings of the Senate.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: CODE OF CONDUCT FOR MINISTERSCODE OF CONDUCT FOR SENATORS AND MEMBERS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before this matter was interrupted, I had been making the general point that if one does not know what has been going on how can one decide what to do about it? That is why I was saying there is a need for an inquiry, but not simply what may well end up being a phoney committee really capable of achieving nothing because it did not know what sort of behaviour it was required to deal with.

PARA.TAB: Among the many questions that need to be answered arising from the Marshall Islands affair, for example, is: who benefited from the disappearance of $1.25m from Hong Kong under the Symons scheme; who are the beneficial owners of a Virgin Islands company called Inter-China Enterprises Ltd which was set up by Mr Symons's Hong Kong lawyers? Inter-China Enterprises Ltd was incorporated on 3 January 1990. It has an IBC number, 23450; and a registered address, care of Arias Fabrega Trust Company, British Virgin Islands, Cutless Buildings, Whickham's Cay, Roadtown, Tortula, British Virgin Islands. Those are some of the questions that should be pursued by any proper inquiry.

Surely, it would be proper to examine payments relating to coal dealing in the Hunter Valley between Symons and members of the New South Wales Right in which Senator Richardson—then Mr Richardson—is alleged to have played a role. What are the links that Mr Symons had with WA Inc., particularly the link through Mr Keith Gale? These two people shared offices and were effective partners. The payments by the Western Australian Labor Government to Mr Gale were washed through Mr Symons's company, Bittai Pty Ltd, because the Western Australian Labor Government did not want people to know it was paying money to Mr Gale. Mr Gale is the bankrupt white collar criminal well known for his activities, yet he was able to get an export development grant through his now collapsed company, Interex Pty Ltd. All these matters have to be looked at. No-one is looking at them and, under this arrangement, they are not going to be looked at.

What are the links with Mr Noel Ling, a mate of members of Labor's New South Wales Right, who ran a chain of failed English language schools for Chinese students? He got hundreds of thousands of dollars in export development grants. It has cost the Australian Government multi-millions of dollars in compensation to these Chinese students which the Australian Government is now trying—so far unsuccessfully—to recover from Mr Ling. Mr Ling appears to be an associate of Mr Symons because Mr Ling lent Mr Symons $282,000 by buying out a National Bank mortgage on Mr Symons's home. I have a copy of that mortgage certificate dated 30 March 1990. It was lodged by Mr John Kinna, a Sydney solicitor, who also happened to be a director of Mr Gale's Interex and who appears to be involved with Mr Ling in a lot of these failed enterprises. Just what is this group? How significant are they? Here they are in a matter of some substance relating to education schemes—and an education scheme which Mr Symons tried to introduce in his stunt which has brought him before the courts in the Marshall Islands.

I am intrigued to know—and I think the Senate would like to know—the answers to a whole lot of questions. For example, why did Senator Richardson feel that he had the capacity to instruct a public servant in 1987 to take action on an immigration matter? I have a letter dated 19 August 1987 from the Minister for the environment and the arts to Mr McCann, the Regional Director of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in Perth, the last paragraph of which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Would you have a cable sent to the United Kingdom to ascertain what is the delay in processing this urgent application and advise me of your findings.

I would have thought it would have been more appropriate to ask the Minister for immigration whether he would give such instructions, not the Minister for the environment and the arts. Strangely enough, of course, that matter related to an immigration application for Mr John Davenport under the sponsorship of Taurus Resources NL of Western Australia which was closely associated with Mr Symons's failed company, Feedtech. I think it is appropriate that `taurus' means bull, and there seems to be a lot of that around in these ventures.

PARA.TAB: Matters which should be examined relate to whether people actually phoned Senator Richardson, as suggested by Mr Symons, when they were to check on his status and standing and what it was that Senator Richardson did reply to these people if they did in fact ring. I refer the Senate to an article written by Jenni Hewett in the Financial Review which stated:
Greg Symons would frequently use the name of his relative, Senator Graham Richardson, as a reference in business deals, according to a former business associate of Mr Symons.
Mr Noel Dennis, a financial consultant who has had various business dealings with Mr Symons dating back many years, claimed that Mr Symons would invite people to call Senator Richardson.

SPEECH.PARA: This raises the simple question: did anyone call Senator Richardson? What did Senator Richardson say? I believe we are entitled to have an inquiry to find out, among the many other things we need to find out, what Senator Richardson did in such an event. The Hewett article goes on to state:

PARA.TAB: `He was very proud of the relationship and would often bring it up', Mr Dennis said. `He would tell people to ring Graham up.'

`When he wanted to call Senator Richardson himself, he would go into his office and close the door. He did not do it every day or every week—just when he felt a need to. Twice in one month perhaps, and then once the next month'.

Another. . . business associate, who did not wish to be named, said that Mr Symons would frequently `big-note' his connection with Senator Richardson to colleagues but he had never heard him try to use the senator as a reference with prospective clients or partners.

Mr Dennis, a former solicitor who was struck off, requested the Australian Securities Commission yesterday to institute civil proceedings against Mr Symons and other former directors of Asian Investments Corporation, a company Mr Dennis now controls, over a $1.2m management fee which he claims was paid by Asian Investment Corporation to Feedtech Pty Ltd, a Symons family company. . .

SPEECH.PARA: There are a lot of questions relating to the relationships between all of these people. This is quite apart from the question of whether there was really any need for Senator Richardson to assist in the matter of the Norwegian barman and so on. The simple point is this: there are a host of unanswered questions, as has been raised in many newspaper articles. There is a view, editorialised in the Sydney Morning Herald, which I think raises some problems too. It is reported that:
Mr Symons's scheme promised `to train Asian students and accredit them for onwards entry into higher education in Australia. . .

We have a right to ask: what has happened; were there any such arrangements made in Australia; and, in view of the links between Mr Symons and Mr Ling with all these failed English language Asian schools, what is the nature of that link? Unless these questions get answered, unless there is a proper inquiry into them, the Senate simply will not know the real nature and the real substance of the matters relating to what is current behaviour of the Senate. We need to establish what should be the proper behaviour of the Senate. That seems to me to be a simple, uncomplicated proposition.

PARA.TAB: I take Senator Cooney's point that, if anything like this has to be done, the best place to do it is in house in the Senate. I strongly support that view. I regret that on this occasion the Democrats are taking a view which I do not think gets to the heart of the problem. As I said, we do not know what the problem is, so it is pretty difficult to work out how to resolve it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask Senator Coulter a few questions because I am not sure what he expects to get from the code of conduct of Ministers. I say in all sincerity that I am not sure what Senator Coulter is hoping to achieve. Is the honourable senator suggesting that we will be able to stop the sort of language that goes on in the House of Representatives which, as he knows, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) uses every day? I do not have to repeat the words for Senator Coulter as he knows the ones to which I am particularly referring. Is he suggesting that we would be able to stop that with the code of conduct?

PARA.TAB: Is Senator Coulter suggesting that we would be able to stop Senator Richardson, for example, phoning the President of the Marshall Islands and using his ministerial powers to pressure the President into allowing his relative to retain his passport so that he can come home? Is Senator Coulter suggesting that we would be able to stop Senator Evans, as Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, giving Senator Richardson permission to ring the President of the Marshall Islands? Is he suggesting that we would be able to stop Mr Mick Young bringing illegal baggage owned by his wife into Australia and not declaring it?

I ask these questions in all sincerity. Is Senator Coulter suggesting that the practice of jobs for the boys, which is used so extensively by the Government, would be stopped? Does he believe that we would be able to stop jobs for the boys? Bill Hayden was appointed Governor-General; Mick Young, who resigned after not declaring his wife's baggage, was sent off to Qantas; David Combe, who we know was guilty of a security risk, was sent off to represent Australia in Vancouver; and David Charles, a former member of parliament, was given a job with a salary of $100,000 by Senator Evans so that Mr Crean could take his position in the Parliament. Does Senator Coulter believe that those are the sorts of jobs for the boys that we would be able to stop by using this code of conduct?

Under this code of conduct does Senator Coulter hope to persuade Senator Evans to support the judicial inquiry that the Australian Democrats so rightly have asked for? Does Senator Coulter really believe that Senator Evans will agree to do the decent thing under the code of conduct; and that he will not if we do not have a code of conduct?

If I believed that what Senator Coulter is suggesting could be accomplished, I would join him. But I cannot believe that Senator Coulter could stop the Government from creating jobs for the boys. I have mentioned only three or four instances. I have not gone through what has happened during the whole time the Government has been in power. I have been here a long time, and I know that whenever one of the Government's friends or mates has to resign or is found guilty of something, it sends them off to some very well-paid job. Is Senator Coulter hoping that his code of conduct will stop that from occurring?

I do not want to take up any more time. As I said, I will speak for only five minutes. But I would like to establish just what Senator Coulter hopes to accomplish with his code of conduct and how he would go about prohibiting the things that I have mentioned off the top of my head: things that I have been able to think of in just a few minutes; things that I think are most objectionable; things that bring politicians into disrepute.

I agree with Senator Coulter that something should be done to stop such practices. But does he honestly believe that his code of conduct for Ministers could stop the Prime Minister calling members of my Party `sleazebags,' `dogs coming back to their vomit' and all the other repulsive and filthy expressions that the Prime Minister uses so regularly?

Does Senator Coulter believe that he could stop Senator Evans saying to Senator Richardson, `Yes, it's quite all right for you to ring the President of the Marshall Islands to see whether you can put a bit of pressure on him; but, of course, while you're telling him that it is Senator Richardson, the Minister in Australia, speaking, you must not really wear that hat'? I can assure Senator Coulter that I would join him if I believed that his code of conduct would result in Senator Evans agreeing to a judicial inquiry into his behaviour in the Marshall Islands affair and the Marshall Islands affair generally?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I can answer a number of the points which have been raised in the debate on this matter. I need to indicate where the Australian Democrats will stand on the Opposition's amendment to my motion. A great deal of what we have heard so far from Opposition senators really indicates a certain woolliness in their thinking and logic in relation to what could be achieved with their proposition and what will be achieved with the proposition which is before us.

PARA.TAB: I want to refer to a point that was made by, I think, Senator Hill at the beginning of the debate. We will have a very heavily politicised approach if we go down the road which the Opposition is suggesting—an approach which I believe cannot get at the very things that the Opposition is saying it wants to get at simply because a number of the witnesses, particularly the key witness, Mr Symons, would not be available to the committee.

The Opposition has been arguing that it would like to know about a number of things. Senator Baume said that there are a number of things that the Senate would like to know about. I am sure that there are a lot of things that the Senate would like to know about and pursue, but some of them are not particularly relevant—specifically the matters which go to possible criminal behaviour. Picking up Senator Baume's remarks, I instance the $1 1/4m that has disappeared somewhere in Hong Kong; the matter of a company set up in the Virgin Islands; and the matter of whether Mr Symons legitimately had access to Australia's educational institutions when he was offering those facilities to overseas students and whether he was misrepresenting himself or his company in relation to the offer of those services. Those sorts of criminal matters, while they might be of interest to the Senate, are matters that really should be dealt with in the courts. They are not the sorts of things that the Senate should get bogged down with.

Senator Evans raised a number of points. He and several other senators raised whether it was appropriate for him to contact the President of the Marshall Islands and whether it was appropriate for him to give permission for Senator Richardson as a Minister to contact the President of the Marshall Islands—and Senator Walters in her recent contribution has also raised that matter.

In answer to Senator Walters, it would not be possible with a code of conduct to stop that sort of behaviour. But clearly, by setting an objective measure of what is expected of Ministers beforehand, if that sort of behaviour was regarded in that code as unacceptable and a Minister then indulged in that sort of behaviour, I think there could be agreement generally in the chamber that that Minister had behaved outside the established code of conduct. Then there might be general agreement that that Minister should perhaps no longer be a Minister or that that person should be censured, depending upon how seriously the code of conduct was breached. No code can stop somebody breaking a code, just as the existence of a law does not stop people breaking the law, but at least the law's existence allows one to make some better objective judgment as to whether the behaviour is acceptable.

Specifically in relation to the issuing of a reference, Senator Evans made the point that it could well be advantageous for the committee to which a matter was referred to establish a set of procedures whereby a reference may or may not be issued. To use Senator Evans's words, that would get many people off senators' and Ministers' backs. One could then say, `I'm sorry, I can't give you a reference because I have to run this through a certain set of procedures', or `I have run your request through the set of procedures and it simply does not measure up. Therefore, I can't give you the reference'. I believe that many of us would find that highly desirable.

The structure which I have suggested allows us to get to those matters which are of relevance to the Marshall Islands matter and which are already on the table. They are the matters which deal with the issuing of the reference; the way in which Senator Richardson used his influence with other Ministers, particularly the President of the Senate, to get his cooperation and assistance. For instance, if there were a code of conduct which said that Senator Richardson as a Minister would have to have satisfied himself as to X, Y and Z before giving a reference, clearly he would have done that before he went to Senator Sibraa and sought his cooperation in furthering the interests of Mr Symons.

It seems to me that that matter is covered. The evidence that we need for the committee to take that into account and to lay down a set of criteria is already there. We do not need retrospectively to look for further evidence. Similar arguments apply to the phone call to the President of the Marshall Islands. Is it or is it not appropriate for a Minister to approach a president of a foreign country asking for intercession on behalf of an Australian who is already before the courts? If it is, what sorts of checks and assistance should guide a Minister in so doing? Should the making of those approaches be the sole prerogative of the Minister for Foreign Affairs? Again, if so, before making them what sort of guidance should he seek?

In that context, we find that Senator Kemp in his contribution was saying that we do not need these guidelines, we do not lack guidelines, and that we have the Westminster system. Where in those guidelines does one find how a Minister should proceed with references? The general rubric of the Westminster system does not provide that sort of guidance; nor does it provide any guidance on the other matter of contacting Ministers, presidents or others in foreign countries regarding legal proceedings.

So the Opposition's proposed amendments to my motions contain a hotchpotch of ill-thought-out propositions, based on the supposition that there is not enough knowledge to proceed in those areas where clearly there is that knowledge, and on the wish to investigate areas which correctly fall within the purview of the courts. I refer particularly to whether Mr Symons behaved legally or illegally when he was in Australia.

I inform Senator Kemp that I did indeed read all the material which Senator Evans tabled, including the account of the court transcript in the Marshall Islands. Again, to give a specific example, there was reference there to criminal acts in Australia. Those matters are properly to be taken up by the courts in Australia, not by the Senate—and particularly not by the Senate in an attempt to inveigle Ministers into association with those acts unless they arise from proper court proceedings.

One other matter Senator Walters raised was whether the code of conduct would stop bad language in the House of Representatives. I say to Senator Walters that that is quite outside the purview of the committee. That properly comes within the Standing Orders of the House of Representatives and is not within this code of conduct. However, certainly the other matters that she raised, such as the phoning of the President of the Marshall Islands and the form of the permission to make that phone call by Senator Evans, would fall within the purview of the committee. As for jobs for the boys, I was surprised at her raising that, particularly in view of the resignation of Mr Greiner yesterday over just that sort of accusation.

The code will not stop bad behaviour, but it will give us a measure by which we can judge collectively and premeditatively what sort of behaviour we regard as ethical on the part of members and senators and what sort of behaviour we regard as acceptable for Ministers. I believe that will help in making these judgments in the future. It will expedite and make less vindictive some of the debates that take place in this chamber regarding the behaviour of some senators and Ministers. We will not support the amendments moved by the Opposition and I commend the original motions to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum relating to the Bill. I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Parliamentary Presiding Officers Act 1965 to take account of the change of title of the Deputy President and Chairman of Committees of the Senate. The Parliamentary Presiding Officers Act 1965 provides for the exercise of the statutory powers of the Presiding Officers—the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives—in the event of the holders of those offices resigning, becoming incapable of acting, ceasing to be members, leaving the Commonwealth or dying in office, and in the event of a dissolution of the relevant House.

PARA.TAB: Sections 5 and 7 of the Act provide for the Chairman of Committees of each House to exercise the statutory powers of the relevant Presiding Officer in appropriate circumstances. When the Act was passed in 1965 the Deputy Presiding Officer of each House had the title `Chairman of Committees'. In 1981 the title of the Deputy Presiding Officer of the Senate was changed to Deputy President and Chairman of Committees. The title `Chairman of Committees' is now used only in relation to the function of the office as Chairman of committees of the whole.

The Act has not been amended to take account of this change and, while the Act remains unamended, there are potential difficulties. For example, when signing documents on behalf of the President in order to conform with the Act, the Deputy President must sign as Chairman of Committees, a title which is otherwise not used except in relation to committees of the whole. While it is unlikely that instruments signed by the Deputy President would be held to be technically deficient as a matter of law, it is possible that they could be. It is therefore desirable to update the Act to take account of the altered title.

The Bill amends the Parliamentary Presiding Officers Act 1965 accordingly. Opportunity has also been taken in the Bill to amend the use of masculine pronouns in the Act. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any ministerial statements?

PARA.TAB: Senator Archer—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: we have an agenda before us. Nobody has asked for the order of business to be changed at this stage. The matters of `Next Meeting', `Leave of Absence' and `Order of Business' are all before us. I believe it would be appropriate for the good management of the Senate to at least follow the agenda, which would enable the various representatives of the parties to be here when the business is called on.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training and its Higher Education Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak on the report presented to the Senate entitled Advice on Funds Allocated to Higher Education Institutions: Report of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and its Higher Education Council. Essentially, this response shows why NBEET will be abolished by a coalition government. The document's supposed purpose is to provide formal advice on the allocation of funds to higher education institutions, as notified in the ministerial higher education funding statement for the 1992-94 triennium and the extent to which these allocations conform to agreed funding principles.

PARA.TAB: The response we have received on this rather extensive policy is a pitiful two pages long. Considering the standard of commentary by NBEET, however, I suppose one should be grateful for the brevity of the report, given the waste of public resources that would have occurred had the report been longer. This report touches on the issues of shifts between the undergraduate and postgraduate load, the allocation of undergraduate growth and the mainstreaming of equity funding. It has also had the gall to support one of the most damaging policies of this interventionist Labor Government, that being the institutional profile process.

This policy has had a detrimental effect on our higher education institutions. It has been the ultimate tool of government intervention in higher education. The education profile process has allowed this Labor Government to dictate to our higher education institutions the direction of course development and a lot of their research. It is simply not the role of government to interfere in universities in this way. What this ALP Government should have been doing over the past nine years is solving the very real problems facing higher education in this country.

Our universities are suffering from massive overcrowding; students cannot get into lectures and tutorials; libraries are being run down; and capital works are being neglected. In addition, even though our universities are overcrowded, there is still a record number of 50,000 eligible students who cannot be found a place in tertiary education. The figure is even worse for vocational education, with 150,000 eligible students being unable to find a place in TAFE colleges.

As we can see from this report, the Government is doing very little to correct these enormous problems. However, the coalition has recognised the problems and intends to implement policies to do something about them. The coalition will provide an additional $245m over the rest of this decade in the area of research. Freedom to set their own courses will be returned to universities, ending the process of bureaucratically administered profiles.

We will give universities the freedom to offer additional places to Australian undergraduates beyond government funded places on their own terms. We will establish an effective student market in higher education by a recurrent funding of systems through national educational awards and scholarships. These measures will restore independence to universities and increase support for their basic research effort. Links with industry will be encouraged in ways which will enhance research opportunities rather than through the disruptive ad hoc policies pursued by Labor.

Clearly, it is time for this Government to abandon its current attempt to administer higher education in this country. The coalition's Fightback policies need to be implemented before this Government completely ruins the higher education sector. This Government is not meeting the demands being placed on the sector, nor is it giving universities the freedom to save themselves. The report from NBEET on the funding of higher education for 1992-94 does not provide the Senate with any confidence that this body has any idea of how to solve the very real problems that are facing this vital sector of education in the next triennium.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training and its Schools Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The document I wish to speak to is the ministerial responses through NBEET to the discussion paper entitled, Review of the Commonwealth Capital Grants Program for Non-government Schools. I am afraid I must state that it is really a very poor response from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) on such a crucial issue. It is again a case of this Labor Government spouting platitudes and not actually getting anything done. This is in vivid contrast to the policies espoused by the coalition in the Fightback reform package, which recognises the importance of non-government schools in our schooling sector.

PARA.TAB: I have recently addressed meetings of parents who have been very concerned about the way in which this Labor Government has been treating the non-government schools sector. This sector is becoming more and more important as parents are voting with their feet. In 1989, 26 per cent of school children in Australia attended private schools. This increased to 27 per cent in 1990 and to 28 per cent in 1991. It is going up one percentage point a year.

If parents want private education for their children, governments should not stand in their way. Indeed, they should positively assist. Non-government schools are an essential component of Australian schooling. The vast majority of children in these schools are from families in the low to middle income range. The willingness of parents to commit their own resources to schooling on a large scale makes possible a saving to the taxpayer of $1.6 billion. Government funds are therefore able to be concentrated on government schools. At present, private school funding is not based on any secure principle, and it is giving rise to considerable uncertainty among parents and within the community.

I recently attended meetings of concerned parents in Gosford and Lismore involving 1,100 people in all. They were demanding a dramatic increase in capital funding for the non-government sector. A conservative estimate of the funding required by the year 2000 for capital works on the far north coast for the Catholic education sector is $39m. The equivalent figure on the central coast is $19m. That is an incredible burden to be placed on these educational communities.

It was inspiring to note that these people managed to actually raise 75 per cent of the funds themselves, but this level will be harder and harder to maintain with increased demands on the sector. Fortunately, the coalition recognises this and intends to provide significant relief for this burden. This is a much more appropriate response than the empty rhetoric that the Government has given today in this report.

As they affect education, the decisions announced in Fightback express the strongly held philosophy of the coalition that parents have the right to choose a school for their children which reflects their values. We have also been concerned for some time at the very great demands being made on parents and communities to support the building of new schools and to refurbish existing schools. The requirement for infrastructure has increased substantially because of the higher retention rates and changing curriculum requirements in these schools. The real annual value of the non-government schools capital works grant has declined by almost 30 per cent under this Labor Government over the last 10 years.

The coalition believes that the community interest in a viable and high quality non-government schools sector is no longer being adequately addressed in the capital works program. Accordingly, the incoming Liberal and National Party government will double the annual size of capital grants programs for non-government schools from its 1991 level to $162m a year. The increased payment under the program will commence in the 1993-94 year. This level of grant will still require a substantial contribution to capital development from parents and communities supporting non-government schools. However, the current burden will be greatly alleviated by this increase in funding.

Therefore, it can be clearly seen that only the coalition has the policies to help the embattled non-government schools sector as we offer a dramatic increase in financial support. The Minister's response before the Senate today does not propose this and only provides that the Government has very little commitment to support the private education sector. I feel that it will pay for this attitude at the ballot box.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
