PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Order! On behalf of the President, in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Audit Report No. 43, 1991-92, Project Audit, Department of Administrative Services, Conflict of Interest: A matter of principle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet again, I would like to congratulate the Auditor-General in taking up the matter of a conflict of interest within the Department of Administrative Services. I highlighted this issue some 18 months ago when the Department, through its information technology section, entered into joint ventures with companies in the private sector. At the time I made the remark that this put the Government and the Department in an impossible situation. It meant that the Department whose major function was to purchase information technology and computer-type equipment was in partnership with others in the public sector and thereby quoting for business while it sat in judgment of the tenders. The audit report states:

The ANAO has also suggested that reforms and changes to the public sector should appropriately weigh and balance their effect on important and long-standing principles such as public accountability, equity, integrity, ethical standards and due process.
I drew attention to equity, integrity and ethical standards some 18 months ago. The overview of the audit report goes on to point out:

PARA.TAB: The reforms which have taken place have required public sector managers and regulators to focus on and give greater attention to issues like risk management, meeting client needs, standards of public sector conduct and behaviour vis-a-vis the private sector and conflicts or potential conflicts between regulatory and commercial responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraph 3 of the overview points out that the involvement of the Department of Administrative Services in the acquisition of IT as a tenderer and an adviser raises the question of conflict of interest. As you would know, Madam Acting Deputy President, it is important that a government have propriety and probity, particularly when it comes to matters such as purchasing. If that collapses, the whole substance of that government being a major purchaser goes into jeopardy. Paragraph 4 of the overview states:
The Government also determined that DAS:
.could continue to provide advice to agencies on IT acquisitions on a fee for service basis

.could tender for public sector IT business either through joint ventures or in its own right where it could be established that DAS enjoyed no special advantages by virtue of its position as a Government department.
That is where the conflict of interest lies. The audit report also points out:

PARA.TAB: One of the principles embodied in the Code for dealing with a potential conflict of interest is for the separation within the organisation of the organisational units involved in the activities which give rise to the potential conflict.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter has been discussed at a series of Estimates committees. The Department has claimed that it can put up what it calls `Chinese walls'—that a barrier can be set up between the various sectors of the Department, thus giving credibility to one part of the organisation buying and the other part supplying. The Audit report states:
. . . the establishment of `chinese walls' does not in this case resolve completely the potential for conflict of interest.
That is a point that we on this side have been making for the past couple of years. The report continues:
The ANAO believes, therefore, that DAS should be divested of one of the roles it performs in IT acquisitions, perhaps to another agency within the same portfolio.

I have some problems with that. It seems to me that DAS has no role in the provision of services; it has a major role in the acquisition of services. More importantly, the Department, in its purchasing function, must be seen to be absolutely above reproach.

PARA.TAB: It is my view, and the view of the Opposition, that the role of government should be to acquire the essential goods and services with probity and propriety. No matter what safeguards are in place, what Chinese walls are erected, if DAS is in partnership with any organisation in the private sector and is successful in bidding for government tenders on which it itself has a role to play, there is no way in the world that anyone in the private sector will believe that the decision was above board. I am amazed that the Department persists in going down this track; if this were done in the private sector, it would be the subject of investigation. It is absolutely impossible for a person to be the buyer and the seller, particularly with the large amount of money and the sort of equipment which is involved within the public sector. For the Government to go into partnership with the private sector is absolutely reprehensible.

I was visited by one of the participants with the Government. That participant—it was a reputable company—put to me the argument that it was in partnership not so much to obtain business in Australia but because it was thought that it might be of benefit to be joined with the Government when tendering overseas where government participation was seen as being a plus. I do not think anyone could swallow that. It is totally irresponsible. Rather than having, as is suggested by the Auditor-General, a separate section of the Department do it—I guess he means that the purchasing department of DAS do it rather than the information technology section—it would seem that the Government should get out of these commercial operations and address itself to acquiring the essential goods and services it needs for the operation of government. If the Department takes that route, it will save the taxpayer millions and millions of dollars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join Senator Parer in speaking to Audit Report No. 43, 1991-92. I stress the importance of this report. Senator Parer has made a first class case as to why a government department, morally, ought not to be involved with a joint venture in the private sector. The concept that a department can somehow erect a Chinese wall and have its functions seen as being proper is just not possible.

PARA.TAB: I thought the Auditor-General, in recommendation 6, was trying to say that something had to be done about the situation. He said:
The ANAO also recommends that the question of organisational conflict of interest be examined by Government with a view to a policy being developed on it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Audit Office recognises the problem and the fact that government, as a matter of policy, has decided that it is okay for these joint ventures to take place. The Auditor-General is saying that he wants the Department and the Government to look at the question again so that they may come to a different conclusion. The response of DAS to the recommendation is this:

PARA.TAB: Not accepted. DAS advised that it considers the policies and practices it has in place are fully effective for the purpose of dealing with any real potential for conflict of interest.

SPEECH.PARA: That is clearly nonsense. DAS continues:

DAS accepts, however, the external perceptions that a potential for conflict exists, and needs to be addressed. Accordingly, the Department has changed its structure to impose greater organisational separation between the area providing IT procurement advice and the area providing IT services. The procurement function will be part of a newly established `Office of Purchasing', responsible directly to the Secretary of the Department.

That is not adequate. Let us understand the mammoth amounts of money we are talking about. Last year—and it took me a long time to find these figures—the Federal Government and its agencies spent $4.1 billion on IT procurement.

PARA.TAB: Part of the problem with the procurement of IT by the Federal Government—I exclude some of the agencies from these comments—is the fact that we do not have accrual accounting. That means that in a single year under cash accounting a department can buy IT, it has a value in that year, and an appropriation is required. The next year it has no value at all; it does not have to be accounted for. Until such time as we move to full accrual accounting, we will not know whether purchases of information technology are necessary, being utilised, effective, and accomplishing whatever the aim was that they set out to achieve.

Once upon a time, large purchasers of ADP, as it used to be called, were subject to scrutiny by the Public Accounts Committee. Indeed, that was a task that first got me interested and made me learn about computer technology when I first came into this Parliament because I was required to sit on a committee dealing with the approval of those purchases. That function has now gone from the Public Accounts Committee and has been replaced by the creation of ADP acquisition councils which are meant to oversight the purchase of expensive information technology.

Later in the day I will table a report concerning the Department of Defence and the acquisition of information technology. Anybody who reads that report, which has taken a long time to compile, will see the many problems that are inherent in departments' acquisition of information technology and the failure of those councils to work effectively.

The Auditor-General in directing people's attention to this conflict of interest has done a great service. Certainly it highlights for me the need to look at the policies of procurement as a whole. I feel that since the time we moved away from the previous situation where procurement was governed by finance regulations, we now have the situation where the guidelines as published are just that—guidelines. They are not subject to tabling and disallowance.

There is a great deal of disquiet in the way that it is open, should someone wish to do so, for a person in the public sector to draw up his own favourite list and ask his first best friend and two or three others to register expressions of interest in a field in which clearly they have no competency. The evaluation process then becomes meaningless. I would recommend that there be a great deal of investigation, and perhaps the implementation of a two-stage tender process to avert the enormous cost that can be run up where a large tender is to be dealt with. I cite examples of the Tax Office procurement of information technology worth about $1 billion. It can cost a competing firm in excess of $1m or $2m or $3m to prepare a tender. If one were to look more at the process of a two-stage tender under which the first stage is wide open and where in the second stage, dealing with the more technical matters, a smaller group would be involved, I feel the process would be much fairer.

I have grave concerns about the way the procurement process now operates where the Government through its departments spends in excess of $8 billion annually on procurement. Those opposite cannot tell me the temptations are not there. In this whole area of information technology where we see arguments coming from Australian manufacturers that they are disadvantaged in competition with overseas manufacturers, it can be quite attractive to someone who wants to buy information technology to have written into a contract by the supplier that at the supplier's expense there will be need, for instance, to go to Paris twice a year to consult on the most up-to-date methods concerning that purchase. I really think there is a need to look again at the system of procurement. It needs to be tightened up so that there are not abuses of the system.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—On behalf of the President, in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901 I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 51 of 1991-92—Project Audits—Industry, Technology and Commerce Portfolio—Australian Customs Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901 I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 52 of 1991-92—Efficiency Audit—Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs—Information Technology Management.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly, I will quote the report's key findings. These were:
.IT system development methods in DILGEA have been ad hoc and inconsistent in the way systems were documented, programs written and projects managed.
.The consequences for DILGEA have been delays in improving services, such as processing international passengers at entry points, and additional costs in bringing new systems into production.
.The lack of in-house standards and consistency in systems could lead to difficulties in future maintenance of systems, and in DILGEA's current plans for greater integration of its current systems.
.Changes to systems in production are not adequately controlled and documented.
.There was scope for greater participation by user management groups in the development and maintenance of systems.
.There were no firm agreements between IT management and users on acceptable levels of service in terms of system operation.
.Better accountability of IT providers to user groups would provide a means of ensuring that systems are meeting user needs and the agreed system requirement.

.There was limited quality control of systems developed in-house. Apart from Internal Audit activities which commenced recently, there was no review of practices for compliance with acceptable standards.
.Disaster recovery planning was limited. However, many systems must be capable of 24-hour and remote operation to support program management, particularly in the control of entry to Australia.
They are fairly damaging comments about the in-house development. On the implementation of the purchase system, NOMAD, the Audit Office found:
.Users had difficulties in operating the personnel management system, and had avoided controls and manually duplicated some system functions.
.Users needed training in the system and a larger commitment by management was necessary for the system to work effectively.
.There had been no evaluation of whether the personnel system had met the cost and efficiency aims held for it, after being in place for over two years.

It seems the old classic situation, namely, `We cannot deal with you as efficiently as we did in the past because we have introduced a computer'. That is what this report seems to be saying about the Department of Immigration in various matters. It seems to me most unfortunate and there is clearly a need for an improvement. In fact, the Audit Office says:

The ANAO is concerned that the IT management deficiencies found at DILGEA could be a reflection of a wider problem in Departments, in a lack of recognition that IT development groups should be principally responsible to operational user groups for the provision of services. This relationship, backed up by accountability, is the best guarantee that expensive IT systems meet user requirements in a cost effective way.

PARA.TAB: I want to make the final point that, as I mentioned earlier, the Audit Office ordered the implementation of the personnel system widely used in the Department, and found considerable user difficulty with the system. The system was not providing the necessary level of support to users, resulting in avoidance of controls and manual duplication of system functions. There were substantial gaps in user knowledge of the capabilities of the system and evidence that users had encountered operational difficulties in the day to day use of the system.

This personnel system had been in operation for over two years. There had been no evaluation of how effective its introduction had been in meeting the original aims of automating the personnel function and saving resources. The Audit Office doubted that it had achieved these aims and recommended that such an evaluation should be accorded priority in view of the substantial increase in support departmental users would need to help them work effectively within the system. The Department has agreed to this.

As the Auditor-General says, this problem is not just confined to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, but it could be a reflection of a wider problem in departments. It seems most unfortunate that when these expensive systems are introduced, there has not been an effective and proper utilisation of the systems, nor training for the systems, nor determination of the proper methods to be applied in using these systems.

I do not know to what extent the responses to the Auditor-General's reports are going to encourage departments to be more efficient and more effective, and to save taxpayers' money, but there is no doubt we should be grateful to the Auditor-General for once again drawing to the Parliament's attention some serious failures in achieving what should be greater efficiencies within departments. Some Ministers get up and say, `There is no way we can save money', and sneer at Opposition insistence that government has to become more efficient and that money that is being wasted can be saved under such proposals as Fightback. Yet the Auditor-General is demonstrating that waste and inefficiency is going on within the Government. Quite frankly, it is about time the Government really did something serious about it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—On behalf of the President, in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901 I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 53 of 1991-92—Efficiency Audit—Australian Customs Service—Accommodation, Victoria: Lexington Building.
At the request of the Auditor-General, I will also read a letter that the President received from him with the report. The letter states:

PROCTEXT.PARA: In accordance with the authority contained in the Audit Act 1901, I today approved for transmittal to the Parliament my report of an investigation undertaken in the Australian Customs Service in respect of accommodation in Victoria, carried out under the provisions of the Audit Act and other Acts.

I must inform the Parliament that doubt has been expressed by the Attorney-General's Department about my power under the Audit Act to report project performance audits individually where a report to it is not part of or supplementary to the report on the aggregate financial statements. If this view is correct it would mean that Parliament would not receive timely and more accessible reports other than for efficiency audits which would continue to be tabled separately. All substantial project audits would, perforce, have to await tabling of the aggregate financial statement report late in the Budget Sittings of each year.

This would seriously impede my ability to meet the public interest through independent public reporting in a timely manner to the Parliament and would set back the improvements in reporting which the Australian National Audit Office has introduced since Report No.296 of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts.

This reinforces the need to put greater priority on the introduction of the proposed new Auditor-General Act so that the question of reporting and other important issues can be considered by the Parliament against current circumstances. Failing that, an immediate amendment of the current Act to rectify the apparent deficiency would seem necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the dinner adjournment I sought leave to move a motion in respect of the Auditor-General's Report No. 53. I will now speak to that motion. I do so with a sense of irony in that earlier in the day I was speaking about the rort, as I have called it, of the lease that has been entered into between the Labor Party and the Commonwealth in order to provide accommodation for the Australian National Audit Office. When I say that I am speaking on this report with a sense of irony, it is because this report deals with the Australian Customs Service and its accommodation, and the controversy that arose with regard to the selection of consultants and the selection of the building in which it was chosen to take out a lease for the Australian Customs Service.

PARA.TAB: I want to read from page 26 of the report, which is a letter from the Auditor-General to none other than Senator Bolkus. Senator Bolkus referred this matter to the Auditor-General for investigation. Had the Labor Party not tainted the Auditor-General, wittingly or unwittingly, I would have referred the matter of the Labor Party lease to the Commonwealth—where there is a non-commercial lease entered into which will render a capital profit in one year of $15m and $58m over 15 years—to the Auditor-General, just as Senator Bolkus has. But, because of the nature of that lease, in my estimation the Auditor-General has been placed in jeopardy. Therefore, I am unable to refer the matter to the Auditor-General for him to investigate. It is a most deplorable set of circumstances. Therefore, we have to find another avenue to find the truth of the matter of just how this gift of taxpayers' money to the Australian Labor Party has been brought about.
I want to read this letter from the Auditor-General. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Minister—

he wrote this on 14 May 1992, which is literally a month after the agreement for lease was signed to put the Auditor-General in the situation of being a tenant of the Australian Labor Party. The letter continues:

Thank you for your letter of 12 May 1992 requesting the Australian National Audit Office. . . to investigate certain matters relating to the selection of new accommodation for the Australian Customs Service in Melbourne.
The ANAO will conduct an investigation and provide a report to Mr Beddall pursuant to sub-section 54(2)(c) of the Audit Act 1901.

In the context of the terms of reference outlined in your letter I am advised that the relevant provisions of the Lands Acquisition Act provide that you need to be satisfied that the acquisition amounts to a normal commercial transaction between parties dealing with each other on equal terms.
I will read that again:
. . . you need to be satisfied—
that is the Minister, Senator Bolkus—
that the acquisition—
that is the acquisition of the lease—
amounts to a normal commercial transaction between parties dealing with each other on equal terms.

This is what the Auditor-General is being asked to do and that is what he set out to do. Yet in his own premises, where he will now be obliged to reside, we have a lease which is way outside the normal terms and conditions set for leases. There is a bankable arrangement which means that had the agreement to lease not been signed, the Labor Party could not have afforded to build its building. The agreement to lease was signed on 8 April 1992 and the first sod was turned on 24 April 1992. No lease, no building—courtesy of the taxpayer. Yet here is the Auditor-General being asked to investigate and give a report to the Minister that he could be satisfied that the acquisition amounts to a normal commercial transaction. He goes on to say:
I intend at this stage that the ANAO report will address whether:
(a) the selection of the property consultant—

and in the case of the Audit Office it was the Australian Property Group, which is merely a real estate consultant, in the terms of the letter of the Department of Finance commenting on the lease between the ALP and the Commonwealth regarding the Australian National Audit Office. The Auditor-General is being asked to investigate whether:
. . . the selection of the property consultant and the processes leading to the recommendation to lease
the Lexington Building were in accordance with Customs' policies and procedures and government procurement policy, including the requirement to obtain value for money;

In this place today I lodged documentation that showed the statement of this same Minister, Senator Bolkus. He said that the agreement negotiated is to the benefit of the Commonwealth. It is not. It is to the advantage of the Australian Labor Party. There are many questions that have to be asked as to how that Minister allowed himself and his Department to get into that situation. The letter continues:
(b) the processes followed by the property consultant resulted in fair treatment of all of the tenderers;

Honourable senators will remember, in the case of the Australian Labor Party building, that there were 14 expressions of interest; only 13 were sent. The fourteenth, being the Labor Party one, was not sent. It was communicated in a private conversation of which there is no record, and the Labor Party was not disclosed as the landlord or the owner. The Audit Office believed, until months afterwards, that it was Lend Lease who was the landlord.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General has been asked to make a judgment and make inquiries about all sorts of things that he ought to be ordinarily making inquiries about, with regard to the lease that he has found himself tangled in. The letter continues:

SPEECH.PARA: (c) there was any potential conflict of interest involving a former Customs officer,

Here is the question of conflict of interest. Here we have the situation of Minister Bolkus consorting with Mr Hogg, his old factional mate, and at the same time those two were forcing through this Parliament the disclosure legislation; and at the same time they were manoeuvring and arriving at a situation which, if looked at in true terms, could possibly be described as corrupt. Those questions remain to be answered, yet we cannot ask the Auditor-General to do it because he has now become the tenant of the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: He is also asked to investigate in this matter of the Australian Customs Service whether:

SPEECH.PARA: (d) there are any other matters which may warrant investigation by other Commonwealth agencies.

I note your request for our investigation to be completed in two weeks. Because of the importance of your request, the ANAO will take all reasonable steps to finalise the investigation as quickly as is possible. This has meant rearranging our priorities including mandatory financial statement work and some project reports which will result in some deadlines not being met. A reference to the results of this investigation, in an appropriate form, will be included in a report to the Parliament in due course.
I have written in similar terms to Mr Beddall . . .

In the course of this investigation, the Auditor-General commented on the role of the Australian Property Group. So did Mr McPhee from the Department of Finance. He observed that the Australian Property Group acts as a real estate agent and charges fees for the management of property. When one reads the correspondence of how the Australian Property Group was coercing the Australian National Audit Office into accepting this proposition once it knew it was the Labor Party, one will see that it is acting like a real estate agent with a commercial angle.

PARA.TAB: Let me tell honourable senators what the Auditor-General had to say about the Australian Property Group in the inquiry regarding the rental of the Lexington Building as accommodation for the Australian Customs Service—and there have been many complaints about this lease. He found:

SPEECH.PARA: The ANAO identified that the APG involvement in this matter was three-fold:
.as an unsuccessful tenderer for the initial property consultancy
. as an unsuccessful tenderer for the leased accommodation representing the Casselden Building, and
. as advisor to Government in respect of approvals required under the Lands Acquisition Act.
Now here is the nub of what he had to say. He said:
The ANAO believed that the APG found itself placed in a difficult position as there was a clear conflict of interest involved—
just as there was a clear conflict of interest involved with regard to Senator Bolkus and the Australian Labor Party becoming the landlord of the Audit Office—a very large conflict of interest.

PARA.TAB: We have Senator Bolkus, a Minister of the Crown who is required to oversight the activities of the Australian Property Group and the Australian Estate Management group, which refused to give permission initially, corresponding with the Department of Finance without disclosing the ALP's involvement. And any appraisal of all the correspondence which is tabled will show subterfuge and coercion. The Australian Property Group, which is criticised in this report as having a conflict of interest, is the same Australian Property Group which any reading of the correspondence shows was tending to push the Australian National Audit Office into panic and into pleading with the Department of Finance to give it approval to move into this building, which it finally did.

I repeat: no lease, no building; no building, no $15.4m profit the minute it is completed if the Labor Party wants to sell it. In the meantime, it has a pipeline to the Mint, a guaranteed cash flow by way of rentals which is larger than any reasonable appraisal of the repayments it will have to make to the Macquarie Bank which financed the deal. Let me read on:

SPEECH.PARA: The ANAO considered that because of this conflict the APG may not have been in a position or perceived to be in a position to provide full and objective advice to the Minister for Administrative Services in the context of the Lands Acquisition Act. APG at times provided qualified responses to questions—
`qualified responses to questions', just as all its advice was to the Audit Office—

it was asked due to the multiple roles it performed and because it was not party to the full details of the transaction. As a result, there could have been a perception that it had some doubts about the transaction.
This report is all about conflict of interest. It is all about propriety.

PARA.TAB: As I said, the real irony is that normally this 15-year guaranteed lease with a five-year option to extend to 20 years, and a rental with a 9 per cent annual increment with only the lessor, not the lessee, having the right to review the rent, will result in a figure in excess of $100m being paid to the Labor Party in rent. The documents that I tabled in this place earlier today show that no other government department which has leased property in the surrounding area, the same area, has had a lease of similar terms, length or conditions.

The Minister was at great pains here today to say that he had negotiated a clever deal and he had had $400,000 put towards the fitout of the building. What he neglected to also tell us was that the Department of Finance is providing a further $3m for the rest of the fitout. What do honourable senators think $400,000 is going to buy for a fitout besides power points and a few extra leads? It sure is not going to provide for any partitions or any of the fundamental things that are regarded as essential to a fitout. Three million dollars from the taxpayer and $400,000 from the developer—and the Minister tells us that it is a good deal!

It will cost over $17m—a generous amount—to develop the building. The building would be able to be sold for in excess of $33m the day it is completed, giving a clear profit of $15m. If the Labor Party holds it for an extra year, the profit will be $17m; if it holds it for five years, it will be $29m. This amount will increase until the end of the lease after 15 years and probably five years beyond that. At 15 years there will be a property mark-up of $58m—a nice little laundering exercise of taxpayers' money through the Australian National Audit Office to the Australian Labor Party so that it can circumvent its own legislation on disclosure and have plenty of cash for its war chest.

One might ask oneself about conspiracy. One might ask oneself about propriety of behaviour. One might ask oneself what conversations took place between the Minister and Mr Hogg. One might ask oneself how we are going to determine what really went on. The proper procedure is to pursue these matters through the Australian National Audit Office, just as the Minister wrote to the Auditor-General and asked him to investigate the circumstances surrounding the lease of the building in Melbourne for the Australian Customs Service. Yet I cannot refer these matters to the Auditor-General for the simple reason that, by virtue of the Labor Party's actions, by first deceiving him and the Department of Finance, the Auditor-General has been put in a compromised position. I cannot say with a greater sense of sadness how that offends me.

The Australian Audit Office, headed by the Auditor-General, is the linchpin between the Parliament and public expenditure. Yet the Minister has found a way around that. At the same time as he is ramming down our throats the need for disclosure and telling the public that ad bans are in their interests, he is working out a system to launder taxpayers' money, through the Audit Office being a tenant of the Australian Labor Party, into the war chest and the pockets of the Labor Party to spend. So there we have it. We have to find a way of investigating this matter. There are so many questions to be answered that it must remain a very topical and important item on the agenda of this place.

This Auditor-General's report is first class work, as are the other reports that he gives us. How dare this Government place the Auditor-General in a situation where he is compromised. It is not putting it too strongly to say that this is a tragedy. As I said, this is an important report for us to look at because it shows that this Government has, for its own financial gain, manoeuvred itself, by false pretences, into a situation where the taxpayer will be paying for its election war chest.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning we began with a fatuous debate which was full of humbug. This afternoon we received two reports of the Auditor-General—Conflict of interest: A matter of principle and the detailed findings on the accommodation in Victoria of the Lexington Building. All that we said this morning about a code of conduct and so on cannot be dealt with by committee, by legislation, by Parliament, if the will of the people concerned is not bona fide.

PARA.TAB: We now have the report, Conflict of interest: A matter of principle. It is a matter of principle; it is a matter of how the people involved conduct their own principles. The principles are very clear to everybody and it is time that this Parliament understood them completely.

The details of the findings in regard to the Lexington Building have already been stated. Those findings throw up a few direct questions for which answers are necessary and which, if necessary, we may well have to put on notice.

Reading the detailed audit findings that applied to Customs raises the following questions: were the leasing processes in accordance with the departmental and/or Audit Office policy, including the requirement to obtain value for money? Did they comply with the conditions of the Land Acquisition Act 1989? Is the issue of value for money stated in the procedures or is it simply implied? Did the processes followed by the property consultants result in the fair treatment of the various tenderers and parties involved? Was there any potential conflict of interest involved in the leasing arrangements? These questions were raised with regard to Customs; why would they not be just as logical and just as pertinent in the case in hand?

Obviously, the Audit Office cannot audit itself. Any fair-minded person who has any interest in anything to do with conflict of interest, matters of principle, matters of audit, matters of value, matters of what is fair and reasonable, and value for money as far as the Commonwealth is concerned, would be covered in this way, but it has been prejudiced. It is absolutely necessary that there be an independent adjudication and, presumably, the easiest way for the Government is through a parliamentary committee. At this stage, I will leave it to the Government to do this. It does not comply with the minimum standards that would apply in any other case, and it needs to be dealt with accordingly.

I am very sorry that it comes up; I am sorry that it needs to be discussed; and I am sorry that the Government tabled these reports today. It is typical of the absolutely appalling management that we have had from the Government in the last week or so and, as I have suspected, for the last couple of weeks. Every time we have talked about the program for the final part of these sittings, I have said, `How many reports do you think are likely to come down on the last day that will need to be dealt with?'. All these time schedules that we have seen have never taken into account the stupidity of bringing down 13 reports that require debate on the last day.

How darned foolish can it be to fall for a stupid thing like this on the last day of sitting. So be it. This is the way the Government chooses to run things, and the reports include this one that has direct reference to the question that we have been debating over the last few weeks. I will leave it to the Government to decide what it is going to do. I expect an answer as to how it is going to tidy this up in accordance with its own rules, regulations and reports. That is all I ask for. I do not regard this as a witch hunt. All I want is to see that it is done in accordance with the proper routines.

I do have an advantage in that I have been involved in property rentals and management for a long time—or I was; I am not now. I do understand how these things work. I also support things said earlier about various clauses and conditions of the lease, which I have never, in all my wildest dreams, imagined could appear in a lease that would involve the Commonwealth Government and the taxpayers of Australia. In the meantime, I have mentioned the questions that I intended to ask, and I will be putting them down unless we receive answers to them.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: On 12 November 1990 the Senate referred the following matter to the Standing Committee of Privileges:
Having regard to the report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority presented on 17 October 1990:
(a)whether there was improper interference with a person in respect of evidence to be given before that Committee;

(b)whether false or misleading evidence was given to that Committee in respect of directions given by the National Crime Authority or its officers to a person, affecting evidence to be given before the Committee; and
(c)whether contempts were committed in relation to those matters.

The inquiry associated with this report has been surprisingly lengthy and arduous, involving almost a half-century of deliberative meetings and two public hearings, which were notable for the phalanx of highly qualified legal practitioners in attendance. The Committee was again assisted by Mr Theodore Simos QC, whose incisive work in connection with the hearings is gratefully acknowledged. There is much more that needs to be said about a reference which took 19 months, 48 meetings of the Privileges Committee of the Senate and the participation of at least six QCs, but not today in deference to the pressure on the Senate's time.

PARA.TAB: The Committee has ultimately concluded, as stated at paragraph 4.15, that it should not find that a contempt has been committed in respect of any of the matters referred to it by the Senate for reasons which are set out in the report, particularly at paragraphs 6 to 11 of chapter 4. Nonetheless, it is seriously perturbed about a number of issues arising from its consideration of the matters referred to it, and the recommendations set out in paragraph 16 of chapter 4 reflect those concerns which are discussed in more detail in the body of the report.

I acknowledge with gratitude the unfailing, high quality support of Anne Lynch, the Committee Secretary and Deputy Clerk of the Senate, and the staff and members of the Senate establishment, who periodically were placed under intense pressure and who performed admirably. My personal indebtedness is also due to all members of the Committee for their tireless work and their generous contribution of their respective political, industrial and professional skills. In order to place the recommendations of the Committee on the public record immediately, I seek leave to incorporate the recommendations in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The recommendations read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendations
4.16The Committee recommends as follows:

PARA.TAB: 1.That the Senate endorse the finding in paragraph 4.15.

2.That, in so far as there may be some imprecision in the terminology of sections 51 and 55 of the National Crime Authority Act 1984, appropriate legislative steps should be taken to clarify the matters of concern, as foreshadowed in the Government's response to the PJC's report, "Who is to guard the guards?", tabled in the Senate on 1 June 1992. [paragraph 3.23]

3.That care should be taken, during passage through the Parliament of legislation which may include provisions comparable to those which have caused concern, to resolve any conflict between provisions which lay down guidelines for accountability of bodies to the Parliament and obligations to protect confidential information and privacy. [paragraph 3.26]
4.That it might be appropriate for the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills to draw such provisions to the attention of members of the Parliament. [paragraph 3.27]
5.That the Parliament should give urgent and serious priority to considering legislation such as the Parliament Privileges Amendment (Effect of Other Laws) Bill 1991. [paragraph 3.27]

6.That the Senate should warn persons dealing with Houses of Parliament and their committees that they have an obligation to direct their attention to the real effects of their actions, and in particular to ensure that they give answers to committees as fully and frankly as possible, without recourse to legalistic or bureaucratic casuistry. [paragraph 4.13]

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Coates, the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, I seek leave to make a statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Coates, I seek leave to have this statement incorporated in Hansard.
—What's it about? Do we know?
—Yes, it is about Commonwealth bodies whose annual reports are not tabled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: COMMONWEALTH BODIES WHOSE ANNUAL REPORTS ARE NOT TABLED IN PARLIAMENT
Statement by Senator John Coates,
Chair, Senate Standing Committee
on Finance and Public Administration

PARA.TAB: On 14 December 1989 the Senate adopted a nine-part resolution concerning the examination of annual reports by Senate legislative and general purpose standing committees. Amongst other matters, the resolution required that I, in my capacity as Chair of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, after consulting with the chairs of the other standing committees and having regard to the list of statutory authorities, non-statutory bodies and companies maintained by the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, present to the Senate each year a report indicating whether there are any bodies which do not present annual reports to the Senate and which should present such reports (Journals of the Senate 1989, p. 2378).

It is my view that it is a minimum requirement of proper accountability that all government bodies which operate as discrete entities should report annually to Parliament on their operations, irrespective of any legislative requirement for them to do so. On this basis, the Committee staff have compiled lists per portfolio of bodies which have apparently not reported and I have circulated these lists to the relevant standing committee chairs for comment.

The comment, both formal and informal, that I have received to date has led me to defer making a definitive report on non-reporting bodies at this stage. There appears to be some lack of agreement on a number of fundamental issues, issues which in my view warrant further examination. They include the following: the Government's exclusions from its definition of non-statutory bodies; the reporting of Government companies; and the reporting of minor or inactive statutory authorities. Differing views also emerged on what degree of compliance with the Government's reporting requirements actually constitutes reporting. The question of separate reporting, as opposed to reporting within the annual report of a related body, was also of concern.

At present, for example, Commonwealth State bodies and ministerial councils are exempted from the Government's reporting requirements for non-statutory bodies. Nevertheless quite detailed reporting is provided by some such bodies; the resolutions of others are tabled; and yet others do not even acknowledge their existence. Companies limited by guarantee present special problems. In some cases, this corporate form has been chosen to carry out a function which is mainly a Commonwealth initiative or is mainly funded by the Commonwealth. In other cases, the involvement of the Commonwealth in the company is merely as one of several significant parties and funding is not primarily supplied by the Government. While the basic assumption that all such companies should report to Parliament has received support, the issue of the nature and extent of their reporting is one that requires more deliberation.

While the number of bodies not reporting is small compared to the total (and the number of significant ones is smaller still), I am concerned that there are some Commonwealth bodies which are apparently not meeting their responsibility to account properly to the Parliament for their activities. I am also mindful of the already heavy burden of paperwork which we as senators are subjected to and I do not wish to add to that load unnecessarily.
I propose, therefore, to consider these matters further and to report further on them in the Budget sitting period.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 317th report of the Committee on the defence supply systems redevelopment project. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The report which I have just tabled on behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Accounts presents the Committee's findings and recommendations on an inquiry into the Department of Defence supply system redevelopment project or, as it has become more commonly known, SSRP. SSRP aims to create a common core computing system to cater for the supply needs of the Australian Defence Force. The title of the report, A champagne taste on a beer income, sums up SSRP. It is a project which seeks to do too much. Having commenced in the mid-1970s, SSRP is not scheduled for completion until 1998.

PARA.TAB: DESINE, which has become the contract central to SSRP, is an important element. SSRP is closely linked to another defence project, namely project DESINE. A significant amount of the Committee's inquiry was taken up examining various aspects of the DESINE contract—a five-year contract with IBM which makes IBM the sole supplier of computing equipment for Defence up until February 1994. Although the DESINE request for tender explicitly set out a requirement for network architecture supporting open systems, the Department of Defence was later to describe the solution it acquired through the DESINE contract as an implementation of systems application architecture, or SAA as it is more commonly known—an IBM proprietary architecture.

I will tell people what that means. Proprietary architecture is designed, basically, to ensure that purchasers buy only one brand name. Open systems, to which this Government is committed, is a policy whereby one is able to buy many brands and have them interlinked. That is perhaps an oversimplification, but that is the distinction.

The current trend in computing is towards open systems. By this I mean a situation where different computer networks can talk to each other and where applications or programs can be moved from one brand of computer to another without change. The Committee was concerned by the possibility that the Department of Defence could be unable to move from IBM equipment at the end of the DESINE contract without incurring untenable costs and delays through having to redevelop all the systems developed under IBM's systems application architecture. The Committee believes the Department's commitment to IBM, and more particularly to SAA, unless carefully managed, will leave it with no easy path to open systems and other vendors' solutions, and thus competition.

The operating system most commonly associated with open systems is called Unix and throughout the inquiry there was considerable debate on the role of the Unix operating system in the DESINE environment. This issue was not resolved to the satisfaction of the Committee and the Committee remains concerned about the manner in which Unix solutions were passed over in the initial tendering process. The Committee is of the view that a departmental working party, known as the Unix working party, should be reactivated to explore options for the introduction of alternative Unix solutions.

The Committee concludes that with the DESINE request for tender the Department set out with a clear intention to support international standards for open systems, but that the outcome of the tendering process left it with an unsatisfactory solution. At best, IBM may prove SAA to support open systems and, at worst, the Department has acquired a proprietary architecture which directly supports only IBM proprietary products.

Examination of the DESINE request for tender has drawn the Committee's attention to the fact that billions of dollars are spent on information technology by the Commonwealth each year but that very little is known about the equipment and systems owned by the Commonwealth departments. To remedy this situation the Committee has recommended that departmental annual reports contain a comprehensive listing of current information technology assets—the listing to detail the quantity and current value of these assets.

The DESINE contract contains a clause which makes IBM the sole supplier under the contract. This clause was the basis of much questioning during the inquiry as the Committee sought to ascertain why it was written into the contract. It became apparent that, from the view of the Department of Defence, having a contract with one vendor would enable it more effectively to achieve its standardised computing environment.

The sole supplier clause is linked to another clause which the Committee believes was inserted into the contract in an attempt to lessen the effect of the sole supplier clause. The question of whether the second clause was enforceable was also raised by the Committee but was not resolved to its satisfaction.

The Committee is of the view that no future information technology acquisition contract should contain a sole supplier clause, nor should any such contract be written so that another sole supplier situation can eventuate. Of the DESINE contract itself, the Committee believes that a contract like this must never, ever be entered into by the Commonwealth again. While it is right and proper that a commercial organisation such as IBM should negotiate the best contract for itself, the Commonwealth must also maintain strength and expertise in its negotiating. The Committee sees that there are significant problems when the negotiating skills of the Commonwealth are not up to scratch and, regrettably, this appears to have been the situation in the case of DESINE.

Turning to the supply systems redevelopment project, the Committee considers that the achievements of the project have not been encouraging. In fact the Committee is quite critical of the administration and global management of the project. Little progress can be identified prior to 1988 and even since then the project has lacked continuous momentum.

The Committee found that throughout the life of SSRP, its subprojects have continually fallen behind schedule. The three main causes of slippage were: difficulties in staffing the project, a scarcity of funds, and overly optimistic assessments of what subproject deadlines should be. The Committee's assessment is that the slippage is to a large extent the result of poor administration and management of the project at a global level.

The common core approach of SSRP—that is, the development of a single computer based system to satisfy the core supply requirements of all three Services—is considered by the Committee to have had a major impact on the progress of SSRP. While there is potential for considerable cost saving in this approach, the Committee believes that it has imposed a level of complexity on the project which would not otherwise have existed.

The Committee is not convinced that the common core approach is best for Defence. It considers that there is insufficient evidence to show that the common core approach will produce a system in a reasonable time frame and with a positive cost benefit ratio which will effectively satisfy the requirements of the Department and the three Services. Cost estimates of the project have been of continuing concern to the Committee. Six analyses of costs and benefits for SSRP were provided to the Committee. Inconsistencies in these analyses caused the Committee some concern and led it to conclude that SSRP's costings are not accurate.

The situation is further clouded by recent advice from the Department that benefits will be adversely affected by other departmental initiatives such as the Force Structure Review. The Committee sees that there is an urgent need for the SSRP Prime Systems Integrator, the body which is responsible for ensuring the operation and compatibility of equipment and systems purchased for SSRP, to provide updated cost estimates for the project.

During the inquiry a significant amount of evidence was received about the level of effort that the Department of Defence places on effective project management for SSRP. The success of high cost complex projects such as this relies heavily on effective project management. In the case of SSRP the Committee found that there did not appear to be a management tool which was consistently applied to ensure dependent activities were completed in an orderly fashion.

The Committee is particularly concerned that there is a significant commitment by the Department of Defence to the long term engagement of consultants and contractors for the implementation of the project. The Committee is of the view that the engagement of consultants and contractors should be for specifically designated tasks which are both measurable and to be achieved over a fixed period. It is of paramount importance that the necessary skills transfer to the departmental staff occur when there is an ongoing requirement for those skills. There is a significant benefit to be gained from the external scrutiny of major projects being undertaken by Commonwealth agencies and the Committee considers that external review of SSRP and DESINE should not stop with the completion of this inquiry.

The inquiry into SSRP has been one of the more complex and technical inquiries to be conducted by the Committee. It required the examination of a number of difficult information technology issues upon which even experts could not agree. With the finalisation of the inquiry with this report, it is to be noted that, as with all inquiries by parliamentary committees, changes in the area of investigations occur not just because of a report and its recommendations, but because of the raising and consideration of issues during the inquiry. This has undoubtedly been the case with the inquiry into the Supply Systems Redevelopment Project.

The Committee is of the view that this inquiry has contributed significantly to the progress of the project and, moreover, to the level of commitment that the Department of Defence and three Services have to the project. We noted in evidence that we heard during the inquiry that the last time there was a technology changeover, Sir Arthur Tange, the then Secretary, was heard to observe that they took eight years to stand still. We do not want that to be repeated.

The inquiry has been a catalyst for the introduction of the Unix operating system onto the DESINE contract. It has been given prominence in the issue of the ANZ content, stemmed a significant leap in the price of the software paid by the Commonwealth—there was said to be a hike of quite large proportions; we were successful in lowering the cost of the rented software—and led the Department of Defence to clean up those parts of the contract known as the Defence standard project list and its addendum, which clearly covered more than was intended.

Inquiries such as this require the work of many people. I take the opportunity to pay tribute to the work done in the previous Parliament by its Chairman, the Hon. R. Tickner, MP. I also thank the Parliamentary Library and the Parliamentary Research Service for their assistance. Last, but not least, I thank the Committee's secretariat for its contribution to the inquiry. In particular, I thank the Committee's two information technology advisers—Mr Brian Hendy, who was seconded from the Australian Taxation Office, and Mr John Wood from the Australian National Audit Office.

Finally, I note that during the inquiry the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff commenced a trial of loading transcripts of committee hearings onto the parliamentary database. The availability of the transcripts of this highly difficult and technical inquiry on the database has been of considerable assistance to the Committee and the Committee congratulates the Department on this initiative.

I commend this report to honourable senators, noting that it has been a lengthy and difficult report, containing language which is perhaps foreign to many people who will read it. We have made every endeavour to make it a comprehensible report—cutting down its initial size to a readable length and providing a rather elaborate glossary in a form that is not normally provided. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 318th report of the Committee on public sector research and development—Volume 1 of a report on research and development. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate the tabling speech in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Introduction
Mr President, I wish to make some brief comments in relation to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts Report 318—Public Sector Research and Development.
The starting point for the Committee's Inquiry into Research and Development (R & D) in Australia was two contrasting facts:
Australia's people have a reputation for inventiveness and its scientists a high standing in their professions;
Australia is not known for its ability to translate research discoveries and inventiveness into dollars.
The Committee sought to establish why this situation exists and how it can be remedied.

The Committee's Inquiry into Research and Development was started in 1989 to review research and development in the public sector. When it was taken up again at the start of this Parliament, its terms of reference were extended to examine the Government's support for R & D in the private sector. The Report that I am tabling today contains the Committee's conclusions and recommendations relating to its first term of reference, R & D in the public sector. We will table our report on R & D in the private sector during the Budget session of Parliament.
The Essential Infrastructure
The crucial point in considering the contribution of R & D to the nation is its interrelatedness with many other facets of national endeavour and the policies determining them.
The education system must deliver adequate numbers of appropriately trained scientists and research administrators to satisfy the demand for personnel.
Accommodation and equipment must be supplied to the research institutions if they are to work with technologically sophisticated methodologies at the forefront of knowledge.
If research developments are to be commercialised cost effectively, research must be an integral part of the industrial process.

Above all, Australia needs a scientifically literate population; the positive role that R & D can play in the nation's prosperity and international standing must be more widely understood and the outlook of our leaders in industry must be based on this understanding.
To achieve these goals, the Committee has made recommendations relating to:
providing the equipment and accommodation for scientific research;
training in science and research management in universities; and
raising the profile of science in the community.
Guidelines for the Government's Support for R & D in the Public Sector

In the present economic circumstances, there are great pressures to cut costs and use public funds as efficiently as possible. The Committee therefore paid considerable attention to the best way of wisely managing the considerable assistance provided by the Government for R & D—$2.6 billion this financial year. We concluded that two points are important and have made recommendations to this effect.

The first point is that the public sector research organisations should not be involved in fields in which the private sector can expect to conduct R & D for profit. The primary aim of public sector research organisations should be the conduct of longer term, basic research and research for the benefit of the community as a whole. For example, they should be involved with research on such topics as public health and understanding the environment and how our society is adjusting to the changes that it is experiencing.

The Committee's second point is that priorities for spending on research should be determined in the light of criteria selected to obtain maximum benefit for the nation. This means considering the wider public interest as well as possible economic returns. A method of using criteria like this to set priorities for spending on research has been developed by CSIRO and picked up and used by a variety of organisations. The Committee believes that this is a valuable approach that should be further developed and widely used in priority setting exercises.

If decisions are to be made about what research the public sector should carry out and which areas of research are most important, information must be available to decision makers. The Committee found that much of the necessary information is lacking and several of the Committee's recommendations are directed towards ensuring that it is collected and accessible to those who need it.
Commercialisation: its Impact on the National Research Effort

Research organisations have, for some time, been facing pressures to cut costs and focus on commercial applications for their research. As this has happened, it has become clear that a new balance must be found between the traditional roles of these organisations and their research staff and the new one that emphasises commercialisation. For example:

How should an organisation's research effort be divided between the short term process of developing applications for their research and long term basic research that may show no returns to the nation for many years, if at all? and

Can researchers cope with the demands of managing their research to tight targets, selling their ideas to industry and working within the constraints of a commercial timetable? Asking researchers to assume tasks additional to their research has required organisational changes and changes to the culture within which they work.

We need to strike a balance between long term basic research and shorter term strategic and applied research. How this balance is struck is vital. The private and public sector both warned that it would be a fatal mistake for Australia not to maintain its research capacity and the flow of information about the fundamental natural and physical processes of the world. This information is the foundation of applied science and an important step on the path to the ultimate commercialisation of research results. It is therefore essential that, in the current emphasis on the commercialisation of R & D, we do not overlook the need to continue basic longer term research and maintain the national capacity to do so.
The Costs of Commercialisation
The Committee identified three important points in relation to the commercialisation of public sector research:
Firstly, we need to be aware of the costs of commercialisation when public sector research organisations are charged with commercialising their work and we need to provide for these needs to be met;
Secondly, a reasonable rate of return must be obtained from the Government's investment of public funds in R & D; and
Thirdly, what charges should be made for research contracted from public sector organisations by outside bodies?

The Committee favours passing on the full cost of carrying out such work for the private sector. Passing on the full cost of research to other government bodies may not be appropriate; they may not be able to afford it, unless they are provided with additional funds. A good case exists for such public interest projects being carried out without full cost recovery.
The Public Sector Research Organisations
The Committee examined five research organisations in some detail. They were:

PARA.TAB: CSIRO;

SPEECH.PARA: the Defence Science and Technology Organisation;
the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation;

PARA.TAB: the Australian Institute of Marine Science;
the Office of the Supervising Scientist; and
the Bureau of Mineral Resources.

SPEECH.PARA: We found a number of shared problems among these organisations:
they are short of funds for capital works and staffing is difficult at times because salaries are not high enough to attract the best people;
the efficiency dividend, imposed across the public sector on administrative expenses, has also been applied to research activities, which appears not entirely appropriate;
annual and even triennial funding does not provide an adequate framework for the planning and prosecution of very long term research projects; and
raising funds for research from non-government sources cuts down the time that the research organisations can devote to research.
The Committee has made recommendations relating to these concerns, including recommendations for increased funding for long term research.
Other Issues
The Committee has also made recommendations about:
research into radioactive waste management, the provision of a nuclear waste repository and the regular inspection of the nuclear reactors at Lucas Heights by independent observers; and
levying the tourist industry to help finance environmental research.
Conclusion

Mr President, the R & D report that I have presented today is important. The report contributes to the harnessing of Australia's research capacity to our economic well-being and maintaining the role played by scientific research in the nation's life.
I commend the report to honourable senators.
