These proposed amendments to clauses 6 and 16 of the Territories Law Reform Bill 1992 now before the Senate, to add new sections 8AA to 8CC to be inserted in the Christmas Island Act 1958 and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act 1955 by the Bill, are to enable either the Senate or the House of Representatives by resolution to repeal Acts or parts of Acts of the Western Australian Parliament in their application to the Indian Ocean Territories.

Within three months, and six monthly thereafter, the Minister for the Arts and Territories will be obliged to table in each House lists of Western Australian Acts which have commenced operation in the Territories. Either House will then be able to disapply Acts specified in the lists by provisions based on existing provisions for disallowance of ordinances.

In respect to the first list of Western Australian Acts—several hundred in total—which will apply from 1 July 1992, each House will also be able, by resolution, to extend the period of possible disapplication of specified Acts for three months from the date of tabling of that initial list. Thereafter, the normal 15 day provision for disallowance will apply as for ordinances and regulations. I present the supplementary explanatory memorandum to these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the Territories Law Reform Bill 1992 which is before the Senate this evening, it is important to also take this opportunity to comment on the report by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs which has been tabled and which has very direct application to the piece of legislation that we have before us.

PARA.TAB: It is important to recognise that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator McMullan) has just moved for an extension of time to enable further Committee consideration. We need to be reminded that, because of the guillotine and the deal between the Government and the Australian Democrats, only one hour was initially available for this discussion. We have now extended that by another 30 minutes. That is a total of 1 1/2 hours for a very important piece of constitutional legislation.

This matter will progress from here this evening into the House of Representatives where I will be watching with particular interest for the amount of time and the detailed debate, other than the Minister's second reading speech, that will take place in that chamber on this important piece of legislation.

We have seen highlighted through the process of the Senate Standing Committee, which considered this matter for approximately four hours last Monday, what I can only describe as paternalism, colonialism, ignorance and arrogance on the part of the Government in the way in which it has dealt with this legislation. The Opposition certainly supports the thrust, tenor and main principles of extending a legal regime to the Indian Ocean Territories, but only after the full support and concurrence of the communities, involving a lot of consultation. It is not a matter of the Government clicking its heels and jumping to the tune of departmental bidding. There has been a lot of departmental work on this issue, and I acknowledge that, particularly by the various administrations.

Firstly, let us look for a moment at the genesis of this legislation. It can be traced to the Islands in the Sun report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs brought down a year or so ago. In dealing with this legislation here in the chamber, we have not had explained to us, either in the Committee hearing or here, the differences between that original report, Islands in the Sun, and the matters which surfaced in the Government's responses or in this legislation. There has been no schedule setting out the differences because of the haste that the Government uses when it is pushing a hidden agenda such as this.

Secondly, in the Senate Standing Committee hearing another WA Inc was revealed—a special deal between Labor governments. So far on this issue, there has been only an exchange of correspondence between former Prime Minister Hawke and an Acting Western Australian Premier. I refer my colleagues to the Hansard of the Senate Standing Committee hearing on 22 June when I questioned the Western Australian representative. On that occasion I asked Mr Mulhall:

SPEECH.PARA: Has this matter been presented to the Western Australia Cabinet?
He replied:
No, not to my knowledge.
I asked him further:
Have there been any agreements between departments or agencies of Western Australia and any Federal agencies at all?
His answer, a bit further on, was:

Our legal advice, from a meeting that was held on 16 June, indicates that Western Australian agencies should not enter into agreements in advance of enabling legislation and in advance of a formal agreement between the Commonwealth and the Western Australian Government.
My third question was:
Is there any draft complimentary legislation already prepared in Western Australia?
Mr Mulhall replied:
There is no draft legislation in preparation at the moment.

These are direct quotes from the Hansard. This is a farce, a charade and an administrative arrangement. Thirdly, we are aware of the constitutional aspects of this legislation. The voice of the people of Cocos (Keeling) and Christmas Islands has not been properly heard. It will be very interesting to hear the comments of Mr Snowdon, their representative in the House of Representatives, in this gagged debate tonight. Of course, there has been no voice or representation in the Western Australian Parliament with regard to the legislation.

PARA.TAB: There is, of course, the possibility of a constitutional challenge. That was brought out in the Senate Standing Committee hearing when Senator Vanstone asked the company, Phosphate Resources:

SPEECH.PARA: Do you rule out Phosphate Resources challenging this legislation if it is passed?

The director of that company, Mr Huston, replied in one word—no. Fourthly, there has been no answer from the Government on the issue of citizenship and how the application of laws relating to Western Australian local government will change the ethos of representation. The reciprocal benefits and responsibilities of the islanders have not been explained.

PARA.TAB: Fifthly, we need to look at the way in which the legislation has been considered, which makes a mockery of Labor's so-called constant and touted from time to time consultation process. Just who could make comprehensive submissions to the Senate Standing Committee in the time allocated? The Christmas Island residents were very concerned about this and one of the witnesses who appeared on Monday, Ms Choy Lan, said in her evidence:

SPEECH.PARA: The people want to be fully consulted before the laws are passed: not after, but before.

The comments from Cocos (Keeling) Islands were reflected in many angry submissions to the Committee that were faxed in last weekend, particularly the concerns from the local council chairman, Haji Wahin bin Bynie, and I draw that submission to the attention of anyone who is researching this matter. Patronising comments have been made by Labor Government Ministers and departmental officers in the evidence to the Committee and in this Parliament. As far as Christmas Island is concerned, I refer in particular to the evidence in that Senate Committee hearing when I said:
. . . we have got to be careful here that Christmas Island is not being sold a pup in this instance. . .

The amendments which have just been moved by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) do not acknowledge the consultative process; nor is there any indication that there will be a process with the elected representatives on either island. It is not incorporated in the legislation. That was looked for and sought by the residents of the island. It came out again in the Senate Standing Committee hearing the other day. I refer to comments made by Senator Spindler when he said:

. . . a move to exempt certain legislation, there is another option to get it on the floor of the Parliament in response to a Consultative Committee request to exempt certain legislation? . . . So I am really looking for a mechanism that the Government can offer in that legislation to enable that to be done.
The Chairman of the Committee, Senator Cooney, said:
What he is saying is what sort of controls can the islands have once the Bills go through. . .
The evidence of Lillian Oh, Secretary of the Union of Christmas Island Workers, is very important where she said:

What we are suggesting is that that is the whole process of consultation. You do that first. You can identify what areas are not going to be applicable, or what clearly are not going to be applied, and then you have a more informed judgment as to what is going to happen on the island, rather than trying to change it the other way around.
Further on, Ms Oh said:
The availability of resources is another point; but I think the consultation, especially from the union, is very important.

I refer the Senate to the dissent of the Opposition senators, Senators Vanstone, O'Chee and Kemp, where the recommendation was made that the Bill be postponed in its enactment for a period of at least six months until the residents of the islands have been properly consulted, advised and educated in relation to the operation and effect of the new legal regime. Where best can we see this concern illustrated than in a couple of late submissions that came to the Committee. One came from three imams on Home Island, which is part of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, and the other from the Australian Federation of Islamic Councils Inc. This submission reflected the particular Muslim reaction to the imposition of the family and marriage law. I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate those two submissions in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs
House of Representatives
Canberra ACT
To the respected Committee,
We, the three imams of Home Island in the Cocos Islands, wish to raise a matter concerning legal reform.
We have heard that the Muslims Ordinance of the Singapore laws in use in Cocos is to be replaced. We would be very unhappy about that.

We the Islanders are Muslims. We figure that the most appropriate law (for us) is one that is made specially for Muslims. We have our traditions and customs concerning marriage, divorce and so on according to traditions based on Islam. We do not want any of our practices to be changed.
The old Muslims Ordinance is none other than the law that we usually use. None of the Islanders objects to following that law, because it is indeed in accordance with our ways.

We ask sincerely that the Government be very careful about imposing the Marriage Act and the Family Law Act on us. The reason is that the Government has not talked to us about these matters. The Government has not explained things to us. The Government has not heard the views of the community regarding these laws, whether they agree or not. The Government has not yet been able to guarantee us that our traditional practices will be able to continue. So we are not yet able to say that we agree to the new laws.

So we would ask the Government not to impose the Marriage Act and the Family Law Act yet. We ask for more time to talk with the Government about these laws, so that we can seek together the solution that is most suitable in terms of the traditions, needs and rights of the Cocos Islanders. It can be said that religious traditions and customs are very important in the life of Cocos Islanders.
That's all we would like to say, so that the Government might try to understand about the opinions of the Cocos Islanders.
Respectfully yours
(signed)Imam Haji Wallie

THE AUSTRALIAN FEDERATION
OF ISLAMIC COUNCILS INC.
23rd June, 1992
Senator Hon. Grant Tambling
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Mr Tambling
Re: Territories Law Reform Bill 1992

PARA.TAB: We understand that shortly the Senate is due to consider the above bill leading to the introduction of mainland laws in the External Territories of Australia namely Christmas Island and Cocos Island. Whilst other laws do not present any problems or raise any concerns the anticipated introduction of Marriage Act 1961 and Family Law Act 1975 effectively replacing and repealing the existing Muslim laws affecting important and sensitive matters relating to marriage, divorce and inheritance rights of the Muslim majority of these Islands raise issues of great concern to the Muslim community of Australia at large.

As the national body of Australian Muslims and on behalf of our constituents in Christmas Island and Cocos Island, the Federation wishes to appeal to you to please seek a delay of consideration of this bill in the Senate and House of Representatives until the views of the Muslim community of Australia have been heard through their recognised national body.

We understand that we are making this approach in the eleventh hour but we would like to inform you that this Federation has become aware of these matters in the last few days and it appears that the Standing Committee of the Senate itself was given a very tight schedule before bringing the matter to the Senate. It is unfortunate that this Federation and its Law Reform Committee was not even aware that a public hearing for one day was being held by the Standing Committee on Monday the 22nd June, 1992. Therefore, in the interest of natural justice and in deference to the wishes of second largest religious community of Australia namely the Muslims of Australia, we appeal to you to speak in favour of delay of discussions and to provide opportunity to our representatives to voice these concerns before a Parliamentary Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Yours sincerely
Salahuddin Ahmad
Chairman
Law Reform Committee of AFIC

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. As I said earlier, the challenge to Warren Snowdon, Federal member for the Northern Territory and for the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island—Mr Snowdon is known for his constant criticism of supposedly unfair and unjust programs when it suits his political agenda, particularly when they affect his Aboriginal constituents in the Northern Territory—is that he must now set aside his usual political opportunism and prove his consistency of both argument and principle by adopting the same advocacy for his Indian Ocean Territory constituents. Otherwise, he proves only his shallow commitment and narrow political focus and reveals that he is only the mouthpiece for Labor's socialist Left faction in Canberra. If he agrees to the hasty imposition of this legislation tonight, he is acting against the expressed will of his own electors.

PARA.TAB: The haste of this legislation and the paucity of detail only shows that the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has done a major snow job both in Canberra and on the islands. The inadequacy of the legislation and the lack of community support will come home to haunt the Labor Party, the Parliament and the Department. I am reminded of the story of the emperor with no clothes. I question whether the departmental parade on this occasion is just a lot of fancy paperwork with no substance to hang it on.

We are well aware that much of the haste for this legislation is predicated on the casino on Christmas Island and the need for gaming regulations. A cloud now hangs over that casino because of the investment issues that have become very apparent in the media in the last week or so, and the fact that there is no commitment—which has been reinforced now for over a week—as to a major stop-work project on a $50m program.

The other departmental agenda on this issue relates to a capital works program of $132m on Christmas Island. That program has not received the full support that the Department would have liked from the parliamentary Joint Committee on Public Works. The parliamentary Public Works Committee has written to Minister Fatin and put in an interim report in which it certainly acknowledges that there is a need for the upgrading of public infrastructure.
I support that and I have said that, but the questioning of the need, the amount and how it backs up is borne out in one of the final questions of that letter, where the Committee says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . prior to the final commitment to the total ten year program, the Committee believes there should be a re-assessment of the success of the initial funding which may lead to changes in the priorities and/or funding levels.

So we will not see the grandstanding of the Department of Administrative Services in its empire building, and the creation of a project that was not endorsed by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the One Nation statement because of that. Because of the importance of this letter, it is also important that I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works
4 June 1992
The Hon W F Fatin
Minister for the Arts
and Territories
Suite MF 22
Telelift 10-8
Dear Minister

As you would be aware the Committee is currently inquiring into the Christmas Island Rebuilding Program which was referred to it by the House of Representatives on 25 March 1992. In public hearings on Christmas Island and in Perth and Canberra the Committee has taken evidence from a wide range of persons and organisations and while on Christmas Island had the opportunity of inspecting both existing facilities and the proposed sites for the new facilities.

Unfortunately due to the pressure of other inquiries the Committee will be unable to table its report on this project before the winter recess. However the Committee believes that its attitude toward the rebuilding program and the $37m already committed should be made known to the Government so this can be taken into account during Budget considerations.

While the committee has concluded that there is a need for the upgrading of the public infrastructure on Christmas Island to align conditions with mainland standards, indeed many of the facilities are in an appalling state, the Committee believes that the priorities determined by the Government for inclusion in the $37m committed over the next five years do not include all the essential items.

I should say at the outset that the Committee agrees with the priority given to new and upgraded sewerage works, water supply works and the new hospital. However, it became obvious to the Committee during its inspection that the wharf facilities are completely inadequate and in need of urgent upgrading. The Committee was advised by the Christmas Island Administration that the rebuilding program will more than double the current usage of the already inferior infrastructure of the port. The port infrastructure is obviously vital to the success of the rebuilding program, for if it fails the whole rebuilding program will be severely compromised.
The Committee strongly recommends to the Government that in relation to the wharf facilities the following item be included in the first five years of the rebuilding program:

PARA.TAB: new crane
minor upgrading of the wharf to support the crane.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the new hospital it is clear to the Committee that the removal of the sand and aggregate plant from the site of the new hospital should also be undertaken in the first five years of the program. The Committee understands that the removal of the sand and aggregate plant would require expenditure on water and power supply to the hospital site.
The Committee realises that to accommodate these changes it will be necessary to either exclude some existing items from the $37m already committed or to increase the amount committed at this stage.

Your department has advised that this would necessitate deferring the police station and also expenditure of some $700,000 proposed for the combined schools and housing items. However before any item is excluded the Committee believes that the Government should consider increasing the amount to be committed over the next five years.

In conclusion I would like to emphasise the Committee's support for the rebuilding program but stress that the priorities should be reviewed as detailed above. In addition, the Committee is of the view that current Christmas Island residents and others who are prepared to invest in the future development of the Island, should be encouraged in their efforts by the provision of at least the $37m and possible additional funds to address the immediate health and safety issues. However, prior to the final commitment to the total ten year program, the Committee believes there should be a re-assessment of the success of the initial funding which may lead to changes in the priorities and/or funding levels.
I am forwarding a copy of this letter to your colleagues the Prime Minister, the Minister for Finance and Minister for Administrative Services.
Yours sincerely
Colin Hollis
Chairman

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. As I said, this is important legislation. There is no doubt that all parties and all interested groups, both on the islands and on the mainland, support the thrust of the legislation. As Opposition senators pointed out so tacitly and so correctly in the report, the Standing Committee only met for a very brief period on Monday; heard evidence from representatives of only one of the affected islands—Christmas Island; did not hear and did not consider in detail any of the submissions from the Cocos (Keeling) Islands; and many members of the Committee, before deliberating on this report, had not read the detailed submissions that came in a couple of days before the report. That makes me angry.

PARA.TAB: I am certainly going to insist that the Minister, Mrs Fatin, makes a personal representation to each and every one of those submissions and explains each and every one of the concerns that has been raised. It will be a test of the administration and the political masters of this issue, to see that what I say is nothing more than paternalism, colonialism, ignorance and arrogance is not reinforced. I want to see a proper administration. The haste with which this legislation is being foisted on the Parliament and thrust on the people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island is totally inappropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is tonight debating the Territories Law Reform Bill 1992. The Bill will amend the Christmas Island Act and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act and repeal existing Indian Ocean Territories laws, unless specified in new schedules. It will apply Western Australian laws as enforced from time to time, including some 700 pieces of legislation which will now be applied to Christmas Island. It will also, from time to time, subject to modification by ordinance, introduce laws made under the Christmas Island Act or Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act and extend appropriate Commonwealth laws.

PARA.TAB: The reform that will affect these islands is a far-reaching one. To a large extent I share the concerns expressed by Senator Tambling. We are faced with a population which has a unique ethnic mix. We also face a legal history which has given that population laws which, in many respects, belong to the past and no longer have any relevance to a modern community. To that extent, one would welcome the reforms which will be introduced. Indeed, all parties have stated that the substance of the Bill is supported.

I find myself at variance with Senator Tambling when he says that there has been no consultation, no education and no advice given to the people of Christmas Island and the Cocos Islands. At the meeting of the Joint Committee on Public Works we heard considerable evidence of consultation which has taken place on those islands. Whether it has been sufficient to make people aware of the laws that will be applied to them is another question. But there has been some consultation. The question certainly arises of just how long a consultation process can be continued before laws that are in keeping with modern times are introduced.

On hearing all the evidence, I was also impressed with the evidence given by the representative of the Christmas Island Community Legislative Consultative Committee, Mr Terry White, who said that, on the basis of examining the total body of some 700 laws which were going to be applied to the islands, there was real concern with only about 33. Nevertheless, these concerns are real.

Some way had to be found to ensure that the laws were not imposed on the people of Christmas and Cocos Islands without them having some possibility not only for consultation but also some effective influence through this Parliament. In that way they could ensure that, if there were real concerns and they found that certain laws were not appropriate for their conditions, these laws could be disallowed, and the people, through their consultative mechanisms, could make their views known to Parliament and the Senate. I gave an undertaking that we would listen carefully to their concerns.

As Senator Tambling mentioned in his speech, at that Committee hearing I was looking for a mechanism that would enable the people of the islands to bring before us laws that they felt were not appropriate for their communities. I refer to my recommendation in the Committee report that the Bill could be passed subject to amendments which ensure that the existing and subsequent Western Australian and Commonwealth legislation which is to be applied to the islands be brought before the Commonwealth Parliament at three-monthly intervals by way of schedules, any part of which may be disallowed by the Commonwealth Parliament. This would be preceded by consultation with the island's consultative committee and adequate resources would be provided by the Commonwealth for this consultative process. I will return to the consultation process and to the resources for that process in a moment.

I wish to pay tribute to the officers of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories who, until about 12 o'clock on Tuesday night, engaged in a considerable amount of work to put this requirement into legislation, to wit, the amendment that the Minister read at the beginning of this debate. I suggested that an additional gloss would be useful. That was in response to the concern expressed in the last minutes of the Committee meeting by people from the Christmas Island community who said that, in some instances, they might need more time to consider legislation before they actually made their views known.

I therefore suggested that it would be appropriate for the Australian Parliament to be able to make a choice between three responses to legislation placed before it in the form of schedules, any part of which could be disallowed. Apart from letting the legislation pass and, therefore, perpetuating the law in its application to Christmas Island, we had the choice of disallowing it. I suggested that it would be useful to have a third choice where we could ask that these Bills be brought before the Australian Parliament again within a three-month period. This provision should apply only to the first batch of 700 Bills and subsequent schedules which are brought before this Parliament should be brought before it at six-monthly intervals. That should provide sufficient time for the consultative process to take place on the islands.

I have had the draft Bill examined. I find that it does implement the requirements which I have stipulated in my recommendation. On that basis, the Australian Democrats will support this legislation. However, there is one proviso. In discussions with the Minister and departmental officials, it was agreed that it was impractical to put the provision of resources for the consultative process into legislation. There will be general assistance by the Commonwealth to ensure that consultation takes place and the results of that consultation will be brought before this House. Therefore, I request the Minister to give an unequivocal assurance to this House so that it is in Hansard that the Commonwealth Government accepts that responsibility to ensure that consultation takes place and to provide adequate resources to the people of the Christmas and Cocos (Keeling) Islands so that that consultation may take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —The horse has bolted, has it not? This talk about consultation is out of place.
—Before disallowance, Senator.

—Yes, but we can only disallow certain matters. As I understand it—somebody can correct me—we cannot disallow the operation of the provisions of Federal law. We are only talking about Western Australian State law, are we not? We are not talking about disallowance when it comes to Commonwealth laws which apply forthwith, as from next Wednesday. One of those laws is the Family Law Act. That Act relates to probably the most important matters, decisions and contracts that human beings make with each other. There has been no consultation about that Act.
—Yes, there has.
—We have received information and Senator Tambling has tabled a statement from certain groups, including religious groups, on the islands which says that there has not been any consultation.
—That doesn't change the facts.

—Senator McMullan will be able to tell us. I can only go on what is known to me. I did not need to rely on the material that was tabled by Senator Tambling because it had been reported to me quite reliably that there had not been consultations with the people about the operation of this measure as from 1 July 1992. There would be one way of settling all of this: the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), Senator Tambling, me and anyone in the chamber who wants to accompany us should go to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands on Monday of next week and take a survey of the people there. We could take interpreters and find out whether there have been consultations. My advice from the islands is that consultation has not taken place, that the people would not have a clue about the operation of that particular legislation which will operate from next Wednesday and which relates to the most important contracts that people enter into between themselves.

PARA.TAB: That is a very important matter for us to be considering. In my view, it is extremely important that we do not pass this measure until such time as we know that that consultation has taken place and that there is agreement in respect of that matter. It is all very well to say that the decision was made and the referendum was undertaken. That is true. Referenda are often undertaken, but people expect that the consequence of the vote will be explained to them before the next process takes place. We have had a number of referenda in Australia. Before a referendum people are given detailed information about the proposal. After the proposal has been adopted a further step is taken, generally in the form of legislation which comes before the Federal Parliament. It is at that stage that further consultation can take place with affected individuals.

Could the Parliamentary Secretary tell the Committee what consultations have taken place. Can the Parliamentary Secretary assure the Committee that he or the Government is confident that the people of the islands know about the operation of the Family Law Act in respect of the matters that are so important to them as individuals and as a community?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I share Senator Harradine's concerns on this matter, particularly with regard to the application of the Family Law Act and the common law of Western Australia which will be embraced by this legislation. That was brought out in the hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on Monday. I think it is important to put on the record the comments of Haji Wahin bin Bynie, the Chairman of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Council. He said in the submission to the Senate Committee:

SPEECH.PARA: The Council is very concerned that the islanders are not fully educated or made fully aware of the proposed laws and how these will affect them in their daily lives—politically, socially and financially. The Department of Territories has been sending teams of persons from various Commonwealth and state departments to visit the islands. However the Council is of the view that despite this, insufficient information has been disseminated to the community. It is only last week that the Minister appointed a Community Legal Adviser but this is only 2 weeks before the proposed laws are implemented and enforced.

The Council is concerned that several issues have yet to be resolved especially those that impinge on the culture, customs and tradition of the islanders. There are also several issues that have to be considered by Council in preparation for the introduction of the proposed laws. Of immediate concern is the land tenure system and its application thereof affecting the whole community. A decision has yet to be made on the lands held on trusts by the Council. The Council is still in the process of liaising with the Department of Territories on the trust documents and the alienation of the lands thereafter to the community.

It has also been brought to the Council's attention yesterday that the Muslim Ordinance of Singapore shall be repealed and replaced by the Commonwealth Family Law Act and the Marriage Act. This will radically change the customs, culture and tradition of islanders which is contrary to the terms of the Memorandum of Understanding.
At the end of the letter he said:
We submit that the Bill be deferred to a later date after the community has been fully consulted.

They are the issues that Senator Harradine and I share a concern about. Obviously the consultation process with the Australian Democrats is a much better one than that with the islanders of Cocos and Christmas Islands. Very obviously, Senator Spindler was given the opportunity on Tuesday night to work with officers on an amendment and then was given a handwritten copy of the amendments in advance of them coming here and being made available generally. I can certainly indicate that I was not invited to participate in the drafting of any amendments whatsoever and I was handed a formal copy of them only this morning by the parliamentary liaison officer in this place.

PARA.TAB: Very obviously, the process of consultation, or deals that are done, with the Democrats certainly show out. I am surprised that Senator Spindler obviously has not read the detailed submissions that went to the Committee on Monday from the islanders. Even though Senator Spindler calls for an assurance from the Minister about the consultation process, quite frankly it is not good enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will concentrate on the question of consultation because that is an issue about which I have a specific question. I would like briefly to comment on some general remarks. I welcome the positive contribution from Senator Spindler. The indication that he was involved in the negotiation of an amendment to implement his reservation is not surprising. A reservation from Senator Spindler is what we were implementing. That is why it was Senator Spindler that we spoke to.
—There is a similar one in the dissent.

—Senator Tambling actually did not say such a thing at all. Opposition senators raised similar concerns. They said, `The proposal is not before us and we cannot proceed'. In particular, Senator Spindler said the legislation should go ahead, subject to an amendment. Therefore, of course, we needed to make sure the amendment met his particular—
—They do a backroom deal, a backroom consultation.

—Very exciting. I am sure that the fact that Senator Tambling has made that interjection will do something wonderful for him overnight. Senator Tambling also made a very unfortunate political attack on the honourable member for Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) whose principal contribution in this matter has been to be one of those who has persuaded the Government, and ultimately the Parliament, that the current unsatisfactory body of law in general on Cocos and Christmas Islands cannot be allowed to continue, and he has brought this major reform which will improve the rights of all the people in that Territory. It is a very positive contribution. He has also supported the substantial public works, which will be very good for the island, over Senator Tambling's opposition. We know that he is scrambling to catch up from the adverse reaction to his opposition to that. It probably explains some of his enthusiasm about this particular matter.

PARA.TAB: There are a lot more general remarks I would like to make, but it would be unfair not to take up the limited time to respond to Senator Harradine's points. The question about consultation falls into two parts. One is the question of general consultation and the other one is specific consultation with regard to the Family Law Act. I have to cover both as quickly as I can.

There has been a very large amount of consultation generally about the application of laws to these two islands—the Federal laws and relevant State laws of course principally. There has been extensive work by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which visited the islands twice and had a large amount of consultation. Fifty officials from the Western Australian and Commonwealth agencies have made visits there, 100 impact statements have been sent to representative bodies, law reform newsletters translated in Chinese and Malay have been sent to both newsletters, videos have been sent, there have been local radio and television broadcasts and Chinese and Malay speaking community advisers have been appointed to provide advice on the impact of particular laws. That is not exclusive to the family law area but it includes the Family Law Act. That part of it is general.

There is some specific action as well concerning the Family Law Act and the Muslim community. My advice is that the Territory administrators met with the imams in mid-1989. The Cocos administrator advised that the Cocos (Keeling) Islands imams had no difficulty with the extension of the Marriage Act, confirming that Muslim marriage on Cocos Islands is already monogamous, and they were happy for the courts to decide on family law matters, particularly custody of children after divorce. I am advised that the Islamic community on Christmas Island at that stage accepted the argument that Islamic communities on the mainland accept and operate under the Federal Acts. It was also noted, I am advised, that Muslim, Chinese and European communities tend to marry or divorce off the island anyway.

The House of Representatives Committee, which took extensive submissions and visited the island twice, noted that at no time during the inquiry had reservations been expressed in respect of family law as it applies on the mainland. It recommended application of the Family Law Act to the Territories. After that report had been sent and circulated, the Minister for Territories sought comment from the island communities but neither community raised any comment about the Family Law Act matter.

The Government response to the report was tabled in Parliament on 10 September 1991 and provided to the communities, and that specifically confirmed the intention that the Family Law Act would be extended. There was no reaction from the communities or their elected representatives.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS LEGISLATION (TARIFF CONCESSIONS AND ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: House of Representatives message:

PROCTEXT.PARA: SCHEDULE OF THE AMENDMENTS MADE BY THE SENATE TO WHICH THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES HAS DISAGREED

PARA.TAB: Clause 13, page 24, paragraph (a), line 43, omit "25 days", substitute "5 days".
Clause 13, page 25, paragraph (d), line 19, omit "25 days", substitute "5 days".
Reasons of the House of Representatives for disagreeing to the amendments of the Senate
Senate amendments Nos. 1 and 3, the effect of which would be to reduce the prima facie stage of a dumping inquiry from 25 days to 5 days, are not acceptable becasue:

(i)5 days leaves insufficient time to give effect to the requirements under the General Agreement on Tariff and Trade (GATT) Anti-Dumping Code, and the requirements of Australia's domestic legislation, relating to the consideration of an application for anti-dumping relief prior to the initiation of an anti-dumping investigation;

(ii)5 days leaves insufficient time to comply with the requirement under the GATT Subsidies Code for consultation with affected Governments for the purpose of clarifying the situation and arriving at a mutually agreed solution, prior to the initiation of a subsidisation/countervailing duty inquiry; and

(iii)a 5 day prima facie period effectively nullifies the reforms contained in the Bill which enable the Australian Customs Service (ACS) to supplement an application for dumping relief with other relevant information, by leaving the ACS with insufficient time to obtain and properly weight such other information.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the Committee does not insist upon amendments Nos. 1 and 3 made by the Senate to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see that the House of Representatives has acceded to the Senate's request to omit paragraphs (b) and (e) of Clause 13 of the Customs Legislation (Tariff Concessions and Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1992 which is now back before the Senate. That means that the word `strictly' will not be inserted before the word `comply' in the Act. I will not go over the debate we had on this point the other day, particularly at this hour of the evening, other than to note that inclusion of the word `strictly' was either unnecessary or had implications that the Government had not sufficiently spelt out—implications which could have posed considerable difficulty for applicants for dumping inquiries, particularly those engaged in the production of raw materials for processed products.

PARA.TAB: I regret, however, that the House of Representatives has not acceded to the Senate's other request, namely, to reduce from 25 days to five days the time limit for the prima facie stage of a dumping inquiry. The reasons that have been given by the House for not acceding to that request are basically that five days leaves insufficient time to give effect to the requirements of the GATT anti-dumping code and the requirements of Australia's domestic legislation, and also that a five-day prima facie period effectively would nullify the other reforms in the Bill enabling the Australian Customs Service to supplement an application for dumping relief with other relevant information.

Since this request was carried in the Senate earlier this week, the Opposition has had the opportunity to discuss the matter in some further detail with officers of DITAC and also the Customs Service. Whilst noting the Government's arguments against reducing the time limit from 25 days to five days, we in the coalition are nevertheless not convinced that a five-day prima facie stage poses the difficulties that the Government and its Public Service advisers claim.

The coalition's anti-dumping policies, which were published many months ago now, include a five-day prima facie stage for a dumping inquiry. That remains our policy and we will proceed to its implementation on coming to government later this year or early next year. However, the coalition will not continue to press for a reduction to five days in this Bill. Although this Bill goes nowhere near far enough in ensuring that adequate remedies are available to Australian producers against unfair practices, particularly by our major trading partners, it is at least an improvement over the existing situation.

In particular, the changes in the Bill to the tariff concession system should make for more balanced decisions where a local producer will have to demonstrate in the future a capacity to produce the items in question. Of course, as protection winds down over time, the use of tariff concession orders will also decline. The Bill also implements various other changes to anti-dumping and countervailing arrangements, including the adoption of changes to the Anti-Dumping Authority timetables that were proposed by the coalition more than a year ago. This eventual though belated adoption of the coalition's proposals is, of course, welcome.

As I said earlier, the changes in this Bill are a step in the right direction, even though they are only a pale reflection of what is required. But because they are a step in the right direction and because the Government has indicated that it will withdraw the Bill or simply let it wallow on the Notice Paper rather than accept the reduction from 25 days to five days for the prima facie stage, the coalition will not continue to press this request at this time. To do otherwise would be to deny Australian producers the other benefits that the Bill contains. We will proceed with the implementation of our much stronger and much more effective anti-dumping policies on our own terms and through our own Bills after coming to government in the next few months.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share Senator Short's pleasure at the Government's agreement to leave in place the amendments which remove the word `strictly' before `comply' and to that extent the onus of proof is weakened slightly. However, I regret very much indeed that the Government has seen fit not to accept the Senate's amendment to reduce the time period for the prima facie stage of an application from 25 days to five days. That amendment, although technically moved by the coalition parties, was identical to a similar amendment that the Australian Democrats had formulated and circulated. In contrast to the Opposition, we continue to press our amendment. We do not accept the Government's contention that the requirements of GATT cannot be met in that five-day period.

PARA.TAB: I believe it is time that our Department of Small Business, Construction and Commerce saw as part of its task a responsibility to ensure that Australian manufacturers face a level playing field. It is a misnomer to call this the prima facie stage if we ask our manufacturers, our producers, to prove in that stage virtually all the aspects of a case that they would have to make to achieve countervailing duties when dumping occurs. That review of procedures is well and truly overdue.

I derive some comfort from the statements made by the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) at various times that the Government is preparing legislation which would introduce the countervailing duties at the end of the prima facie stage. When that actually happens, when that legislation is in place, then I could accept that a 25-day period would be realistic. But when we proceed during the prima facie stage no further than simply to say, `You now can have an inquiry as to whether you should have countervailing duties to protect you from dumping', then I really do not see why our Department cannot get its act into gear and protect our manufacturers when they are crying out for help at a time such as this. Thousands of jobs are going down the drain on a weekly basis because we reduce our tariffs but allow other countries, through their exporters, to compete on our market virtually unhindered.

I express very profound disappointment about the fact that now both the Government and the Opposition are not prepared to take up the cudgels on behalf of Australian manufacturers and are prepared to sacrifice Australian jobs when they could assist in keeping some jobs here. They are exporting this work to Taiwan, Korea, the United States, Japan and other countries that use our lax provisions—provisions which assist importers and act against our manufacturers. The net effect is that we will lose more jobs and that the one million unemployed that we now have will be exceeded in the very near future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PARA.TAB: The following Bill was returned from the House of Representatives without amendment:
Telecommunications (Interception—Carriers) Bill 1992
Consideration of the House of Representatives message.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Committee, having considered message No. 575 of the House of Representatives in relation to the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1992, whilst not conceding that Senate amendment No. 2 should have been a request for an amendment, requests the House of Representatives to amend the Bill in accordance with that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall speak only very briefly to this matter. I suppose that most sections of the Constitution can be a puzzle, but section 53 certainly has some difficulties. Whilst it is clear what the general intent is, in a particular instance this may lead to some confusion and to a difference of opinion between people who are of goodwill, who try to look at the section with a fair mind, and who are quite apart from those who have an institutional interest in the pre-eminence of one chamber rather than another.

PARA.TAB: When one has the combination of the difficulty of the section and the territorial imperative, which sometimes grips those who advise us in these matters—I am referring to those in both chambers—I believe that there is always the possibility of a difference which requires more time for reflection than is accorded to us on this last night of the sitting. That is why the motion that I have moved has been cast in a way which is probably rather unusual.

When I moved an amendment in relation to the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill, I thought that all I was doing was creating a situation where money which would otherwise be payable to the State of Tasmania would be paid to the municipalities of Tasmania. In other words, there would be a shift away from a grant to the State to a grant to the municipalities. A slightly higher amount would go to the municipalities and, therefore, a correspondingly lesser amount to the State to enable municipalities to carry out road programs. I certainly had no impression that I was doing anything which might increase a charge or burden on the people. For that reason I believed that an amendment was quite in order.

However, the House of Representatives has taken a different view. I must say that the opinion of the Clerk of the Senate on this matter—which I have had a chance to read, but which I have to confess I do not fully comprehend and have not digested at this moment—does not seem to put it quite as simply as that. It seems to make a claim that, where an amendment simply effects a discretion which a Minister may have as to the level of expenditure which might be attained to advance a particular matter, it does not amount to a provision which could be characterised in terms of section 53 as a proposal to `increase any proposed charge or burden on the people'. I find that more broad proposition, aside from the actual facts of what we did yesterday, a little more difficult to agree with, if I have characterised it properly.

I do not think this is an easy matter, and I certainly do not think that setting up straw arguments—for example, saying that the House has been involved in a misunderstanding, the essence of which is that anything possibly involving money must require a request—would be a fair characterisation of the view of the House of Representatives either. I think there does need to be reflection over the winter months on the matter that has arisen as to the correct procedure that ought to be adopted between the two Houses. In the end there has to be a meeting of minds between both chambers in order for the matter to proceed through the Parliament and to the Governor-General for assent so that a law is effected at the end of the process.

There is a difference in procedures; they are constitutionally mandated. We have to abide by the Constitution. I do not believe that it is justiciable, in the sense that the High Court can peer over our shoulders and decide whether we got it right between our two chambers. What occurs between the two chambers or within the walls of each chamber in these matters, is a matter for us. Nevertheless, we have a real obligation, despite the fact that the High Court will not be able to give a definitive view, to do our best ourselves to abide by the Constitution. I think we need more time to reflect on this matter; hence the motion I have moved tonight is in the peculiar form that it is. Without conceding that Senate amendment No. 2 should have been a request, I nevertheless request the House of Representatives to amend the Bill in accordance with that amendment. It is cast in that way in order to enable the legislation to be dealt with, but without prejudice to further consideration of the constitutional issues involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am convinced, by the advice that I have read, that Senator Tate was correct originally in moving an amendment rather than a request to the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill. I am not quite sure how to take Senator Tate's comments, when he talked about jurisdictional ownership or words to that effect and straw arguments. I do not whether he was suggesting that this was simply some sort of contest between the Clerks this side and the Clerks the other side. I am sure he was not suggesting that because I am sure that is not the case.

PARA.TAB: What is right is right, and the Constitution needs to be obeyed. It would be most improper and completely wrong to suggest that trying to get the correct interpretation of the Constitution is something dealing with arguments between two sets of Clerks, jurisdictional property or straw arguments. So I am sure I misunderstood Senator Tate when he made those comments.
I think the Constitution is quite clear. The relevant section, section 53, says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people.

It is that particular paragraph which the Speaker of the House of Representatives has used to support his returning this to the Senate to make it a request rather than an amendment. With due respect to the Speaker of the House of Representatives, I think he is

wrong in his interpretation and in his request. I would not presume to argue the constitutionalities myself. As I say, I am encouraged and convinced by the advice given to myself, Senator Tate and other senators interested in this matter by the Clerk of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I seek leave to incorporate the advice from the Clerk of the Senate and table the attachments, namely, three other papers contained in this package referred to in the Clerk's letter.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 25 June 1992
Senator I.D. Macdonald
The Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Macdonald

The House of Representatives has returned the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1992 with a claim that one of the Senate's amendments should be a request. That claim is based on poor advice and a lack of understanding of the issue. During the debate in the House of Representatives the Rt. Hon. Ian Sinclair, MP, expressed a wish "to understand why the clerks in the other place believe the resolution [amendment] to have been within its [the Senate's] power". It is regrettable that the House has not been given that understanding hitherto. I hope that this letter will assist.

Before I go to the matter in issue, I note that the amendment was moved in the Senate by the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, and now apparently the government's advisers have decided that the Minister was wrong to move the amendment. The government's advisers do not understand the question of amendments versus requests. This is demonstrated by the fact that last week government amendments were circulated to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1992, a bill which the Senate clearly cannot amend, and it was only when I pointed that out that the amendments were withdrawn and changed to requests.

The matter in issue is the provision in section 53 of the Constitution whereby the Senate may not amend any bill to increase any "proposed charge or burden on the people". An amendment which would have that effect must be put in the form of a request.

It is clear that this provision requires a request where an amendment would increase expenditure under an appropriation. It is also clear that there must be a necessary and direct increase in expenditure for a request to be required. If one takes the view that a possible or indirect effect on expenditure is all that is required, as some of the government's advisers occasionally seem to do, then virtually every amendment will have to be a request, because virtually every amendment can be seen as having some possible or indirect effect on expenditure. Apart from a misinterpretation of the Constitution, this will involve many more bills coming back to the Senate to be finally dealt with after they have been returned to the House. An amendment should be put in the form of a request only where it would necessarily and directly lead to an increase in expenditure. This principle has been followed in moving amendments in the Senate over many years.

In the case of this bill, the effect of the Senate's amendment would be to raise the upper limit within which the relevant minister may, in effect, determine the amount of a grant to a state. The amendment therefore does not necessarily and directly involve an increase in expenditure, but merely enlarges the area of a ministerial discretion within which expenditure may be made.

In 1981 the Senate considered amendments involving a similar principle, and determined by resolution that it was in accordance with the Constitution for the Senate to amend a bill to remove a ministerial discretion to reduce expenditure. This resolution may be regarded as establishing the principle that an amendment which affects a ministerial discretion to authorise expenditure does not have to be in the form of a request, and that a request cannot be required simply on the basis that the discretion might be exercised in such a way as to increase expenditure. This case is discussed in Australian Senate Practice, 6th edition, pp. 607-10.
All of the relevant issues are treated more fully in a paper which was tabled in the Senate on 6 March 1989, a copy of which is attached. Also attached is a recent letter on a relevant recent case.

It is quite clear that the Senate's amendment does not need to be a request. The analysis which has been put here has never been explained to the House or answered. The claim made in the House of Representatives message, which, with the wider issue of the interpretation of the relevant constitutional provision, has also not been explained to the House, is based upon a misunderstanding, the essence of which is that anything possibly involving money must require a request.

As is also pointed out in the paper tabled in the Senate, the difference between amendments and requests under section 53 of the Constitution is essentially a procedural difference, which affects the procedural method by which bills are dealt with by the two Houses. As a constitutionally-mandated procedure, however, it must be taken seriously and properly observed.

The line apparently being taken by the government's advisers, if accepted, would lead to more amendments being put as requests, which would cause considerable inconvenience to both Houses, quite apart from the distortion of the application of the constitutional provision.
I have written in similar terms to the Senators who took part in the debate on the bill and other interested Senators.
Yours sincerely
(Harry Evans)

TALK.START.PARA: —Without in any way trying to explain the Clerk's advice—which is very comprehensive and I hope will be understood by those on the other side with an interest—I would point out that this amendment does not increase the burden or charge on the Australian people. It simply gives the Minister a discretion up to which he may be able to amend some money figures. It is not a charge in itself. That argument is contained very concisely in the Clerk's advice.

PARA.TAB: As mentioned in the House of Representatives Hansard, and as the Speaker seems to have acknowledged but then to have taken no notice of, both the Minister's speech and the explanatory memorandum quite clearly indicate that this amendment in no way will increase any burden on the Australian people. What it is really doing is saying that money that was allocated for Tasmania, for local government purposes and for local government roads purposes in particular, is being directed away from the State Government for use on local roads towards local authorities for use on local roads. The upper limit of the money the Commonwealth will give to the State of Tasmania—and it does not apply to the Northern Territory as it is only specifically in relation to the State of Tasmania—will not alter. Accordingly, under section 53, nothing we do to amend this particular Bill will in any way increase any proposed charge or burden on the Parliament.

Finally and briefly, I think my colleague the member for New England, the right honourable Ian Sinclair, was right in the first instance when he said in the other place that it was simply `a re-apportionment of moneys'. It seems to me that Mr Sinclair, no doubt through his very long and wide experience in this Parliament, has quickly grasped the issue. Unfortunately, he then seems to have been talked out of it, but I suggest that he was right in the first instance.

I might also mention that I thought some of the remarks made about the Senate by my colleague the honourable member for Farrer, Mr Fischer, were cavalier rather than, as he suggested, that the Senate was treating the other place in a cavalier fashion. I might indicate to both gentlemen that the two amendments, although eventually moved by Senator Tate, were brought at my instigation at the request of the Liberal Government of Tasmania and the Tasmanian local authorities. But I think Mr Fischer is not quite right on the mark in his comments about the Senate and the way it deals with these matters.

It seems there is a lot of confusion on the other side about these matters. I hope that the Clerk's advice, which is now on record in this chamber, will be of assistance in understanding this matter when it arises on future occasions. In other circumstances I would be much firmer on this and insist that it go back as an amendment rather than acquiesce in the requirement of the House of Representatives' that it be a request.

However, it is very late on the last day of a very long session and, somewhat regrettably but because of the hour and the work yet to be done in this chamber, I would point out that the coalition will support the motion moved by Senator Tate, notwithstanding that we think constitutionally it is quite wrong. I just regret we are at a stage in the proceedings where it would not be well looked upon by my colleagues if we took the matter any further at this stage. However, this is a matter that should be cleared up later.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to make four points, all of which are in support of my colleague Senator Macdonald and have the end result of supporting the pragmatic approach of the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, section 53 of the Constitution will not be avoided by any of us. Anything that is done in the Senate or the House of Representatives must uphold that relevant part of the Constitution. Therefore, any dispute or discussion is only to clarify what the genuine intent and rightful application of that part of the Constitution is in this matter.

Secondly, we are in the last day or so of the sitting of this Parliament and it is pragmatic to see the intention of the Senate achieved by the form of words that the Minister has used. However, I wish to emphasise, as Senator Macdonald did, that in no way are we as senators conceding the outcome of the argument, which ought to be given more time and care in discussion and advice—much more than can be given in the few hours that we have to debate the matter in the face of the necessity of seeing the Bill adopted by both houses.

Thirdly, it is clear from the Clerk's advice, which has been incorporated in Senator Macdonald's speech, that this matter has been carefully considered by officers and members of the Senate for more than a decade. Precedents touching upon this matter occurred particularly in 1981 and 1991. We will not escape upholding section 53 of the Constitution, and it would appear to me at this stage that the Clerk's advice does that.

Fourthly and finally, I happened to be watching the direct live television broadcast of the House of Representatives debate on our message. At that time there were very few members in the House of Representatives and it was handled by interruption of the business that was then being transacted. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who was discussing industrial relations, took his place while the Speaker came in and made the announcement to the House of Representatives. Then, with no more warning than that, the member for New England, the right honourable Ian Sinclair, with whom I had dined just half an hour earlier, quickly jumped to his feet in his usual manner. I say `usual manner' because of his experience and knowledge of the law and the Constitution. He made a very constructive point with regard to what we, in very loose fashion, see as the money power of the House of Representatives. It was in such general terms that I fully understood the motivations both of the Speaker and of Mr Sinclair in their rather unresearched but immediate constructive remarks protecting the constitutional rights of the House of Representatives.

On deeper reflection, I feel that the Clerks of our two Houses and the members involved in the discussion will come to a consolidated view. I hope that that view will be along the lines of our Clerk's advice.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.
