That, in accordance with paragraph 49(1)(b) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, the Senate approves the making of regulations the same in substance as regulations made under the Broadcasting Act 1922, deemed to have been disallowed at the expiration of 26 May 1992, namely:

PROCTEXT.PARA: Political Broadcasts (New South Wales) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 489 and made under the Broadcasting Act 1942;
Political Broadcasts (New South Wales) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1992 No. 3 and made under the Broadcasting Act 1942;
Political Broadcasts (New South Wales) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1992 No. 6 and made under the Broadcasting Act 1942;
Political Broadcasts (Australian Capital Territory) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1992 No. 1 and made under the Broadcasting Act 1942;
Political Broadcasts (Tasmania) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1992 No. 2 and made under the Broadcasting Act 1942;
Political Broadcasts (Australian Capital Territory) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1992 No. 4 and made under the Broadcasting Act 1942; and
Political Broadcasts (Tasmania) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1992 No. 5 and made under the Broadcasting Act 1942.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will very briefly explain the genesis of this motion.
—We know the genesis of it.

—Well, I will not spend much time on that at this stage. The necessity for this procedure stems from the fact that a few months ago Senator Parer moved a disallowance motion in this place. That motion was not debated in the Senate, but not dealing with it had the effect of precluding further action by the Government for a six-month period from the date of it not being dealt with.

PARA.TAB: I will refer to the relevant provisions in the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 to lay the groundwork with respect to this. Section 48(5A) of the Act says that if a disallowance resolution in respect of regulations has been moved, but that notice has not been withdrawn and the motion has not been called on, or the motion has been called on, moved and seconded and has not been withdrawn or otherwise disposed of, the regulation specified in the motion shall thereupon be deemed to have been disallowed. Therefore, for the purposes of the Acts Interpretation Act, in law, the regulations which were the subject of Senator Parer's notice of motion in this place are, pursuant to that section that I have read, deemed to have been disallowed.

What is the effect of that? The effect of that becomes quite clear when one looks at section 49(1) of the same Act. It says that if a regulation is deemed to have been disallowed under section 49(1), then no regulation which is the same in substance as the regulation so disallowed, or deemed to have been disallowed, shall be made within six months after the date of the disallowance. The result would be that any regulations that would be made to provide for free time with respect to State elections would, pursuant to the Acts Interpretation Act, not be able to be made for six months from the date of the disallowance or the deemed disallowance.

The Government is obviously very keen—and we had this debate some time last year—to ensure that the full impact of our legislation in this area takes effect. The question was basically whether to have a massive debate a few weeks ago in response to Senator Parer's notice of motion, or whether to have one later in the session. What has obviously happened is that we are having one later in the session.

The Government's intention is to draft a comprehensive set of regulations to cover State, Commonwealth and Territory elections to provide for free time pursuant to the Act that was passed in this Parliament. To do that, and for the regulations to have the effect of applying in those States that are mentioned in the notice of motion, we have to do one of two things. Either we cannot bring them into effect for six months from the date of disallowance, or we have to move the notice of motion that is before the chamber at the moment.

Being keen to ensure that the regulations have an impact as soon as possible, obviously we are moving this particular notice of motion tonight to allow us to implement an Act of this Parliament which was passed towards the end of last year. In fact, it was given assent on 19 December last year. Therefore, this resolution before the Parliament ensures continuing effect of an Act passed by both Houses in this place.As I have said, we are preparing regulations to cover the field in terms of State, Territory and Commonwealth elections—one comprehensive set of regulations which will apply to all future elections. That is the guts of the proposal before us.

I am sure that there will be some debate on this legislation, which has attracted some controversy. I could go back through the debate, but that would not serve the purpose of this Parliament all that much. However, I want to make the point that progressively over the last seven or eight months we have had more and more indications of the success of the Government's proposals last year. I think as time goes by there will be a growing acceptance of what we did last year and of the necessity for it. We will have a repeat of previous debates on this matter. A lot will be made of the fact that some people claim that this side of the Parliament, in a party sense, is broke, and that that is why we have actually introduced this legislation. I do not think that is a fair assessment; in fact, I am quite sure it is not.

Having made that point, I was interested to read on 9 June—some two or three weeks ago—an article in the Australian, under the headline `Lib branch broke in fight against Goss', which contained comments by Mr Everingham, the Queensland State President of the Liberal Party. The leading paragraph is interesting. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Queensland Liberal Party is broke and will be campaigning for the upcoming State and federal elections on a shoestring budget complemented by whatever volunteer services the party membership can muster.
Mr Everingham made the following interesting point in that article:

PARA.TAB: `All along the Labor Party and the National Party have both depended on deep pockets to win elections for themselves'.

SPEECH.PARA: Being a Liberal, he does not include himself in that. He goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: `But I think perhaps what the Federal Government has done with electronic advertising laws will suit the Liberal Party because we're going to depend very much on our own resources rather than the power of the big purse.
`So this is an opportunity to capitalise on our lack of financial resources.'

SPEECH.PARA: There is a clear acknowledgment by the Opposition of the necessity for legislation such as this. Not only can it be alleged that one side of the process may be strapped for funds, but I think it is fair to say that the experience in this country, as well as overseas, is that it is becoming more and more difficult for parties and individuals to become part electoral process.

PARA.TAB: Everingham's intervention in this process is not just one-off. During the Tasmanian election, Michael Hodgman, a former member of the House of Representatives, discussed the legislation which is the subject of debate tonight. What he said is reported in the Age of 1 February 1992. As a consequence of that, it was pretty clear that politicians were getting closer to the electorate. He basically said something that I have believed in all along in this debate. He said, `I think people are very glad not to see politicians in their living rooms all the time'. In the context of that, it is interesting that the Tasmanian campaign director, Mr Bob Lister, is on the record as saying that he did not believe the ban caused any disadvantage for any particular party.

I think the legislation has been successful. That success is not only evidenced by Hodgman and Lister but also by the current Premier of Tasmania in his comments around the time of the Tasmanian election. He is reported in the Australian of 13 January as making a point which basically confirms one of the Government's intentions when we introduced this legislation. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberals' total expenditure will be less than half the average amount spent by a successful single candidate at the last federal election.
That is the expenditure for the State election in Tasmania. What we have seen since this legislation has been in place is the democratic process working fairly well.

PARA.TAB: We have a change of government in Tasmania. We had massive turnouts in that election. For instance, the voter turnout for Denison in the 1989 election was 92.14 per cent. Without advertising, the turnout in Denison for the State election was 95.8 per cent. That rejects the claim that people would not know about elections. It is also interesting to note that in the Entrance by-election in New South Wales conducted at the start of this year, the voter turnout was 91 per cent despite the fact that the poll took place during school holidays and postal voting was not available.

Legislation was passed in this place to ensure that campaign funds and all donations into and out of organisations involved in the political process were made transparent. I think as time goes on this legislation will be acclaimed as being extremely successful and extremely valuable to our process.

As the second leg of the Government's program, we were very keen to ensure that the costs of campaigning were reduced. We embarked upon a course which has been adopted by, in one way or another, most Western democracies. It is a course which limits the capacity to advertise on electronic media, a medium which has been recognised as being the Bermuda Triangle of campaign spending. That is why other countries have done it and that is why we have done it. The evidence so far has indicated that we have been successful in that respect.

The other thing that I think future generations of Australians will acclaim this legislation for is that we will not have to worry about the Perot syndrome. When one can see, as starkly as we can, that a rich individual can buy, or get close to buying, the presidency of the United States, one has to worry about the capacity to buy elections. This legislation ensures that we will not have that sort of situation in Australia.

The intention of the motion before the Senate tonight is to ensure that the legislation that was passed by this chamber in the last few weeks of December last year can be given effect as soon as possible. As I explained earlier, to do that we have to pass the motion that is now before us.

Some suggestion will be made—it is always made—that the Government did not get it right in the first place. Let me say in response to that that officers have been working on regulations in this area for quite some time and it is our intention to get the comprehensive set of regulations in place as soon as possible. I expect that will happen over the next month or two. Once that is in place, obviously free time will apply in all State, Commonwealth and Territory elections into the future. The two objectives which set the Government on its course at the outset will then have been achieved—namely, the disclosure of parties funding; and a decrease in the necessity to raise and to expend millions of dollars.

We in Australia probably have been spending more per capita on Federal elections than has been spent in recent years for US presidential elections. It is a situation that we could not have allowed to continued. We have acted responsibly and we have had the support of the Senate.

The assertion made by senators on the other side of the chamber that this has been done to satisfy one party is not confirmed by facts. As I have pointed out, the Queensland Liberal Party President is one person who has been honest about this. If one were to look at the Liberal Party across the country one would find that it, like other parties in the process, is stretched for resources. The rhetorical point to be made is that if we, as major political parties, cannot afford to be part of the process, then what hope do other individuals in our society have? It is a very democratic measure and I urge the Senate to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) has moved that in accordance with the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, the Senate approves the making of regulations under the Broadcasting Act 1922, which were deemed to have been disallowed on 26 May 1992. I move:

PARA.TAB: At end of motion add:

SPEECH.PARA: subject to the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) tabling the legal advice provided to the Government by the Chief General Counsel in relation to regulations and referred to during the debate in the Senate on 26 February 1992.
We have a very serious reason for moving that amendment and I will come back to it later.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to intervene for a second. With your indulgence, Senator Parer, I indicate that the advice I have had has been verbal. The best I can do is table those sections of the Acts Interpretation Act, which we are all presumed to know, which confirm our position. I have not been handed any written advice.

—I am glad the Minister intervened because my understanding is that when I gave the legal advice provided by the Clerk, the Minister said that he had advice from the Chief General Counsel. I will come back to that later and perhaps the Minister can refer to it at that stage.

PARA.TAB: This is yet another chapter in a very sorry and sordid saga of a government, aided and abetted by the Democrats, which sought to restrict freedom of speech and freedom of political expression in Australia. It is all very well for Senator Bolkus to stand up here and give all the reasons in the world as to why this particular method of approach—of restricting freedom of political expression in Australia—is a good idea. It is the most outrageous attack on freedom of speech that this country has ever seen.

A deal was first struck with the then Leader of the Democrats, Senator Powell. Ironically, it was because of that perceived deal that Senator Powell found herself in trouble and the benign Senator Coulter then decided he would make a challenge. I can recall having a debate on Brisbane radio on the Haydn Sargent show with Senator Kernot. I said, `It's perfectly obvious, isn't it, that a deal has been made between Senator Powell and Senator Bolkus'. She hesitated and said, `I hope not'. Out of all that came a new leader and a promise by the Democrats that they would not support this attack on freedom of speech.

However, Senator Bolkus was awake to this. He knew that when the Democrats, who claimed they came in here to keep the bastards honest, were offered the choice of money or principle, they would take the money. Out of all this came all sorts of freebies for the Democrats which they never would have been able to support in a future election campaign. It was from that point that grubby self-interest became the guiding light of the Democrats except, to be fair, for Senator Sowada, who did not at any stage support the rest of the Democrats on this atrocious Bill.

The Bill to ban all political advertising on radio and television during all election campaigns—Federal and State—became law on 19 December 1991, a black day for freedom and a black day for democracy in Australia. However, that was not the end of it. We were then subject to a series of events which reflected the absolute incompetence of this Government and this Minister. Let me recount them as best as I can. The Bill became an Act on 19 December 1991. The statutory rules were made on 23 December for application on 1 January 1992, however they were gazetted on 3 January, which was after the date of application.

I asked the Clerk of the Senate to provide me with an opinion as to whether the regulations put forward were valid. On 23 January 1992 the Clerk obtained a legal opinion for me which indicated that the regulations were invalid. As a result of that, I issued a press release which said that on the opinion obtained by the Clerk of the Senate, the regulations as put forward by the Government, were, in fact, invalid and I attached the legal opinion to that press release. In subsequent debate in this place, Senator Bolkus made some remarks; in fact, he made the remarks publicly through the press. It was reported that Senator Bolkus accused the Opposition, me in particular, of running a very emotive and very dishonest campaign. I believe that Senator Bolkus sailed very close to the wind with those statements. The last thing in the world that could be said was that that campaign was dishonest.

The Clerk in this chamber gave me an opinion at my request. It is the responsibility of the Clerk to respond to requests, whether it be from the Labor Party, the Liberal Party, the National Party or the Democrats. In subsequent debate—and this is the reason for our amendment to this motion—he was ferociously attacked by this particular Minister because he responded to my request and gave me the opinion that he did.

I subsequently gave notice to disallow the regulations made under the Political Broadcasts Act 1991 on the condition that the Minister table the advice given to him, because he claimed that his advice was correct and the advice given to me was incorrect. It was a matter of, `We have put up our legal advice'—it was an opinion, and everyone knew it was an opinion—`you put up yours'. The Minister refused to do that. Therefore, when I gave my notice to disallow I put the requirement in it that he would provide his legal advice, at which stage those particular regulations would have been accepted. He refused to do it. With the effluxion of time—the 15 days after that notice of motion—there was no response whatsoever from the Minister which meant that the regulations had been disallowed. Hence, we are now at the position we are in today where the Minister has to bring in a notice of motion to the effect that, in accordance with the Acts Interpretation Act, these particular regulations would be allowed.

The question one asks is: why is the Minister now bringing in regulations with regard to New South Wales? I think we can understand how these regulations occurred. Initially, when there were rumours floating around that this Act was going to be introduced, I asked the Minister in this place: is it a fact that Mr Hogg, the General Secretary of the Labor Party, is behind a move to ban all political advertising on radio and television? He denied it in the Parliament and subsequently came in and introduced it.

What happened recently? We have had some problems in New South Wales in recent weeks. I guess what happened is that the phone rang and Mr Hogg said, `Is that you, Nick, the leak? It's Hogg here'. `Yes, Paul, mate', said the Minister, `What can I do for you?'. Mr Hogg said, `No, no, Nick, it's not the PM, comrade; it's Bob Hogg, General Secretary of the Labor Party. You know, we're both in the socialist Left'. Just because he said `Hogg', the Minister thought it was the Prime Minister.

Mr Hogg went on to say, `I suppose you've noticed, comrade, that with the assistance of the minority in New South Wales we look like getting Greiner. We had to get him, comrade; he was probably the most honest Premier that New South Wales has ever seen and they are the most dangerous people you can have. He was a real concern; we had to do something about him. Anyway, what I rang you for is to make sure that the regulations are in place under the ad ban Act in case there's an election in New South Wales. And don't stuff it up the way you did last time'.

The Minister said, `I cannot bring in new regulations for five months because the previous regulations were deemed to have been disallowed, but with the support of the Democrats we could seek approval in accordance with paragraph 49(1)(b) of the Acts Interpretation Act'. Hogg said, `They have already sold their souls; they've already taken the money instead of principle'. The Minister responded, `Listen, Hogg, you should be all right. Senator Sowada will probably support the Opposition if she's consistent. By the way, comrade, are you paying for this phone call?'. Hogg said, `Well, no, comrade, but the Party is. Why do you ask?'. The Minister then said, `Well, it's something that haunts me from time to time'. That is the background to where we got to today. These regulations had to be brought in.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister is again being requested by Mr Hogg to introduce some regulations just in case there might be an election in New South Wales.
—Don't give up your day job. You have got them worried, Warwick. You stick to being a straight man.

—Senator Faulkner could never be a straight man. He makes life great for us on this side of the chamber. I ask the Labor Party to please keep him there. I know he is a member of the socialist Left, but we must always have a Senator Faulkner.

PARA.TAB: This is the position in which we find ourselves. There is one thing I would like to say to the Democrats. We have moved an amendment to the Minister's motion. The reason we have moved this amendment to the motion is that we think it is vital that this Senate determines once and for all the right of every honourable senator to go to the Clerks of this Senate for advice and the responsibility of those Clerks to give that advice. It is all right for Senator Collins to nod, but it was because of the advice given by the Clerks that the Minister abused the Clerks for giving the advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can take it.

—The Clerks are in a vulnerable position. They are in no position to respond. It is all very well for Senator Collins to make a flippant remark like that. It shows the sort of arrogance that Government members show towards a very important institution within the parliamentary system.
—They are the hinges on which the doors of democracy swing.

—Senator Collins might tell his colleague about that because that certainly was not the case. That is the purpose behind it. When that opinion was given, we laid it on the table. The Minister claimed that our opinion was wrong and that I was being dishonest in what I did. He said he had an opinion from the Chief General Counsel that refuted the advice given to me by the Clerks.

PARA.TAB: I then challenged the Minister to produce that advice and he refused to do so. In subsequent motions by me to disallow the regulations, I again threw out the challenge to the Minister. That is the present position. We have moved the amendment. It is up to the Minister to provide that advice. It is up to the Democrats to determine once and for all whether it is right and proper that we receive that advice from the Clerks and that they themselves have a responsibility to do it and that they can be shielded from being unnecessarily abused by an arrogant Minister and a very arrogant Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly in support of my colleague Senator Parer and to strongly support the remarks he has made to the chamber this evening. In particular, I wish to underline the concern that Senator Bolkus caused with his most unfortunate attack on the Clerks. Naturally, Senator Parer in the course of the debate on this issue sought advice quite properly from the Clerks and Senator Bolkus tried to make a political issue of this.

PARA.TAB: We have seen this sort of behaviour a couple of times in the last year or so where the Clerks have been subjected to what can only be described as political attack. My view is that the debate should be focused not on the source of the advice but on the quality of the advice. The mindless and needless attack on the Clerk by Senator Bolkus was most unfortunate and needless.

The reason I rise in the debate this evening is to draw attention to one of the concerns which was predicted at the time of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures and which, in my view, has now come to pass. It was certainly not mentioned by Senator Bolkus in his remarks. Senator Kernot, who is now in the chamber, will recall that there was concern. In the attempt to ban political advertising on radio and TV by political parties concern was expressed that special interest groups may be able to pick up broadcasts where the major political parties were banned. Unfortunately, this has occurred.

I instance a very serious matter which I think will become the focus of attention in this chamber and in the other place over the coming months, certainly as we move towards the election. I refer to the fact that on 14 May 1992 the Australian ran a story headed, `Unions plan $10m attack on Coalition'. In general, I have no objection to interest groups strongly putting their views—they are entitled to put their views—but in this case we are dealing with a movement that is receiving very large handouts from the Government, handouts of the order of $40m. Honourable senators will remember the massive amount of money given in special grants to trade unions and the ACTU and the grants that Senator Cook gave to assist with union amalgamations. All this has added up to millions of dollars from the taxpayer.

What is of particular concern to me is that, whether or not the union movement needed all this money and the taxpayer was required to give all this money to trade unions, these figures have never been refuted by the trade union movement or the Government, despite the very extensive press that Senator Short has given to highlight this problem and others in this place. They cannot refute them because these figures are of course based on the information—

TALK.START.PARA: —Thanks for that speech. Goodnight.

—I know this is embarrassing to Senator Faulkner, but bear with us. The issue of corruption has been highlighted recently. I know that Senator Faulkner is particularly concerned about corruption and has raised his concerns about particular activities in the press and at recent Labor Party conferences. The trade union movement is apparently able to find $10m to conduct a campaign against the coalition, but the same trade union movement is apparently entitled to receive millions upon millions—and I have mentioned the figure of $40m—from the taxpayer.

PARA.TAB: We wait to see the sort of campaign that the unions will outline. Undoubtedly, there will be media campaigns, and one assumes it is possible that we will see—would you believe it—political ads on the radio and TV. This is a major issue—I know this is well supported by a number of my colleagues—and it is extraordinary that an organisation which is so desperate to get funds from the Government to fund a whole range of activities and assist with amalgamations is able to find $10m to conduct a political campaign against the coalition.

I suggest that this issue will be a matter of public inquiry and public debate. It was interesting that at the ACTU congress last year—and I know this will be of concern to you, Madam Acting Deputy President—the ACTU revealed that Commonwealth grants to the ACTU fund 10 members of its staff. How come an organisation which needs government grants to fund its staff can find money to conduct political campaigns against the political opponents of the Labor Party? I suggest that this will become a very big issue.

This whole stunt to ban political advertising was to shackle the political opponents of the Labor Party. Bob Hogg was asked in evidence before the Committee whether the Labor Party was the political arm of the trade union movement. How come this organisation can now find all this money to campaign against the coalition? I believe that there is a prima facie case that the Labor Party is funding a political campaign against its political opponents by providing large scale grants to the trade union movement.

Senator Bolkus is looking concerned, as well he might, because the game plan was precisely to shackle the political opponents of the Labor Party. The view was put by me to the Committee that we would be seeing vigorous trade union campaigns to support its political party's run against the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you watch the Couchman program on life in New Zealand?
—I know that this is causing Senator Collins concern—as well it might.
—Ten dollars an hour, 45 hours a week, no penalty rates and no overtime.

—I do not know why Senator Collins raises the example of New Zealand because the story in New Zealand is particularly attractive for working men and women. I am surprised that he raised that issue. It is an interesting feature that, after the last election campaign, the Party of Senator Bolkus and Senator Faulkner was so strapped for funds that it had to sell one-third of John Curtin House. We are still waiting to hear how much the ACTU was able to pay for that one-third share. That figure is still not yet publicly—
—The answer to that is none of your business.

—It is my business if my money has been used to help fund this purchase. We know that the ACTU has received some $12m in grants from the taxpayer. If the ACTU received $12m in grants from the taxpayer and was able to find $2m, $3m or $4m to buy its share of John Curtin House, it is of major concern to the taxpayer, because my taxes and other people's taxes have been used to do this deal.

PARA.TAB: The point I am making to the chamber is that the entire Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill was designed to inhibit the opponents of the Labor Party from putting their views to the public while the Labor Party mates in the trade union movement—
Government senators interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Order! Proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I have but a few minutes to go. I wonder whether it would be possible for you to instruct your colleagues on that side of the chamber to restrain themselves briefly for some two minutes.
—I cannot prevent people from interjecting, but I do ask them to restrain themselves.
—We will observe two minutes silence in memory of you.

—Thank you very much. I certainly appreciate the promise which we have managed to extract from Senator Collins. This is the background to the regulations which are now before the Parliament. This is the background which was predicted at the time of the special standing committee which was established to examine this issue. We would find—
—Select. I was on it.
—Just proceed. It is your time, so take it.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, you have asked them to keep quiet and they are flouting your ruling. I ask you to enforce your ruling.
—No, I did not ask them to keep quiet; I asked them to moderate their interjections, as I would ask of interjectors on my left.
—I would hope, Madam Acting Deputy President, that you would be even-handed on this issue.
—I am being even-handed.

—I am delighted to hear it, but I notice that your colleagues are ignoring your ruling. What was predicted at the time has now come to pass. The unions are now planning to run a $10m campaign against the coalition. The trade unions have received $40m from the taxpayer. We in this Parliament are concerned to ensure proper accountability of taxpayers' funds. I believe that what was predicted at this Committee has now come to pass. This will not be the last time that this issue is raised in the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the motion. We do not think anything substantial has changed to alter the principles and the intent of the Act and the regulations. The making of regulations for New South Wales is necessary. There is absolutely no need to recanvass all the old arguments. You boys can fight all you like about who has raised the most funds, but it will not make any difference to the opinion of the Democrats.

PARA.TAB: I want to take one minute to draw to the attention of honourable senators an article in an American publication, National Journal, of 4 April 1992 entitled, `Ad Attack', which deals with the American political campaign. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: This election season, truth in advertising may have taken on a new meaning. Press and public interest watchdogs are barking louder than ever, and the Federal Communications Commission has entered the fray with a vigour that has not been seen in 20 years.

The article goes on to outline the public's outrage at the negative and dishonest advertising and how its reservoir of tolerance is being exhausted. I draw that article to the attention of honourable senators.

PARA.TAB: I believe that we have made the right decision in supporting this motion. We have acted in time to prevent us reaching a situation in Australia where we have to contend with that which is described in this journal.

The issue before the chamber tonight is a different one. As I said earlier, I have received no written legal advice on the need for this exercise this evening. There is really nothing else that needs a reply, other than for me to indicate that the Opposition has clearly lost the debate tonight. I would honestly like to know what Senator Parer is on because the last person—
—He wants some.
—I want some.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Advice and Report From the Privacy Commissioner on the Disclosure of Arrest Details of AIDEX Demonstrators

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report of the Privacy Commissioner on the disclosure of arrest details of AIDEX demonstrators and seek leave to make a statement on my own behalf and on behalf of the Minister for Social Security.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.
—No, I want to hear what the answer is.
—I wish to inform honourable senators that this statement is also being delivered in the House of Representatives today by the Hon. Dr Neal Blewett MP, Minister for Social Security.

PARA.TAB: First, Dr Blewett and I welcome this report, as we welcomed the Privacy Commissioner's decision to initiate an inquiry.Second, as a fundamental principle we endorse the right of any person, employed or unemployed, to exercise their democratic rights, including the right to protest. We also endorse the right to privacy.

In his report, the Privacy Commissioner quite rightly points to the sensitivity of actions which touch on the exercise of civil and political rights. But our democratic society is one in which rights are accompanied by obligations. Individuals must exercise their rights consistent with those obligations. Employed people have obligations under industrial law and people receiving income support payments such as Job Search allowance have obligations under social security law. Rights cannot be exercised with complete disregard of those obligations. The striking of a balance between these rights and obligations can be complex, and goes to the very heart of the issues canvassed by the Privacy Commissioner.

Similarly, the right to privacy, whilst of paramount importance, is not absolute. There is a longstanding tension between minimising fraud on the public purse and minimising intrusion by government bodies into the personal affairs of citizens. Again, a careful balance must be struck. The community expects no less. In working to achieve this balance, we welcome the involvement of the Privacy Commissioner.

The particular and general issues raised by the Privacy Commissioner in relation to the operation of the Privacy Act deserve careful consideration by Government. A working group, chaired by the Attorney-General's Department and including representatives of the Department of Social Security, the Australian Federal Police and the Privacy Commissioner, will examine these matters.

The examination by this working group of the issues noted by the Privacy Commissioner will include consideration of the use by the Department of Social Security of formal demands for information from other Commonwealth agencies, and the return of information supplied mistakenly or without proper authority.

The Government accepts the comment of the Director of the Privacy Compliance Unit that the release of the information by the Australian Federal Police was not in accordance with its own internal procedures governing the release of information, but notes the Director's comment that the release was inadvertent—paragraph 3.2 of his report. The AFP officer who released the original list on or about 20 December 1991 was not an authorised records review officer under the AFP's internal procedures. The Government accepts the Privacy Commissioner's finding that the internal policy of the AFP relating to the release of information was not adequately implemented in this case.

Shortly after the inadvertent release of the information, the AFP examined its internal procedures to ensure that as far as possible there would be no recurrence of this kind of incident. The Commissioner advises that the AFP's training relating to the release of information has been upgraded, that the AFP is confident that effective internal mechanisms now exist to control the release of information and that the need for proper supervision has been reinforced.

These particular measures must be accompanied by a more general sympathetic understanding of and sensitivity to the fundamental values embodied in the Privacy Act, though also giving due weight to the proper provision for the enforcement of the criminal law or of a law imposing a pecuniary penalty, or for the protection of the public revenue.
Having made that statement, I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement and document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the advice and report to Ministers regarding the disclosure of arrest details of AIDEX demonstrators, the Privacy Commissioner concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Department of Social Security should develop a clear policy as to circumstances in which it is appropriate for the Department to make requests for information . . . The policy should address specifically the need for officers to be mindful of the negative effect on the exercise of civil and political rights that certain kinds of requests may have. The policy should make clear that the factors upon which the Department relies in making a request . . . must be sufficient to ensure that the other agency . . . does not itself breach the Privacy Act in effecting disclosure.

The disclosure of the arrest list information by the Australian Federal Police . . . was unauthorised. . . On the basis of the material currently available to me, breached Information Privacy Principle 4.
The principle reads:
A record-keeper who has possession or control of a record that contains personal information shall ensure:

(a) that the record is protected, by such security safeguards as it is reasonable in the circumstances to take, against loss, against unauthorised access, use, modification or disclosure, and against other misuse; and

(b) that if it is necessary for the record to be given to a person in connection with the provision of a service to the record-keeper, everything reasonably within the power of the record-keeper is done to prevent unauthorised use or disclosure of information contained in the record.
The Privacy Commissioner recommends that the Australian Federal Police undertake procedures, including the training of its officers, to prevent the recurrence of this kind of mistake.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Tate said, the AFP has taken action to address this issue. The Privacy Commissioner recommended that the Privacy Act be clarified in relation to whether agencies, once they became aware that information has been supplied mistakenly or without proper authority, are entitled to continue to act on the information or should return it to the source agency. Finally, the Privacy Commissioner concludes that he does not agree with the contention that the disclosure, even if authorised, did not breach information privacy principle 11 because it conformed to exception (e) of the principle. However, the Privacy Commissioner concludes:

SPEECH.PARA: It would greatly assist the effective administration of the Privacy Act if Parliament made it clear what, if any, constraints are meant to be provided by exception (e).
Information Privacy Principle 11(e) states:

A record-keeper who has possession or control of a record that contains personal information shall not disclose the information to a person, body or agency (other than the individual concerned) unless:
(e)the disclosure is reasonably necessary for the enforcement of the criminal law or of a law imposing a pecuniary penalty, or for the protection of the public revenue.

So the Privacy Commissioner's conclusions are pretty clear cut. First of all, he states that there has been a breach of information privacy principles 4 and 11. He expresses concern about the Social Security Act in so far as it outlines the circumstances in which a request can be made by the Department for information. Thirdly, he expresses concerns that the Privacy Act does not allow or preclude agencies from continuing to use unauthorised information rather than returning it to the source agency and, finally, recommends that the AFP should institute procedures to prevent the recurrence of such a mistake.

PARA.TAB: The Privacy Commissioner's recommendations are clear cut because it is clear cut as to what actually happened. He lists in this report day by day the events that occurred. I will not go through all of those at this stage, but first of all DSS asked for the names of Aidex demonstrators despite its supposed expert knowledge of the Privacy Act. Secondly, a list drawn from the police records containing the names, addresses and dates of birth of 238 individuals was given to DSS by the AFP. Thirdly, the DSS distributed the list to regional offices and provided instructions for the review of those listed. Fourthly, one DSS officer even managed to get another copy of a part of the list from the AFP despite the officer in charge of the strategic intelligence in AFP advising the potential privacy constraints. Fifthly, three weeks after the release of the information, written advice was provided by the administrative law branch that the information should not be released. Sixthly, DSS had no record of receiving this advice from the administrative law branch.

This is bureaucratic bungling at its worst in the AFP. It had lost advices; one area did not know what the other area was doing; and a total breakdown seemed to occur between junior and senior officers in the AFP. In the Department of Social Security, from the Secretary down, we had either a lack of knowledge of or a complete lack of respect for the Privacy Act. It was the Secretary who annotated the original press clipping and sent it to the Privacy, Fraud and Control Branch of DSS. I admit there is a possibility that the interpretation of that annotation on the press clipping could have been interpreted as `Can we obtain the information?'—in other words, as a question or as a direction. Perhaps we should have expected the Secretary not to have put such an ambiguous note on the press release. Presumably the AFP liaison officer in DSS was either from the Privacy Branch or in contact with that branch, yet no-one in DSS, from the Secretary down—including the Privacy Branch—had seen fit to take account of the important privacy considerations.

Then we have the Government's response to the Privacy Commissioner's findings. It claims that it is a case of weighing up a person's rights and their obligations as social security beneficiaries. There are also claims of a longstanding tension between fraud and privacy. What evidence did DSS have that any of the other 200 protesters on the list, bar one, had anything to do with DSS? These claims just do not gel in this case; nor does the claim that the release of the information was inadvertent. It is not really a valid excuse. The admitted fact of the matter is that the release by the Australian Federal Police was in breach of its internal procedures governing the release of information, as well as a breach of the Privacy Act.

Finally, it is not good enough for the Government to rely on the fact that the AFP examined its internal procedures after the release of the information. The coalition welcomes the setting up of the joint working group to examine the matters in the Privacy Commissioner's report. I give notice that we will be making sure that this working group is not just a damage control mechanism which will gloss over these very damning findings.

I wonder whether this is something that the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs could look at. That might require a notice of motion from me during the next parliamentary session. The Privacy Commissioner has in particular asked two things. On page (i) of his summary, he states:

The Privacy Act should be clarified in relation to whether agencies, once they become aware that personal information has been supplied mistakenly or without proper authority, are entitled to continue to act on the information or should return it to the source agency.

SPEECH.PARA: On page (ii) at point 6, he states:

PARA.TAB: It would greatly assist the effective administrative of the Privacy Act if Parliament made it clear what, if any, constraints are meant to be provided by exception (e) of Information Privacy Principle 11.1 in respect of the flow of personal information within Commonwealth administration.

SPEECH.PARA: That is something that we as a Senate could legitimately address because it is, as Senator Tate has said, a balance between fraud and privacy. We have to be very careful at any stage that information is passed between departments, especially at a junior level or without proper authority. We need to examine that and to respond as a Parliament to the Privacy Commissioner's concerns. I hope that in some way, especially through the Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, we can address the two issues that the Privacy Commissioner has raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate tonight is debating the Advice and Report to Ministers—Disclosure of Arrest Details of AIDEX Demonstrators: Australian Federal Police and Department of Social Security, which relates to the release of information by the Australian Federal Police to the Department of Social Security. I do not intend to rehearse all the details that have been recounted by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) and so ably by the previous speaker. However, I shall try to lift out one or two of the major, valuable conclusions that the Privacy Commissioner has drawn which should be considered very closely by the joint working group but which also set up certain standards.

PARA.TAB: In the first instance, the Privacy Commissioner says that the disclosure of the arrest list information by the Australian Federal Police to the Department of Social Security was unauthorised. To a large extent that relates to the actual regulations of the Australian Federal Police, the mix up that occurred between various levels in the AFP. But also it leads back to the basic question of whether the Department of Social Security was in the first place entitled to make that request in the form in which it was made. We need to consider this matter very carefully. This is not just a conflict between fraud and privacy, as has been said before; it is much more sensitive because it concerns the exercise of civil and political rights. We must be certain that in our system, in a democracy we do not allow departments—which are understandably and justifiably concerned about protecting the Federal revenue—to encroach upon the civil and political rights of citizens.

I note that the Privacy Commissioner in this report refers to the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Social Security and the Australian Customs Service as having an almost unlimited licence in our system. In the perception of the community, they have licence to pursue people who are suspected of defrauding the public revenue system. In this case the Privacy Commissioner found that the request was informal. It was not a formal request. However, it extended to 283 people who had participated in the Aidex demonstration.

The starting point of this exercise was a press report and a photograph of one demonstrator—one person. As it happens, that person's name was not included in the list of the 283 people whose names were requested by the Department. Therefore, we need to draw the conclusion that the Privacy Commissioner—and I heartily agree with him—found that section 11E, which enjoins government departments and officers to protect public revenue, does not entitle them to go on a fishing expedition. It does not entitle them to ask for the names of whole classes—whole groups—of people simply because they have engaged in political behaviour which was similar to or the same as the political behaviour of the one person that they had possible reason to believe should be investigated as to whether any fraud on the revenue was being committed.

That is probably the single most important aspect of this report to which we should pay attention. Potentially it sets up a guideline for the future that government departments would be well advised to follow. Obviously the Australian Democrats welcome the recommendation of the Commissioner that the procedures both in the AFP and in the Department of Social Security be tightened and overhauled to ensure that the delegation of decision making to staff is properly supervised and that privacy considerations are protected at every turn.

One other matter to which I would like to briefly refer is the recommendation by the Privacy Commissioner that the adequacy of the training of officers of the AFP be examined. I believe that matter requires detailed attention, in particular from the point of view, on which this report touches, where we have a potential conflict between the exercise of civil and political rights in demonstrations by Australian citizens extending to civil disobedience protests where the behaviour of both the protesters and the police officers requires examination and where we need to set up some standards.

I believe that the training of officers goes beyond the principles of privacy. I believe that we need to consider that on occasions, when we are looking at the behaviour of police officers, it may be useful—it may even be imperative—that they do not insist upon enforcing the law to its very letter when it concerns people who are engaged in a political civil disobedience demonstration.

I think it is a principle where it is extremely difficult to establish hard and fast rules, and that is precisely why the training of officers is such a challenge. The Australian Democrats welcome the formation of the joint working group. We will contribute to the best of our ability and we will be interested in examining its results.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take just one minute to identify with what the previous speaker, Senator Spindler, has said. This is a matter of civil and political rights. I congratulate the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). I think the setting up of the work group is very important. It does worry me—and it has worried me about the whole AIDEX issue—that several issues have involved the question of people with power suppressing other people. There is a common theme. I do not want to develop it except to say that I am concerned that in both the AIDEX dispute, which we are not dealing with, and the AIDEX demonstration a question of a lack of training and discipline was involved.

PARA.TAB: While I congratulate the Minister, I am concerned. I think in both cases it comes back to the fact that we cannot blame officers if they are not trained properly. But in this case and in the case of the AIDEX demonstration itself I think it is necessary to look at the balance. Unfortunately, in this issue, I think we have a good example where the balance was not understood because of the lack of training and understanding of the people concerned.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to make provision in relation to certain crimes against the safety of ships and fixed platforms.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the following Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill implements the Convention for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts Against the Safety of Maritime Navigation and the Protocol for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts Against the Safety of Fixed Platforms Located on the Continental Shelf, both of which were done at Rome in March 1988. The convention and the protocol were drafted at an international conference convened by the International Maritime Organisation to discuss international measures that needed to be taken to protect ships and fixed platforms from acts of terrorism.

PARA.TAB: The conference took place against the background of the hijacking of the Achille Lauro in the Mediterranean Sea, during which an American tourist, Leon Klinghoffer, was murdered. That incident exposed deficiencies in international law which were fatal to attempts to bring most of the terrorists to justice. I will not now rehearse the facts in that incident. They are dealt with in some detail in various accounts. Suffice it to say that at the trial that subsequently took place in Italy only five of the 15 accused appeared before the court and the three life sentences that were imposed were imposed in absentia on terrorists who were still at large.

This unsatisfactory outcome was due, at least in part, to uncertainties about the legal position of each of the parties involved. The ship sailed under the Italian flag, the first port of call after the hijack was in Egypt and the principal victim was a citizen of the United States of America.

It is instructive to consider what would have been the position if the convention had been in operation when the incident occurred. Italy, as the flag state, and Egypt, as the state in whose territory the offenders were `found', would each have had jurisdiction and would have been obliged to consider whether to initiate prosecutions themselves or to grant extradition to another state. The United States, as the state of the victim's nationality, would also have been able to establish jurisdiction under the convention. There would be clear obligations imposed on the relevant states to take action so as to ensure the alleged offenders did not escape prosecution. A legal regime of this kind would clearly have been preferable to the situation which obtained at the time and would constitute a greater deterrent to any future terrorist act of this nature. Apart from this specific instance, the convention and the protocol deal comprehensively with acts which endanger safe navigation or operations.

The offences created by the Bill include seizing control of a ship or fixed platform, committing an act of violence against a person on board a ship or fixed platform, destroying or causing damage to a ship, its cargo or a fixed platform, placing a destructive device on a ship or fixed platform, destroying navigational facilities, giving false information likely to endanger a ship or fixed platform, causing death or injury to a person in connection with the commission of any other offence and threatening to commit certain of these offences on a ship or fixed platform.

This Bill will apply to terrorist acts of the kind perpetrated in the Achille Lauro incident. It will have no application to other acts such as might be committed during an intense industrial dispute.

The Bill will apply to an offence committed on an international voyage or on a fixed platform located on the continental shelf of a protocol state, but outside its territorial sea. It will also apply to domestic offences where the alleged offender is found in a convention or protocol state other than the one where the offence was committed and to offences committed overseas where the offender is found in Australia.

The passage of this Bill will enable Australia to become a party to the convention and to the protocol and thereby contribute to an improvement in the general international legal environment relating to counter-terrorism. The Bill complements our legislation dealing with the safety of air navigation, which is now consolidated in the Crimes (Aviation) Act 1991. It is not envisaged that the Bill will have any significant financial impact. I commend the Bill to the Senate. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
