DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on the Commonwealth's response to the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, and to move a motion to take note of the statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on 26 February the Prime Minister presented the One Nation statement. In it he announced measures to help close the gaps which for so long have separated Australians. He said then that all our efforts should go towards uniting the country. He also said we should combine a more efficient economy with a fairer and more equitable society. I wonder whether, given the hour of the night, I might seek leave to incorporate the balance of this statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 27 May was the 25th Anniversary of the 1967 referendum to give the Commonwealth the power to legislate for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
On that occasion the Prime Minister said that, as a nation, we have not yet succeeded in meeting the challenge set by the triumphant referendum result.
Today, there is no more central issue to our national identity and self-esteem than the injustices brought home to us all by the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.
There is nothing more central to our reputation in the world.
Or to the kind of democratic, just society to which we aspire.
Mr President
The needs are clear.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have about half the average yearly income of other Australians.
Participation by Aboriginal young people in post-school education is around a fifth of the rate for non-Aboriginal young people.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in all age groups have mortality rates almost three times higher than for the overall population.
The custody rate of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people is 29 times that of the general community.
These few statistics give some idea of what the Royal Commission called "the disadvantaged and unequal position" of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in all aspects of Australian society.

The Commonwealth sees the Report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody as a national opportunity for genuine change in the lives of Australia's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
On behalf of the Government, I would like to say again how much we appreciate the work of the Royal Commissioners and their staff.
Their work documented a tragic waste of life.
The Royal Commission investigated the deaths of ninety-nine Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in custody.
But at least thirty more Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have died in custody since the Royal Commission finished its investigations.
We know that nothing can remove the grief, anger and loss felt by the families, relatives and friends of those who died.
But it is fundamentally important that the Royal Commission found the real killer.
The responsibility lies in large measure with entrenched, institutionalised racism and discrimination.
Those who died were victims of over two centuries of dispossession, prejudice and neglect.
We cannot evade these harsh truths. Nor should we.
But we can work to change them.

On 31 March this year, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Robert Tickner, tabled responses by the Commonwealth and all mainland State and Territory Governments to the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.
This kind of cooperation is a truly national achievement, crossing boundaries of jurisdiction and politics.
Its importance cannot be minimised.
In our response to the Royal Commission, the Commonwealth supported all but one of the Royal Commission's recommendations.
We allocated $150 million over five years for law and justice initiatives and to assist Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in their own efforts to overcome alcohol and substance abuse.

Today we are proud to announce the second stage of the Commonwealth's response—a concerted attack on the economic and social disadvantage which is reflected nowhere more starkly than in the numbers of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in custody.
And a renewal of our commitment to empower Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders.
These measures entail an additional $250 million over five years, taking the total Commonwealth expenditure in response to the Royal Commission, over five years, to $400 million.
In difficult times, this level of funds is not easy to find. But the need must be faced.
Mr President

The Royal Commission's report described the efforts, initiatives and dedication of Aboriginal people and communities and organisations across Australia to protect their culture, restore self-esteem and achieve real equality.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are taking control of their lives and communities.
They are demonstrating the will for renewal and for self-determination.
Today the Government reaffirms its support for these Australians.
The concepts "self-determination" and "renewal" are increasingly a reality.
The structures are there to ensure both their effect and their survival.
Elected Commissioners of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission now make national decisions in Aboriginal Affairs.
Sixty elected Regional Councils now make decisions on priorities, needs and funding for their areas.
The knowledge and expertise of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations are now vital in developing and delivering important Commonwealth programs and services.
Mr President
From the beginning, the ATSIC Commissioners had a major role in shaping the responses by Governments to the Royal Commission.
I would like to express the Commonwealth's gratitude to the Chairperson of ATSIC, Miss Lois O'Donoghue, and to the Commissioners for their dedication.

I would particularly like to thank the Commissioners and Regional Councillors of ATSIC for their efforts over many months of consultations and negotiations to ensure the best possible responses by Governments to the Royal Commission.
The ATSIC Commissioners were closely involved in developing the measures announced today and endorsed this package of measures before it was considered by Cabinet.
We would also like to recognise the energy and dedication of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Robert Tickner.
His contribution has been extraordinarily valuable and central in responding to the Royal Commission.
The initiatives that the Prime Minister is announcing today constitute a renewed attack on economic and social disadvantages among Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
These are initiatives with a difference—in that they are firmly based on the notions of empowerment and self-determination.
No real change is possible without the energy and will of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people themselves.
Imposed solutions will not work.
This has been the fundamental flaw in many previous, well-intentioned policies.
We are focusing on the future—on economic development and on Aboriginal young people.
We are working for increased income in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and organisations, thus reducing dependence.
We have balanced this strong emphasis on economic development with equally strong initiatives in social and cultural self-determination.
These initiatives will mean more jobs, enterprise opportunities and more training for Aboriginal people.
They will raise community and individual incomes.
They will improve community living standards.
They will increase community self-reliance.
They will address the needs so clearly set out in the Royal Commission's report.
Mr President, I turn now to the detailed economic development aspects of this package.
$60 million over five years will be provided for a land acquisition and development program.
It will provide the capital resources and training for better use and sustainable development of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander land.
$6.6 million over the next three years will be directed to an Aboriginal Rural Resources program to encourage enterprise, particularly in managing pastoral properties.
A Community Economic Initiative Scheme, costing $23.3 million over five years, will foster local enterprises.
The Australian National Parks and Wildlife contract employment program for managing natural and cultural resources will be expanded at a cost of $10.6 million over five years.
ATSIC will develop long-term Aboriginal industry strategies in the pastoral, arts and tourism industries.
$15 million over five years will be provided for these strategies, to draw together and build on existing initiatives.
The Community Development Employment Program will be expanded at a cost of $43.9 million over five years.
This will ensure an increased emphasis on income-generation and will enable CDEP to better meet the needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women and young people.
A Young Peoples' Employment Program will be established, at a cost of $21.9 million, to provide work placements largely within Aboriginal organisations and linked to TAFE training.
The total cost of these economic development initiatives is $181.1 million over five years.
They will make a difference because they ARE different. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people will shape and control them.
Mr President, I now turn to the youth aspects of the package.

A Young Peoples' Development Program will be established, at a cost of $23 million over five years, to encourage planned community action to meet the specific needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander young people.
We will set up an Aboriginal Youth Sport and Recreation Development Program at a cost of $9 million over five years.
This initiative will provide Aboriginal sports development officers to work in communities.
$20 million over five years will be provided for 200 additional Aboriginal Education Workers from 1993.
$10 million will be provided for 600 more pre-school places for Aboriginal children from 1994.
We will also work for better Aboriginal access to pre-schools.
These measures respond directly to the strong views of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people that their children are their future.
All Australians can understand and share this view.
Mr President

We will also provide $6.9 million over five years for measures to improve cooperation between the Commonwealth, States and Territories and to assist them to monitor initiatives arising from the Royal Commission.
We have already announced that ATSIC will monitor progress by Governments in implementing the Royal Commission's recommendations.
These processes will be public and will continue our commitment to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander participation.
The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission will also report annually on the human rights situation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Australia.
The Commonwealth Government cannot, alone, eliminate the disadvantage of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
Aboriginal affairs is the concern of all Australians and their Governments.
For real change, Commonwealth, State, Territory and Local Governments must work together with Aboriginal communities and organisations.
We are making progress. On May 11, Heads of Government endorsed a framework for intergovernmental cooperation in Aboriginal affairs.
The Commonwealth is working with State, Territory and Local Governments to put this cooperative framework into action.
We will develop, with the States and Territories, a National Aboriginal Policy Statement and negotiate joint responsibility agreements in specific areas.

These arrangements will take some time to put in place. However, our discussions with the States, Territories and Local Government on the response to the Royal Commission have emphasised the need for real cooperative planning and delivery.

Among the measures announced today, the Rural Resources, Australian National Parks and Wildlife Contract Employment, Sport and Recreation and education initiatives all involve funding or delivery through the States and Territories.
Local Government is also actively involved in the intergovernmental cooperative framework now accepted by Heads of Government.
It would confer a great advantage on our efforts if local government were to actively participate in our initiatives.
We will continue to encourage practical cooperation between Local Government and Aboriginal communities and organisations—particularly the sixty ATSIC Regional Councils across Australia.
Mr President
Last year, by Act of Parliament supported by all political parties, we established the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation.
In itself, this is evidence of the desire for justice among Australians.
We have great faith in the Council and its Chairperson, former Royal Commissioner, Mr Patrick Dodson.

We think the Council offers Australia its greatest chance of learning that there is no true loyalty or affection for this country that does not include respect for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians.
Mr President
These issues are central to our nation and its future. They are also urgent.
As a nation, we face the challenge of the consequences of dispossession, conquest, brutal treatment and equally inhuman neglect of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people—the first Australians.

As the Prime Minister has said more than once in recent months, in this last decade of the 20th century there is no greater goal for Australians than the delivery of long overdue justice to Aboriginal people.
The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody reminded us of that.

This year should be the turning point: the year when as a people we decide that if we are to be truly one nation, true to our traditions and ideals, then by the year 2000 justice will have been delivered, and the shame removed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —In most respects the Opposition has adopted a bipartisan approach to the matters emerging from the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. However, we would like to make some strong points relating to this statement and some of the decisions included in it.

PARA.TAB: Countless well-meaning programs devised by countless well-meaning Ministers and bureaucrats may well have given these people a warm inner glow, but these have often led nowhere or, even worse, have cruelly raised expectations only to dash them subsequently. The Government seems to believe that another $50m per year over the next five years, on top of the $1,150m that is spent per year on Aboriginal assistance, will make the difference between success and failure. So far, we regret to say, there has been a lot of failure.

When we talk of the failures in Aboriginal Affairs, the tendency is invariably to lay the blame at somebody's feet. Often there has been a tendency to begin by blaming the Aboriginal people themselves. Yet, quite frankly, until Canberra and the well-meaning bureaucrats get out of the way of the Aboriginal people and give them greater scope to chart their own course, they will have little cause for which to thank us.

The simple fact is that the Aboriginal people want to be more responsible for themselves collectively and as individuals. They want to share in an expanding economy, but this Government has failed to deliver one. They, perhaps more than any other group in the country, cannot understand why, in a nation that is so wealthy and well placed as Australia—apart from this current recession that we had to have—they have been allowed to fall or have even been pushed so far off the pace.

The statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) talks of creating jobs for the Aboriginal people and of creating economic independence. But the only answer has been to offer more money, with little improvement in the effectiveness of its delivery or accountability. There are, of course, many other and more immediate ways to give the Aboriginal people a better chance to make it on their own.

For example, why will the Prime Minister not agree to the mining of Coronation Hill and let the Jawoyn people get on with their own lives? Why will he not let Aboriginal people negotiate directly with mining companies? Is the Prime Minister seriously saying that Aboriginal people are incapable of doing so? Is he saying that they have to be protected by two central land councils which, in so many instances, put political interests ahead of those of the Aboriginal people? There is no doubt that many Aboriginal people wanted to negotiate directly with the mining companies but were denied the right by the power of the land councils. Empowering the Aboriginal people to do that would deliver more economic independence than any quick-fix job creation program that the Government can dream up.

Despite all ATSIC's good intentions and devoted workers, the fact is that in its current form ATSIC has failed the Aboriginal people, and it has failed them principally for two reasons. First, it remains predominantly a Canberra-based operation with 88c in every dollar of its spending still being decided in Canberra; and, secondly, it has an incredibly unwieldy structure of 60 regional councils and 850 regional counsellors, which has yet to produce the outcomes we are all promised. In the whole present ATSIC structure, where is the accountability and where is the performance? Where are the benchmarks against which to measure the desired improvements in Aboriginal health, housing, education and employment opportunities? Where are the deadlines against which these performances must be assessed?

The long term success of ATSIC is vitally dependent on accountability, upon how the money is spent and upon how Aboriginal organisations and programs are monitored. We are still a long way short of attaining that success. For example, Aboriginal programs run by the Department of Employment, Education and Training are clearly in a mess. Successive Auditor-General's reports have highlighted a number of DEET's inefficiencies. We have referred to them here in the Senate often: insufficient verification checks for applications, total lack of coordination with other departments and no procedures to avoid duplication of benefits. A recent Auditor-General's report stated that auditing was not undertaken in relation to $80m of expenditure under Aboriginal education supplementary assistance because auditing had revealed that the departmental records were not adequate to determine whether payments were accurate or not.

Promises are made that things will change, but little ever seems to happen. Not only is maladministration wasting taxpayers' money and building unnecessary duplication of services but, most importantly, it is denying economic and social opportunities to the Aboriginal people—the very thing it set out to achieve. There are 1,300 to 1,400 agencies involved in the delivery of Aboriginal assistance. For example, even in the State of Victoria, there are about 174 organisations for just over 12,000 Aboriginal people—that is one organisation for every 74 Aborigines. Clearly things have to change.

The coalition's policy on the administration of ATSIC and Aboriginal Affairs, like our support for the process of reconciliation, will continue to be squarely aimed at improving the well-being of the Aboriginal people. Our priority in doing so is to help them break out of welfare dependency. The Aboriginal people themselves tell us that this dependency is slowly killing them and slowly killing their culture. Politicians and bureaucrats should be listening more closely to what the Aboriginal people have to say. It is essential that we restore self-reliance and self-respect to the Aboriginal people.

Those politicians who think solutions to Aboriginal problems are to be found simply by throwing more money at them are deluding themselves and selling the Aboriginal people short. Compassion should not be measured by the size of a government's cheque book. Adopting the spirit of the recommendations of the report on aboriginal deaths in custody gives us a real chance finally to start to get it right—not only in the way black and white Australians treat each other, but also in the ways Aboriginal affairs are conducted in the wider community.

The coalition will soon be releasing a major policy document on the administration of ATSIC and Aboriginal Affairs. This will have as its centrepiece the decentralisation of ATSIC's decision-making processes; a national funding model which will allocate funds to regions based on criteria such as capacity to use the funds effectively and efficiently; regional need and level of disadvantage; a greater planning and budgetary role for the regional councils; tighter accountability provisions for ATSIC and Aboriginal organisations that will ensure that benefits reach those who need them most; and a more community-based focus on the delivery of programs which aim to place more responsibility in the hands of the individual.

We will support ATSIC in its moves to seek bilateral joint responsibility with State and Territory governments. In this way we can ensure that State, Territory and local governments can take a greater role in managing the delivery of essential services to Aboriginal citizens.We believe this policy will deliver the best chance for economic independence—and I must keep stressing that. We are seeking economic independence for the Aboriginal people and offer a viable alternative to a life of endless dole cheques and other forms of assistance from governments.

Our policy document is the outcome of months of extensive nationwide consultation with Aboriginal people and organisations. ATSIC itself has been involved in this process. Indeed, all 850 regional councils were contacted during the formulation of our policy. Our policy is designed to address the core of the administrative problem in relation to Aboriginal Affairs, and to deliver a system in which government expenditure can achieve maximum results to the benefit of the Aboriginal people.

If economic independence can at last be given to the Aboriginal community, then we can begin to address those other problems that have divided sections of black and white Australia and have led to the continued mistreatment, abuse, discrimination and racial violence which many Aboriginal Australians experience daily. But it has to be a national effort. No longer can we accept mediocre results in Aboriginal Affairs. Only when we genuinely equip Aboriginal people for an independent economic future will black and white Australians be able to work together as friends, as equals and with mutual respect towards our common future.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly and to bring the Senate's attention to several puzzling questions that need to be raised about a proposed Commonwealth office block for Newcastle. I will tell the Senate about the way in which the proposal has been mishandled by the Department of Administrative Services and the Department of Social Security and then raise the matter of contradictory statements by the respective Ministers for those departments in relation to this proposal.

PARA.TAB: To quickly paint the picture for the Senate, two constituents asked me to look into the proposal that the Department of Administrative Services, via the Australian Property Group, had been looking at—the possibility of a Commonwealth office block in Newcastle. The Department of Social Security in Newcastle was looking for new office space. The Australian Property Group obviously felt that it might be able to take this opportunity to test the feasibility of a Commonwealth office block for the city. This would bring together the various Commonwealth departments into one area and create a badly needed stimulus for the Newcastle CBD and the Newcastle construction industry. The Department of Social Security would be the major tenant in such a building.

In order for its proposal to be taken more seriously by both the Department of Social Security and the Department of Finance, and ultimately the Cabinet, the Australian Property Group sought information so that its proposal could be as detailed as possible and therefore have a higher chance of success. Opengrand Pty Limited and the Doran group of companies, both of Newcastle, were able to provide such information. At no stage did the Australian Property Group suggest that the project was going ahead.

Opengrand had an initial meeting with the APG in May 1990. Then over the period up to January this year the APG had several meetings with Opengrand and sought information on site costs, tenant and space requirements, an architectural brief and concept proposals. The APG also inspected possible Newcastle sites, and Opengrand was given a tour of the Parramatta office block to see the preferred layout.

In September last year Opengrand was advised by the APG that its proposal would be incorporated in the APG's submission to Canberra. At this time Opengrand knew that the Australian Property Group could not guarantee that the proposal would get the okay. Then in January this year the Department of Social Security advertised that it was looking for office space. Obviously, the Commonwealth office block was no longer a consideration to that Department.

On writing to the respective Ministers to discover what was going on, I was informed by the Minister for Social Security (Dr Blewett) on 10 April this year that the option of a Commonwealth office block was not considered practical and that the DSS had been advised by the Department of Administrative Services that it never had any plans for such a proposal. The letter from the Minister said it had been copied to the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus). Three days later I received a letter from the Minister for Administrative Services informing me that DAS was currently considering the feasibility of constructing an office block in Newcastle but that no commitment had been given and none would be given until the Commonwealth Government departments in the area indicated their desire for space in such a building.
I would like to know how such a contradiction can occur between two Ministers of this

SPEECH.PARA: Government. I would like to know just where that proposal is currently up to within the departmental approval process. If the Department of Administrative Services has rejected the proposal, will it please explain why and inform Opengrand and Doran of the decision? Given that departments have enough autonomy to decide whether they are going to occupy space, how did the departments get organised enough to agree to the Parramatta office block?

PARA.TAB: I also find it deplorable that ALP members of the House of Representatives, who are supposed to represent the people in Newcastle, have practically ignored this proposal. They have not put their weight behind the idea and used their influence in their own Government. What good is having a voice in Canberra if that voice is not used at all? Surely, they can see that this project would be of enormous benefit to Newcastle, but it looks as though the people of the city have been taken for granted by the Labor Party yet again.

The problems I have raised tonight are typical of the problems that are holding back developments in Newcastle. Bureaucratic inefficiencies must be eliminated, as must poor representation for Newcastle in the House of Representatives. Newcastle needs a very sensible addition to its infrastructure, so I hope that the relevant Ministers will take note of the questions I have raised here and find out what has happened to this proposal and ensure that it becomes a reality.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Circuses in the Australian Capital Territory

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is rather appropriate that I rise in this forum, particularly at this late hour, to discuss circuses. To be more specific, I am referring to the amendments to the Animal Welfare Bill 1992, currently before the ACT Assembly. The original Bill going through the Assembly required that circuses needed permits to be able to operate in the ACT and that strict animal care conditions must be met. The penalties for running a circus without a permit are $10,000 or one year's imprisonment or both.

PARA.TAB: That Bill was supported by circus operators who rightly believed that if the circus animals were being mistreated in any way the circus involved should be prosecuted. Adequate penalties for any such offences are already set out in existing ACT legislation, not to mention that a code of practice exists in New South Wales. In the last couple of years there has been much improvement in the traditional circus industry because of the sensitivity and the sometimes exaggerated claims of animal liberation groups around Australia. Circus people are fighting for their lives and their existence. The circus industry has existed in Australia for over 150 years and is a part of our heritage. I believe that the circus people themselves are very well aware of their responsibilities but, unfortunately, they are sick of being misrepresented by these pressure groups.

The animal welfare groups have exerted this pressure on the ACT Assembly, despite the fact that no circus in the ACT has ever been charged or convicted of committing any act of cruelty against animals. The Labor Caucus of the ACT Assembly has decided to amend the Animal Welfare Bill by inserting clauses to ban the exhibition and caging of exotic animals. These exotic animals to be banned will include giraffes, lions, monkeys, bears, elephants, tigers, cheetahs, pumas and leopards. In other words, these amendments effectively ban traditional circuses from operating in the ACT.

The question that must be asked is why the Labor Government of the ACT Assembly is attempting to ban a popular form of family entertainment. Mrs Lorraine Grant, who is the performance director of Ashton's Circus, said that the last time the circus was in Canberra was April this year and 27,000 people from Canberra went along in the three-week period to see that circus. Obviously, Canberrans do not subscribe to the same sorts of attitudes that the ACT Government does.

Why is there all this concern about a few exotic animals in circuses when the Assembly has many other more important things to deal with? Important matters which seem to be of very little concern to the Assembly include brothels, treatment of the mentally ill and abortion. We have seen just this week that it has legalised abortion clinics here. It seems to be okay to have abortions and murder innocent young unborn children, and it is okay for Canberra to be the pornography centre of Australia, but if someone wants to come along and have a traditional circus with a few animals acts, that is not good enough at all!

The Publication Control (Amendment) Bill 1992 is currently before the Assembly, the key element of which is the banning of production and sale of X-rated videos in the ACT. Yet because the Government would rather ban circuses than pornography the Bill will be defeated, as have similar Bills before it.

It is pleasing to see that my Liberal colleagues in the ACT Assembly—most notably the spokesman for the environment, Mr Lou Westende—have expressed their grave concerns in regard to these amendments. Currently, the Bill has been delayed in its passing through the Assembly by Independent members Michael Moore, Helen Szuty and Dennis Stevenson. These members claim that they want to give the public time to consider the changes. Hopefully, they will listen to the views of all Canberrans, not just the opinions of a noisy minority.

The ACT Labor Government, on the other hand, has made its decision without consulting the very people who will be most affected—the circuses. The ACT Government has refused to meet representatives from the Circus Federation of Australia, the Circus Fans Association of Australia and the National Circus Association of Australia, who only want to put their case to the ACT Assembly. The ACT Government will not listen to them.

A similar attack was made on the circus industry in North Sydney last year. I made the point in an adjournment speech that I made in the Senate that the North Sydney City Council had been lobbied very successfully by animal liberationists and it went ahead and decided to have a referendum. The referendum was held without giving the circus people any chance to prepare a case and after letting the animal liberationists spend a month putting their case. Sixty per cent of people in North Sydney voted in favour of allowing traditional circuses, with animal acts, to perform in North Sydney. That was a watershed decision for the circus industry. The industry thought that that should be the end of these sorts of pressures being put upon it, but not so. The animal liberationists just moved their campaign into Canberra. They have sucked in this particular Labor Government. As I said, there has never been a recorded case of a circus having been prosecuted in Canberra.

This ACT Labor Government fell for the old thimble and pea trick that the animal welfare organisations have played. They gave the Government a list of 42 incidents that have happened since ANZFAS has been keeping records of circuses. I had a look through those incidents tonight. Out of the 42 incidents there are only six or seven cases of cruelty to animals. There were quite a lot more cases of cruelty to humans where the animals have had their revenge on some of the humans who had been mistreating them.

Nevertheless, a lot of these claims are hard to justify. Six of the incidents were caused by non-Australian circuses that were visiting from overseas. One incident cited related to a pony called Rocky which was killed by a tree. On investigation we found that that night there was a wind gust of 80 kilometres an hour. I do not know how they can blame the circus for a limb falling off a tree and killing a horse.

They claimed that an elephant called Abu escaped into a sugar cane field. On checking that out, I found out that it happened on the same day in the same place in alternate years. I found out, when talking to the circus people, that it was a publicity stunt. They cited the case of an elephant being involved in a truck crash in February 1983 north of Moree. On investigation one finds that the truck was parked on the side of the road with the elephants in it and a freighter ran into it. How can one blame the circus people for that?

These are the sorts of claims that are made in this document. Obviously, the Minister for the environment in Canberra has refused to talk to the circus people and has gone ahead and tried to put through this Bill. I am pleased to see that the Independents at least, without committing themselves on which way they are going to vote, by delaying the passage of the Bill have given the circus people a chance to put their case.

This Bill also seeks to ban rodeos, even though there has not been one in the ACT for the last 10 years. I would like to quote a very eminent member of the National Party, Senator, David Brownhill. In a letter to the Canberra Times he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, if rodeos contained practices that were cruel, the RSPCA inspectors who attend every known, publicised rodeo would step in and stop such an act, and force prosecutions. That this does not happen either implies the RSPCA is also condoning these practices or they don't happen.

PARA.TAB: It is a sad indictment of the Labor Government of the ACT Assembly that it has placed a higher priority on legislation that abolishes family entertainment than it has on abolishing the human suffering and degradation which exists in the ACT. It seems only a matter of time until the ACT Government succumbs completely to the views of the radical element which exists within the animal liberation movement and bans horse and greyhound racing meetings as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on a couple of speeches on superannuation that have been made during the week, not particularly on the superannuation aspect but on the misrepresentation of the Liberal Party position on one matter in particular. I am referring to the speech of Senator Sherry on 23 June 1992. I have attempted to tell him that I was going to comment on this portion of his speech.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry spoke on superannuation when the Committee presented its report on 18 June. He spoke to the Bill on 23 June. To a significant extent, he dealt with the Labor Party's policy on superannuation and he referred to the differences between that and our policy. That is, of course, legitimate debate. But then, for some reason best known to him, he went on to say in relation to pensions:

SPEECH.PARA: What is the reality of the Opposition's policy?
He answered the question himself by saying:
The reality of the Opposition's policy is that in 30 to 40 years time, based on contribution levels of 5 per cent, it will effectively halve people's pensions.
That is not true, but that may be his understanding of it. He goes on to say:
That is the Opposition's policy going into the next election—to halve pension payments. That will be the outcome.

We have Government Ministers commenting on our policy in just about every answer in every Question Time. They all attempt to present it in a way that indicates that they have read the Fightback package. It is very obvious to anyone who has read the Fightback package that most of them have not, and they are merely making things up as they go along.

PARA.TAB: It is very clear that Senator Sherry has not read the Fightback package—otherwise it would not be possible for him to make this assertion. It is part of the misinformation that Labor Party members keep spreading. They make assertions such as this, designed to frighten people, just as they will tell people that the GST is 15 per cent on top of what they pay now. Of course, that is not true, but that is the only level on which the Labor Party can attack our package; it cannot go to anything more substantial than to indulge in such scare tactics.
It is very clear from the Fightback package that there are numerous provisions which greatly assist pensioners. In fact, they are very specifically dealt with. One paragraph says:

SPEECH.PARA: More specific measures to compensate and assist age and service pensioners and retirees include—
and the second measure is a GST tax credit. There are a range of other health insurance credits. The first point mentioned is:
. . . direct increases in age, service and all other pensions by eight per cent to over 28 per cent of average weekly earnings;

The reason that I very confidently quote that and say that that is specifically an increase in pensions, and deliberately so, is that on 18 June when Senator Sherry was speaking again on the presentation of the report he referred to the Labor Party policy, relating it specifically to women, which was why I spoke on the superannuation Bill the other night. He said:

PARA.TAB: With regard to those persons who do not spend significant time in the work force—that includes, particularly, women who, for significant periods, are in many cases bearing children—it is important to emphasise that the current old age pension will be maintained.

SPEECH.PARA: Everybody knows that the current old age pension is 26 per cent of average weekly earnings. If Senator Sherry had read the Fightback package, he would have read that our proposal will lift it to 28 per cent of average weekly earnings when he himself clearly knows that it is presently—and likely to remain under the Labor Government—26 per cent of average weekly earnings. Every time the Labor Party does this it is necessary to get up and explain where it is wrong. It may be that Senator Sherry was misunderstanding what it meant. I do not know whether he misunderstood or not. I cannot tell what his state of mind was when he made his remarks in the first speech he made when referring to our policy. I wish to draw the attention of the Senate to the facts and to where he is quite wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, I have a very serious matter to raise this evening, one that does not bring me any great joy. It relates to a problem with the advisers to the Aboriginal Council at Woorabinda. There are now a substantial number of contractors who have done civil engineering works for this Council who appear to have been ripped off or very badly treated ostensibly by the Council but arguably by the people who are the advisers to the Council and, in particular, by a number of people who are supposedly project managers to the Council. At this point, I seek leave to table two sets of documents, one headed `Rutland Contractors' and the other `Jeff James (Constructions) Pty Ltd', which outline some of the substantial problems which exist with this particular Council and its operations.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate and I thank Senator Collins. I wish to quote from one of the reports prepared for Rutland contractors by Kinhill Cameron McNamara. This relates to some difficulties it has had with the construction of the Black Boy Creek access road. It asked the consultants Kinhill Cameron McNamara to investigate some of the difficulties it was having with the Council. In particular, it was having a great deal of difficulty because the Council had snatched from it the contractor's performance guarantee—its bank guarantee. It is alleged that the Council claimed this bank guarantee before the end of the six-month defect liability period and without giving any reason why that guarantee should be called in. Subsequent to that, the Council provided the contractors with a list of supposed defects and purported to extend the length of the defect liability period for a further six months. Kinhill Cameron McNamara investigated many of these claims and found them to be without substance or found them to be design faults for which the contractors were not responsible. It is very disturbing to note the conclusion of the report, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is our firm professional opinion that the administration of this Contract warrants investigation and that particular decisions by the Superintendent, Mr Brian Hogan, and/or the Woorabinda Land Council or the advice upon which they have acted have been unfairly onerous to the Contractor, AJ & KM Rutland.

That is very disturbing in itself, but it is disturbing because it is just one of a number of complaints of this nature. Very serious allegations have been raised with me by contractors in relation to Mr Hogan and his associate, who masquerade under a business name but who are alleged not to be qualified for the task for which they hold themselves out. In so doing, they are really conning the Aboriginal Council and nobody else because they are giving advice which they are incapable of giving. They are exercising supervision over matters which are beyond their capabilities. That is one matter.

PARA.TAB: There are also concerns about their previous business dealings and the results of those previous business dealings that also deserve consideration. It has been alleged that at some time when they were consultants to the Council or shortly before one or both of these gentlemen was a bankrupt. Of course, I would have grave concerns about somebody who was a bankrupt, if it was so shown, being an adviser to an Aboriginal council, or any other council for that matter.

I believe that these matters deserve very serious consideration. The list of concerns that was given to me is several pages long. I do not intend to go into it tonight. Suffice to say, I hope the matter will be taken up by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner). I am sure that the Minister would also be very concerned about these allegations, as I know he is particularly interested in improving accountability and ensuring good administration of Aboriginal councils and good advice to the Aboriginal councils themselves. I close by saying that I hope the Department of Aboriginal Affairs will contact me to discuss these matters in detail but, in any event, if it does not do so, I shall be raising the matter in Estimates in substantial detail.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Building Industry Working Party: Travel Expenses

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in Question Time and following Question Time in noting my answer, Senator Winston Crane made what he described as a serious charge against me and which I regard as a serious allegation. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Why has the Minister approved payments of $2,267 and $634 for travel and related expenses for 3 December 1991 and 17 December 1991, respectively, to his mate Mr Kevin Reynolds, the Secretary of the Western Australian Builders Labourers Federation, as these payments are clearly outside the terms of his own letter and against the advice of his own Department and his own adviser?

That is the allegation put in positive terms by Senator Crane. It is an allegation which is not true. No money has been paid to Mr Reynolds for claims for travel to meetings in Canberra on either 3 December or 17 December last year and no decision to do so has been made by me.

PARA.TAB: I want to go to the facts and not the untrue allegations that Senator Crane is making. I also provide all documents and all possible details in making this full statement. Mr Reynolds travelled to Canberra from Perth for meetings on 3 December for three purposes: first, the launch of the Government's building industry reform strategy—Mr Reynolds played an important role in developing this strategy through the Government's working party on industrial relations reform in the building industry—secondly, for the inaugural meeting of the Government's Construction Industry Development Council; and, thirdly, and most importantly, for a meeting with me as Minister for Industrial Relations to discuss further Government legislation arising from our 1990 legislation which contained the deregistration of the Builders Labourers Federation.

Mr Reynolds's discussions with me on this critical issue were necessary, irrespective of any other business he had in Canberra that day. He travelled to Canberra for that meeting at my express request. The meeting was required at that time because the Government was in the process of drafting the Builders Labourers' Federation (Cancellation of Registration Consequential Provisions) Amendment Bill to apply to certain specified State associations of the BLF to enter a form of registration with the BWIU and allow for further amalgamation.

Because of the time and distance involved in travel from Western Australia, as Senator Crane would well know, it was sensible to have this meeting in conjunction with the launch of the building industry strategy and inaugural council meeting. I stress the importance and necessity to have this meeting at this time. The meeting, of course, was necessary in Canberra, as the Senate was sitting in all of December that year.

On 17 December Mr Reynolds travelled from Melbourne to Canberra to continue the discussions of 3 December on the legislation and the amalgamation with both me and Mr Stan Sharkey, Federal Secretary of the BWIU. On 20 January 1992 Mr Reynolds wrote two letters addressed to the Department of Industrial Relations, one seeking reimbursement for a return air fare Perth-Canberra for the meeting with me on 3 December, and the other seeking reimbursement for an air fare Melbourne-Canberra-Melbourne and one night's accommodation in Canberra for 17 December. Both meetings extended over a number of hours; both were held during the evening because of parliamentary and other commitments earlier on each day. My Department subsequently put formal advice to my office dated 6 May 1992 arising from Mr Reynolds's requests for reimbursement. That advice was tabled by Senator Crane today.

My Department advised that Mr Reynolds's claims were outside the conditions governing payment for travel and costs related to the Government's industrial relations working party which the Government funded and that, furthermore, members of the council had been informed by me in a letter dated 23 October 1991 that their attendance at council meetings would be at their own cost. A member of my staff, one of my advisers, Mr Ashley Mason, notated on my Department's advice of 6 May that in his view we should not pay for Mr Reynolds's expenses for 3 December, but indicated that he did not know whether we should pay for the expenses of 17 December. His view was based on the understanding that the purpose of the 3 December meeting travel was to attend the Construction Industry Development Council.I subsequently discussed these questions with my senior adviser, Mr Gary Quinlan. I now seek leave to incorporate a note from him dated 1 June 1992 to my Department arising from that discussion.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: MINISTER FOR INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS
Mr Russell Richmond
Executive Director
Australian Federation of Construction Contractors
PO Box 320
ST LEONARDS NSW 2065
Dear Mr Richmond

The purpose of this letter is to advise you of progress and seek your participation in the implementation of the Federal Government's Construction Industry Reform Strategy, the aim of which is to develop a more efficient, reliable and internationally competitive industry.

We are working towards the Prime Minister announcing full details of the implementation arrangements for the strategy at a special ceremony mid-to-end of November. Your participation and assistance is sought at this stage to ensure that the necessary industry commitment and financial support are in place in time for the announcement.

The In Principle Reform Agreement (copy enclosed) is the cornerstone of the strategy. It commits industry and the Government to a range of industry development and labour market reform initiatives. It has been developed in consultation with the key industry organisations and has their broad support. We would now appreciate your confirmation in writing of your organisation's willingness to sign the Agreement at the proposed announcement of the strategy in November.

The Agreement is to be complemented by a Code of Practice which sets out the terms under which public sector and major private sector clients will offer contracts for new work to the industry. A draft framework for the Code of Practice has been developed by a small working group of Commonwealth and State Labour and Public Works officials.

It must be stressed that the framework for the Code is at a very early stage of development, and that there will be extensive consultations with all sections of the industry and relevant areas of Commonwealth, State and Territory administrations before it is finalised. It is intended that the Code be progressively implemented by the Commonwealth and its agencies from 1 July 1992.

We would welcome any early comments on the attached draft of the framework of the Code to be forwarded to Terry Brosnan (Department of Industrial Relations) on 06 2437521 or Rod Brown (Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce) on 06 2762270.
We also intend to take immediate steps to establish a tripartite Construction Industry Development Council to provide a permanent national forum for the consideration of industry issues.

We will jointly chair the Council, which will be given legislative status, and will be representative of all major national industry parties, the Commonwealth, and each State and Territory Government. You are invited to nominate an appropriate person to represent your organisation on the Council.

It is proposed that the first meeting of the Council be held to coincide with the November announcement. You should also be aware that, while our Departments will be meeting the costs associated with the servicing of the Council, your representative will be expected to meet all travel and other costs related to attendance.

The main responsibility for the implementation of the Construction Industry Reform Strategy will rest with a small multi disciplinary Construction Industry Reform Agency which will also be given legislative status.

The Agency will be established and funded for the period ending 30 June 1995. We will be settling the details of the Board over the next few weeks so that these appointments, together with the name of the Chief Executive Officer, can be announced in November.

To facilitate the process of workplace reform, the Government has already provided considerable assistance to the building and construction industry through the Workplace Reform Program by providing grants for the engagement of workchange advisers. The work of the advisers has been crucial at the workplace level, and this important contribution will need to continue in close consultation with the work of the Reform Agency.

The Government has proposed a funding package to facilitate the implementation of the strategy, but its finalisation is dependent upon there being a significant contribution from the industry both in cash and in kind, and it is in this area that we invite the immediate attention of your organisation. Understandably, different organisations will be able to contribute in different ways and we would be grateful if you could contact Peter Berry in the Office of the Minister for Industrial Relations on 03 4861618/03 4861044 (telephone) or 03 4823379 (fax) to discuss the details of any contribution that you might consider making before responding in writing.

In summary this letter seeks your endorsement of the In-Principle Agreement, your participation as a member of the Construction Industry Development Council and a tangible contribution towards the cost of implementing the strategy.

If you have any queries about the strategy or any of the issues we have raised in this letter, please contact either Terry Brosnan (Department of Industrial Relations) on (06) 2437521 or Rod Brown (Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce) on (06) 2762270.
