—They were not relevant to my question. I did not ask the question in terms of that document, but I did table those documents which were relevant to my question. They still pose a number of questions which I believe the Minister has not answered. They relate particularly to the amounts of money that I referred to this afternoon which are on those documents. For example, figures charged for an airfare from Perth to Canberra and back are substantially more than it costs to fly from Canberra to Perth. I am sure the Minister can check that out. I shall be looking at the additional information.
—Do you withdraw your allegation against me?
—I remind the Minister that I sat in virtual silence and listened to him.
—Do you withdraw your allegation?

—I am not withdrawing any allegation. I will look in detail at the documents the Minister tabled and then make a statement. I will not withdraw any allegation. There is no question in terms of these documents and the explanation given that the Minister—and I believe it will be in those documents—did take action. From what I have gathered, the document of 1 June from which the Minister quoted shows quite clearly that he did take action—I am speaking from what I understand of the document—on the representation made from his Department.
—I did not and I said I did not.
—I shall read that document. I was listening.
—Withdraw your allegation.
—I said that I shall look at that. If I am incorrect, I will withdraw it.
—If you have any honour or dignity, you will withdraw the allegation.

—Listen to who is talking about honour and dignity. What a joke! The note at the foot of the document which I had incorporated today says, `We should not pay for Reynolds expenses in this case, particularly 3/12'. It then has the words `meeting—don't know about'. I believe that the Minister's comments were quite different from that. I shall check the Hansard record on that matter. There is no question in my mind that it was the intent of the Minister to pay Mr Reynolds for these expenses. I have no doubt about that.
—I have said it is not so.
—The Minister said there was no money to pay those accounts and that, as a result, it would not because there was no money. But we shall check on that through the documents that are tabled.
—I was advised by my Department of an entitlement; so there was an entitlement but there was no money and it will not be done. Recognise the truth of the situation and withdraw your allegations.
—I will not withdraw anything at this time.
—We know what sort of person you are.
—You have a bit of withdrawing to do.
—I have no withdrawing to do. I have done nothing wrong and I expect allegations that are baseless and false to be withdrawn.
—Order! Senator Crane has the call.

—As I said before, I shall be looking very carefully at the documents tabled tonight. I do not believe that what the Minister has said at this stage changes my position. But, as I said, I will make that judgment when I have looked at the various documents.

PARA.TAB: I want to make reference to the note about these meetings, because I certainly got the impression from the Minister here tonight that, in his view, those meetings were legitimate in terms of the program, yet his own adviser wrote on the note that he did not even know what the meeting was about. The letter to Mr Mason with regard to reimbursement of travel from the WABLF says:

SPEECH.PARA: You may recall that claims made by Mr Reynolds last year after the formal completion of the Working Party were paid in the interests of "ensuring progress in building industry reform".

My question today did not relate to those particular claims. The Minister has tabled documents relating to those claims and they are currently before the Senate. As I said earlier, I had those documents but did not incorporate them in Hansard because they did not relate to my question. When looking at the documents it is interesting to note that the airfares are for 18 April, 18 May and 17 July. Those dates match three lots of expenses for accommodation on 18 April, 18 May and 17 July but there are also additional accommodation claims on 14 February, 7 March, 13 March and 25 March. The claims vary significantly. It is interesting to note the claims for accommodation. One claim is for $517.50 and another is for $172.50.

PARA.TAB: I raise those particular claims because there are cents attached to the dollar amount. I have stayed at many hotels during my life and I have never had a room hire charge which ended in cents. I question whether all of those accommodation claims were for accommodation or whether they included other items. I also ask the Minister whether invoices and air tickets accompanied these claims.

This afternoon I referred to airfares from Perth to Canberra and return of $2,267. At that particular time the highest first class fare between Perth and Canberra, going through Sydney—which most honourable senators would know is more expensive than travelling through Melbourne or Adelaide—was $1,850. There is a significant difference between the going first class rate and the claim.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are an utter disgrace.
—Order! Senator Crane has the floor.

—I have raised a number of aspects of this. I shall be looking very closely at what the Minister has said in this place tonight. I believe that the question I asked today was perfectly legitimate. I did not come across these papers by improper actions on my part. It is not my problem if the Minister's Department and/or office leak like a sieve. That is the Minister's problem. I think it highlights very clearly the lack of confidence that a number of people in his office and his Department have in him right now. That is what this highlights.
—You are an utter disgrace. You are a disgraceful person.
—Mr Deputy President, I ask you to demand that Senator Cook withdraw those statements, which are unparliamentary.
—I do not regard the Minister's remarks as unparliamentary, but the President does. I therefore ask Senator Cook to withdraw.

—Mr Deputy President, if they are unparliamentary, I withdraw them. Allegations have just been made against me which are fundamentally and absolutely untrue. Senator Crane has made an allegation which is now proven to be untrue. He should withdraw that.
—Mr Deputy President, did Senator Cook's comments constitute an unconditional withdrawal? In my view, they did not.
—I believe that they did.
—I did not make an allegation against the Minister; I said that this highlights the dissatisfaction which exists in his office and his Department at this particular time.
—That is a slur on my staff and my Department.
—At a future time the Minister will no doubt explain why these papers were leaked to me.
—We have only your word for that and we cannot trust your word.
—Order!
—That is getting beyond the pale. I have been very patient here tonight.
—You have made unsubstantiated allegations and you have not withdrawn.

—Mr Deputy President, I have been very patient tonight. I have sat in this place many times when you have frowned at me when I have made an interjection. The Minister has continually interjected on me tonight and you have given me little or no protection.

—Senator Crane, that is not correct. If you look at the Hansard you will find that you are wrong. I have called the Minister to order. I do not take kindly to your remarks suggesting that I am biased.

—I thank you, Mr Deputy President. I accept your comments. I conclude by saying that I will look very carefully at the answers the Minister has given. As I said at the beginning of my comments, I thank the Minister for coming into this place and speaking to this issue. I do that sincerely.
—You're joking.

—There is one person in this place tonight who is a joke—that is the Minister. His behaviour during this debate has been absolutely deplorable. If he wants to behave like this, that is his problem, not mine.
—Senator Crane, I suggest that you disregard any interjections.
—I shall, Mr Deputy President. I sincerely thank the Minister for coming in here and speaking to this issue.
—There is not a sincere bone in your body. Don't patronise me.
—My word, he is touchy.

—Yes, he is very touchy. As I have said, I will look very carefully at these documents and respond to them when I have had an opportunity to study them. I had the courtesy of photocopying these documents and showing them to the Minister prior to incorporating them in Hansard. The Minister had the opportunity to look at them. The Minister did not grant me that courtesy. His office did not ring me until five minutes after he had started speaking in this place tonight so that I could be in the chamber and hear all that he had to say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This is a very sorry night. It is not me who needs to be sorry—the last speaker needs to be sorry. I have put down a full and open statement, tabling documents that are new and fresh, to all of these allegations so that not only are the allegations answered but all of the circumstances surrounding or pertaining to them in any way, shape or form are covered as well. This is a complete, open and thorough statement. It establishes that the allegation made against me by Senator Crane in Hansard at Question Time today is not true, is baseless and is false. If there is any honour, it should be withdrawn. I note that it has not been withdrawn. Therefore, the only conclusion is that there is no honour; there is a deliberate desire to maintain a falsehood and something that is baseless.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane made some fresh allegations. As I recall them, those fresh allegations were that somehow or another I am party to a falsification of payments based on reimbursements made on accounts delivered to my Department. In the first instance, I have never seen those accounts and it is not something that in the ordinary course of events I would expect to see, nor would anyone want me to expect to see them. The reimbursements that were made for this particular series of meetings concern not only Mr Reynolds—about whom I have tabled a complete set of reimbursements—but also the MBHR, the Victorian Department of Labor, the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union of Australia, the Building Industry Specialist Contractors Organisation of Australia, the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors and the Building Owners and Managers Association of Australia. I have said in my statement that as soon as I can collate all of those expenses I will make a statement and make them available publicly so that they too could be scrutinised.

Mr Reynolds was one person. All of the individuals who represented those organisations were other persons who obtained reimbursement. I note that there is nothing wrong in that, and that was acknowledged this afternoon. What is now being alleged is that amounts were improperly reimbursed by my Department. I never saw the claim; I never authorised the reimbursement; but I have absolutely no grounds for believing that officers of my Department have acted improperly or have reimbursed beyond what is the required level. I have no reason for believing that. As Senator Crane has made the allegation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Winston Crane?

—Senator Winston Crane has made the allegation that they are improperly reimbursed and I will check to see whether that is the case. I expect that it will not be. When I find, if I do, that it is not, I would expect vainly, as I do now for the original allegation, a withdrawal. I do not expect that it will be forthcoming, even on the face of the most compelling evidence. I do not expect that it will be, because Senator Crane has never demonstrated any inclination, upon being proven wrong, to retract.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane has been party to at least five efforts of alleging that I have misled the Senate. On not one occasion has Senator Crane been proven right, but on not one occasion has Senator Crane withdrawn. That simply describes the sort of person he is and I invite other Australians and senators to share my conclusion about the type of person he is. There are names for that sort of person which are well known in this community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President—
—Order! I call Senator Collins.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Senator Crane was on his feet. He sought leave to respond to those allegations by the Minister, who I see has now left the chamber. I think the matter should be resolved. Senator Crane surely has the right to seek leave to respond to those scurrilous remarks.
—I am not quite sure how it is going to be resolved if we keep going backwards and forwards all night. I have been watching Wimbledon, and this is becoming like that.

—The situation currently is that we have had the adjournment debate while amendments have been drafted in order to dispose of the Broadcasting Services Bill. I have been advised that those amendments are now finished and we are anxious to do that. What I would be seeking to do, with the concurrence of the chamber, is give leave to Senator Crane now, but I just wonder if we could just prevail upon him to make his remarks as brief as possible so we can dispose of the legislation.

—by leave—I thank Senator Collins. After I had explained that I would look at the documents put before us carefully and assess them, Senator Cook made further claims that I made allegations against him and his Department. I did; it is true. It is indeed true that I asked whether there were tickets and supporting documents for those particular claims. I think that is a reasonable question. The Minister chose not to answer that and instead came out with a barrage of allegations against me.

PARA.TAB: It is indeed unfortunate that the Minister has left as he raised again this issue of there not being sufficient money to pay these accounts. Yet we see on this particular departmental minute which I tabled here today headed `Reimbursement of Travel—WABLF', that even though Ashley Mason—picking up the Minister's words—said, `We should not pay for Reynolds' expenses', he has also written on this particular document that there is $13,000 left in the fund. That seems to me to make a mockery of the claim that there was no money in the bin to pay these additional funds. I would be rather interested to see what has actually occurred here today in terms of the matters I raised in this chamber in Question Time and again here tonight.

I said I would only take three minutes, but I want to say that the Minister's behaviour tonight has been quite irrational—maybe it is a good thing that he has gone home to cool off. He said that I am malicious, I have abused the system and I am duped. I totally reject all of those comments.

I wish to follow this through to get to the bottom of all those expenses—not only those that have been paid to Mr Reynolds, but also those that have been paid to other bodies. There was initially a sum of $19,000, as we were able to extract through Estimates and other means. If the level of expenses and the number of organisations that it has been claimed have been paid this money for setting up this particular fund, at the sorts of levels that these accounts amount to—some $10,000—one must also beg the question of whether that really represents the amount.

I will leave my comments at that, except to reinforce the question why, even though it was indicated that there was $13,000 left in that particular fund, all of a sudden after a question is asked, is the finance not available? I would be interested to look at the document of 1 June because I think that would reveal a lot to this chamber in terms of what the instructions were from the Minister to his Department with regard to payments to Mr Kevin Reynolds.
Question resolved in the negative.
Message received from the House of Representatives acquainting the Senate that it had agreed to the Bill with amendments.
Ordered that the message be considered in the Committee of the Whole forthwith.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1)Clause 93, page 39, line 29, omit from subclause (1) "Subject to sections 94 and 95, the", substitute "The".

(4)Schedule 2, Part 6, paragraph 10(1)(g), page 96, omit all the words after "ABA", substitute "but will not broadcast such an `R' classified program until the ABA has completed a hearing into the content and the impact on viewers of `R' classified programs;".

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Collins) negatived:
That amendments Nos. 1, 2 and 3 made by the House of Representatives be agreed to.
Motion (by Senator Collins) proposed:
That amendment No. 4 made by the House of Representatives be agreed to.
Amendment (by Senator Alston) proposed:

PROCTEXT.PARA: 5.Amendment no. 4, omit "a hearing into the content and the impact on viewers of "R" classified programs", substitute "extensive, Australia-wide qualitative and quantitative research on community standards of taste and decency in relation to classifications for pay television and on what levels of violence and depiction of sex should be allowed, and the ABA has approved the broadcast of such programs.".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be opposing this, but the one thing that I want to point out is that it has a very interesting effect. I am not sure that it is intended, because I have only just picked it up. The original wording that has come over from the House of Representatives, with which I frankly do agree, is that `the ABA will not broadcast such an R classified program until the ABA has completed a hearing into the content and the impact on viewers of R classified programs'. Honourable senators would recall that this came about as a Government amendment. Senator Alston certainly knows this and so does the Leader of the Democrats. I had a look at this last night and even though, as all senators know, this is not my own position, I felt that it was the view of the Senate, and that was confirmed—
—The amendment of the Senate was a survey. Surveys and hearings are different things.

—I can make the point and Senator Tierney can respond to it if he so wishes. The difference that I have just noticed now—and we do not object to this—is that `hearing' has been removed. The difficulty with that is that the hearings under the ABA, of necessity, include the involvement of the public.
—No, they do not.
—Yes, they do. I am not saying it stops them. The amendment now reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . omit "a hearing into the content and the impact on viewers of "R" classified programs", substitute "extensive, Australia-wide qualitative and quantitative research on community standards of taste and decency in relation to classifications for pay television and on what levels of violence and depiction of sex should be allowed, and the ABA has approved the broadcast of such programs.".

I have no objection to that at all. All I want to clearly point out, so that no one is under any misunderstanding of what we are changing, is that that means—and it explicitly says it—that the ABA has no requirement whatever to conduct a hearing because it takes the word `hearing' out in the amendment and simply substitutes `research'. I am happy with that. It means the ABA will simply have to conduct its own research—

TALK.START.PARA: —Right.

—Fine, I am happy with it, but I do not want there to be any misunderstanding or recriminations afterwards. That is why I am making the point. The message that has come back from the House of Representatives involves a public hearing. The word `hearing' is taken out and we are supporting it. The reason I am saying this—and all honourable senators know it—is that I know how controversial an issue this is, particularly so with some senators, and I do not want any misunderstanding about what we are agreeing to.
—Don't encourage them.

—I think, in honesty, that it needs to be made clear because it is a controversial matter that a number of senators do have an interest in. It takes out the requirement for any public hearings at all and substitutes instead only a requirement for the ABA to conduct research which it can, and probably will do, of course, through Morgan Gallup or ANOP or one of the major research organisations. We are happy about that; we will support it.

—I say to the Minister that that was the intention of the Committee. There were to be not public hearings, but extensive Australia-wide qualitative and quantitative research. That would include surveys. We do not want public hearings, but that does not stop groups from being approached in surveys, et cetera. We do not, and the Committee did not, want public hearings; it wanted just what is written here, and I am glad the Government is supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to explain to the Committee that having examined this matter thoroughly over a considerable period of years, and having looked at the situation of tribunals and the need for tribunals, including the Australian Broadcasting Authority, to reflect the views and attitudes of the public in matters of taste and decency, the quality of the type of research that is included in this legislation will, of course, depend significantly upon the persons who are appointed to the ABA. It will depend significantly on their ability to ensure that they are truly reflecting the community attitudes of taste and decency in relation to the classifications for pay TV and what level of violence and depictions of sex should be allowed.

PARA.TAB: I moved a previous amendment which, unfortunately, because of the time limits that were on us, caused us some considerable problems in explaining the meaning of the proposal. I reiterate that I was a bit sorry to see that proposal go down the gurgler without any real discussion about it. My amendment really was to ensure that prior to appointment to the ABA there would be broad consultations made. That recommendation was in a report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee of which many of Senator Schacht's mates were members. In fact, John Langmore and Colin Hollis were on the Committee, and John Sanderson was the Chairman of the Committee, as far as I can remember.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some people call me left of left these days after what I said about the superannuation Bill the other night. I am just raising the point. I understand that the Minister will probably in any event take account of those recommendations, and I hope that he does.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.
Amendment (by Senator Alston) proposed:

SPEECH.PARA: 4.The following further amendments be made to the Bill:

PARA.TAB: Part 7, pages 39 to 45, clauses 93 to 114, clauses to be opposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —(1.03 a.m.)—The Government will trenchantly and vociferously oppose this amendment, and we will divide on it. It is utterly irresponsible, and we made that abundantly clear in the debate last night when such a proposal was suggested originally by the Democrats. We make it abundantly clear again this morning.

PARA.TAB: Over the last few weeks, in what was a rather rapid introduction into this portfolio, I have actually succeeded in speaking to a wide range of people who would be considered by everyone to be the serious contenders for pay TV. Some of those people have agreed with the Government's proposals wholeheartedly; others have agreed to them with reservations; and some have opposed them.

Some of the people who have been to see me have gone public with that opposition. But there was one consistent message delivered to me by all those who came into my office, whether they disagreed with what was being done or not. They all said one thing to me, and I can assure honourable senators that this is an absolute fact. They said, `Look, whatever else you do—whether it is four transponders and two, or three transponders and one and one and one, or six transponders or whatever—get on and do it'. That is a consistent theme that I have heard for the last three weeks from them all. They all said, `Look, we think this has some problems with it'. Others said, `We're on the beach and we intend to stay there'. That is a quote from one of the very serious contenders; one with a wallet, I might add, that actually has the finance to support it. They said, `We have some concerns about it. We think it can be fixed up around the edges by enhancing a few things, but get on with it'. That is what they all said to me.

It has been 10 years now. We are behind everyone else. We are the only English speaking country in the world that does not have pay TV. As Opposition senators have pointed out during this debate, it has been 10 years—

TALK.START.PARA: —Twelve years.

—Twelve years. It was the shadow Minister for communications (Mr Smith) himself in the House of Representatives this afternoon who said that. I have some regard for the shadow Minister. In my view, the shadow Minister is the best of the Opposition front bench. I hope that puts the kiss of death right on him. I do think that: I have some regard for the shadow Minister.

PARA.TAB: The reason I raise that is deliberate. The shadow Minister did say in his address—and I thank him for it—that as concerned as he was about the Government's proposal, he still thought that it was a commercially viable proposal. I thought that was an extremely responsible thing for him to say. I noted it and I thank him for it. It would have been irresponsible for him to have publicly talked it down. I know he wants pay TV. He might not be personally enthusiastic about it, but I know he wants to see it for this country because of the jobs that it will create. It will create jobs if it is given an opportunity to do so. I acknowledge the statement that the shadow Minister made that, despite his concerns and despite the fact that he thought the commerciality had been eroded to some extent, it was still a commercial proposition. I thought that was a responsible thing to say when, if he had been after the points, he could easily have gone the other way and said that he thought it was a lemon. He did not say that.

Frankly I am amazed that the Opposition has supported this proposal. I know where the Australian Democrats are on this issue. They have a principled position on this, which I respect, but I do not think they have a very real position on it. I think their position on most things is principled and unreal. I have made that point before many times in debate, and I might add so have members of the Opposition on regular occasions.

I am genuinely stunned that of all of the options available the Opposition has supported this one—the worst possible one. One would not refer one's worst enemy to a Senate committee. If one wanted to do something nasty to a person, the last thing one would do would be to send him to a Senate committee, because nothing would happen to him until he died. That is the problem: the great black hole of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stiff.

—I have watched Senator Walters. She has been very busy in this debate, and I give her credit for it. She has been running around like the Tasmanian mafia, terrorising the poor old Democrats and waving her walking stick in people's faces. I know that, and I know why and so does everyone else. She does not want to see pay TV. She says `stiff'—a very inelegant expression. I thought I was the only rude and crude person in this chamber. I will have to revise that opinion. I know that Senator Walters has what she wanted. She should not help me make my case too hard. She does not want pay TV because she does not want the children to see it. She has made that abundantly clear. She is delighted with this result. The Opposition has sent this to a Senate committee, which means we will not get pay TV for at least three more months.

PARA.TAB: It is an outrageous, disgraceful decision of the Opposition. It will never be able to come in here again with any credibility and attack this Government or anyone else for not wanting to create some employment in this country. I am not saying that pay television will be a miracle that is going to solve all our problems; it is not. I am not going to say that it is going to bring down the unemployment rate on its own.

I am quite happy to embarrass myself a bit here and say this: my public position on matters such as Coronation Hill was very well known when I was a backbencher. I got sick and tired of people saying, `It only has 80 people. Why worry about it?' It all adds up; that is my view. But this one could genuinely have produced 4,000 jobs. That is not an over the top assertion. Senator Alston knows it is true. The shadow Minister knows it is true. I have had all the people who were going to provide those jobs trooping through my office telling me that it was true—the people who were going to make the plastic dishes; the people who were going to train the installers. Whole business were going to be set up. Honourable senators should have a look at New Zealand if they do not believe me—it is over there to have a look at. It is a tiny market compared with ours, but it is a very viable business. I know that Senator Powell has seen it because she told me. It is a viable business for New Zealanders putting this stuff in in such a small market.

Pay television would have taken off in this country and installing it would have created 4,000 real jobs. I am annoyed and angry about this because it is a very negative thing we have done. We could have done a whole lot of other things. We could have perhaps considered doing a few other things to have got this up in some form.

As I say again, even the most severe industry detractors of the Government's proposal, every one of them, has said to me, `Whatever else you do, don't sink it; we would much prefer to see pay TV in whatever form you want it rather than not see it at all'. That has been stressed to me. I have said to them, `Look, I have views on this; the Government certainly is intending to have this processed and put into effect so we can start creating those jobs'.

Nobody is interested in pinging and ponging this legislation backwards and forwards uselessly between the House of Representatives and Senate. It is academic because we cannot anyway. The Senate has the power to excise this whole section from the Bill and consider it until it dies—which is what is going to happen. This is going to totally destroy whatever interest was out there—and the interest was intense—in putting anything together, in raising finance and even in investigating whether it is now possible. People will just go to sleep again for another three months—and they will be disgusted. The shadow Minister knows that; Senator Alston knows it too. The business community is not going to thank the Opposition for this work here tonight.

I do not attack the Democrats on this because I know they have a highly principled position. They never ever worry about budgets because they know they will never be in government and will never have to worry about putting a Budget together or getting some revenue or creating a few jobs. They do not have to. But there were 4,000 real jobs to be had out of this decision, no matter what form the structure had taken. I was given that assurance by the people who were going to finance it and provide the jobs.

All those opposite know this. Senator Walters says she is delighted with this decision. She has made that very clear. She does not want to see this industry established. She does not want to do it in front of the children. She is delighted, and saying so, that it will be buried in a Senate committee. But the industry will not be delighted—and the shadow Minister knows it and so does everyone else on that side. The industry was keen to get geared up and get going. Its representatives have been trooping through my office one at a time. I must have seen, I think, 20 or 30 of them in the last fortnight all saying the same thing: `It might not be the best, it might not be the flashest, it might not be the one we wanted, but for God's sake do it'.

Tonight, we have just undone it—not the Government, not the Democrats, because they would have failed on their own, but the Opposition that comes trooping into this Parliament in both Houses every day castigating us, rightly, for the rising unemployment rate. It says, `When are you going to do something about it?'. As I have said before, it might not have been the miracle of the century, it might not have taken everybody off the list, but it would have helped. We were trying to do it and those opposite have stopped us.

I will finish on this point. I feel like talking for half an hour but I will not. I think I have made the point. This is an extremely negative decision. It will not be a decision that industry is going to welcome. The wowsers might; the Tasmanian mafia might; and the people who do not want adults to see anything that is not produced by Walt Disney will love it. But the people who were actually prepared to put an industry together and employ a very large number of Australians in doing it will hate this decision—and they will let the Opposition know, I have no doubt, if they have not done so already. They will hate this decision. It will sap business confidence at a time when we can do without it being sapped.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Hill can giggle all he likes. Giggling is Senator Hill's chief contribution to this chamber—and everybody knows it. Giggling is his strong suit. This is not a joke and it is not a giggle. Industry will love to know that the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate thought it was a big giggle. The reason Senator Hill is getting so agitated is that he knows that this decision that his Party has taken tonight is stupid.
—You have stupid economic policies. You have put people out of work—one million unemployed.

—It is a stupid, negative, retrograde decision and a decision for which industry will condemn those opposite. He can interject constantly and be disorderly all he likes because I understand his agitation. He knows this is a bad decision that has been taken tonight. Those opposite have quarantined the whole pay TV industry for a further three months in a Senate committee from which it may never emerge, if Senator Walters and the others who want to bury pay TV have anything to do with it. But the people who might have got a genuine, sustainable job out of pay TV are not going to thank them for it at all.
—I had thought, in view of the time, that we were not going to need to resort to this sort of slanging match at the eleventh hour. But it has to be said—
—Your leader interjected on me.
—Just a moment. I will tell Senator Collins the facts. He may have a very single-minded view of the world, but he ought to understand—
—I don't, actually.

—He might be very interested, therefore, to hear about some of the things that have been said to us in recent times. The way Senator Collins spoke tonight, what this Government is all about is a pay television employment led recovery—a preposterous proposition, given that his is the mob—
—I said it was not going to be an economic miracle.
—Senator Collins has spent half his time saying this was all about us putting people out of work.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—Order! I am calling order on both sides of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact of the matter is that his is the mob that has been opposed to pay television. Why is it not in the country at this very minute? It is because there is a moratorium on it. Who put the moratorium in place? Senator Collins was here at the time. It has been in place, despite private members Bills from our side of the chamber. This is the mob that has fought tooth and nail to stop pay television coming into Australia.

PARA.TAB: It is preposterous hypocrisy to have someone getting up and pretending that somehow a delay whilst a Senate committee considers what has been said to us on many fronts by the industry to be a totally unworkable proposal should somehow almost kill the future of pay television in this country. I find it an extraordinary proposition to hear Senator Collins stand up with a straight face and say that what they all said consistently was, `We don't care what model you come up with, for God's sake, put it through'. I cannot imagine anyone in their right mind saying, `I've got $500m in my back pocket; I'm prepared to put it on the table and walk away with a smile in 12 months time'. That is not what they are saying to us. They are saying to us, `For God's sake, what about what the Democrats are saying? A seven-year exclusivity period is about the only way in which the Government will get its mickey mouse four transponder licences into viable shape. This is an infant industry which needs all the protection in the world'. People would not have a bar of it.

People from very diverse sections of the industry sat around the table all pleading with us in one shape or form to have the matter delayed to expose the absolute nonsense that arose late at night when Senator Collins got rolled. I would have thought that takes a bit of doing, but he got rolled last night as well. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has once again told him that he will not have a bar of the ABC being in pay television. It is an outrageous situation to find Senator Collins now coming in here and pretending that somehow the future of pay television is on the line because a committee is to look at something which his Party has been instrumental in deferring for the last 10 or 12 years. Who else ought to claim the credit for the current moratorium? Why have we a moratorium on pay television in this country? Because the Government insisted on it. Mr Duffy, when he was communications Minister, insisted on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to make it worse.
—Do not stand up and mouth all these hypocritical platitudes about somehow we are the mob wanting to wreck pay television.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—Order! Withdraw that, Minister. I heard it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw it.

—Let us be clear on the facts of the matter. Senator Collins has had a position on pay television for some months. In the heat of the moment, when someone felt he needed to do a triple backflip with pike, what happened? Senator Collins gets called in, Peter Barron's grand plan is put on the table, Senator Schacht then comes in and speaks to it, Senator Collins is told what the new deal is; and it is then announced on Sunday television. What a wonderful way to devise a pay television policy. That is how it works. Of course, last night the same thing happens. Who goes in and says he is happy to see the ABC get a share of the action? But no, once again he was told by the Prime Minister, `No way, you go in there and hold the line; tell them all that our proposal is the only way to go'.
—Did I really?
—Absolutely. The fact is that Mr Keating, as we well know, has come up with a totally unworkable proposal on the run, which the industry has been telling us in spades in recent weeks—
—That is not what your shadow Minister said tonight.

—I am just saying what industry has said to me. It may not say the same thing to both sides. It may say all sorts of encouraging things to the Minister because it thinks it needs to curry favour. I am just saying what has been reported in the press.
—You are the only splinter in the true cross, are you?

—No, I am not saying that. Senator Collins has misunderstood me. I did not say that because it said it to me it could not have said something different to the Government; it could have. I am just giving the facts. Indeed, there have been reports in the newspapers about a wide range of concerns about this mickey mouse proposition being totally unviable. That is why people have been coming to us and saying, `For God's sake, can we have—
—In the newspapers.

—No, they have been coming to us privately. People have been asking, `Can we please have a committee?'. What is wrong with the Democrats' proposal for a committee? What is wrong with a seven-year exclusivity period?'. We say, `Seven years—that's a lifetime'. They say, `What about five years? Here are our financial flow charts. Here is the break even point'. Some of them said, `You would need 10 to 12 years to break even. There is just no way that you can get off the ground'. The Minister gets up and says that these people have been saying, `Sure, we've got a few good turns at the margin, we would prefer you to reshape that and knock that around, but at the end of the day, for heaven's sake, do something'. I cannot believe that for a moment. They may have said it, but it does not ring true to me.

PARA.TAB: If the Government has to spend the sorts of vast amounts of capital that are involved in this exercise, why would the Government in its right mind be indifferent to whatever model is put on the table as long as somehow some model got there? That is not the way to do business. No-one in their right mind would be saying, `Yes, we prefer this or we argue for that but at the end of the day do something, just make a decision and we will wear that'. People would overwhelmingly prefer to test Mr Keating's mickey mouse model to see how viable it is. See what sorts of real expressions of interest you get, see what sort of viability there is in your model, and then we will have a look at it.

People will not be going to sleep for the next three months any more than they have been going to sleep for the last 12 years. They have been dying to get into the game, but the Government has not let them. It has been slamming the door in their faces for all sorts of odd reasons. No-one wanted a moratorium except perhaps the commercial television network. Nonetheless, the Government has been running around saying, `There is no demand. How do you prove this thing? Why should we assume that people want it? This is just pressure from a few suppliers'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I haven't been saying any of those things.
—Those are the sorts of arguments that have been constantly advanced.
—I said that it would take off, and it will.

—Senator Collins has indeed been saying that in recent days. But the Government should not for a moment try to hang on us the responsibility for pay television not having got off the ground to date. Therefore, it is an outrageous suggestion to say that somehow proper consideration by a committee that might take three months is somehow going to wreck the industry.

PARA.TAB: There are people out there dying to get into the game on the proper terms. They do not want to be forced into an unworkable model. Anyone who is sensible about the game will want to ensure that the rules are sensible. One does not run on to the field and play if one does not even understand the rules or is firmly convinced that one cannot possibly win the game at the end. People want an opportunity to explore the proposals that have been put forward and to test them publicly, and that is what they have been arguing for. I cannot keep on saying it, but we utterly refute the suggestion that there is any responsibility attached to us. There are certainly not going to be any jobs lost as a result of a three-month delay.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not make it six months?

—Does Senator Collins want to extend the life of the committee? We will give the Government the option. We know that the Government is desperate to get a few more jobs, but really and truly it will not make much of a dint in one million.
—It would make a difference for the 4,000 who will get them.

—The trouble is that they might get a job in the first 12 months, but when the thing falls over they are out of work again. I would prefer to see them have long term employment prospects in a viable arrangement rather than them going into something, pushed into it, just for the sake of getting there before the commercials come on stream 12 months later and then finding that the whole thing did not work. That is what they are terrified about. That is what they say to you.
—The Senate will make a judgment on that for them, will it?

—The committee will not be talking to itself. The committee will be taking evidence from the people who are in the business. That will include a whole range of interested parties, and they will be able to tell the Minister and me in public what they really think. Let us see what they come up with. But I do not feel any sense of responsibility, in terms of deferment, other than that we think it is a very necessary step to try to patch up the damage that has been done and imposed on the Minister by the Prime Minister. I know why Senator Collins wants to squeal like a cut cat, but the fact remains that if the Government thinks it can do a triple backflip with pike and impose something on an industry which has been carefully and meticulously planning for months and years and suddenly tell it with the flick of a finger, `This is the new model, you have to run with it and, for heaven's sake, we cannot even afford to test it in the light of day', the Government is kidding itself. If it thinks that is a deal, it is not a deal that will work for the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I almost find myself in a position of saying to Senator Alston that I could not have said it better myself, but it is a late hour. I want to reassure the Minister, in case he has forgotten how to count, that there will be pay TV. The Labor Party supports it and so do the Opposition parties. The Government has the numbers for pay TV. The Australian Democrats quite openly acknowledged that it did not want pay TV, but we can count as well. So when the Government decided that the moratorium would be lifted our game had to shift. We then had to take on board the task of seeing that, if we are to have pay TV in this country, a few benchmarks were put down towards which we could work when presented with whatever proposal was eventually going to come out.

PARA.TAB: The two basic benchmarks were the Australian television consuming public in all its technologies and, as a spin off of that, the viability in particular of the free to air operators, both commercial and the ABC, because for a very long time, probably forever, the majority of Australians will be free to air television watchers. We have looked at the various proposals that have been put forward—we have all waited with bated breath—and we finally got the one that we did. Within that period of time those concerns were paramount to us.

Our Australian consuming public will not be protected if a system is put in place which does fall down after a short period of time, after consumers have purchased equipment and committed themselves and then problems occur. This has happened around the world. Australia is in a marvellous position to do the very best, pick out the best, and make it happen.

The Labor Party Caucus was sold this one on the basis that there would be jobs, that there would be manufacturing development in this field and in the production industry in this country and that that would open markets in Asia—our region. That is fair enough, but not if we do not get it right. As far as the viability of the free to air broadcasters is concerned, many of the aspects of the present package have concerned the Democrats, as did many aspects of packages that were tossed around before that.

I do not want the Minister to have a sleepless night on the basis that pay TV is being killed off; it is not. We have not had the present proposal before us for very long and it is a very flawed proposal. But in the end the coalition and the Labor Party will deliver pay TV to this country. As a result of three months intensive work by six senators, I am sure that it will deliver a better package than it would have at this time.

We all know that we have to have pay TV because of the Aussat white elephant. If we want to talk about Democrat irresponsibility, never having to put up a Budget or never being in government, I do not think any government or party associated with the history, or future for that matter, of Aussat can make that allegation against the Democrats. There has been an awful lot of irresponsibility involved with Aussat right from the start and that has been bipartisan between the Labor and Liberal parties.

There has been intensive negotiation to get us to this point—which is why it is so late. I think both the Minister and the shadow Minister have been pretty shabbily treated in this whole exercise by both their leaders. They are two of the most the competent Ministers or shadow Ministers that we have and their leaders would have done much better to have listened to their counsel and not to have overridden them or given them such a hard time.

The Democrats are pleased that our proposition that this section of the Broadcasting Services Bill should go off to a committee has been accepted by the Opposition. We are committed to ensuring that account is taken of the issues that have been raised over the past few weeks—and Senator Alston has referred to many of them—by people interested in this matter, people upon whom we will depend for viable pay TV in this country.

Because we were initially guillotined in the debate on the substantive Bill, and because it is late tonight, all of these issues cannot be read into the record. I dearly wish they could. Most of them are on the public record. But I will just quote Optus, the carrier. In documentation which many of us will have received it said:

SPEECH.PARA: Advice from most prospective bidders for the initial licence is that their business viability will be substantially impacted by the early entry of competitive Operators. They have indicated that a longer exclusivity period is required (five years rather than one) to ensure that the risks in establishing the initial service are acceptable to potential investors.

It goes on. As of tonight the intention is to explore these concerns and also, since the prospect has been raised by the Opposition, to do what we believe, in the end, is the best to provide for involvement by the ABC, which will make a marked difference to what Australians receive via pay television.

PARA.TAB: I am not saying that pay television should not deliver this, that or the other thing, but I am saying that through some of its broadcasts it should be producing something that is worth while. I am absolutely positive that it will when the ABC is involved. The sooner that happens the better. The more security and the more assistance that the ABC has in doing that the better. For these reasons, we are certainly very happy that our initial proposal for reference of the pay television provisions of the Broadcasting Services Bill to a committee has been accepted. We support the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make this my last contribution to the debate tonight, because we all want to go home—sorry, to our beds.
—They are called crocodile words.

—I will not be going to my home, but I guess those opposite want to go to theirs. Talking about things that happen in the heat of the moment, the Opposition has stuffed us up again with this amendment. I am prepared to fix it, again.

PARA.TAB: I will briefly comment on a few extraordinary statements that have been made here tonight by the frontbencher responsible for communications. It is worth drawing attention to them. One statement that I thought was astonishing was, `What is the problem; 4,000 jobs is not going to make much of an impact in a million'. I think that is extraordinary.

TALK.START.PARA: —And then he said he was looking for lasting jobs, not temporary jobs as the thing collapses.
—That was the next point I wanted to make. If the honourable senator reflects on it he will find that it is even more extraordinary. I am glad the honourable senator has joined him on that.

PARA.TAB: He went on to say something even more extraordinary, in defending a decision to send this commercial matter off to a Senate committee. I make no bones about saying this. He went on to say—and Senator Baume quoted him with support—not only that 4,000 jobs were not going to make much of a dent in a million, but also that those jobs may last for only 12 months and then fall over and people would be back out of work again. I tell those opposite that the cold, hard fact is—and Senator Baume, who has had some commercial experience, knows it—that that is what happens in the labour market all the time with businesses.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are advocating the virtues of short term employment?
—Not at all; I live in the real world. The lion's share of employment in this country comes from small business which has, regrettably, for all sorts of reasons that we are all aware of—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—Order! There are too many interjections and I ask that we pay attention to the matter before this Committee, which is that the Opposition's amendment No. 4 moved by Senator Alston be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is absolutely pertinent to that decision to send it to a committee. It was in that context that Senator Alston made his comment that what we want are viable jobs. I tell those opposite, from personal experiences over the last five years, that if I had to pick the least appropriate organisation to make a predetermination on the commercial viability of an industry, it would be a Senate committee.

PARA.TAB: I could not think of a more absurd proposition: before we even provide people—the people who actually have the money—a chance to provide someone with a job, we are going to refer it to a Senate committee to determine whether or not that job will be viable! Senator Baume thinks that is something he should support, too; that is an absurd proposition. Businesses are better fitted to make those decisions and I could not think of a worse group of people to make those kinds of commercial decisions in the real world than a Senate committee that does not ever have to put its money where its mouth is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well cop our amendment, Senator. That will fix it.

—That is the problem. It was said that six senators are going to make this better. The people that are better fitted to make a judgment are those who are actually going to put the money into the investment and provide the jobs. What are we told by these people about our uranium policies? We are told constantly, `Don't you make a determination about whether the market cannot bear it. What a stupid position. Let the market determine whether or not these jobs in the uranium industry are going to appear'. That is a very silly inconsistency. They were two very silly statements delivered tonight.
—We know you are embarrassed; you got rolled.

—Senator Alston knows it is a stupid decision. There are two errors in the amendment that have to be corrected and I think that can be done as drafting amendments. The amendment purports to remove part 7 from the Bill, I presume; it does not do it. It says that `Part 7, pages 39 to 45, clauses 93 to 114', will be removed. The only trouble is that it still leaves two clauses of part 7. That is easily fixed, but that will have to be amended, if the Senate agrees, to read `pages 39 to 46' and `clauses 93 to 116'.
—I seek leave to amend the form of the words accordingly.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister is obviously very emotionally involved with this particular Bill. Indeed, he is completely out of control and was spitting with fury at one stage. It was absolutely unbelievable.
—Order! Senator Walters has the floor. I expect no interjections from my right.

—As Senator Knowles would say, the Minister should stop throwing a wobbly. The mind boggles. Tonight the Minister was clutching at straws and was quite desperate in his personal attacks. He claimed that I said I was delighted. Indeed, he said, `She says she was delighted'. He was not telling the truth. Mr Chairman, as you would be well aware, I would like to use stronger language but it would not be considered parliamentary. The Minister was not telling the truth. I am not like Senator Collins in any way at all, thank God!
—I'll attest to that.
—I do not mind if people want to pay for pay television.
—If I was in any way like you I'd shoot myself.
—Order!

—Do not worry, Mr Chairman. I could not care less what the Minister says about me. I really do not mind because I have been insulted by experts and he is no expert. I really do not want you to ask him to withdraw anything he cares to say tonight. As I said earlier, he is out of control and spitting with fury because he has once again been rolled.

PARA.TAB: Tonight the Minister said that I was opposed to pay television. I have never said that I was opposed to pay television, nor am I. Indeed, I do not mind how many people want to pay to watch television. Good for them! I am not like Senator Collins, who in an interview said—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Walters has the floor. I expect no further contributions from my right while Senator Walters has the floor.

—Mr Chairman, I am not like Senator Collins, who is the most selfish man I know. In an interview he said that he did not want to watch pay television and, therefore, he would not allow his family to watch pay television. His wife could stay home in Darwin for the whole week—indeed, for a fortnight at a time—while the Minister is down here in Canberra, but he is so mean and so selfish that he would stop her having pay television if she chose.
—Order! I have mentioned that I expect no contribution in any form from my right while Senator Walters is speaking. If I have to, I will take action to make sure that that happens.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. The Minister is very good at dishing it out but he cannot take it. He never has been able to and whenever he is upset he gets very personally abusive. I gather that his wife has to put up with that too. He has made it perfectly clear that she will not be watching pay television because he will not be able to. If that is the way he wants to behave in his family life, all I can say is that I feel desperately sorry for his wife, but then I guess I always have thought that she must be some woman to put up with him.
—I think it might be a good idea to get back to the motion before the Chair.

—Yes, Mr Chairman, I certainly intend to. The only reason that I rose to my feet was because of the personal abuse that Senator Collins was heaping on my head, even though I had never mentioned at all that I was opposed to pay television. He called me the Tasmanian mafia. I will be interested to see whether the media take that up with Senator Collins and ask him to prove that I belong to the Tasmanian mafia, in the same way that they asked Dr Hewson to prove that Paul Keating belonged to the mafia of the Right of—
—Mr Keating, thank you.

—I am sorry—Mr Keating belonged to the mafia of the right wing of the New South Wales Labor Party. It will be interesting to see just what the media will do with his out of control statements. I support the Opposition's amendment. I believe that if we are not able to give the ABC one of the channels, we will go to the public—we will have a Senate committee hearing—and see what it wants. That is the only way we will be able to establish that our way is the correct way and that the way the Government is moving is totally inadequate.

—I rise to oppose this amendment. I do so knowing full well that the Democrats and the Opposition have the numbers to carry the amendment. We have heard much from Senator Alston tonight, saying that the reason for this is that an endless number of people have come to see him, lobbying the Opposition and saying that the model that the Government has proposed was unworkable, flawed, et cetera. I say to Senator Alston that some of us have been involved in listening to people for nearly two years, lobbying on various forms of how they want to see pay television operate in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The best quote of all—it has been hackneyed around and I have used it before—is that it is a bit like Mandy Rice-Davies saying, `Well, they would say that, wouldn't they?'. The endless interest groups want to get a structure that favours their particular interest and their particular advantage. Dare I say it: there is an endless range of structures that can be put in operation about pay television. When this Committee returns with whatever it may recommend—with majority or minority reports—about a possible structure for the operation of pay television, there will still be endless whingeing and complaints from interest groups in the community who say, `This system won't work, this won't operate' because it obviously does not suit their vested interests.

What we have operating in pay television in any structure we look at, no matter how we try to structure it, are three conflicting principles: firstly, having a model that provides competition; secondly, diversity of ownership; and, thirdly, having exclusivity or monopoly operation to get the thing going to encourage investment. In many ways those three principles are in conflict with each other. As we try to balance out the issues of competition, diversity of ownership and exclusivity, we will end up with differences of opinion and we will not be able to satisfy all of them.

I suspect that after another three or four months the Committee will come back with a different model. There will be complaints and belly-aches about it. Whatever is finally adopted will not be perfect. After 18 months to two years of listening to all the various propositions, there is no perfect model. Technology itself will overturn any model that I, the Opposition or anyone else may care to adopt. It may last four or five years. Whether it will be a mixture of satellite delivery, fibre optic delivery, microwave or narrowcast delivery—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your preferred method of policy making?

—All I can say to Senator Alston, in some sense of weariness having been at this for about 18 months, on the issue of exclusivity, for example, is that I have had people sit in my office and say that they want 15 years exclusivity to make a quid. Some people want that. Others come in and say that they do not want any exclusivity at all. Others want no cross-ownership rules at all. Others want absolute cross-ownership rules. As we hear it all, we can make a good argument for most, if we deal with it rationally, but in the end we will have to come up with a model and it will not be perfect if we go on the basis of trying to get a consensus amongst people.

PARA.TAB: Another thing that will lead to endless conflict in the model is the argument over how much program content restrictions or Australian content rules are applied vis-a-vis free to air rules. We will also have arguments about how much of it should be made in Australia. What are the industry specifications? Should we insist on how the first operator structures its black box and decoder so that every subsequent operator has to use the same black box and the same decoder so that we get one industry standard?

There will be an endless range of opinion about that and arguments that if it is given to the first one, it will then set the tone for the rest of the industry. The Government is obviously aware, as I said before, that the Opposition has the numbers to impose the referral of this matter to a committee and as a result some of us have been asked to volunteer to go on the Select Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh no! You're not going to be chairman?

—I must say that Senator Kemp is dead right. I have been at it for two years. I might as well do it for another three months. I will be a member of the Committee. I have heard that Senator Kemp was not selected by the Liberal Party to be on a select committee with me. I understand Senator MacGibbon and Senator Alston are on the Committee.
—Don't speak too soon.

—One thing we know for certain; whatever deficiencies Senator Alston has, Senator Kemp has no chance of rolling him in the party room to get on a committee after his startlingly bad performance on the ad ban Select Committee. The only thing I have to say with some slight joy is that Senator Walters will not be on this Committee with me. After putting up with Senator Walters on the 0055 Committee, that is a matter of great relief.

PARA.TAB: I conclude with remarks about the 0055 Committee, which is the shorthand name for it. It is true that people like Senator Walters are greatly concerned about restricting people's access to material that does not fit their criteria. Senator Walters and her ilk are the last great censors. They try to control what adults should be able to see and make choices about seeing. That is not surprising. She has always had that authoritarian streak about her. It has certainly come out in the 0055 Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —You censor TV advertising. Why turn on Senator Walters?

—I know it is a matter of great indignation to Senator Kemp, and he has never been able to get over the fact that he promised the Liberal Party room that he would be able to stop the ad ban legislation. To his great chagrin, he was not able to do so and he has been damaged ever since. He has been rewarded by being made the messenger boy to take messages from this chamber down to Dr Hewson's office because he cannot use a telephone.

PARA.TAB: I look forward only in one sense to being a part of this Committee; that is, again seeing the range of opinion put forward. Senator Alston has put forward the Opposition's amendment here tonight, but he will find that there are a lot of people who will oppose what the Liberal Party proposes for pay television. Whatever is put up, there will be strong opposition to it. This amendment is unnecessary, but the Opposition has the numbers to carry it. I hope that when we come back in September, despite the whingeing from various vested interests, we can establish pay television in Australia.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Alston's) be agreed to
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Select Committee on Subscription Television Broadcasting Services

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Alston)—by leave—agreed to:

PROCTEXT.PARA: SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON SUBSCRIPTION TELEVISION BROADCASTING SERVICES

(1)That a select committee, to be known as the Senate Select Committee on Subscription Television Broadcasting Services, be appointed to examine and report on the provisions of Part 7-Subscription Television Broadcasting Services of the Broadcasting Services Bill 1992 by 10 September 1992.
(2)That in its inquiry the committee may at its discretion examine such previous inquiries, recommendations and evidence the committee thinks relevant.
(3)That the committee consist of six Senators, as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a)three nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b)two nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and
(c)one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (4)That the committee may proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(5)(a)That the chairman of the committee be appointed by and from the members of the committee;

PARA.TAB: (b)That the deputy-chairman of the committee be appointed by and from the members of the committee immediately after the appointment of the chairman;

(c)That, if the chairman is a Senator nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the deputy-chairman shall be a Senator nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate or the Leader of the Australian Democrats, and if the chairman is a Senator nominated by the Leader of the Opposition or the Leader of the Australian Democrats, the deputy-chairman shall be a Senator nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(d)That the deputy-chairman act as chairman when there is no chairman or the chairman is not present at a meeting; and
(e)That, in the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chairman, or the deputy-chairman when acting as chairman, have a casting vote.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (6)That the quorum of the committee be three members.

(7)That the committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

(8)That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the subcommittee.

(9)That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee with the approval of the President.

PARA.TAB: That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that at this hour everyone is very keen to hear the last word on pigs for this session, but a few things have been left up in the air such as pigs' tails and various other things. I believe it is important that we recognise that the Government has skirted around some matters which really must be put very firmly to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I started off this matter by raising the failure of companies in this group to report to the Australian Securities Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rage on, Gough.

—I am overjoyed to acknowledge that interjection. Senator Ray is maintaining the fiction, along with the normal pattern that the Labor Party adopts in these matters, of totally fabricating a nonsensical response to a very serious proposition.

PARA.TAB: The matter I first raised was one of concealment. Not one of the operating companies in this group—quite apart from Mr Keating's private company and quite apart from Euphron, which we only found out as a result of searches that he half owns—has presented an annual report to the Australian Securities Commission which has been in a state to be communicated to the public for three years. In other words, the public has no access to any reports of substance of any of these companies, which are companies involved in a multi-million dollar joint project. This is the matter of substance. In fact, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which I have discussed with Senator McMullan outlining the state of the `Porkergate' company annual returns as at June 1992.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw to the attention of the Senate the fact that the Brown and Hatton group which was formed in 1988 did not put in a tax return for 1988-89—I suppose there was nothing to report anyway. It did put in a return for 1989-90 on 10 January 1992. A couple of weeks later it received a letter from the Securities Commission asking it to put in a meaningful return that included such vital elements as the statement of the accounts and so on. In other words, the return was a phoney return. That letter of early January had not been responded to, so there was no annual return available for public scrutiny by, when I last checked, 20 June this year.

PARA.TAB: Another return was magically put in earlier this month after this matter became public. It has still not been processed. When we look down the list—Jensay, Brown and Hatton Wholesale, Brown and Hatton Rural, Olympia Refrigeration and so on—we see that no return has ever been submitted. This is a serious matter. In fact, it has been raised consistently by the Australian Securities Commission. In a press release on 11 December 1991, the Australian Securities Commission noted that nearly 80,000 penalty notices had so far been issued to companies and directors which had failed to lodge annual returns in response to earlier warnings. The ASC warned that failure to respond to these notices could result in substantial fines and the cancellation of company registrations.

This matter has come to the attention of company directors. I would have thought that those companies involved in schemes in which the Prime Minister is a major shareholder would have felt at least some duty—some duty to him—to put in returns. I stress that this Government sought to divert attention away from that serious matter by playing the goat, concentrating the issue entirely on the Prime Minister's own late return. The substance of this matter is serious and cannot be concealed by Senator Ray's ridiculous interjections, such as the one he made tonight.

There is a requirement in the Cabinet handbook that Ministers provide the Prime Minister with detailed information, including monetary values of interests declared, in their statements of interest. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . any substantial alterations should be notified to the Prime Minister as soon as they occur.

This statement is significant because Mr Keating acquired his interest while Mr Hawke was still Prime Minister. It would be reasonable to ask: did the then Treasurer, when he acquired this interest on 15 May 1991, advise the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke—as he was required to—that he had acquired a $430,000 half interest in a holding company owning a piggery and a refrigeration fabrication business. Mr Keating was obliged to tell Mr Hawke. I wonder whether he did. Perhaps the media would like to ask Mr Hawke. It is interesting that we have a pattern of concealment. I wonder whether it was also concealed from Mr Hawke in defiance of the Cabinet handbook.

PARA.TAB: There is also a requirement in the Cabinet handbook which obliges Ministers to declare:

SPEECH.PARA: Any other matter which may give rise to a conflict between duty and interest . . . Ministers should adopt a broad interpretation of the requirement that they take into account the interests of family members and all interests of their own, when considering whether there is a conflict, or a potential or apparent conflict, which should be declared.
The handbook further states:
Generally, declarations should be made in all cases where an interest exists which could not be said to be shared with the rest of the community.

I assure the Prime Minister that the ownership of a large piggery operation involved in a multi-million dollar joint venture is not an interest which can be said to be shared with the rest of the community. The handbook continues:
Any such declarations will be recorded by Cabinet officers.

That seems pretty straightforward. I wonder whether the Prime Minister has ever made such a declaration in relation to the Danpork multi-million dollar, multinational pig joint venture in which he holds a half interest in the Australian holding company. Mr Keating might like to address these sorts of matters instead of just ringing up newspaper editors and abusing them for having dared to write about his interests and wealth. Fortunately,
Mr Keating cannot ban me from speaking—no doubt he would try to do so, just as he tried to block the Sunday Age from having access to information.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, the companies in which the Prime Minister has major investments have an appalling record of failing to submit annual reports. The Prime Minister has an obligation to reveal whether he met the requirements of reporting of the Cabinet handbook. We have already seen that in his statement of declaration of interest there was no suggestion that his interest was a half interest and that he had a nominee on the Board of the company of which he said he was not a director. He said that he did not have control when, in fact, he shared control. In this overall pattern of concealment one simply wonders what on earth is going on. Why has it been taking place? What are the potential conflicts of interest? Will the Prime Minister and all his companies eventually come clean?

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 27 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a report in the April 1992 edition of the National Geographical magazine that marine biology studies into seal pups have found a possible clue to identifying infants at risk from Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS), are the study findings available to Australian medical researchers and are marine biologists undertaking or planning to undertake any similar research in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth Government's main funding body for health and medical research is the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC). In relation to SIDS research, NHMRC has provided over $1.2 million in this area over the past four years and is currently funding two projects for approximately $75,000.

The NHMRC does not direct its researchers to undertake research in a particular field. This initiative must come from members of the research community. I am certain, however, that Australian medical research scientists would be aware of promising new developments in their field of research and are able to assess outcomes of properly designed trials which are fully reported in the scientific literature.
There is a significant history of basic biological research proving to be important to medicine, and medical research scientists are very conscious of this.
