(2) There has been no assessment made by the Minister or the Commonwealth of the facilities at Wynyard Hospital, which is a State Government facility.
(3) As the standards have not been assessed by the Commonwealth this question cannot be answered further.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 1 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Australian delegation withdrawing from the negotiations seeking to tighten the International Nuclear Liability Regime; if so, why.
(2) What policies has the Australian delegation been pursuing at the negotiations.
(3) What level of: (a) involvement; and (b) influence has Australia had so far in the negotiations.
(4) How much money has been spent per annum to support the Australian delegation in these negotiations since their inception.
(5) How many people are involved in the Australian delegation.
(6) What is the expected duration of the negotiations.
(7) How much money is expected to be saved by the withdrawal of the Australian delegation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. Australia intends to maintain its participation in the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) Standing Committee on Liability for Nuclear Damage.

(2) There is a large number of complex issues under consideration at these negotiations. If detailed information on Australian policies with regard to a particular issue is required, I would be happy to provide it. In brief, however, Australia is strongly supporting the concept of state liability for nuclear damage. A key objective is to seek a commitment from states hosting nuclear facilities that adequate compensation will be available to victims of damage arising from those facilities.

(3) (a) Australia participated actively in the two preparatory working group meetings on nuclear liability held in May-June and October-November 1989 and in all five meetings of the Standing Committee held from its establishment in April 1990 to date. We have also participated in two intersessional working group meetings.

(b) Pending the outcome of the negotiations, it is difficult to speak conclusively of Australia's level of influence. We are among the leaders of those favouring state liability and have had considerable influence within that group.

(4) It is not possible to provide an accurate accounting of annual expenditure on support for Australian delegations to the negotiations on nuclear liability as costs relate to both salary and travel expenses. Following is an estimate for each year based on the airfare and travel allowance costs of non Vienna-based participants in the negotiations. (It should be noted that in most cases Australia-based delegation members would, while away from Australia, attend at least one and possibly more meetings or conferences unrelated to nuclear liability. The following figures do not take such other duties into account, nor the time of Vienna-based officials on the delegations and Canberra-based officials who contribute to the briefing for the meetings.)

(5) Delegations have varied in size from meeting to meeting. At the first working group meeting in 1989 four people attended. Since then, our delegations have most often numbered two people. The intersessional working group meeting in February 1991 was attended by one person.
(6) The duration of the negotiations is not clear at this stage, although it is hoped that they might conclude in 1993.
(7) Not applicable.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 28 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) With just over one month before the Evandale Hospital in northern Tasmania is planned to be closed why is it that patients currently at the hospital do not know to which location they are to be transferred.
(2) Will the Minister undertake urgent discussions with the Tasmanian Minister for Health to ensure that patients are given full and frank information about the plans for their future care.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) As I have advised Senator Bell in answer to previous questions on this matter, Evandale Hospital is a State Government facility and responsibility for it rests with the Tasmanian Government. While the Commonwealth approved the transfer of the bed approvals to Evandale Hospital, this was at the request of the State Government. Subsequent to that, it was the Tasmanian Government which decided to close Evandale Hospital.

(2) While I share Senator Bell's concern that the residents of Evandale Hospital are kept fully apprised of the future circumstances of their care, questions on the future care of individual residents following the closure of Evandale Hospital can only be answered by the Tasmanian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 3 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What progress has been made by the Interdepartmental Committee which was formed by the Government in 1991 to co-ordinate Australia's response to the World Declaration on the Survival, Protection and Development of Children.

(2) In what ways have State and Territory Governments been involved in preparing their own programs of action to help implement the goals and objectives of the World Declaration arising out of the World Summit for Children.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) An Interdepartmental Committee (IDC) was convened to assist in the development of Australia's national program of action (NPA) in accordance with the World Declaration of the Survival, Protection and Development of Children, and to develop proposals for Australia's participation in the International Year of the Family (IYF), to be celebrated in 1994.

The IDC comprises representatives from the Departments of: Health, Housing and Community Services; Social Security; Finance; Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs; Foreign Affairs and Trade; Prime Minister and Cabinet; Employment, Education and Training; Transport and Communications; Industrial Relations; as well as: the Attorney-General's Department; the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau; the Bureau of Statistics; the Australian Institute of Family Studies; and the Office of the Status of Women.
The IDC has met on five occasions and has reached agreement on the process for developing Australia's national program of action.

IDC members have contributed to the development and approval of an Interim Report, which outlines the process for developing Australia's NPA and provides data and information on strategies already in place at the national level that address the seven major goals of the World Declaration, plus details of Australia's international aid program. The Interim Report was submitted to UNICEF on 31 March 1992.

The Interim Report was welcomed by the Executive Director of UNICEF, who was particularly impressed by the "serious effort at comprehensive review and planning" being undertaken in Australia in the development of a national program of action.
The IDC is overseeing important wide ranging consultations with State and Territory governments

ANSWER.PARA: and non-government organisations to provide specific input to the national program of action.

PARA.TAB: It is envisaged that the final national program of action will be completed in December 1992.

(2) The Prime Minister wrote to all State Premiers and Territory Chief Ministers in December last year informing them of the need to develop a national program of action (NPA) in response to the World Declaration on the Survival, Protection and Development of Children, and seeking their support for, and involvement in, the development of Australia's NPA.

States and Territories were also provided with copies of the World Declaration and its associated Plan of Action, in which the desirability of having `provincial and local governments' develop their own programs of action is clearly expressed.
